Sometimes the Solitude court mage (a Breton woman named Sybille Stentor) will come to the dungeons and perform painful magical experiments on the prisoners. Ahtar will be reluctant to talk about this.
Quotes:
"Not much work being a jailer, long as you can ignore the pleading and all that."
"Aye. I'm the headsman here in Solitude. It's my job."
“I'd fancy a chance at that Jaree-Ra's scrawny neck. Filthy Argonian never would have set foot in this city, if High King Torygg was still alive. I can tell you that."
"I may have accidentally let a prisoner escape. The leader of one of those bandit groups. I told everyone he died during questioning, and I need you to track him down and make sure he doesn't show up to disprove that."
"Mind yourself in my city. This here axe in full swing is a right terrible sight..."
"You stay out of trouble, now. The Castle Dour dungeon can break even the strongest will."
"Ain't many visitors come to the dungeon. Every now and then Sybille Stentor will come by looking for... volunteers."
author: Bethesda

name: Aia Arria
bio:
Aia Arria lives in Solitude, the provincial capital of Skyrim. She is a student at the Bards College. She is an Imperial. As a bard, she sings and plays both the flute and the lute. At night, she sleeps in her small room in the basement of the Bards College.
According to Pantea Ateia, Aia is the only current student at the Bards College with actual talent.
Aia is quite confident about her skills as a bard. She has a distaste for many of the other members of the Bards College. Some of her fellow classmates include an adolescent Redguard man named Ataf, an adolescent Nord woman named Illdi, and a Nord man named Jorn. Her teachers include a Breton man named Giraud Gemane (Dean of History), and elderly Nord woman named Inge Six Fingers (Dean of Lute), an Imperial woman named Pantea Ateia, and an Altmer named Viaramo (he's the Headmaster of the college).
Quotes:
"I'm a bard, trained at the Bards College here in Solitude. Wanderers like you should think about applying."
"Lady Ateia says my voice is second only to hers. But she's selling me short."
"Few can resist my charms. Even fewer are worthy of them."
“Poetry is so dull when it isn't set to music."
“Music tames the most savage beasts. Even Nords."
"You know, my father collected exotic alcohols: rum from Hammerfell, mulled wine from Daggerfall, and the like. None of what he collected tasted as good as Evette's Spiced Wine.”
“Perfection takes dedication.”
"I can't understand why Jorn would want to join the Imperial Legion. Soldiers only appreciate one thing, and it isn't music."
"Oh, if you haven't heard Dean Pantea sing, you should."
“Lady Ateia has already arranged for me to perform in the court of the Jarl of Falkreath, after I graduate."
When discussing the performances of her fellow classmates: "As long as they're playing instruments they're passable. You don't want to hear them sing."
author: Bethesda

name: Aicantar
bio:
Aicantar is an young Altmer man who lives within Understone Keep in Markarth. He helps his uncle Calcelmo in his laboratory. Understone Keep is an ancient Dwemer keep built into the mountainside, used as a palace by the Jarl of Markarth.
Aicantar is a talented conjurer. He is the creator of Aicantar's Spider, and the Spider Control Rod which commands it. Aicantar's spider is a Dwemer spider which has been modified so that it can be controlled by the person using the control rod. Aicantar will not openly talk about these inventions of his. 
Aicantar has been trying to convince his uncle to let him forego participation in his uncle's next archaeological excavation.
Aicantar's is somewhat sad that his uncle Calcelmo doesn't appear to care about him very much.
Quotes:
“Don't let my uncle go on about his theories. You'll be here all night."
"I'm afraid to touch half of the things they keep in the tower."
"I'm Calcelmo's nephew. I help him around the laboratory."
"I try not to think how my uncle got all those Dwemer Centurion parts."
author: Bethesda

name: Ainethach
bio:
Ainethach is a Breton man with dark brown hair, residing in the town of Karthwasten, of which he is the leader. He also owns the local Sanuarach Mine. Karthwasten is located in the Reach.
Ainethach has been arguing with Silver-Blood mercenaries (led by a Nord man named Atar) about Sanuarach Mine. The mercenaries want him to sell it to them in repayment for their help in clearing the Forsworn rebels who had captured it.
The player can choose to help Ainethach keep his mine, by either convincing Atar and his mercenaries to leave, or by simply killing the mercenaries so they are no longer an issue. It is also possible to convince Ainethach to sell his mine to the mercenaries.
Quotes:
"If the Forsworn aren't attacking my town, the Nords are trying to force me off it."
“The Silver-Bloods are trying to muscle in on my land. Forsworn attacked the mines, and suddenly all these sellswords show up to "help." They won't let anyone work until I sell it off."
“The Silver-Bloods are a family of thieves. Running their corrupt empire from Markarth. The Silver-Blood family owns half the Reach, and they won't stop until they own all of it."
"My family has owned Karthwasten for generations. Rare for anyone in the Reach that isn't a Nord. Not that it does me any good. Nords think I'm working for the Forsworn. Forsworn think I'm working for the Nords."
author: Bethesda

name: Akar
bio:
Akar is a member of the Frostmoon pack of werewolves. He can be found under Frostmoon Crag with the rest of the pack. He is a Nord man with reddish-brown hair and a beard. He wears fur armor with matching bracers and shoes, and carries a large melee weapon on his back.
Frostmoon Crag is a small camp under a rock overhang south of Mount Moesring, on the island of Solstheim. The Frostmoon pack is the last true werewolf pack on Solstheim. They are led by Majni, Akar's older brother. Their father and grandfather were the previous alphas of the pack. Along with Majni and Akar, there are two other werewolves in the pack: A young woman named Rakel, whose parents were also pack members, and a woman named Hjordis, whose pack was destroyed by werebears. Hjordis remains with Majni's pack until they can help her reclaim her lands.
The pack members prefer to remain free in the wilderness. They warn non-werewolves away from their camp, but will welcome other werewolves who respect their law. They fully embrace their lycanthropy, and worship Lord Hircine, the Daedric Prince of the Hunt, who is strongly associated with werewolves.
Akar is not very talkative and often growls or replies with one word answers when questioned.
Quotes:
"Grr..."
"What?"
"Hmph."
If asked who he is: "Akar. Majni's brother. I hunt. He talks. Go talk to him."
If asked what he hunts: "Deer. Sabers. Rieks. Boar. Bear. I hunt soon. Go bother Majni."
author: Bethesda

name: Alain Dufont
bio:
Alain Dufont is a Breton man with blue eyes and brown hair. He is the leader of a bandit group which resides in the Dwemer ruin of Raldbthar, located at the southeastern edge of The Pale.
At some point, he heard about the murder of Friga Shatter-Shield and headed to the city of Windhelm in Eastmarch Hold, hoping to swindle money from Friga's relatives. At Candlehearth Hall (a popular inn) in Windhelm, he met a young Breton woman named Muiri. Wanting to exploit Muiri's connections to the Shatter-Shield family, he romanced her. He then robbed the Shatter-Shields, who blamed the event on Muiri. After the deed was done, Alain left Muiri and went into hiding in the Dwemer ruins of Raldbthar.
He wields Aegisbane, a unique enchanted warhammer which he stole from the Shatter-Shield family.
Quotes:
"Well, you must have all of those annoying gods on your side to have made it this far, whoever you are. Even I have to admit that's pretty impressive."
author: Bethesda

name: Alding
bio:
Alding is a Nord man who is a member of the Blood Horker pirate clan. His hair is dark gray, and he has a mohawk and a thick mustache. Alding is an very foulmouthed pirate who prefers to wear tattered and poor clothes. He can be often found in the Windpeak Inn in Dawnstar, accompanying his captain Stig Salt-Plank and the rest of the pirate crew.
Alding speaks disrespectfully and lecherously towards women, exemplified by the crude sexual innuendos he shouts at pretty young women like Karita (the daughter of the innkeeper, Thoring). Karita works as both a bard and a waitress at the Windpeak Inn.
author: Bethesda

name: Alduin
bio:
Alduin, the World Eater, is a mighty dragon and the primary antagonist. He is considered the "wellspring" of the Nordic pantheon, as well as the harbinger of the apocalypse. He is also described as the "creator of dragon civilization".
Scholars speculate that Alduin is the Nordic name attributed to Akatosh. One source states that Alduin and Akatosh are different deities entirely. Alduin calls himself the "Firstborn of Akatosh." Exactly what the "Firstborn of Akatosh" means is unclear, although some sources suggest he was split from the time god at some point in the past. According to Paarthurnax, Alduin's peers considered him the most acclaimed creation of Akatosh. According to some sources, Alduin is the firstborn of a deity named Akha, a greater time god than Alduin or Akatosh, from whom both time gods originate alongside the dragons.
Nordic myth asserts that Alduin destroyed the last world to begin this one, a process known as a Kalpa. As a result, Alduin is perceived as both creator and destroyer, as well as predating the creation of Nirn itself. There are legends of his battles with Shor during this time.
During the Merethic Era, the people of Atmora and Skyrim worshiped dragons, possibly at the urging of Alduin. He also conspired with Orkey to reduce all the Nords to children, until he was again defeated by Shor. Some consider that Alduin's rule during this period was forsaking his proper role as the World-Eater. Alduin served as a leader of the dragons, and he ruled with an iron fist. The humans either worshiped him or were enslaved. The humans worshiped him and the dragons in the Dragon Cult. High ranking members of this cult would be known as a Dragon Priest. Alduin's lieutenant at the time was Paarthurnax, but secretly Paarthurnax was betraying him. Paarthurnax was teaching the voice to the humans so that they could rebel against their dragon overlords. The ensuing war would be known as the Dragon War.
He was ultimately sent forward in time through the actions of three Nordic heroes, who created a new Shout to subdue him, and used an Elder Scroll to send Alduin forward in time.
Quote:
“My belly is full of the souls of your fellow mortals, Dovahkiin. Die now and await your fate in Sovngarde!"
author: Bethesda

name: Alea Quintus
bio:
Alea Quintus is a Nord woman who is currently trapped in a small cabin, in a marsh somewhere in Skyrim. She was recently kidnapped by a woman she doesn't know, and she is currently kneeling on a wood floor with her legs and hands tied behind her back and a sack over her head, preventing her from moving or seeing anything. On Alea's right side is a Nord man named Fultheim, and on her left side is a Khajiit man named Vasha. Just like Alea, Fultheim and Vasha are being held hostage, unable to move or see. The woman who kidnapped them seems to be sitting on the opposite side of the cabin, based on the sound of her voice. Alea can hear and feel the heat from a fireplace on her front right side.
Alea claims to be a good woman. Abandoned by her husband, she has been left with the grueling task of raising her six children all by herself, which most likely explains her unfriendly attitude. She is quite feisty. When approached, she will demand to be set free.
The player has evidently been recently kidnapped and transported to this cabin by the same woman who kidnapped Alea, Fultheim, and Vasha. The kidnapper has just spoken the following words to the player: "I'll cut right to it. You murdered the old woman in the orphanage. You owe the Dark Brotherhood a kill. I've come to collect. One of these poor sods has a contract out on their life. Which one is it? Any idea? Make your choice. Make your kill. And you get to walk away." It seems that the kidnapper woman is a member of the Dark Brotherhood, and that she is now forcing the player to murder either Fultheim, Alea, or Vasha, before allowing them to leave the cabin.
Quotes:
"I don't have time for this nonsense. I've got a home to keep and children to feed. Now let me out of here!"
"Cowards! Stealing a woman from her home! For shame!"
"Get these things off of me!"
"By the gods, when I get out of here you're dead! You hear me? Dead!"
“None of your damned business who I am! If you're going to kill me, just do it already! As Mara is my witness, if I didn't have this damned hood on right now I would spit right in your face..."
If asked if anyone would pay to have her killed: “I'm kneeling here with my hands bound and a sack over my head, and you have the gall to ask me that? What do you think, genius? I'm a woman living in Skyrim with six children and no husband. I don't have the time or patience to be 'nice'. Do some people look down on me? Have I made some enemies? You're damn right."
author: Bethesda

name: Alesan
bio:
Alesan is a orphaned boy who currently lives in Dawnstar. He is a Redguard.
Alesan and his father were on a boat when his father became sick. The crew dropped the two off in Dawnstar. His father died a few days later. Alesan now delivers food to the miners of Quicksilver Mine and Iron-Breaker Mine, to make money to survive. He also feeds chickens. At night, Alesan sleeps in a bedroll on the floor of the Windpeak Inn. This inn is run by a man named Thoring, who has a young adult daughter named Karita.
Alesan would love to be adopted.
Quotes:
When working during the day: "I'm running food and supplies to the miners. Don't pay much, but they let me sleep by the fire in the inn most nights. I'm late! Gotta run!"
When at the Windpeak Inn in the evening: "Whew! I'm worn out."
If asked where his parents are: "My parents are... dead. My Pa was a sailor. Took me with him on his last trip. After he got sick, they... put us off here and left without us. He... died a few days later. I've tried to make do since then but... it's been hard. Real hard."
If someone offers to adopt him: "Really? You mean it? Wow, thanks! I promise, I won't be any trouble at all! Just... just let me get my things and say goodbye to everyone. I'll meet you at home. Thanks! Thanks again!"
author: Bethesda

name: Alessandra
bio:
Alessandra, an Imperial woman, serves as the priestess of Arkay in Riften. She is responsible for taking care of the Hall of the Dead in Riften, and is currently the only priestess (or priest) to Arkay in the city. Alessandra's duty is to ensures that the dead are given the proper rituals and burials. Alessandra wears a set of monk robes and a pair of boots, and has dark brown hair.
The Hall of the Dead is connected to the basement level of the adjacent Temple of Mara, and Alessandra’s living quarters are located in this basement. Alessandra seems to be on good terms with Dinya Balu, a Dunmer woman who is a priestess of Mara and who lives on the floor above. Dinya is married to a Redguard man named Maramal, who is the head priest of Mara in Riften. Dinya has recently become pregnant with her first child.
Alessandra is unhappy about her life and her job, complaining that she never wanted it, but she was forced to take it so that it would continue the family's tradition and keep its honor. Her father was a priest so all that she learned was from him. When she was little she had no friends because she was staying with her father tending the dead so no one wanted to play with her. When she grew older she became a priestess of Arkay, but her father died before she completed her training.
While seeming a bit disappointed and quiet most of the time, she still carries a sense of duty despite her resentment of her rank.
Alessandra would like to journey to Whiterun in order to return the ceremonial dagger given by her father so that she can be at peace with him, but she cannot leave the Hall unattended, so may asked the player to do this for her.
Quotes:
"If you're trying to ask if I tend the hall of the dead alone, then the answer is yes. You think anyone around here is going to lift a shovel to help me? Guess again. 'Leave the dirty work to old Alessandra.' Look, I didn't ask for this job, I got stuck with it thanks to my father."
“My father was a Priest of Arkay. All my life was spent around the dead, being forced to learn the proper burial rituals and prayers. I never had any friends; who'd want to spend time with 'the little weird girl who hangs around dead people?' So I grew up with a miserable trade. This is all I know how to do... prepare and inter the deceased."
"I'd ask you maintain civility while you're here."
author: Bethesda

name: Alethius
bio:
Alethius is a deceased Imperial soldier who can be found inside the Nchuand-Zel excavation site. Nchuand-Zel is an ancient Dwemer ruin under the city of Markarth. Alethius was killed by Nimhe, a giant Frostbite Spider.
Alethius was wearing a full set of light Imperial armor when he died. He was protecting four researchers that went out on an expedition in the excavation site. The researchers' name are Staubin, Stromm, Erj, and Krag. Alethius suspected that Erj and Krag were up to something.
author: Bethesda

name: Alexia Vici
bio:
Alexia Vici is an old Imperial noblewoman visiting Skyrim. She is the mother of Vittoria Vici and the aunt of the Emperor Titus Mede the Second. Alexia's snow-white hair is slightly longer than shoulder-length.
Alexia Vici disapproves of Nords, especially Stormcloaks, and thinks of them as uncivilized beasts.
Alexia is attending the wedding of her daughter Vittoria. She expresses her disapproval of her daughter's groom, Asgeir Snow-Shod, because he is a Nord. She also complains about the Emperor not attending the wedding, despite being the cousin of the bride. She can also be seen arguing with Vulwulf Snow-Shod (the father of the groom) about the Skyrim Civil War.
Quotes:
“Those trouble-making Stormcloaks refuse to submit to Imperial authority. Such seditious behavior. Why it's treason!"
author: Bethesda

name: Alfarinn
bio:
Alfarinn works as a carriage driver. He is a Nord man with reddish-brown hair. He can often be found near the stables outside the stone bridge at the city of Windhelm's main entrance. These stables are managed by a High Elf couple.
For a fee, Alfarinn allows customers to board his carriage, transporting them to their requested destination. Alfarinn can take travelers to any of the major cities and towns in Skyrim.
Alfarinn often shares some information about the traveler's destination, or comments on the weather.
Quotes:
If asked about Windhelm: “Windhelm is an old city, I can tell you that. The Palace of Kings is ancient. It's not the friendliest for outsiders. The Dark Elves were all forced to live in the slum called the Gray Quarter. The Argonians can't even live in the walls. They're all stuck out on the docks. Still, Candlehearth Hall's got decent food and cheap bunks. You could do worse."
author: Bethesda

name: Alfhild Battle-Born
bio:
Alfhild Battle-Born is a blonde-haired Nord woman of the Battle-Born clan, who resides in Whiterun.
Alfhild has a pacifistic nature. She dislikes war and thinks of it as pointless and stupid. She also has great concerns about her son because he gets beaten by other children.
She is the daughter of Olfrid and Bergritte Battle-Born. Her brother is Jon Battle-Born, of whom she thinks highly. She is married to Idolaf Battle-Born, with whom they has a son named Lars. Alfhild's role in the family is to maintain the Battle-Born Farm. This farm grows leeks, wheat, and gourds, and she will be willing to pay the player to assist in the harvest of these crops.
Alfhild has little against the Gray-Mane clan, and views the ongoing feud between the Battle-Borns and the Grey-Manes as stupid and unnecessary.
She also thinks the Civil War between the Imperial Legion and the Stormcloaks is pointless, and credits her brother, Jon, for staying out of it. With the exception of Jon, the men in the Battle-Born clan fervently support the Imperial Legion in the war, while the Grey-Mane clan supports the Stormcloaks.
Quotes:
"This war's as stupid as our feud with Clan Gray-Mane."
"My brother Jon's got the right of it: join the Bards College and avoid this pointless war."
author: Bethesda

name: Alik'r Prisoner
bio:
The Alik'r Prisoner is member of the band of Redguard Alik'r warriors led by Kematu. He was sent to Whiterun by Kematu in order to capture a Redguard woman named Iman and bring her back to Hammerfell, to answer for the betrayal of her people to Aldmeri Dominion. However, while sneaking into the city, he was caught by the Whiterun Guard and sent to Dragonsreach Dungeon.
When he is being interrogated by the player, he will require his bail to be paid as a pre-requisite to revealing any information about Kematu. 100 gold will need to be paid to the guard in the dungeon in order to clear the prisoner's fines and set him free. Once his fine is paid, the Alik'r prisoner will then reveal that Kematu is hiding at Swindler's Den, to the west across the plains of Whiterun.
Quotes:
“Let's talk about how we can help each other. "You buy my way out of here, and I'll tell you what you want to know."
author: Bethesda

name: Alik'r Warrior
bio:
Alik'r Warrior is a member of the Alik'r people. The Alik'r are Redguard, scimitar-wielding natives of the northern part of Hammerfell. They are named after the Alik'r Desert, which is the largest desert in Tamriel.
Led by Kematu, the Alik'r coterie recently arrived in Whiterun, searching for a Redguard woman accused of treason. According to Kematu, they have been hired by the noble houses of Taneth (a major port city in southern Hammerfell) to track down a Redguard noblewoman who sold out the city to the Aldmeri Dominion, causing the fall of Taneth to the invading Aldmeri Dominion armies.The traitor's name is Iman, but she is almost certainly using an alias in order to evade detection.
The Alik'r and Kematu will hide in Swindler's Den, a cave across the plains west of the city of Whiterun. Sometimes Alikr' Warriors are encountered in the throughout other parts of Skyrim, confronting various Redguard women and trying to determine whether or not they are the traitor they have been looking for..
This Alik'r warrior wears standard Alik'r warrior garb and carries a scimitar.
Quotes:
"You there. We are looking for someone in Whiterun, and will pay good money for information."
If asked about whom they are trying to find: "A woman -- a foreigner in these lands. Redguard, like us. She is likely not using her true name. We will pay for any information regarding her location. We are not welcome here in Whiterun, so we will be in Rorikstead if you learn anything."
author: Bethesda

name: Alik'r Warrior
bio:
Alik'r Warrior is a member of the Alik'r people. The Alik'r are Redguard, scimitar-wielding natives of the northern part of Hammerfell. They are named after the Alik'r Desert, which is the largest desert in Tamriel.
Led by Kematu, the Alik'r coterie recently arrived in Whiterun, searching for a Redguard woman accused of treason. According to Kematu, they have been hired by the noble houses of Taneth (a major port city in southern Hammerfell) to track down a Redguard noblewoman who sold out the city to the Aldmeri Dominion, causing the fall of Taneth to the invading Aldmeri Dominion armies.The traitor's name is Iman, but she is almost certainly using an alias in order to evade detection.
The Alik'r and Kematu will hide in Swindler's Den, a cave across the plains west of the city of Whiterun. Sometimes Alikr' Warriors are encountered in the throughout other parts of Skyrim, confronting various Redguard women and trying to determine whether or not they are the traitor they have been looking for..
This Alik'r warrior wears standard Alik'r warrior garb including an Alik'r hood, and carries a scimitar.
Quotes:
"You there. We are looking for someone in Whiterun, and will pay good money for information."
If asked about whom they are trying to find: "A woman -- a foreigner in these lands. Redguard, like us. She is likely not using her true name. We will pay for any information regarding her location. We are not welcome here in Whiterun, so we will be in Rorikstead if you learn anything."
author: Bethesda

name: Alva
bio:
Alva is a resident of Morthal. She is a beautiful Nord woman with flowing dark hair, and typically wears a suggestive barmaid outfit. She lives in her house with a widower named Hroggar, and can often be seen wandering around Morthal after dark. Alva secretly sleeps in a coffin within her basement during a portion of the day, and sometimes sneaks off to Movarth's Lair at night.
Alva is secretly a vampire who was sent to Morthal by the master vampire Movarth Piquine. Naturally, Alva keeps her vampiric nature hidden from everyone, lest she be slain by the combined fury of Morthal's populace. Alva's primary objective is to establish a vampire presence in Morthal, seducing and enthralling the town’s guards and prominent men. After she has performed this task, Movarth and the rest of his vampire coven plan to enter the town and use it as a constant source of blood and protection from the sunlight.
Movarth is the one who turned Alva into a vampire, and she is enthralled by him. Movarth was born in the Second Era, at least 700 years ago. Movarth was originally a skilled vampire hunter before being attacked and turned into a vampire by a priest in Cyrodiil, who was secretly a member of the Cyrodiil Vampyrum Order. Movarth went on to become a master vampire and create his own vampire coven at a cave which is now named "Movarth’s Lair", located northeast of Morthal.
Morthal is the capital of Hjaalmarch hold. Hjaalmarch's terrain consists mostly of salt marshes in its northern half, and mountainous snowy tundra in its southern half. Morthal lies in between these two halves, with the River Hjaal running through the town.
Alva generally considers the townsfolk of Morthal to be nothing more than cattle to feed upon, though her journal reveals a past desire for love and romance. Alva has turned a Breton woman named Laelette into a vampire, so that she will serve as Alva’s secret handmaiden. Alva then ordered Laelette to abandon her husband Thonmir (a lumberjack) and young son Virkmund. Alva has spread the rumor that Laelette left Morthal to join the Stormcloaks, in order to explain Laelette’s apparent disappearance. Alva has also seduced and enthralled a lumberjack named Hroggar so that he will guard her house during the day while she sleeps in the coffin on the floor of her basement.
Not long ago, Alva ordered Laelette to kill Hroggar's family, in a way that would seem like an accident. Laelette then burned down Hroggar’s house, thus killing Hroggar’s wife and daughter. Hroggar was not at home during the fire, and moved into Alva’s house the next day, which raised suspicion among the townspeople that Hroggar killed his family so that he can be Alva's lover. 
Alva is good friends with a woman named Lami. Lami is the proprietor of the Thaumaturgist's Hut, an alchemy shop in Morthal. Lami's husband is a lumberjack named Jorgen. 
Alva acts quite flirtatiously and sexually promiscuously towards men. When at the Moorside Inn in Morthal, she often tries to seduce the tavern's regular patrons, such as Benor and Gorm. Alva even speaks seductively towards the innkeeper, a Redguard woman named Jonna.
Since Alva knows that all of Morthal will converge upon her and kill her if they discover she is a vampire, she keeps her vampiric nature a secret from everyone. Alva will only admit to being a vampire if she is speaking with another vampire. She will attack anyone intruding in her basement.
Quotes:
"I'm bored. Nobody wants to have any fun with me."
"Hroggar doesn't have to know if we sit together. Or drink together. I doubt he would even care. Would you like to buy a lady a drink?"
“Forget about Hroggar. He's always so tired lately. I need someone with a little fire in their blood."
"The people here work so hard, and they never allow themselves a moment of fun. It's such a pity. It won't last forever though."
"These people are like cattle. All they do is work, sleep and eat."
"Gathering plants, picking mushrooms, brewing potions. It all gets so dreary after a while. This town needs something exciting to happen."
When speaking to a man: "Well, aren't you the handsome one. You and I should spend some time together."
When speaking to a woman: "Well, aren't you the pretty one. I bet all the men chase after you."
If speaking to a fellow vampire: "I know you for what you are. This town's blood is ours. Leave it! Now we must return to our roles, lest the sheep suspect the wolves."
author: Bethesda

name: Alvide
bio:
Alvide and her husband Barknar are currently seeking refuge in Dayspring Canyon, near Fort Dawnguard. They came here for protection from the recent vampire attacks in various parts of Skyrim. The Dawnguard are an order of vampire hunters that arose as a response to the recent vampire attacks. Fort Dawnguard is a large castle southeast of Riften which serves as the Dawnguard's base of operations. The castle is hidden deep in Dayspring Canyon, within the Velothi Mountains at the southeastern tip of Skyrim.
The leader of the Dawnguard is a stoic Redguard man named Irsan. Unfortunately, Isran won't let Alvide and the other refugees inside the walls of their castle. Alvide and Barknar now live in a camp in the canyon, just outside castle walls. An old man named Sern and a Redguard woman named Jayri are friendly fellow refugees who also live in this camp.
Alvide is a Nord woman with short dark hair. She usually wears a light-colored belted tunic. She is somewhat annoyed with her husband because he assured her that they would be allowed to take refuge within the castle itself. She spends much of her time chopping wood, cooking, or wandering in the forested area around the camp.
Quotes:
"What if the vampires come here, after the Dawnguard? We'll be stuck right in the middle."
"Barknar insisted we come here, said we'd be safe. He also said we'd be INSIDE the walls."
"At least Barknar and I are here together."
"I hope we can go home soon. I don't like it here."
author: Bethesda

name: Alvor
bio:
Alvor, a Nord man, is the blacksmith for the town of Riverwood. He is the husband of Sigrid and father to their daughter Dorthe.
Alvor's hair and thick beard are a dirty blond color. He usually wears a blacksmith's apron and a pair of blacksmith shoes.
Riverwood is located at the southeastern tip of Whiterun Hold, just north of the boundary between Whiterun Hold and Falkreath Hold. The White River flows along the west side of the town. The Throat of the World (the tallest mountain in all of Tamriel) towers over the town from the east. Bleak Falls Barrow, an old Nordic temple ruin in the snow-laden Brittleshin Hills (a small mountain range that divides Whiterun Hold to the north from Falkreath Hold to the south), stands out prominently above Riverwood to its west. Alvor and Sigrid's house and adjacent smithy are located on the east bank of the river. Directly to the west (across the east branch of the river) is the lumber mill on a small island in the middle of the river, which is connected to the town via multiple wooden bridges. On the east side of the main road directly across from Alvor and Sigrid’s house is the Riverwood Trader general store, which is run by Imperial immigrants Lucan Valerius and his younger sister Camilla Valerius.
Alvor is the uncle of Hadvar, who is an Imperial legionnaire. Alvor and Sigrid will be happy to allow Alvor to stay at their house if he comes to visit.
Dorthe often tries to convince Alvor to let her start working the forge; Alvor believes she’s not yet old enough for this, but encourages her enthusiasm for the smithing trade. Dorthe usually spends her time either indoors, hanging around Alvor's forge, or playing with a young boy named Frodnar. Frodnar is the son of Hod and Gerdur, a respectable couple. Hod and Gerdur own and operate Riverwood's sawmill. Gerdur is informally considered to be the leader of Riverwood due to the mill's importance, and because her ancestors founded the town. Alvor and his family support the Empire, while Gerdur and Hod support the Stormcloak rebellion for Skyrim's independence from the Empire. Despite the two families having opposing stances on the civil war, they still generally get along and respect each other as fellow Nords.
Alvor is a brave man, and if the safety of Riverwood's people is threatened, Alvor will engage the threat with the largest nearby available weapon.
Alvor makes a decent living working as the town's blacksmith, which includes repairing parts for the sawmill when needed, and filling large orders of shields for Hod. He sells typical blacksmith wares, such as weapons, armor and smithing resources, and will also buy these items from others at a cheaper rate.
On an evening, Alvor sometimes has a drink across the street at the Sleeping Giant Inn, which is owned by a Breton woman named Delphine, but is mostly run by a Nord man named Orgnar.
Quotes:
"Ain't everyday we get visitors in Riverwood."
"Whatever you need. By Ysmir, if it's simple and strong, I can forge it."
"You lookin' for a new blade?"
"I could forge you a warhammer that would crush a giant's head like a walnut."
"You the sneaky type? Got some nice daggers around here somewhere.”
"War may be good for business, but it's hard on families."
If asked for directions to Whiterun: "To get to Whiterun, cross the river and then head north. You'll see it, just past the falls.”
If asked about the Jarl: "Jarl Balgruuf? He rules Whiterun Hold. A good man; perhaps a bit over-cautious, but these are dangerous times. So far he's managed to stay out of the war. I'm afraid it can't last, though. I don't think he likes either Ulfric or Elisif much. Who can blame him? But I've no doubt he'll prove loyal to the Empire in the end. He's no traitor."
If asked about Elisif: “Jarl Elisif, I should say, although only because she was married to Jarl Torygg when he was murdered. Ulfric murdered Torygg, you know. Walked right into his palace in Solitude and killed him. Shouted him to death, if you believe the stories. That's what started this whole war. The Empire couldn't ignore that. Once the jarls start killing each other, we're back to the bad old days."
“Skyrim has always been part of the Empire. That doesn't mean I support everything the Empire's been doing lately, but Nords have never been fair-weather friends."
If asked about Riverwood: "Gerdur's family first settled here as wood cutters a few generations ago. She and Hod run the mill. I make a decent living sharpening axes and fixing the sawmill."
If asked for his thoughts on the war: "People are rightly stirred up about the damn Thalmor being allowed to roam around arresting people, just for worshipping Talos. But was it worth tearing Skyrim apart, and maybe destroying the Empire? No, Ulfric will have a lot to answer for in the end. Nords have always supported the Empire, and the Empire has always been good for Skyrim."
If asked why the Thalmor are allowed to arrest people for worshipping Talos: "It's from that treaty that ended the Great War, remember, when the Emperor was forced by the Thalmor to outlaw Talos worship. We didn't pay much attention to it when I was a boy - everyone still had their little shrine to Talos. But then Ulfric and his "Sons of Skyrim" started agitating about it, and sure enough the Emperor had to crack down. Dragging people off in the middle of the night... one of the main causes of this war, if you ask me.”
If asked for permission to use his forge: "I see no harm in it, if you have the skill."
author: Bethesda

name: Amaund Motierre
bio:
Amaund Motierre seeks to contract the Dark Brotherhood to assassinate Titus Mede the Second, the Emperor of Tamriel.
Amaund is a Breton man, dressed in expensive fine clothing.
Amaund has a bodyguard named Rexus, a large and loyal Imperial man.
Amaund has performed the Black Sacrament within the ancient Nordic ruin of Volunruud, in an attempt to hire the Dark Brotherhood. Volunruud is located in the hilly region north of Whiterun.
Amaund is a cautious man, refusing to divulge any information about himself or his aims. He also refuses to outright reveal the names of the first three assassination targets in his note, instead offering a necklace to cover the costs of investigating the vague instructions therein.
Amaund appears calm and confident when first approached. However, as the days and weeks since elapse since contracting the Brotherhood's assassination of the Emperor, Amaund will become increasingly stressed.
Later, Motierre can be encountered in the Bannered Mare, a popular inn in Whiterun. At this point, if the player demands to know where the Emperor is, Motierre will say “You mean, after all that's transpired, the Dark Brotherhood will still... honor the contract? Why, this is astounding news! Wonderful news! The Emperor is still in Skyrim, but not for long. He's onboard his ship, the Katariah, moored offshore in the Solitude Inlet. But you must hurry! If you can get onboard that ship, and kill Titus Mede the Second as contracted... I will reveal the location of the dead drop that holds your payment."
If the player successfully kills the Emperor, Amaund will then instruct the player to return to Volunruud to pick up their reward: 20000 gold, which is located in an urn in the chamber in which Motierre and Rexus first met the player. Amaund will only reveal the location of this dead drop if Titus Mede the Second has been killed.
Quotes:
Upon first meeting the player: “By the almighty Divines. You've come. You've actually come. This dreadful Black Sacrament thing... it worked.” 
“I would like to arrange a contract. Several, actually. I daresay, the work I'm offering has more significance than anything your organization has experienced in, well, centuries.”
“As I said, I want you to kill several people. You'll find the targets, as well as their manners of elimination, quite varied. I'm sure someone of your disposition will probably even find it enjoyable. But you should know that these killings are but a means to an end. For they pave the way to the most important target. The real reason I'm speaking with a cutthroat in the bowels of this detestable crypt. For I seek the assassination of… the Emperor."
“Rexus will now give you two items which must be passed along to your superior. The sealed letter will explain everything that needs to be done. The amulet is quite valuable - you can use it to pay for any and all expenses.”
author: Bethesda

name: Ambarys Rendar
bio:
Ambarys Rendar is a Dunmer man and innkeeper of the New Gnisis Cornerclub in the Gray Quarter of Windhelm. He can usually be seen selling food and drinks to his patrons. Ambarys despises the Nord population of the city, and will frequently vocalize this opinion. He runs the cornerclub with the assistance of his employee, Malthyr Elenil (a Dunmer man), who shares his hatred of the Nords. Ambarys traveled to the city as a refugee during the Red Year almost 200 years ago, but did not realize the hostile reaction the local Nords would have to the Dunmer refugees. Ambarys intends to return to Morrowind as soon as he has the money to do so. 
A true supporter of the Empire, Ambarys flies several Imperial banners on the second floor of the Cornerclub, and keeps a set of Imperial armor.
Ambarys doesn't really care about the recent series of murders happening to young women in the city, committed by a mysterious serial killer whom the city has nicknamed The Butcher. Ambarys will only start caring about the murders if a Dunmer woman gets killed. 
Nords visiting the New Gnisis Cornerclub will not get a warm welcome from Ambarys. He will sarcastically say: "Oh splendid, another Nord. Come slumming to the Gray Quarter, have you?" Ambarys will have a much kinder comment for Dunmer customers.
Ambarys sometimes belittles one of his regular patrons, a Dunmer woman named Suvaris Atheron, for being employed by the Shatter-Shields, a prominent Nord family in Windhelm. During the day, Suvaris assists the Shatter-Shield family’s shipping operation from within their office near the Windhelm docks. 
Quotes:
 “Look where we have to live. This forgotten alley. All the filth from the upper quarters flows downhill, like they say. Good luck getting one of the guards to help with anything. I tried to get Ulfric to even come down here to see the squalor, but the High Lord of His Mightiness couldn't find the time."
“When the Red Mountain burned, you could scarcely breathe in Morrowind. So we came west. Windhelm is the first city on that road, and here we are. If we had known the Nords would be so unwelcoming, we may have kept walking."
"Look around you. Don't you know what their little war is about? They want all non-Nords out of Skyrim."
"Apparently some Nord women were murdered. Not sure why I should care."
"Things have been a lot worse around here since Ulfric took over."
"It's not the cold of Skyrim that gets me. It's the stink of the people."
"Have a seat, there should be plenty of space."
"When I've made enough money, I'm going to return to Morrowind in high style."
If asked about how to learn magic: "The College of Winterhold is the only place in Skyrim open-minded enough to teach magic. Although Ulfric's court wizard has been known to take on apprentices once in a while."
author: Bethesda

name: Amren
bio:
Amren is a Redguard man who lives in Whiterun. His dark hair is styled into cornrows, and he sports a short mustache and beard. Amren wears studded armor and hide boots, and carries a steel sword on his hip.
Amren is married to a Redguard woman named Saffir, and together they have a daughter named Braith. He serves as a trainer of One-Handed weaponry. He left military service for a quieter family life, and although he misses it sometimes, he says he knows he made the right decision.
Amren has argued with his wife Saffir in front of House Gray-Mane about his attempts to retrieve his family sword. His wife is upset that he is wasting too much money on the endeavor.
When encountered, he will ask the player to retrieve his family sword, which has been stolen by a thief. Upon completing the quest, he will give the player a lesson in One-Handed weaponry and in the effective use of a shield.
Quotes:
“I'm a Redguard. My family hails from the Imperial Province. Ah, but I left home when I was just a lad. Been wandering ever since."
"My Saffir doesn't like that I've been spending so much time looking for my father's old sword. He fed his entire family with the gold he made using that weapon. I'm not about to let it gather dust in some thief's trophy room."
"My wife's a good woman. She can be a little hard-headed sometimes, but I love her just the same."
"You tried mercenary work? It might suit you."
"Sometimes I miss the soldier's life, but when I hold my daughter in my arms, I know I've made the right choice."
If the player retrieves his sword: "You found it? I've been looking for that blade for months. You took on all those bandits yourself? Thank you. Here, my father had a favorite sword and shield technique. Let me teach it to you, in honor of his memory."
author: Bethesda

name: Ancano
bio:
Ancano is a Thalmor operative. He is currently serving as an "advisor" to the Arch-Mage of the College of Winterhold. The College is the primary institution for magical learning in Skyrim.
Like most Thalmor agents, Ancano is an Altmer. He wears standard Thalmor robes with matching boots and gloves. He is a powerful mage and knows an impressive number of spells, particularly those from the Destruction and Restoration schools of magic.
Ancano has an overbearingly arrogant attitude and openly voices his belief that the mages of the College are inferior to those of the Thalmor. The College community demonstrates a palpable mistrust toward him due to his Thalmor allegiance. Ancano is also highly suspicious of others. He is annoyed that he has not been called upon by the Arch-Mage for counsel, and is angered that the College's Master Wizard (second in command at the College and subordinate only to the Arch-Mage) has not granted him greater access to the College's resources. The Arch-Mage is a male Dunmer named Savos Aren. The Master Wizard is a Breton woman named Mirabelle Ervine.
Ancano spends much of his time in the Hall of the Elements in the College's central tower, carefully listening to everything that is going on. His living quarters are on the ground floor of the Hall of Attainment, where the College's apprentices dwell.
Ancano is secretely very interested in the Eye of Magnus. He is deeply distrustful of the Psijic Order, which is considered a rogue organization and enemy of the Thalmor. Ancano vehemently denies that he is a spy for the Thalmor, though secretly, his primary mission is to report any interesting developments at the College to his Thalmor superiors.
Quotes:
"Another new Apprentice, I see. Are you of the sort that believe you're here to change the world? Or are you only in it for yourself? I assure you that I'll be watching you -- all of you -- very closely."
"I have many important things on my mind. Your concerns are not among them."
"Are you quite sure we need to be speaking?"
"I'm disappointed to say I've learned little during my time here."
“I had hoped your scholars would be on a level comparable with my own colleagues. They are not."
"I am an advisor to the Arch-Mage. The Thalmor wish to promote relations with your College. I am at the Arch-Mage's disposal if he requires advice."
"Now that stability has been established between the Dominion and the Empire, we seek only to help Skyrim. To guide its people through this time of transition, to help lead them to a better future."
author: Bethesda

name: Ancarion
bio:
Ancarion is a Thalmor agent in Solstheim on a secret mission to obtain Stalhrim smithing techniques from the Skaal.
He is found on a boat in Northshore Landing in possession of the Stalhrim Source Map, which must be obtained.
author: Bethesda

name: Anders
bio:
Anders is a deceased Nord man whose dead body lies inside the Twilight Sepulcher, a cave at the base of the Jerall Mountains that functions as a sort of shrine to Nocturnal, the Daedric Prince of darkness and luck.
Anders and Nystrom posed as priests of Nocturnal to obtain the Sepulcher's treasure. According to Nystrom's notes of Lythelus' riddles, this treasure is found inside Pilgrim's Path. Anders subsequently murdered Nystrom and left his body inside the first room of the Twilight Sepulcher, so that he would not have to share the treasure.
As part of the last riddle, Anders jumped down into a pit, but found himself trapped at the bottom and eventually starved to death.
Anders' wrote a note before he died, which reads as follows: "I can't believe it. I came all this way, solved all of those ridiculous riddles just to end up here! After I memorized Nystrom's clues he'd collected from Lythelus, I slit his throat. Now I guess the joke's on me, because I'm stuck here and I don't see a way out. Hope someone comes by soon, I'm getting hungry."
author: Bethesda
note: Shawn - done. Probably not able to be talked to. MaleBandit voice assigned, just in case

name: Andurs
bio:
Andurs is an older Nord man living in Whiterun. He has a bald head and fairly long white and gray beard. Andurs serves a priest of Arkay at the Hall of the Dead in Whiterun, watching and maintaining the crypt. He is responsible for preparing dead bodies for the afterlife.
Andurs may ask the player to recover his Amulet of Arkay in the catacombs, so that he can rebuke the corpses that have risen back to life within the catacombs. If the player does this, Andurs will reward them with 15 gold.
If someone delivers a dagger to Andurs from Alessandra (an Imperial woman who is a priestess of Arkay in Riften), Andurs will accept it.
A few months ago, Andurs was visited by Runil, an old Altmer man who is a fellow priest of Arkay in Falkreath. They shared words and each other’s company for just over a week before Runil returned to Falkreath.
Arkay or Ark'ay sometimes referred to as the Bringer of Light, and also known as the God of the Cycle of Birth and Death, and Lord of the Wheel of Life, is a major divinity of the Nine Divines. Arkay represents the qualities of birth and death, and is particularly associated with burials and funeral rites, as well as being linked to the cyclical nature of the seasons. Any dead body that is properly buried by a priest observing the proper rituals, is protected by Arkay's Law from being raised as undead. Therefore, necromancers view Arkay as their ultimate enemy, and make covert efforts to undermine his worship throughout Tamriel. Because of this association with, and protection of, mortality, Arkay is sometimes called the Mortals' God. Some sources state that Arkay's life began as a mortal, who joined the ranks of the gods. Arkay's followers regard Arkay as the god of the cycle of life and death, and as such Arkay’s priests are staunch opponents of necromancy and all forms of the undead. Arkay has had several diverse origins attributed to him at different times. Some say he is the son of Akatosh, who did not exist before Nirn was created. It is said by some, including Arkay's priesthood, that Arkay was a mortal man whose apotheosis was granted by Mara. Another source suggests that Arkay is one of the original spirits that crystallized after time began, meaning he was always a deity. Still others say that Arkay is a syncretic god, created from a fusion of Xarxes and Orkey, and is possibly also the same deity as the Redguard god Tu'whacca. In Skyrim, every city has a Hall of the Dead dedicated to Arkay, and Arkay is especially prominent in the city of Falkreath. There are also shrines in his honor scattered across Skyrim’s landscape.
Quotes:
"I spend so much time among the dead, I sometimes forget how much I miss the company of the living."
“Arkay is the god of life and death. You'll find his temples and Halls of the Dead all across Tamriel. Priests of Arkay such as myself perform rites for the dead and sometimes console the bereaved. We also keep a constant vigil against those who practice the vile arts of necromancy.”
"With this terrible war, I'm a bit overwhelmed. As are the catacombs."
"As Whiterun's priest of Arkay, I spread his word whenever I'm able. In the meantime, most of my hours are spent with the city's dearly departed.”
author: Bethesda

name: Angeline Morrard
bio:
Angeline Morrard is an elderly Breton woman who owns and runs an alchemy shop called Angeline's Aromatics in Solitude. Angeline's niece Vivienne Onis helps her run this shop. Angeline and Vivienne live on the second floor of the same building that contains their alchemy shop, which is on the ground floor. The Winking Skeever, a popular inn in Solitude, is located right next to this building.
Before the Skyrim Civil War between the Imperial and the Stormcloaks, Angeline used her store to sell ingredients for perfumes used in homes. However, because of the war, Angeline often has customers looking for healing ingredients, and Angeline has transitioned her store into an alchemy shop which sells potions and alchemy ingredients. 
Some time ago, Angeline's daughter Fura signed up for the Imperial Legion and was assigned to a scouting party in Whiterun. Angeline may ask the player if they have seen her daughter, as well as ask the player to inquire with Captain Aldis (the captain of the guard in Solitude) if there has been any news regarding her daughter.
If the player asks Angeline if she can train them in alchemy, she will reply that she is not qualified to train people in alchemy, and refer the player to Lami (a Nord woman living in Morthal) or Arcadia (an Imperial woman living in Whiterun) as potential alchemy teachers.
Despite her name being Angeline, she is frequently referred to as "Angela" both by herself and other citizens of Solitude.
Quotes:
“It's good to see a fresh face. You wouldn't happen to come from Whiterun would you?”
“We mostly carry herbs and alchemical ingredients, that sort of thing. Before the war, our stock was mostly used for aromatic use in homes, yes. These days we have more people like you coming in, looking for healing and the like.”
“My daughter Fura was assigned to Whiterun after she joined the Imperial Army. I was hoping you might have met her. I haven't heard from her lately. I've tried talking to Captain Aldis but he hasn't been any help.”
“Well hello!”
“Need something for a potion? You're certainly in the right place.”
“Don't forget me next time you need herbs or potions.”
“I hope your parents are proud of you. They have a lot of reason to be.”
If her daughter dies: “I told her. I told her the imperial army would kill her. That this was a war of Jarls and Imperial Generals and we had no part in it. She just wouldn't hear it. It was brave of you to come to me with this. I can't thank you for it, not for this, but you have done me a service."
author: Bethesda

name: Anger
bio:
Anger is a Nord who appears in Pelagius the Mad's mind during the quest "The Mind of Madness."
During the quest he is seen beating Confidence and has to be made smaller using Wabbajack.
author: Bethesda

name: Angi
bio:
Angi is a Nord woman who lives in seclusion in her camp south of Falkreath, fairly high up in the mountains. She used to live in Helgen. She has shoulder-length blonde hair, and wears a belted tunic and boots.
Angi is currently in hiding after taking revenge on the pair of drunken Imperial soldiers who killed her parents. Angi is very skilled with her bow and is willing to train the player in Archery for free by providing practice sessions near her camp, using unsharpened practice arrows. The first training challenge Angi presents is Test of Accuracy, which is divided into short-range, medium-range, and long-range portions. Afterwards she will present the Test of Speed, followed by the Test of Precision (requires hitting a target that is even farther away than the previous long-range targets), and finally the Final Test, which incorporates aspects of all the previous challenge into one ultimate test of the player’s archery ability. If player successfully completes all of these archery challenges, and if the player has spoken to Angi in a positive and friendly manner throughout their interaction, Angi will gift the player with a bow. This bow is an improved, non-enchanted hunting bow which belonged to her family. While this bow holds sentimental value to Angi, it brings back too many painful memories for her, and she will happily give it to the player if they sufficiently demonstrate their archery skill. 
During the training challenges Angi presents to the player, she will talk about her family, with each completed stage of the tests revealing more about her and how her family trained her to use a bow. 
Her mother was the one that trained Angi with the bow, as her father was frequently absent. Her mother taught Angi that the secret is speed and composure. She also taught Angi that keeping calm, even in the midst of chaos, will allow arrows to always find their target. 
When Angi was younger, her older brother would take her out hunting. At the time, food was hard to come by, making it difficult to put food on the table, let alone sell at the market. Whenever the two of them came across multiple deer in a single area, it was important to kill as many as possible. This helped Angi become not only accurate, but also quick. 
Angi has a book called "The Gold Ribbon of Merit" in her shack.
Quotes:
“A girl can't be too careful out here. Name's Angi and I've been living out here for a couple of years now."
"I moved here from Helgen after my family was killed. At the time I couldn't stand to be around anyone. They all felt sorry for me and I didn't want them to. It was my problem, not theirs."
"My family was killed by two Imperial drunks who thought they were above the law.”
“I’ve already killed the two men who killed my family. That’s part of the reason I’m living out here now.”
"I set up those targets a long time ago. I shoot at them from time to time. Don't want to get rusty with my bow."
“Let me know if you ever want to practice archery. If you need a bow, there's one on the rack to the left of the door."
author: Bethesda

name: Angrenor Once-Honored
bio:
Angrenor Once-Honored is a Nord man. He is a beggar and former Stormcloak Soldier in Skyrim who lives on the streets of Windhelm. He can be found walking through the Gray Quarter of Windhelm (the quarter of the city to which the Dunmer are confined) or around Candlehearth Hall (a popular inn near the center of Windhelm, ran by a middle-aged Nord woman named Elda Early-Dawn.
Angrenor fought in the Great War against the Aldmeri Dominion as a footman. After the war, he lost everything. Angrenor is bald, and wears a roughspun tunic with simple footwraps. He carries an iron mace on his hip.
In more recent times, he was a Stormcloak soldier, but this was cut short when he took a sword through the chest. He claims he defeated six men at once while rescuing his friend from an Imperial Patrol.
Angrenor and Rolff Stone-Fist can be observed accusing Suvaris Atheron (a Dunmer woman) of being an Imperial spy. Angrenor is clearled prejudiced against elves. 
If Angrenor is shown kindness and is given gold, clothing, or armor by the player , he will consider the player as his friend. Subsequently, Angrenor will accept a marriage proposal made by the player.
Quotes:
"Hey, maybe the reason these gray-skins don't help in the war is because they're Imperial spies!"
"I would be out there fighting the Imperials right now if it wasn't for my war wound."
"I was one of the best soldiers in the Stormcloak army, until I took a sword through the chest."
"Ever since that Imperial craven ran me through from behind, I've had trouble breathing. Don't have any trouble drinking though."
"I once killed six men, single-handed, while rescuing my brothers-in-arms from ambush by an Imperial patrol."
"I'm not too proud to admit that I need a bit of help from time to time."
author: Bethesda

name: Angvid
bio:
Angvid is a Nord man who works as a miner at Whistling Mine. His hair is white. Whistling Mine is a small iron mine southeast of Winterhold. The mine is situated along the southern path that leads out of Winterhold towards Windhelm, at the base of the mountains.
Angvid wears a standard miner's outfit and carries an iron mace. He can usually be found swinging a pickaxe at various ore veins around the mine. When not working, Angvid can usually be found sleeping in one of the bedrolls just inside the mine. Angvid is not sure if continuing to work at the mine is worth it because of the lack of ore, and he is losing faith in both Thorgar and the mine. 
Thorgar is the Nord man who owns the rights to the mine, also helping in the mining efforts. Unlike Angvid, Thorgar optimistically still believes that they will strike something better than iron and become rich, even though the mine barely even has any iron. Badnir and Gunding are two of the other miners at the mine, both of them strong Nord men. Angvid, Thorgar, Bandir, and Gunding all sleep in bedrolls just inside the mine.
Quotes:
"We were supposed to be rich by now, you know. Thorgar insisted we'd be swimming in gold."
"I'm starting to think we might not even find iron in here. We've been at it for so long."
"Is it still worth it? When do you decide enough is enough, and just walk away?"
author: Bethesda

name: Anise
bio:
Anise is an elderly Nord woman who lives just southwest of Riverwood. She can often be found gardening or sitting on a chair outside her cabin. Her log cabin home is located not too far of the point at which Lake Ilinalta transitions into the White River, flowing northeast. Her cabin is not too far south from Bleak Falls Barrow and its accompanying mountains.
She appears indifferent to anyone just visiting, but is secretly a witch and will become hostile if she sees anyone stealing from her or if anyone enters her cellar, which contains an arcane enchanter and an alchemy lab, as well as various alchemical ingredients. There is also an unsent letter in the cellar which indicates that she desires to create a witches coven. The letter is address to a woman named Helgi, and reads as follows: "Helgi, dear, why do you hesitate? You can feel the power coursing in your blood! You have only to reach out and grasp it! Renounce that boy of yours and come, come live with me in the forest. My sister will be here soon. Together, we can form a proper coven, and your training will truly begin."
Quotes:
"I'm just a poor old woman, dear. No need to trouble yourself with me."
"It's so nice to have a visitor."
"It's tough just scraping by out here, but I make do."
"I get so lonely out here."
If the player finds her secret cellar: "Fool! None may know my secret!"
author: Bethesda

name: Annekke Crag-Jumper
bio:
Annekke Crag-Jumper is a Nord woman who lives in Darkwater Crossing with her husband, Verner Rock-Chucker. She has blonde hair and blue eyes. She and her husband work at Goldenrock Mine just to the east of their house. Annekke was the one who discovered the veins of corundum ore within the cave that is now called Goldenrock Mine.
Annekke and Verner are the parents of Sylgja, a young woman who currently works as a miner in the town of Shor's Stone to the southeast of Darkwater Crossing. 
Annekee and Verner have put their exploration days behind them, but while Verner is seemingly happy with a more relaxed lifestyle, Annekke has a hard time settling down. Annekke's husband can often be heard complaining that Annekke never spends enough time working at the mine, and that she spends too much time adventuring. Admittedly, Annekke only works at the mine for approximately 5 hours a day, spending much of her time exploring the wilderness around the town.
Annekke admires the player's adventurous spirit, and may ask the player to slay a local bandit leader. If the player performs this favor for her, Annekke will consider the player as a friend, give the player a useful tip regarding the use of light armor, and subsequently become willing to follow the player on adventures across Skyrim.
Annekke wears a set of miner's clothes, with boots and a pair of gloves. She carries an iron dagger, a pickaxe, a hunting bow, and a quiver with iron arrows. She is talented with Archery and the use of Light Armor, and to a lesser extent with One Handed weaponry and the use of a shield. She is not particularly talented at stealth.
Quotes:
"I used to be an adventurer in my day. Then I settled down. Got married."
“I used to explore all over. I'm the one who originally found the mine Darkwater Crossing was built around. I was actually scouting a bit the other day, old times sake. Spied a brigand heading back to his camp. Up for a little hunting? My husband is being a sad stick, so I can't go myself."
"Bandits are cowards. Don't strain yourself chasing them all down."
 I found the most amazing tree growing right out of a cave yesterday."
"A traveler? I'll be you've seen some sights. We should swap tales sometime."
"There's a gorgeous tree that grows right up through a cave to the northeast of here."
"If you're heading to Kynesgrove, stick to the road. Some pretty dangerous caves between here and there."
"Verner used to love exploring before we got married. Now he's become a bit of a milk drinker. Likes to stay home."
After the player slays the bandit leader she mentioned: "You remind me of myself a few years ago. Let me show you a little bit about wearing light armor. It's helped me out whenever I was scouting. Now I've got the itch to travel again. If you're leaving town, I wouldn't mind coming with for a while."
author: Bethesda

name: Anoriath
bio:
Anoriath, a young Bosmer man, works as a hunter and merchant in Whiterun. He and his brother Elrindir own the Drunken Huntsman. The Drunken Huntsman is a tavern and hunting supply store in the Plains District of Whiterun, near the main gate of the city.
Elrindir works the counter at the Drunken Huntsman, whereas Anoriath hunts and sells hunting goods and meats in the market during the day. Anoriath's market stall is located near The Bannered Mare, the most popular inn in Whiterun.
The name "The Drunken Huntsman" is a reference to a drunken hunting accident in which Anoriath accidentally shot an arrow into Elrindir's rear. However, Anoriath doesn't usually like to admit this.
Anoriath is generally friendly when conversed with. He is keen huntsman, and all the game he sells at his stall has been hunted by him personally. He sometimes converses with customers and others who walk by his stall in the market, such as Olfina Gray-Mane (a young Nord woman with white hair who is secretly the girlfriend of Jon Battle-Born), Ysolda (a young red-headed Nord woman who is an aspiring merchant), and Brenuin (an annoying disheveled Redguard man who is a beggar and never buys anything).
Quotes:
During the day at his market stall: "The finest cuts, fresh from the wilds!"
During the day at his market stall: "Tired of bread and stew? Had enough of fish and fowl? Treat yourself and your kin to a choice cut of steak or a tender rack of ribs."
During the day at his market stall: "Try the venison - it's delicious."
During the day at his market stall:“Chops and steaks fit for a Jarl! Come and see my selection of finest-quality meats!"
"Do you hunt? The plains outside Whiterun are ripe with game."
"Remember, I've got the freshest meat in all of Whiterun.
"I've been thinking of hunting out beyond the boundaries of Whiterun Hold."
"Good hunting."
“Hunting is my great passion. That's why my brother and I opened a shop to sell hunting supplies. It's the Drunken Huntsman, down by the main gate. He tends the store, and I've got this stall.”
If currently in the Drunken Huntsman: "Need something? Talk to my brother, Elrindir."
author: Bethesda

name: Anska
bio:
Anska is a Nord woman who is currently exploring High Gate Ruins, near Skyrim’s northern shore. She has gray hair. She wears fur armor and light boots, and carries a dagger on her hip. She is a mage, and knows spells from the Alteration, Destruction, and Restoration schools of magic, including armor spells, elemental damage spells of each type (fire, frost, and shock), ward spells, and healing spells.
Anska will ask for the player’s help with finding a particular scroll that she believes is located deep within High Gate Ruins. This scroll will supposedly help trace Anska’s ancestral bloodline all the way back to the legendary Ysgramor from the late Merethic Era, thousands of years ago. If the player agrees to help Anska, she will accompany him through the ruin. The scroll is believed to be located in the tomb of the ancient Dragon Priest Vokun, deep within the ruin. 
If the player assists Anska and hands her the scroll, she will reward them with a “Conjuring Flaming Familiar” spell tome, which teaches the spell to summon a flaming wolf familiar which charges into battle and creates a fiery explosion with a radius of about 10 feet. However, if the player insists on keeping the scroll for themselves instead of giving it to Anska, Anska will have no choice but to try to take the scroll by force.
After being given and examining the scroll, Anska will discover that it has been encrypted, and that it will take a while for her to figure out the encryption.
Quotes:
“You look strong.”
“I'm Anska. Are you here to help?”
"I've finally located Vokun's crypt! The scroll I'm looking for just has to be here."
“Vokun is some old priest buried here long ago. I've been searching for his tomb for a few years now."
“According to family legend, the scroll links our bloodline back to Ysgramor himself."
"If Vokun is as powerful as I think, I may need a little help um ... dealing ...with him."
"You can have anything except the scroll of course."
author: Bethesda

name: Anton Virane
bio:
Anton Virane is a Breton chef in Understone Keep. He wears a chef's tunic and a chef's hat. He sports a white-gray mutton chops beard.
Originating from Daggerfall in Rock, Anton Virane serves as the master chef for Understone Keep in Markarth. He is also a minor merchant who sells food items as a side business. Anton has two assistants, Rondach (a Breton man) and Voada (a Breton woman), who are siblings. Antona considers both of them to be worthless assistants. 
In High Rock, Anton studied cuisine with The Gourmet, the chef famous across Tamriel for his cookbook "Uncommon Taste". Anton is a close friend of The Gourmet, and keeps a signed copy of this book on his nightstand. Anton will only reveal the secret identiy of The Gourmet (The Gourmet is secretly an Orc man named Balagog gro-Nolob) if Anton is threatened with imminent death.
Anton will emphatically clarify that he was born in High Rock, and that he is not affiliated with the Forsworn. He is often assumed to be a native of the Reach; an accusation which he finds offensive, since he considers the natives of the Reach to be uncultured savages compared to the people of his homeland.
Quotes:
"Before you say anything, no, I'm not from the Reach."
“I'm a Breton from High Rock, and I refuse to be mistaken for a filthy native. I don't care if we share the same ancestors, these people are savages. Half of them are Forsworn barbarians, and have you seen what they eat? What have I done for the gods to take me so far from my beloved Daggerfall?"
“Daggerfall is the finest court in all of High Rock. You think politics here are something? Well, we Bretons invented politics. That is where I learned to cook, and where I belong. Not here, with all these dogs."
"I have meals to cook for the entire castle, and almost no help. The Jarl give me two incompetent assistants. Worthless."
"Yes, yes, for the hundredth time, I am a Breton. I was born in High Rock. And then I came here. I am not a Reachman!"
If asked about the secret identity of The Gourmet: “I don't know what led you here, but nothing will betray my trust. I'll take the secret of the Gourmet's identity to my grave."
author: Bethesda

name: Anuriel
bio:
Anuriel, a Bosmer woman, serves as the stewardess to Jarl Laila Law-Giver of Riften. Anuriel wears a set of fine clothes and a pair of fine boots. Her attire and belongings mark as a member of the upper class of society. She has light-colored hair.
Anuriel is usually found at the Jarl's side in Mistveil Keep, and her bedroom is just beyond the doorway to the inner part of the Keep. Anuriel is the girlfriend of Unmid Snow-Shod (a strongly built Nord man who serves as Jarl Laila’s housecarl), and the two of them sometimes sneak away to a private location for romantic trysts, which they refer to as "training sessions" when in public.
Anuriel’s boyfriend Unmid is a member of the influential Snow-Shod clan. Unmid’s father Vulwulf is a staunch supporter of the Stormcloaks in their war against the Imperial Legion. Unmid’s mother Nura is a priestess of Talos. Unmid’s sister Lilija was recently killed while fighting alongside the Stormcloaks against the Legion. Umid has a brother named Asgeir, who works as an investor and business parter to Maven Black-Briar at the Black-Briar Meadery in Riften.
Anuriel is secretly an infiltrator put in place by Maven Black-Briar to manipulate Jarl Laila into defending Maven's interests and keep Laila blind to the activity of the Thieves Guild in Riften. Maven rewards Anuriel well for this, via gifts and gold. Anuriel will not admit to secretly being an infiltrator for Maven unless the player finds the incriminating letter from Maven (Anuriel hid this letter in her dresser in her room) and threatens to show the letter to Jarl Laila or the public. If this occurs, Anuriel will attempt to buy back the letter and the player’s silence on this matter, by offering to divulge to the player valuable information regarding the location of a large shipment of gold and weapons related to the Stormcloak war effort against the Imperial Legion. If the player agrees to return the letter and remain silent regarding Anuriel's relationship with Maven Black-Briar, Anuriel will subsequently reveal that the slow-moving shipment of gold and weapons should currently be traveling on the road south of Cragslane Cavern, roughly halfway between Riften and Windhelm (the shipment's intended destination).
If the player is the Dragonborn, Anuriel will ask them to kill the dragon at Northwind Summit, in the mountains at the northern edge of The Rift.
If the player has been named Thane of the Rift, the player will be allowed to purchase the Honeyside residential property in Riften from Anuriel, for 8000 gold.
If the Imperial Legion were to take control of Riften and depose Jarl Laila, then Jarl Laila, Anuriel, and Unmid would be exiled to the Palace of the Kings in Windhelm. 
Quotes:
"Welcome to Mistveil Keep. I'm Jarl Laila's steward, Anuriel."
"As Riften's Steward I'm afraid I can provide only limited assistance, but speak your mind."
"If you're here to report any instances of corruption, be confident that we're handling these rumors accordingly."
"As steward, I serve as an intermediary between the Jarl and her subjects. I also handle the less important and day-to-day policies that effect daily life in Riften. Lately I've had my hands full suppressing these ridiculous accusations of corruption in the keep."
"There are those that believe the Jarl does nothing for this city... that it's corrupt and run by the Black-Briar family. I can assure you that this is entirely false. We are fully in control of everything."
"You're welcome in Riften as long as you continue to obey our laws."
If in the Palace of the Kings: "I'm afraid my days as the steward of Riften has come to an end. The Imperials now control Riften and have placed Maven Black-Briar on the Jarl's throne. Perhaps the Stormcloaks might rally to take back Riften one day. Only time will tell."
author: Bethesda

name: Anwen
bio:
Anwen, a Redguard woman, serves as a priestess at the Temple of Dibella in Markarth. She wears hooded monk robes.
Anwen serves under Hamal, the head priestess of Dibella in Markarth. Hamal is an older Nord woman, and is often referred to as “The Mother” by the other priestesses. Other priestesses at the temple include Senna (a Breton woman) and Orla (a young Nord woman).
If the player has successfully rescued the new Sybil of Dibella (a Nord girl named Fjotra) from her captivity by the Forsworn, and the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse), Anwen will accept a marriage proposal from the player.
Unless married to the player, Anwen is so devoted to her duties as a priestess of Dibella that she almost never leaves the Temple of Dibella. If Anwen weds the player, she will be willing to live at the player’s house instead. If the player has already adopted children, then before moving to a new house, Anwen will remark that their new house must have enough room for the children.
If the player and Anwen get married, Anwen will open up a general goods shop to provide some extra income for herself and her new spouse. She will give her spouse 100 gold daily from the store’s profits.
If the player and Anwen get married, Anwen’s dialogue towards the player will often be more assertive than most other wives. However, she also will speak tenderly to the player sometimes. 
Anwen is somewhat skilled with magic, and she knows the following spells: Conjure Familiar, Flames, Heal Other and Fast Healing.
Quotes:
"Yes, yes. I haven't got all day...
author: Bethesda

name: Aphia Velothi
bio:
Aphia Velothi is wife of an elderly Imperial man named Crescius Caerellius. They live in Raven Rock on the island of Solstheim. Aphia disapproves of her husband venturing into the ebony mine on the edge of the settlement, because she thinks he is getting too old for such dangerous things.
Like the majority of Raven Rock's population, Aphia is a Dunmer. She has bright red eyes and long gray hair. She has a particularly soft soothing voice, making her sound younger than she is. Aphia is an adept trainer of Restoration magic and will be willing to sell lessons in it.
Aphia was once a priestess at the Raven Rock Temple. She eventually left the Temple over a disagreement with Elder Othreloth regarding the divinity of the Tribunal gods.
Othreloth is an adherent of the New Temple religious movement, which preaches that the Tribunal gods (Vivec, Sotha Sil, and Almalexia) should be considered false prophets, and that the Daedric princes Mephala, Azura, and Boethiah should be hailed as the True Tribunal. Aphia strongly disagrees with this, and adheres to the older religious tradition in which Vivec, Sotha Sil, and Almalexia were worshipped in Morrowind for thousands of years as living gods at the cornerstone of the Dunmer culture and religion.
Quotes:
"It's been tough running the household alone, but Crescius isn't getting any younger."
"Those East Empire people should be ashamed of themselves for abandoning Raven Rock."
"That foolish old man thinks he's thirty years younger than he is. He's going to get himself killed traipsing around the mine."
If asked how she met Crescius: "To understand how we met one another, you have to appreciate what he's going through. Crescius is a third-generation miner... all his life, he's lived and breathed nothing else. By the time Crescius came of age, the ebony mine in Raven Rock was shut down. He took that quite hard. Our home has been in his family for over two hundred years. Leaving would have been like abandoning precious memories. Instead, he stayed on Solstheim and spent most of his life prospecting for a new ebony source. Sadly, it never surfaced. A decade ago, this drove him into a deep depression. He shut himself inside his home and refused to come out. After refusing to allow anyone to bring him food, Councilor Morvayn ordered his door to be knocked down before Crescius starved to death. I was a Temple priest at the time, and they had me use my healing arts to restore strength to his ailing body. I stayed for a while and cared for him, then... I suppose we fell in love."
If asked if she is a priest at the Temple: "Far from it. In fact, I'm no longer welcome there. In all honesty, it came down to a disagreement between what I believe and what Elder Othreloth believes.
I'd prefer not to get into the details, but let's just say our opinions about the current status of the Tribunal vary widely."
If asked if she wants to be the new steward of Tel Mithryn: "Me? I hardly think so. That Telvanni wizard is unhinged. I heard he tries to drink the ash."
If offered a free sample of Geldis Sadri's new sujamma drink: "Well that sounds lovely. Thank you."
author: Bethesda

name: Aquillius Aeresius
bio:
Aquillius Aeresius is an Imperial man living in Solitude. He wears a set of fine clothes and fine boots.
He lives at Vittoria Vici's house, but his relationship to Vittoria is purely platonic. Vittoria Vici is the cousin of the Emperor of Tamriel, Titus Mede the Second. Vittoria is engaged to be married to Asgeir Snow-Shod, a Nord man from Riften. They plan to have a large wedding ceremony and reception in the Castle Dour courtyard.
Aquillius sometimes attends Thalmor parties at the Thalmor Embassy north of Solitude.
Quotes:
