note: Shawn - done. Limited interactability. His actual voice type is MaleUniqueGhost. No voice model currently exists for this voice type. Feel free to change his assigned voice at your discretion.

name: Babette
bio:
Babette, a Breton, is a vampire and member of the Dark Brotherhood. She also functions as a merchant of potions and ingredients for the Brotherhood, and sometimes sells master-level Alchemy lessons.
At the age of ten, Babette was bitten by a vampire, thus becoming one herself. She has lived over three hundred years since then, and boasts about how her innocent appearance makes killing people easier. She has reddish-brown hair.
Babette will be willing to buy and sell potions and alchemy items with the player. Babette has a large supply of gold.
Babette can sometimes be found wandering the wilderness of Skyrim in search of a "snack".
If Auriel's Bow is used to block out the sun, she will comment on it, saying, "The tyranny of the sun is over! It's our time, now."
Quotes:
“Astrid's told me all about you. Heard she pulled the ole' "Choose your victim" gag with you. Ah, I love that one..."
"You're going to love it here. We have a lot of fun, and we look out for each other. Just like any family."
“In truth, I'm no more a little girl than you are. I was once, of course. Three hundred years ago. Vampirism tends to keep one remarkably... fresh."
"Can't wait to hear all about the next person you murder."
"It's been quite a boon looking like a child. No one ever suspects a thing."
“Two hundred years ago, I would have lain down my life for the Unholy Matron. But that is an ago long since passed. Astrid is my matron now."
"I could brew some potions for you. Or train you in Alchemy."
"You looking to buy some potions? Or maybe I could help train you to make your own?"
"My targets make the mistake of not perceiving me as a threat. Last mistake they ever make."
author: Bethesda

name: Badnir
bio:
Badnir is a Nord man who works and resides in the Whistling Mine, southeast of Winterhold.
When not mining ore, he can be found near the entrance of the mine, either cooking, sitting or sleeping. He wears Hide Armor and Hide Boots, and wields an Iron Warhammer. He is strongly built and has shoulder-length dark hair.
He works for Thorgar, the owner of the Whistling Mine. Thorgar believes that they soon will strike something better than iron and become rich. Angvid and Gunding are two of the other miners at the mine, both of them strong Nord men. Badnir, Thoring, Angvid, and Gunding all sleep in bedrolls just inside the mine.
Quotes:
"It's cold in the mine, but Thorgar really needs me, so I stay."
"Thorgar says we'll find rocks soon, the kind worth gold."
"I'm the best at breaking up rocks. Thorgar says so."
author: Bethesda

name: Bagrak
bio:
Bagrak is an Orc woman found in the Orc Stronghold of Mor Khazgur in Haafingar. She is one of the two wives of Chief Larak. Bagrak and Larak have a daughter named Borgakh, who is sometimes referred to as "Borgakh the Steel Heart". Shuftharz is Chief Larak’s other wife, whose son is named Olur. Bagrak and Chief Larak are both the children of Sharamph, the stronghold’s wise woman. This means that in addition to being husband and wife, Larak and Bagrak are also siblings, which is not unheard of in Orc strongholds.
Bagrak spends much of her time patrolling the watchtowers of the stronghold.
Quotes:
"Larak is strong, but he has much to prove as chief."
"You should see my mother, Sharamph, if you need a cure or a poison."
"Shuftharz can forge you some armor, outlander."
author: Bethesda

name: Balagog gro-Nolob
bio:
Balagog gro-Nolob is an Orsimer man residing at the Nightgate Inn in the small village of Heljarchen. Heljarchen is located in a remote southern region of the Pale, with Mount Anthor and its surrounding mountains clearly visible in the northeast direction. Balagog is described by the innkeeper of Nightgate Inn (a Nord man named Hadring) as being more refined than most other Orcs. Balagog keeps a hidden identity as the famous chef called "The Gourmet", a secret which he will not divulge to anyone but his closest friends. Balagog was trained in Breton cuisine during his time in High Rock, where he befriended a fellow student named Anton Virane (a Breton man). 
Balagog later went on to publish a cookbook called "Uncommon Taste" under the pseudonym "The Gourmet". This cookbook became wildly successful throughout Tamriel, which led to Balagog being hired as the Emperor's private chef on retainer for the Emperor's potential visits to Skyrim. Balagog was scheduled to cook for Emperor Titus Mede II in this capacity, but the event was recently and abruptly cancelled. Penitus Oculatus agent Gaius Maro has decided to keep Balagog in Skyrim, just in case the Emperor ends up visiting Skyrim as originally planned. Balagog’s role as the Emperor’s chef is a closely guarded secret which he will not reveal under most circumstances.
Balagog lives in the cellar of the Nightgate Inn, only leaving once a day around noon to fish by the nearby pond. He wears fine clothes and fine boots. He prefers to interact with other people as little as possible in order maintain his secret identity, and is known to most of the Nightgate Inn's regular patrons only as "The Orc". The other patrons pay him little mind, and the innkeeper says that he doesn't care, since Balagog always pays his rent on time.
Quotes:
“I'm just here on... holiday."
"I can't help you, friend. Talk to Hadring, the Innkeeper."
"I don't mean to be rude, friend, but I'm not feeling particularly sociable..."
"I value my privacy.”
author: Bethesda

name: Balbus
bio:
Balbus is a Nord man who roams Skyrim. He is a fan of the Gourmet and is collecting ingredients for him.
If the player claims to be the Gourmet, Balbus will believe them, as long as they show him the document named “The Gourmet's writ of passage”.
Quotes:
"I'm collecting ingredients to bring to the Gourmet. He'll think my tastes so refined when I offer them to him. You have heard of the Gourmet?"
“The Gourmet keeps his identity a secret. I'm hoping to discover who he is, so I can tell him how he changed my life. For all I know, the Gourmet is a woman!"
“The Gourmet is the author of 'Uncommon Taste'. He's a wizard with a spatula. Well, not an actual wizard, but his recipes are legendary."
"You know, I've heard that the Gourmet is in Skyrim right now..."
If the player shows him the document named “The Gourmet's writ of passage”: "Oh my! You? It is an honor! Your food has opened my eyes to the wonders this world can hold. I've cooked every dish in your book, and I must say your brilliance is inspiring. My technique doesn't even approach yours...but whose would? Allow me to give you this, the fork I used the first time I tasted one of your dishes. Oh, and these ingredients I've been collecting for you. I've risked life and limb so that you may create another masterpiece. Make sure to think of me when you use them!"
author: Bethesda

name: Baldor Iron-Shaper
bio:
Baldor Iron-Shaper is the village blacksmith for the Skaal village, at the northeast corner of Solstheim, an island in the icy Sea of Ghosts. Baldor spends most of his day tending the forge outside his house.
Baldor is a middle-aged Nord man. He is balding and has a mustache. He usually wears a Skaal-style fur coat, boots, and gloves, and carries a steel mace on his waist. When asked why he's never gotten married, he jokes that he is married to his forge.
Baldor sells armor, weapons, and smithing materials. Unlike most blacksmiths, Baldor also sells ancient Nordic pickaxes, stalhrim weapons and armor, and raw stalhrim. Stalhrim is a rare form of enchanted ice found only on Solstheim. Due to its innate properties, frost enchantments placed on items made of stalhrim are more potent. Stalhrim is very hard, impossible to break by conventional means. The only known way to mine it is with an ancient Nordic pickaxe, made from superior craftsmanship. It has a rigid, blue-white crystalline metal, unnaturally cold to touch. Working with stalhrim is much like ebony smithing, and can only be performed by a skilled blacksmith.
The Skaal tribe strives to live in harmony with nature in accordance with their worship of the All-Maker. They live a simple existence in the frozen north of Solstheim, subsisting on hunting and minor agriculture. The village's buildings circle the central well, with a communal tanning rack and a meat preparation shed sheltering a cooking pot on either side of the well. 
The leader of the Skaal village is a woman named Fanari Strong-Voice. The village shaman is an elderly man named Storn Crag-Strider, who has an adult daughter named Frea. Baldor's blacksmithing apprentice is a woman named Morwen.
Like most of the Skaal villagers, Baldor was recently mind-controlled by Miraak and mentally forced to build a strange structure around the Wind Stone near the Skaal village. Luckily, the player (who is the Dragonborn) used their dragon shout to cleanse the Wind Stone of Miraak's influence, thus freeing Baldor and the other mentally enslaved villagers.
Soon after the Dragonborn rescued the Skaal from Miraak's mental domination, Baldor was abducted by High Elves and taken to an abandoned lodge somewhere else on Solstheim. These elves interrogated Baldor in an attempt to learn the secrets of how to shape stalhrim.
Quotes:
"I fear to think what would have happened if you hadn't saved me from the elves."
"The weapons of the Skaal will never be dull as long as Baldor Iron-Shaper tends the forge."
"There have been many strangers in our lands these past few moons."
"We call you a friend, but you must still respect our ways."
"The Dark Elves sometimes visit our village, though it's been awhile since I've seen one."
"Strong steel guard you, friend."
If spoken to in the abandoned lodge: "Outsider! I remember you. You're the one who freed the Skaal from the dark spell. Thank the All-Maker that you have come. These accursed elves have taken me from my home."
If asked why elves would abduct him: "They were trying to learn the secrets of forging Stalhrim. Their leader, an elf named Ancarion, has a map. He says that it shows the location of a hidden source of Stalhrim."
If asked what Stalhrim is: "Enchanted ice as hard as iron and cold as death. Stalhrim can be forged into deadly weapons, but the art is known only to the smiths of the Skaal."
If asked where Ancarion is: "They have a ship. They took me there and showed me the map. You will find it on the northern coast of the island. Please, do not let Ancarion make his weapons. Kill him or let him live, but take the map from him. It belongs with the Skaal. I will return to the village. When you have the map, please bring it to me there. And thank you. May the All-Maker bless your days."
If brought the map to the Stalhrim source: "I know you faced great danger to bring this map to me. There are no words to tell how glad my heart is. Thank you. I name you friend of the Skaal, and I will trust you with the knowledge of forging Stalhrim. If you bring Stalhrim here to my forge, you can use my tools to make what you will from it. Until our next meeting, Skaal-friend, may your hunts always bring you game and your crops grow tall and bountiful."
When ending conversation with the Dragonborn: "Farewell, strong one."
author: Bethesda

name: Balgruuf the Greater
bio:
Balgruuf the Greater, a Nord man, is the Jarl of Whiterun. He resides in Dragonsreach, his great palace in the Cloud District of Whiterun. 
Balgruuf wears clothing fit for the nobility of Skyrim, along with fur-lined boots and a gold and ruby circlet for a crown. He owns a set of steel plate armor that he will wear if battle is imminent, and his weapon of choice is a war axe. He has thick blond hair and a full beard.
Balgruuf is a direct descendant of King Olaf One-Eye, who reigned all the way back in the First Era. Balgruuf is an admirer of the Greybeards, and he made the pilgrimage to High Hrothgar in his youth. He has carried on a rivalry with Ulfric Stormcloak since they were both young men.
Following the White-Gold Concordat (the treaty which ended the Great War against the Aldmeri Dominion 30 years ago), Balgruuf and the other Jarls of Skyrim were given chests of gold as compensation for treaty’s regrettable terms (such as a ban on the worship of Talos). Despite this, Balgruuf has continued worshipping Talos privately.
Balgruuf hates the Thalmor (the ruling body of the Dominion) as least as much as Ulfric and the Stormcloaks hate them. Out of sheer diplomatic necessity, Balgruuf sometimes attends Thalmor ambassador Elenwen's parties at the Thalmor Embassy, near Solitude. If Balgruuf is encountered at one of these parties, he will make his disdain of the Thalmor very clear, and will be happy to create a distraction if requested.
Balgruuf has a younger brother named Hrongar, who serves as an advisor and courtier in Dragonsreach.
Balgruuf puts Whiterun’s interests first, many times denying the Imperial Legion permission to garrison soldiers in his city so as not to portray a state of martial law: if he is asked what side he is on in the war, he will say that he is "on the side of Whiterun," showing a great sense of loyalty towards Whiterun. 
Balgruuf and Ulfric Stormcloak have been at odds for years. Balgruuf's distaste for the Stormcloaks is exacerbated by Ulfric’s declaration that he considers anyone who does not support him to be an enemy.
Balgruuf is generally more interested in threat posed by the dragons than in the civil war between Imperials and Stormcloaks. Balgruuf is viewed by many as the embodiment of a true Nord.
Balgruuf still worships Talos and hates the Thalmor as much as Ulfric and the other Nords do, if not more. If encountered at the party at the Thalmor Embassy, he will make this view very clear and will also be more than happy to disrupt the proceedings on behalf of the player.
Balgruuf has a strong bond with his friend and housecarl Irileth, a Dunmer woman he fought alongside during his time in the Imperial Legion. Irileth rarely lets Balgruuf out of her sight and berates him for being too reckless with his own safety. Irileth is often concerned about potential assassination attempts on Balgruuf.
Balgruuf has three children: his sons Frothar and Nelkir, and his daughter Dagny. Nelkir is his youngest child. Unlike Dagny and Frothar, who were both mothered by Balgruuf's now deceased wife, Nelkir is secretly the child resulting from Balgruuf's affair with another woman. Balgruuf's secret extra-marital affair and the fact that Nelkir is a bastard child is not public information, and Balgruuf tries to keep these embarrassing facts a secret. Balgruuf will not mention or be willing to discuss the death of his wife, nor will he willing to discuss the secret identity of Nelkir's mother.
Proventus Avenicci is Balgruuf’s steward. Farengar Secret-Fire is Whiterun’s court mage.
If the player slays the dragon that attacked Whiterun’s western watchtower, Balgruuf will dub them a Thane of Whiterun, and appoint a reliable Nord woman named Lydia to serve as the player’s housecarl. Balgruuf will then advise the player (who at this point, will be revealed to be a Dragonborn) to visit the Greybeards at High Hrothgar for instruction on how to learn the Thu'um. Additionally, he will then grant them permission to purchase Breezehome, a house in Whiterun, for 5000 gold. He also will then present the Axe of Whiterun to the player, a status symbol of the Thanes of Whiterun.
At first, Balgruuf will remain neutral in the Civil War. Since Whiterun's provisions have been terribly diminished as a result of the war and the costs of goods have doubled, Balgruuf will likely eventually choose to side with the Empire in order to preserve the more lucrative trade agreements with the Empire.
Balgruuf has been having problems with his youngest son Nelkir, whose personality seems to have turned dark.
Unbeknownst to anyone else, Balgruuf and his court wizard Farengar each have a key to a locked door within the lower levels of the palace, called the Whispering Door. Stored away in the room behind this door is the Ebony Blade, a powerful katana-like weapon associated with Mephala. Mephala is the Daedric Prince associated with murder, lies, deception, spiders, sex, and secrets, and is always weaving a web of intrigue and terror. Balgruuf keeps the key to the Whispering Door with him at all times, wanting to ensure that no one is able to access this evil and dangerous Daedric artifact. Balgruuf is not willing to divulge any information regarding the Ebony Blade to anyone, and will not admit to carrying a key to the Whispering Door.
Balgruuf has significant respect for Kodlak Whitemane, the Harbinger of the Companions.
If the Stormcloaks attack and conquer Whiterun, Balgruuf will have no choice but to take refuge with Jarl Elisif at the Blue Palace in Solitude, along with Irileth, Proventus, and Hrongar. 
Quotes:
"May the gods watch over your battles."
If asked whose side he's on: “If it's the war you're referring to, I'm on the side of Whiterun. No doubt General Tullius and his friends in the Empire will tell you that I owe them my loyalty, and perhaps I do. Ulfric Stormcloak would say that I owe my allegiance to the Nord people as they fight for Skyrim's independence. Perhaps this is also true. The day might come when I am forced to draw my sword for one side or the other. But that day has not come yet."
If asked about Whiterun's readiness for a dragon attack: “We will protect Whiterun with good planning and constant vigilance. Even now, my court wizard, Farengar, continues his research into ways we might drive back these... terrors. We must also have ample reserves of water to combat the fires that will surely spread after an attack. But our greatest weapon? Courage. For if we cannot kill the beast, we must at least have the tenacity to drive it back. Until brave heroes step forward to destroy these monsters, that is the best we can do."
If a dragon is attacking Whiterun’s Western Watchtower: "There's no time to stand on ceremony, my friend. I need your help again. I want you to go with Irileth and help her fight this dragon. I haven't forgotten the service you did for me in retrieving the Dragonstone for Farengar. As a token of my esteem, I instructed Avenicci that you are now permitted to purchase property in the city."
If the player slays the dragon attacking Whiterun’s Western Watchtower: "You've done a great deed for me and my city, Dragonborn. By my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of Whiterun. It's the greatest honor that's within my power to grant. I assign you Lydia as a personal Housecarl, and this weapon from my armory to serve as your badge of office. I'll also notify my guards of your new title. Wouldn't want them to think you're part of the common rabble, now would we? We are honored to have you as Thane of our city, Dragonborn."
If asked about Dragonborns: “In the old tales, the Dragonborn heroes would use the power of their Voice to defeat the enemies of Skyrim. Wulfharth was Dragonborn. Talos, too - the founder of the Empire, back in the good old days. In the very oldest tales, back from when there still were dragons in Skyrim, the Dragonborn would slay dragons and steal their power."
If asked about the Greybeards: “The Greybeards are the masters of the Way of the Voice - of Shouting. They live up on top of the Throat of the World. I made the pilgrimage once. High Hrothgar is a very peaceful place. Very... disconnected from the troubles of this world. I wonder that the Greybeards even notice what's going on down here."
If asked about his youngest son: “He's a dark child. I don't know what to do with him. He was always a quiet lad, but lately... something has changed. He's become brooding. Violent. He won't say a word to me, but I don't know how I upset him. If you could speak to him. Draw out the truth. I would be immensely grateful."
author: Bethesda

name: Balimund
bio:
Balimund is a Nord man living in Riften. He is a blacksmith and works at the forge outside his shop the Scorched Hammer, located near the Riften Grand Plaza marketplace. He lives in the same building as his shop. He has shoulder-length dirty-blond hair and a thick mustache.
In the morning Balimund usually  starts by working on the tanning rack. He restocks his supply iron and steel ingots about once a month, and keeps them in his basement.
Balimund may ask the player to bring him 10 Fire Salts (a valuable alchemical ingredient), in order to fuel his special forge.
If the player gives Balimund 10 Fire Salts, Balimund will consider the player a friend. Another way for Balimund to consider the player a friend is for the player to invest in Balimund’s business.
If Balimund considers the player a friend, and if the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one's intention of finding a spouse), Balimund will accept a marriage proposal from the player.
Balimund buys and sells weapons, apparel, and miscellaneous items. He is also an expert Smithing trainer. 
Several years ago, Balimund adopted a Nord boy named Asbjorn Fire-Tamer from the Honorhall Orphanage, and has been teaching Asbjorn the blacksmithing profession ever since. Asbjorn has deep gratitude and admiration for Balimund.
Quotes:
"Come to see Balimund perform miracles with steel, eh?"
"What brings you to Balimund today? Repair? Purchase?"
"Nothing like the smell of a white, hot blade, eh?"
"Looking for some armor, a weapon perhaps?"
If the player asks him for a lesson in Smithing: "You wish to do what I do? Very well."
"Return anytime. You're quite welcome here."
"Smithing's been in my blood for generations. I owe my success to my forefathers and their recipe for flame. The secret is my forge. It consumes fire salts, a strange mineral that burns as hot as Red Mountain lava."
If he is asked where fire salts can be found: "A flame atronach's body might provide fire salt. They're dangerous creatures that can be summoned by wizards. Of course, it would be much easier to check with an alchemist. They occasionally have them for sale."
If the player gives him 10 Fire Salts: "Amazing! These must have been very hard to come by. You've saved my business and warmed an old smith's heart. For that, I thank you."
author: Bethesda

name: Banning
bio:
Banning is a Breton man who works as a dog breeder. He has dark brown hair. He lives outside of Markarth, in the Markarth Stables. 
His family has been training war-dogs for many years, and he has followed in their footsteps. He will offer to sell the player a dog named Vigilance for 500 gold.
Banning may also ask the player to deliver some "spiced beef" to Voada in Understone Keep in the city. Voada handles the dogs owned by the Jarl of Markarth. Banning is secretly a cannibal with the taste for human flesh. He also secretly feeds his dogs human flesh. He first acquired his taste for human flesh when he accidentally killed his friend Marex on a hunting trip. Banning will never admit to being a cannibal unless he is being conversed with inside Reachcliff Cave, which secretly houses a shrine to Namira.
Quotes:
"A war dog is good company and good protection. He'll follow you to Oblivion and back, if it comes to that."
"Need a trained war dog? Fiercest companion money can buy."
"My family has been training dogs for years. You need one out in the Reach. Don't want to be alone when some Forsworn comes swinging. I personally trained a whole litter for the Jarl. That reminds me, I was going to deliver some dog food to the Keep. Spiced beef. Their favorite."
You have to train a good war dog from a pup. Bite your arm clean off otherwise."
author: Bethesda

name: Baral Sendu
bio: Baral Sendu is a deceased Redguard man who was killed in the Stumbling Sabrecat tavern, which Baral owned before he died. This small tavern is located in the wooden stockade adjacent to the stone battlements of Fort Dunstad. Fort Dunstad is a large fort located south of Dawnstar, which was recently overrun with bandits, who killed Baral. Baral's bloodstained body is lying on his bed in the tavern's basement.
author: Bethesda

name: Barbas
bio:
Barbas is the companion and counterpart of the Daedric prince Clavicus Vile. Clavicus Vile is known as the Prince of Bargains, and is best known for granting wishes and entering into pacts with mortals which they later come to regret. Barbas is a shapeshifting Daedra who houses a significant proportion of Vile's power, and usually takes the form of a dog (currently, an Irish wolfhound). Despite being of use to Clavicus Vile, Barbas has been known to bore or annoy him, driving Clavicus to abandon Barbas in recent times.
Despite taking the form of a dog, Barbas can still speak as if he is a human. He will ask the player to take him to Haemar's Shame, a cave far to the east of Falkreath at the base of the Jerall Mountains. Barbas will warn others not to accept any deal with his master, as those always backfire immensely on the mortal.
Quotes:
"You see, my name is Barbas. And I have a problem I think you can help sort out."
"My master and I had a bit of a falling out. We got into an argument and it got rather... heated. He's kicked me out until I can find someone who can settle our disagreement. That's where you come in."
“Since he banished me, Vile's been rather weak. He can't manifest very far from one of his shrines. I know there's a cult that worships him at Haemar's Shame. We should be able to talk to him there. If this works out, I'll make sure you're rewarded. Just don't trust any offer he makes you... okay?
“My master is Clavicus Vile, Daedric prince of wishes. As you can imagine, he's quite the important person."
“A wizard named Sebastian Lort had a daughter who worshipped Hircine. When the daughter became a werewolf it drove Sebastian over the edge. He couldn't stand to see his little girl take on such a bestial form. The wizard wished for the ability to end his daughter's curse. Clavicus gave him an axe."
“I guess you could say I got on Vile’s nerves. I tend to be the voice of reason and he finds that... irksome. Vile couldn't just kill me, you see. We're technically part of each other. But he was able to banish me from his domain. Of course, because of our separation, Vile is now much weaker. I guess he figured it was a small price to pay for not having to listen to me anymore."
author: Bethesda

name: Barknar
bio:
Barknar, a Nord man, is a pilgrim who can often be found examining the etched tablets along the 7000 Steps on the path to High Hrothgar, or at the Vilemyr Inn in Ivarstead. He wears hide armor, gloves, and has reddish-brown hair.
Barknar has been spending most of his time on the path to High Hrothgar, walking the steps and meditating on the emblems. He likes to hunt, and carries a bow and a multitude of arrows with him.
Quotes:
"I like to spend time up here. Walk the Steps, meditate on the emblems. Doesn't hurt when I bag some game along the way."
author: Bethesda

name: Barknar
bio:
Barknar and his wife Alvide are currently seeking refuge in Dayspring Canyon, near Fort Dawnguard. They came here for protection from the recent vampire attacks in various parts of Skyrim. The Dawnguard are an order of vampire hunters that arose as a response to the recent vampire attacks. Fort Dawnguard is a large castle southeast of Riften which serves as the Dawnguard's base of operations. The castle is hidden deep in Dayspring Canyon, within the Velothi Mountains at the southeastern tip of Skyrim.
The leader of the Dawnguard is a stoic Redguard man named Irsan. Unfortunately, Isran won't let Barknar and the other refugees inside the walls of their castle. Barknar and Alvide now live in a camp in the canyon, just outside castle walls. An old man named Sern and a Redguard woman named Jayri are friendly fellow refugees who also live in this camp.
Barknar and his wife are Nords. Barknar wears standard clothing, boots, and typically wears a cowl over his head. His wife is slightly annoyed with him because he had assured her that they would be allowed to take refuge within the castle itself, as opposed to having to camp outside the castle walls. Barknar spends much of his time chopping wood, cooking, or wandering in the forested area around the camp.
Quotes:
"I've no love for living out of a tent, but I'll take that over being ripped apart."
"Why can't they just let us in? We won't get in the way!"
"It looks like this is as close as we're going to get being safe from the vampires."
"I hope Alvide doesn't think less of me, but I can't protect her on my own. We're safer here."
author: Bethesda

name: Bashnag
bio:
Bashnag, an Orc man, is spellsword who leads the group of necromancers inside Southfringe Sanctum.
The mages found in the sanctum are a group of necromancers that practice their school of magic in hiding. Bashnag recently put a curse on a conjurer named Selveni Nethri (a Dunmer woman) so that she could not cast any spells, and threw her in the spider's pit.
In combat, Bashnag will summon Frost Atronachs and use Frost and Shock spells. When out of Magicka, he will attack using his staff and mace. He wears Ancient Nord Armor.
author: Bethesda

name: Bassianus Axius
bio:
Bassianus Axius is a Nord man who lives in Ivarstead. He is romantically interested in a young woman named Fastred. Fastred's father is Jofthor and her mother is Boti. Bassianus wears a belted tunic and a pair of boots. He has long red hair and a goatee.
Bassianus tends to act somewhat arrogant and snarky. He appears to be tired of his daily life in Ivarstead.
He lives with his friend Klimmek at Klimmek’s house in Ivarstead. Bassianus is eager to leave his boring life in Ivarstead, but his love interest Fastred is the only thing keeping him from leaving the village to live in Riften. Bassianus wants Fastred to move to Riften with him, but is afraid of the potential wrath of Fastred's father that might result from eloping with her. He often spends his time in the Vilemyr Inn drinking and talking to Wilhelm, the innkeeper.
Quotes:
"You don't look like a pilgrim. Why bother visiting Ivarstead?"
"Hmm? What do you want?"
"Hmph. What a boring conversation."
If asked about High Hrothgar: "Klimmek brings food supplies up to them once every few weeks when the weather permits it. Other than that, they seem like a quiet lot. Don't really know too much about them."
author: Bethesda

name: Batum gra-Bar
bio: Batum gra-Bar, an Orc woman, was a Hunter of Hircine sent to kill a werewolf named Sinding. Batum was recently killed by Sinding within Bloated Man's Grotto. Batum's corpse can be found inside Bloated Man's Grotto, next to J'Kier, a dying Khajiit man.
author: Bethesda

name: Beautiful Barbarian
bio:
Beautiful Barbarian is a Nord. She resides in the town of Ivarstead.
Quotes:
"I'm dying for a rest. I swear, I could lie down right now, and just sleep forever."
author: Bethesda

name: Beem-Ja
bio:
Beem-Ja is a mage who travels with his fellow companion, a young Redguard woman named Salma. He is an Argonian.
Through Salma, Beem-Ja wants to enlist a passing adventurer's help in order to find Gathrik's tomb within the ancient Nordic ruin of Ironbind Barrow, in the mountains west of Mount Anthor.
Quotes:
“Don't rush ahead. This is a trap if I ever saw one."
"Speak with Miss Salma, if you wish to speak."
"I admit, there is strength in numbers. Perhaps between us..."
"Not now. Stay alert."
"This is no time for idle talk."
"We're in this together. Stay close."
author: Bethesda

name: Beirand
bio:
Beirand, a Nord man, is a blacksmith living in Solitude. He runs the Solitude Blacksmith business, near Castle Dour. Beirand’s wife is a Redguard woman named Sayma, who owns the Bits and Pieces general store. Beirand and Sayama have a young son named Kayd. Beirand is bald-headed, and is beard is reddish-brown.
Beirand’s job is to make weapons and armor for the Imperial soldiers stationed in Solitude. He's a "king's man at heart", but doesn't especially like or dislike the Imperials. His loyalty lies with Solitude, and with Jarl Elisif (now that Elisif’s husband, High King Torygg, has been killed).
When asked why he doesn't join the war, he will reply that it is partially because his wife Sayma would be angry at him, and because he couldn't leave his son Kayd. Beirand will say that fighting his wife about it would be tougher than fighting any war.
If Beirand is told that the player has recently joined the Imperial Legion, he will be obliged to offer player a set of armor for free. He will give the player the choice between the three types of Imperial armor: light, medium, or heavy.
If the Stormcloaks take control of Solitude, Beirand will make armor for the Stormcloaks. 
Beirand has a smithing apprentice, a young Nord named Heimvar. Beirand likes to joke that his young son Kayd could work the forge better than Heimvar can. Despite this, Beirand seems to enjoy training Heimvar in smithing and respects his work ethic.
Quotes:
“Making armor for the Imperials takes up almost all my time these days. The men training here in Solitude and the troops out in the field, they all need weapons and armor. You should look into joining. They could use every hand they can get."
“To be honest, no, I’m not particularly dedicated to the Empire. But High King Torygg supported them, and now her lady Elisif has thrown in with them. You could say I'm a King's man at heart. Hmph. I guess that's 'Jarl's man' now. My loyalty lies with Solitude. So where Jarl Elisif leads, I follow."
“Sayma would have my hide if I even suggested I might step foot on a battlefield. You think Stormcloaks and Legionnaires are dangerous? Ha!"
"Return any time you need arms or armor. My forge never rests."
"Seems there is no end to the need of the Imperials... but what can I help you with?"
"Keep safe. And always wear your armor."
"I've got weapons for givin', and armor for gettin'!"
"Arms and armor! Forged by a master craftsman!"
"I got some fine armor, if you're lookin'."
"It's good to be away from the forge for a bit."
"Wanderer like you must have plenty of tales to tell. But I'm afraid I'm too busy to hear 'em."
If the Stormcloaks have captured Solitude: "When the Stormcloaks took Solitude I thought for sure things would slow down, but they keep me just as busy as the Imperials did."
author: Bethesda

name: Beitild
bio:
Beitild, a Nord woman, lives in Dawnstar. She owns and manages Iron-Breaker Mine.
Beitild has shoulder-length brown hair. She usually wears a set of miner's clothes and boots, and keeps her mining pickaxe close-at-hand.
Beitild and her husband Leigelf have recently separated, and they now run competing mining operations.
Iron-Breaker Mine is a small iron mine located at the base of the snowy cliffs that loom over the southeastern corner of Dawnstar. The mine is just east of the White Hall, the jarl's longhouse. Beitild works hard to make sure Iron-Breaker Mine yields more profit than her husband's Quicksilver Mine. Beitild often has to motivate her unenthusiastic employees to work harder, via threatening their jobs.
Beitild will pay a small amount of gold for every chunk of iron ore brought to her.
Despite Beitild's animosity towards Leigelf, she will still be sad if he dies.
Dawnstar is the capital of The Pale, near the center of Skyrim's northern coastline with the Sea of Ghosts. Dawnstar is known for its rich mines, harbor, and fishing. Dawnstar is one of the colder settlements in Skyrim, and resides in almost perpetual snow and ice.
Beitild's house is on the north side of town, near Dawnstar's inlet harbor. Silus Vesuius' house and Dawnstar's small lighthouse are close to her house.
Quotes:
“I own Iron-Breaker Mine. We make twice as much coin as those horkers over in Quicksilver Mine, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise. I pay a good wage for any iron ore you dig up, if you're looking for work."
"Iron-Breaker Mine is three times the worth of that Quicksilver Mine and its fat-head owner."
"My miners are as dumb as rocks are grey."
"Everyone here is having nightmares. I have miners tripping over their own feet from lack of sleep. I heard there was a Priest of Mara who was supposed to be looking into it. We'll see if anything comes of that."
When addressing her workers: "Keep at it. We need to work twice as hard now that fat-headed Leigelf has declared war! He's not my husband anymore, he’s the enemy, and we are going to crush him. Work hard, now! The pride of Iron-Breaker Mine is on the line."
If her husband Leigelf dies: "My husband Leigelf is dead. I... I never thought I would miss that oaf so much."
author: Bethesda

name: Belchimac
bio:
Belchimac is a Breton man who lives in Karthwasten, a small mining village in The Reach. He has shoulder-length light brown hair. A Breton man named Ainethatch is the owner and leader of Karthwasten. Belchimac works as a miner, and resides in the Karthwasten Miner's Barracks.  He complains a lot, mostly about the better of the town's 2 silver mines (Sanuarach Mine) being closed. Sanuarach Mine is currently closed due to being occupied by a group of mercenaries hired by the Silver Blood family. Karthwasten's other silver mine, Fenn's Gulch Mine, has much fewer veins of silver ore. If Sanuarach Mine reopens, Belchimac will shift the subject of his complaining to how much work he has to do now.
Quotes:
"You want something?"
"Damn Nords. Always getting in the way of us honest folk."
"Maybe I will join the Forsworn. What do you think about that?"
"I don't like bunking with Orcs. It's not... clean."
"The good mine is closed and the other mine has no ore. Gods have cursed me."
“The Divines have abandoned us."
author: Bethesda

name: Belethor
bio:
Belethor is a Breton man who owns the Belethor's General Goods store in Whiterun. As a general merchant, he buys and sells almost everything. His store is located next to the Arcadia’s Cauldron alchemy shop, and is on the opposite side of the market square from the Bannered Mare inn.
Belethor will occasionally jokingly remark that he would sell his sister for gold, if he had one, and that he would be willing to buy any customers' relatives, should they have any. His reputation within Whiterun is far from sparkling, as the Whiterun Guards refer to him as a "sleazy little man." Unlike most Bretons, he does not have a serious personality. He is constantly making puns and is very sarcastic, especially when he's asked why he moved to Skyrim, or whether or not the Skyrim Civil War has been hard on the city's merchants.
When conversed with, he may speak of the current trading situation in the Whiterun region. Because of the dragon attacks in Helgen, there is a lack of goods and products around the city, which results in higher prices. Belethor has employed the help of a young Nord man named Sigurd to do menial tasks around the shop for him. Belethor and Sigurd live in separate rooms on the second floor of the store building.
If the player invests in Belethor’s business, he will consider the player to be his friend.
Quotes:
"Everything's for sale, my friend. Everything. If I had a sister, I'd sell her in a second."
"I'd even buy one of your relatives, if you're looking to sell! Ha ha ha... That's a little joke."
"I know what you're thinking: 'This Belethor, how could he part with such magnificent treasures?'"
"I can tell you're a discriminating customer. Maybe a wealthy one too?"
"Imperials, Stormcloaks... I don't care who's in charge around here. I just want to make money!"
"Everything's for sale, my friend! You need visit no other shops today!"
"I assure you, I'm prepared to make any deal."
"Please, do look around. I'm sure I have something you'll want."
"Remember, I'll give you the best deals, or die trying."
author: Bethesda

name: Beleval
bio:
Beleval, a Bosmer woman, is a vampire hunter and member of the Dawnguard.  She is the only elf (Bosmer, Dunmer, or Altmer) member of the Dawnguard, unless the player is also an elf. She has shoulder-length red hair and brownish-red eyes. She is a bit taller than the average Bosmer, who are typically quite short.
Fort Dawnguard is a large fort southeast of Riften which serves as the Dawnguard's base of operations. The fort is home to an order of vampire hunters who guard Skyrim from vampires (especially those of the Volkihar clan). The fort is hidden deep within the Velothi Mountains at the southeastern tip of The Rift (and of Skyrim), and can only be reached via Dayspring Canyon.
A Redguard man named Isran is the leader of the Dawnguard. Isran is stoic, uncompromising, and is always deadly serious. Isran probably hates vampires more than anyone else does, and many have deemed his methods to be extreme.
Beleval and Ingjard (a Nord woman) are two of the newest members of the Dawnguard. Sorine Jurard and Gunmar joined shortly before Beleval and Ingjard joined. Sorine is a Breton woman who specializes who in the art of crafting crossbows and crossbow bolts, heavily influenced by the methods of the ancient Dwemer. Gunmar is a Nord man who serves as the Dawnguard's main blacksmith, and who also trains and armors trolls for use in fighting vampires. The player joined shortly before Sorine and Gunmar joined, and helped convince them to join.
Beleval is willing to follow the player on adventures across Skyrim. She will also be open to being hired as the steward of one of the player's homesteaded properties, if asked.
Beleval's default attire is a brown set of Dawnguard heavy armor. She only puts on her helmet if battle is imminent. When it comes to fighting, her default melee weapon is a Dawnguard war axe, and her default ranged weapon is a crossbow supplemented with a supply of steel bolts. During combat, she will switch between the war axe and the crossbow, depending on the situation. If she runs out of crossbow bolts, she may switch to her hunting bow and her supply of iron arrows. She will be willing to use other melee weapons instead of her Dawnguard war axe if she finds or is given a weapon of higher quality.
Beleval spends a fair amount of time practicing with her crossbow on dummy targets within Fort Dawnguard, often alongside Ingjard.
Quotes:
Upon first meeting the player, if the player is not an elf: "Seems that I'm the only of my kind here. Suppose I shouldn't be surprised. Still, it's my duty to help protect Skyrim as much as any Nord's, don't you think?"
Upon first meeting the player, if the player is an elf: "Not a lot of our kind here, I see. Suppose I shouldn't be surprised. Still, those of us here have as much of an obligation to protect Skyrim as any other, wouldn't you agree?"
If asked why she joined the Dawnguard: "Isran is the only one trying to do something about these vampires. I don't much like him, but I can't allow the people of Skyrim to be preyed upon by those monsters."
author: Bethesda

name: Belrand
bio:
Belrand, a Nord man, is a mercenary by profession. He can often be found in the Winking Skeever, a popular tavern/inn in Solitude. He has long white hair, though the top of his head is bald. His default apparel is a set of iron armor, and he carries an iron sword.
The player can hire Belrand’s mercenary services for 500 gold, after which he will follow the player on adventures across Skyrim. After traveling with the player for some time, if the player is wearing the Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse), Belrand will accept a marriage proposal from the player. If Belrand and the player get married, Belrand will open up a general goods shop to provide some extra income for himself and his new spouse. Belrand will subsequently give his spouse 100 gold daily from the store’s profits.
As a Nord, he is very proud of his heritage, will express amazement at the craftsmanship of Nordic Tombs, and will even go as far as suggesting to the player that a few treasures should be left behind as a sign of respect. He also has some knowledge of the ancient Dwemer (also called the Dwarves), though he considers the ancient Nords to be the superior civilization since they outlasted the Dwemer despite the advanced technology and culture of the Dwemer. He sometimes gets nervous around Dwemer ruins, stating that they make him uneasy. Belrand has a tendency to provide commentary on most locations, particularly their architecture and historical significance.
Belrand is a spellsword that fights best alongside magic users and archers. He is well known for his stalwart resilience due to both his usage of Restoration healing spells, and his natural sturdiness. He has high skill with Destruction magic, one-handed melee weapons, and light armor usage. He is also moderately skilled with archery and two-handed melee weapons. At the initiation of combat he often summons a familiar and casts Oakflesh or Stoneflesh spells on himself to boost his defenses, despite not being generally skilled with Alteration or Conjuration.
Quotes:
"Versatility is the key to survival. Hire me, and you'll well-prepared to face threats both magical and mundane."
"By blade or by spell, if you want it dead, I'll make it dead. All you need to do is pay my fee."
"I fight with both blade and spell. You might say I'm equipped to handle nearly any threat. So, shall we talk price?"
"Sure, you can hire a swordsman or a spellcaster to fight at your side, but why not get both for the price of one?"
"The blade can be as lethal as the spell, but stronger still is the one who wields both!"
"What dangers and wonders shall we discover in the frozen wastes? I can hardly wait to find out!”
"Onward to our next adventure!"
author: Bethesda

name: Belyn Hlaalu
bio:
Belyn Hlaalu, a Dunmer man, is a farmer who lives in his house in Gray Quarter district of Windhelm. He owns Hlaalu Farm, located just outside the city on the other side of the River Yogrim, shortly before it empties out into the Sea of Ghosts. Belyn is a descendant of House Hlaalu, as his name would suggest.
Regarding the Dunmer segregation in Windhelm, he mentions that many of his kin complain too much about the way they are treated. In his opinion, complaining does little good. He is a firm proponent of hard work, and believes it's the only way to win the respect of the local Nords.
He occasionally converses with his employee, an older Nord woman named Adisla, about various topics, one of which is Captain Lonely-Gale. Belyn seems to have a strange obsession with Captain Lonely-Gale and his past, for unknown reasons. Belyn is rather gruff, a harsh master, and treats his employee Adisla with little respect.
Belyn will offer to pay the player for any bundles of wheat they help to harvest from his farm. 
Quotes:
“Adisla, make sure the back fence is repaired. I swear I saw some skeevers in nibbling the leaves yesterday."
“Adisla, the way you burn through all that wood to keep the cabin toasty, the skeever might mistake this place for Elsweyr. You need to remember that there's a war on, and firewood isn't cheap these days."
"I'm proud of my farm. It takes no small effort to grow crops in this part of Skyrim."
"The best way for us to win the Nords' respect is through hard work."
"Too many dark elves in Windhelm complain about the way we're treated. What good does complaining do?"
author: Bethesda

name: Bendt
bio:
Bendt is an elderly chef at the Bards College in the city of Solitude.
Bendt is the chef for the College, preparing and serving the food for the bards at regular intervals. His kitchen is in the basement of the Bards College building.
He is a rather grumpy individual and not usually in high spirits. The exception to this is when he gives out free candy to those attending the Burning of King Olaf festival.
Quotes:
"Meals are served to bards at designated times. Find an inn if you want to make requests."
"You've found the Bards College kitchen. Congratulations."
"You look a little sturdier than most of the popinjays around here."
During the Burning of King Olaf festival: "You might as well have some sweets. I made them for the festival after all."
author: Bethesda

name: Benkum
bio:
Benkum is a Nord sailor who is met at the Water Stone along with his fellow shipmates Hjalfar, Liesl, and Palevius Lex.
He is indoctrinated with his shipmates under Miraak's control, until the Stone is freed from the Dragon Priest's influence.
Once he and his shipmates are freed from Miraak's influence, they walk to the shore to await their ship. After the quest, they may be encountered on the west shore near the water stone, still waiting for their ship to arrive.
author: Bethesda

name: Benkum
bio:
Benkum, a Nord man, is the one responsible for managing and keeping order in the Windhelm Pit, although he is not completely honest and he is willing to take bribes.
Quotes:
"Hello, hello, hello. Interested in fighting in the Pit? The rules are strict, but if I don't see it, it didn't happen, know what I mean?"
"It's very important to Huki that all the battles are fair. What's more important to me is that my pay is fair."
"Prove your valor in the Pit! If you haven't got any valor, prove your pocketbook!"
author: Bethesda

name: Benor
bio:
Benor is a Nord man who lives in Morthal. He applied for guard duty once, but for unknown reasons he has not been accepted. He now helps the Morthal guards in any way he can. He has brown hair and a beard.
Benor is friends with a Nord man named Gorm, who serves as Jarl Idgrod Ravencrone's housecarl. Both Benor and Gorm dislike Jarl Idgrod and are considering plans to overthrow her. He also dislikes Hroggar, because Hroggar is suspected of burning down his own house with his wife and child still inside in order to be with another woman named Alva. Despite being attracted to a local woman named Alva, Benor still rejects Alva’s sexual advances because he doesn’t feel comfortable cuckholding another man.
Benor can often be found hanging around the Morthal Guardhouse. He often visits the Moorside Inn at night.
Benor is distrustful of magic and is not happy about Jarl Idgrod allowing the Redguard mage Falion to live in Morthal. This is one of the primary reasons Benor dislikes Jarl Idgrod.
When encountered by the player, Benor will want to demonstrate his fighting abilities, as he claims to be the best brawler in Morthal. If he is beaten in a brawl, he will give the player 100 gold and will subsequently be willing to follow the player on adventures across Skyrim. After traveling with the player for some time, Benor will accept a marriage proposal from the player if the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse).
Benor strongest skills are the use of heavy armor and two-handed weaponry. He is also somewhat proficient in archery. His physical stamina is relatively low for a warrior. Despite this, he is proficient in the use of a shield and can survive in a fight fairly well.
Quotes:
"I'm the best warrior in Morthal, and that's no boast."
"Morthal used to be a quiet place. But then, the world used to make sense."
"I figure the guards could always use some help, so I keep my eyes open."
"Been hoping they'd make me a guard, but not yet. Still, I'll help them out if I can."
"The Jarl does little to protect us these days."
"You ask me, we'd be better off without that wizard in town."
"This isn't the time or place for magic, or whatever it is Falion does."
“I won't cuckhold another man, even a murderer like Hroggar."
If the player defeats him in a brawl: "You're a real fighter. I like that. You ever need my steel by your side, you just ask."
author: Bethesda

name: Bergritte Battle-Born
bio:
Bergritte Battle-Born is an elderly Nord woman who resides in Whiterun.
She is a member of the Battle-Born clan and is married to Olfrid, the patriarch of the clan. Alfhild is Bergritte's daughter. Alfhild is married to Idolaf. Lars is Idolaf and Alfhild’s son, and Bergritte’s grandson. 
As family elder, Bergritte lives a relatively anonymous existence in Whiterun. Her daughter Alfhild reads to her sometimes during the evening. 
Bergritte’s clan is currently in a heated feud with the Gray-Mane clan, another prominent family in Whiterun.
Quote:
"There's a rift here in Skyrim, and can't neither magic nor the passin' of time make it right."
"Lars, dear, why don't you go outside and play? It's a beautiful day."
"Can you believe those pathetic Gray-Manes still show their faces in public?"
"There was love between our families. For generations. Now, there is only enmity."
If the Stormcloaks have taken control of Whiterun: "It's a miracle these Stormcloaks haven't robbed us blind yet. I'm sure it's only a matter of time."
author: Bethesda

name: Bersi Honey-Hand
bio:
Bersi Honey-Hand, a Nord man, is the proprietor of The Pawned Prawn, a general goods store in Riften. He is known for being charitable, and his wife Drifa often mentions that she wishes he would be more concerned with his own needs than the needs of others. Bersi and his wife live in the back of the store building. Bersi wears a set of merchant clothes along with a pair of boots. He is bald, but his beard is a reddish color.
A former sailor, Bersi used to own a fishing boat, which he named the Brawny Prawn. After selling his boat, he named his shop to commemorate his former life. 
Like many other citizens of Riften, Bersi is concerned about the rampant corruption within the city. Unlike most, he believes in improving the morality of the citizens through worship at the Temple of Mara. This has earned him the ridicule of many other citizens, who are convinced that the corruption runs too deep to be removed with prayers.
Bersi currently owes a 100 gold debt to Brynjolf and the Thieves Guild. Bersi is fond of a valuable Dwemer urn that he keeps in his shop.
Quotes: 
If in the Pawned Prawn: "Welcome to the Pawned Prawn. Come on in, take a look around. What can I do for you?"
If in the Pawned Prawn: "Pickings may be a bit slim today, but if you see anything you like I'll make you a good deal."
If not in the Pawned Prawn: "If you're looking for anything to sell for a fair price, I run the Pawned Prawn over by the market."
After asked about the name of his shop: “Catchy, isn’t it? In my youth I was a fisherman... I had a beautiful ship named ‘The Brawny Prawn’. But the years have a way of creeping up on you. I ended up selling that ship to open this place. Seemed only fitting to name it after her. Well, changed it a bit I suppose. If I had been smarter, I would have kept my boat. Coming to this city was a big mistake."
“This city is corrupt. Rotten to the core. No one cares about anything except themselves and how much coin they can make off the misery of others."
“The authorities are all dirty. Every one of them. The only way to get things done in this city is to keep your head down and pay off the right people."
If asked about the Thieves Guild: “They used to be pretty feared around here. I mean, you'd whisper the name and it'd send chills down your spine. Now, they're nothing more than ruffians and thugs trying to pry a few extra coin from honest people. All it would take is a small force of guard to go into the Ratway and flush them out."
If asked about the Ratway: “The Ratway is the name for the old sewers that run under the city. It used to be a huge system hundreds of years ago but it fell into decay, just like the rest of Riften. The Guild stocks the place full of thugs that aren't good enough to join, so watch yourself if you venture down there."
If asked about the Jarl of Riften: "Laila is as clueless as she is stupid. No. If anything's to be done about this, we have to deal with it ourselves."
If the player threatens to destroy his Dwemer urn: "Please, I don't have anything to pay you with! Don't destroy my urn!"
author: Bethesda

name: Betrid Silver-Blood
bio:
Betrid Silver-Blood is a Nord woman who lives in Markarth, and is the wife to Thonar Silver-Blood. She has long blonde hair. Betrid is proud and will brag about her husband's importance. Betrid has no qualms about admitting hat she married Thonar for his money. Betrid also has a tendency to flaunt the vast property and influence the Silver-Blood family holds in The Reach.
Betrid can usually be seen reading books in the Treasury House. She will occasionally brag about the Silver-Blood family’s power and influence when conversing with others.
When she was younger, Betrid worked in the Temple of Dibella, under the priestess Hamal.
Quotes:
“We're the only family worth knowing in Markarth. We own everything in this city, even the jail.
"I'm married to Thonar Silver-Blood. Keep that in mind when you're speaking to me."
“My husband Thonar handles all our family's business. He's an important man."
"I married Thonar for the money, and I'm not the least bit ashamed to admit it."
“Thonar is the real head of this family. He may not be the eldest, but all the work that keeps us respected is handled by my Thonar."
"Oh dear, whatever is a girl to do with such fearful brutes about her?"
When speaking to someone she dislikes: "Every time I see you, I imagine a Saber Cat, closing its claws around your face."
author: Bethesda

name: Big Laborer
bio:
Big Laborer is a Nord man who works at Katla's Farm, near Solitude.
Quotes:
"Would it kill you to let a man go about his business in peace? Really, the nerve..."
author: Bethesda

name: Birna
bio:
Birna, a Nord woman, owns a general goods store called Birna's Oddments in Winterhold. She has blue eyes and shoulder-length blonde hair. Her brother is Ranmir, whom she is constantly arguing with. One of her main customers is Thaena, who is the wife and housecarl of Jarl Korir. Thaena isn’t the friendliest person, but at least she gives provides Birna with business.
Birna may offer to sell the Coral Dragon Claw to the player for 50 gold. Birna has heard that this claw is somehow associated with a hidden treasure in the ancient Nordic tomb known as Yngol Barrow, which is located east of Windhelm on the opposite side of the River Yogrim. Birna has no intentions of venturing through a remote ancient crypt, so she is trying to sell this claw since she has no use for it.
Her brother Ranmir is constantly at the Frozen Hearth inn in Winterhold, drinking excessively in an attempt to forget about his missing lover, a woman named Isabelle Rolaine. Birna is always angry with him because she has to pay for his drinking, and is also worried that he’s going to drink himself to death.
Quotes:
"I'll sell just about anything, if it's worth my time. Keep that in mind, will you?"
If asked why she started her business in Winterhold: “I didn’t set up shop here by choice, I can tell you that. Options were in short supply. Ranmir and I grew up here, and nearly any money I make, he drinks away. Without the coin to pack up and leave, I decided to take to trading."
If asked if she gets a lot of business: “I’m sure you have noticed that the town isn't exactly overflowing with people. So I'll sell whatever I can. If it's worth putting a price on, you can bet I'll do it. I've made a few bad deals. Been burned a few times. But mostly, I come out on top."
“I’m trying to keep my only brother from drinking himself to death."
"I do what's necessary so we can get by. Have to, since I can't count on my brother for anything."
"You looking for Ranmir? He's either passed out in bed, or working on winding up that way."
"Ranmir's a good for nothing drunk. We'd've lost the house by now if it were up to him."
If the player buys the Coral Dragon Claw from her: “Here you go. You get killed on account of this thing, it's not my fault. Got it? But, I suppose, if it does actually turn out to be worth something, let me know, will you?"
If the player offers to invest in her business: "You want to give me money? Just like that? Fine, but I intend to earn that investment. I don't need handouts."
If the player assists Ranmir in overcoming his drinking problem: "Things are easier now that I don't have to worry about Ranmir anymore. I still can't believe you were able to help him pull himself together. Without all our money going to drink, I can afford to expand my selection a bit."
author: Bethesda

name: Bjartur
bio:
Bjartur is a Nord woman who is a prisoner in Solitude. She is locked up inside the Castle Dour Dungeon for publicly voicing support for the Stormcloaks in their war against the Imperial Legion. She often yells at the jailer, a large Redguard man named Ahtar who also serves as the city’s executioner.
Quotes:
"You here for my next interrogation? I got nothing but time."
"It’s only a matter of time before Ahtar's blade finds my neck."
author: Bethesda

name: Bjorlam
bio:
Bjorlam, a Nord man, is carriage driver who can often be found near the stables outside the gates of Whiterun. He has blond hair and a goatee. He offers carriage rides to any of the other 8 Hold capital cities. These 8 cities are Falkreath, Morthal, Markarth, Solitude, Dawnstar, Windhelm, Winterhold, and Riften. He charges anywhere from 20 to 50 gold for the trip, depending on the destination's distance from Whiterun.
Once the traveler boards his carriage, Bjorlam often shares information about the traveler’s destination, or comments on the weather.
Quotes:
"Need a ride?"
"Where do you want to go?"
"You ever met one of them cats? Khajiit I think they call themselves. Heard there's whole countries of them down south."
If asked about Whiterun: “The Companions make their home here in Whiterun. Their mead hall, Jorrvaskr, is the oldest building in the city. Oh, and there's a nasty feud between two families called the Gray-Manes and Battle-Borns. You'll want to be careful there. The rest you can find out by asking the townsfolk. I'd start with the barkeep at the Bannered Mare, or the castle steward."
If traveling to Markarth: "Ever been to Markarth? Some say it was built by the dwarves. I don't believe a word of it, though."
If traveling to Riften: "If you've never been to Riften, be sure and visit the Black-Briar Meadery. A few mugs of that and you'll forget all your troubles."
When traveling to Windhelm: "Ever been to Windhelm? Oldest city in Skyrim, by some accounts. They say the big old palace there was built by Ysgramor himself."
"Better bundle up. This may keep us for a while."
If it’s not currently raining: "Nice weather for a ride. Hope it lasts."
If it’s currently raining: "Why is it always raining?"
author: Bethesda

name: Bjornolfr
bio:
Bjornolfr is a deceased Nord man whose corpse can be found in the tunnel beneath Hrodulf's house, located near the southwestern tip of the island of Solstheim.
Bjornolfr came to Solstheim from Solitude, searching for his lover (a man named Hrodulf) after receiving some bizarre correspondence from him. Hrodulf's Journal, found inside the house, shows the decay of Hrodulf's state of mind. Hrodulf had been sleeping in the basement of the house, due to an obsession with the Dwemer workings beneath it. Hrodulf's mad ramblings and long absence ended up bringing Bjornofr to the house to find him.
Bjornolfr's body is located in the Dwemer tunnel below the house, carrying a bloodstained letter from Hrodulf. After finding Hrodulf's dead body, Bjornolfr took his own life with a dagger.
author: Bethesda

name: Black-Briar Mercenary
bio:
They are one of three mercenaries guarding the exterior around Black-Briar Lodge. This lodge is located near the base of the Velothi Mountains at the eastern edge of the Rift, a fair distance east of the city of Riften. 
These mercenaries all work for Maven Black-Briar, the ruthless matriarch of the most influential family in Riften. Maven has two adult sons named Hemming and Sibbi, and a young adult daughter named Ingun, and they all live in Riften. Maven's prized horse, a white stallion named Frost, is kept in the stables outside the lodge. These mercenaries have been instructed by Maven to keep a watchful guard over Frost, since he is a likely target for horse thieves.
Four additional mercenaries are guarding the interior of the lodge. Black-Briar mercenaries all wear steel plate armor and light boots. This particular mercenary is a proficient archer who carries a high-quality bow and arrows, while all the other Black-Briar mercenaries who guard the lodge wield melee weapons. All the Black-Briar mercenaries have a key to the lodge. Only Maven Black-Briar, Maven's children, and Black-Briar mercenaries are permitted at the lodge. If a mercenary sees an intruder, they will attack and attempt to kill them.
author: Bethesda

name: Black-Briar Mercenary
bio:
They are one of three mercenaries guarding the exterior around Black-Briar Lodge. This lodge is located near the base of the Velothi Mountains at the eastern edge of the Rift, a fair distance east of the city of Riften. 
These mercenaries all work for Maven Black-Briar, the ruthless matriarch of the most influential family in Riften. Maven has two adult sons named Hemming and Sibbi, and a young adult daughter named Ingun, and they all live in Riften. Maven's prized horse, a white stallion named Frost, is kept in the stables outside the lodge. These mercenaries have been instructed by Maven to keep a watchful guard over Frost, since he is a likely target for horse thieves.
Four additional mercenaries are guarding the interior of the lodge. Black-Briar mercenaries all wear steel plate armor and light boots, and wield high-quality melee weapons (except one of the two other mercenaries stationed outside, who is an archer). All the Black-Briar mercenaries have a key to the lodge. Only Maven Black-Briar, Maven's children, and Black-Briar mercenaries are permitted at the lodge. If a mercenary sees an intruder, they will attack and attempt to kill them.
author: Bethesda

name: Black-Briar Mercenary
bio:
They are one of four mercenaries guarding the interior of Black-Briar Lodge. This lodge is located near the base of the Velothi Mountains at the eastern edge of the Rift, a fair distance east of the city of Riften. 
These mercenaries all work for Maven Black-Briar, the ruthless matriarch of the most influential family in Riften. Maven has two adult sons named Hemming and Sibbi, and a young adult daughter named Ingun, all of whom live in Riften. Maven's prized horse, a white stallion named Frost, is kept in the stables outside the lodge.
Three additional mercenaries are guarding the exterior of the lodge. Black-Briar mercenaries all wear steel plate armor and light boots, and wield high-quality melee weapons (except one of the mercenaries stationed outside, who is an archer). All the Black-Briar mercenaries have a key to the lodge. Only Maven Black-Briar, Maven's children, and Black-Briar mercenaries are permitted at the lodge. If a mercenary sees an intruder, they will attack and attempt to kill them.
author: Bethesda

name: Blaise
bio:
Blaise is an orphaned Breton child who lives in the stables near Katla's farm.  He works as a stable boy to earn his keep.
Blaise's parents were members of the Imperial Legion, but both were killed in an ambush by Stormcloak rebels during the currently ongoing Skyrim civil war. After Blaise's parents were killed, a woman named Katla took him in and put him to work as her stable boy. While Katla isn't actively cruel to Blaise, she is neglectful, and Blaise has to sleep on a hay pile in the stables with the animals. Katla lives with her husband Snilling and son Knud. Knud is around the same age as Blaise, and is somewhat spoiled.
The stables that service Solitude (the capital city of Skyrim) are very close to Katla's farm. These stables are run by a man named Geimund, who lives with his wife Fridrika and adult son Horm.
Blaise has to work hard to earn his keep, and he is discouraged about his lonely life.
Blaise would love to be adopted.
Quotes:
"You probably want someone else. I'm just the stable boy."
"I hate the farm. Everyone feels sorry for me, so they don't treat me too bad, but..."
"Both my parents were in the Legion. There was... an ambush. Katla said she could feed me if I made myself useful. I take care of the animals, run errands, that kind of thing. I guess it could be worse. But... I'm sick of sleeping outside with the horses. I want a real home, real parents. Not... this."
"Talk to Geimund if you want a horse, or Katla if you're looking for work. I can't help you."
"I take care of the horses. And the goats. And the chickens. And the garden."
If someone offers to adopt him: "Really? You mean it? Wow, thanks! I promise, I won't be any trouble at all! Just... just let me get my things and say goodbye to everyone. I'll meet you at home. Thanks! Thanks again!"
author: Bethesda

name: Blasphemous Priest
bio:
The Blasphemous Priest is a Nord man who is currently staying at the Temple of Kynareth in Whiterun.
He will pay a sum of gold to the player to assassinate a person he wants dead, then wander through the temple until the target has been killed.
author: Bethesda

name: Blood Horker
bio:
Blood Horkers a members of a group of bandits.
This bandit group was formed by a Redguard named Haldyn, who is a powerful mage. In group's early days, Haldyn sent his men to scout the many hidden islands and forgotten coves throughout the Sea of Ghosts for potential outpost locations, in order to hide any treasure they pillaged. The Blood Horkers are now based on the island of Japhet's Folly, off the northeastern coast of Skyrim.
If a Blood Horker spots anyone not affiliated with their bantit group, they will immediately become hostile and attack.
author: Bethesda

name: Bodil
bio:
Bodil lives in Dawnstar. She works as a miner at Iron-Breaker Mine.
Bodil is a tall Nord woman with blue eyes and blonde hair. She typically wears thin ragged clothing and a pair of miner boots. She usually has her mining pickaxe either in her hands, or fastened to her hip.
Dawnstar is the capital of The Pale, near the center of Skyrim's northern coastline with the Sea of Ghosts. Dawnstar is known for its rich mines, harbor, and fishing. Dawnstar is one of the colder settlements in Skyrim, and resides in almost perpetual snow and ice.
Bodil's boss is a stern and demanding woman named Beitild, who runs the Iron-Breaker Mine operation. Beitild recently separted from her husband Leigelf, who now runs the competing Quicksilver Mine operation on the other end of Dawnstar.
While Iron-Breaker Mine is not particularly large, it produces a lot of iron ore and is a boon to the local economy. This mine is located at the base of the snowy cliffs that loom over the southeastern corner of Dawnstar. The mine is just east of the White Hall, the jarl's longhouse.
Bodil and a man named Gjak are the hardest workers at Iron-Breaker mine. A woman named Irgnir and a man named Karl also work at the mine. Karl often drinks on the job, but still puts in long hours. Irgnir and Karl have been particularly affected by the mysterious nightmares that the residents of Dawnstar have been experiencing recently.
At night, Bodil sleeps in a bedroll inside the mine. She enjoys working hard and tends to keep to herself.
Quotes:
"Here to dig. That's all."
"Dawnstar's got its problems, but as long as the ore is good, I'll stay."
author: Bethesda

name: Bodyguard
bio:
Bodyguard is a Nord who appears in Pelagius the Mad's nightmares during the quest "The Mind of Madness." Two of them are seen sitting next to the standing Pelagius the Suspicious during the Paranoia segment.
During the quest they are transformed into wolves and attack Pelagius the Suspicious.
author: Bethesda

name: Boethiah
bio:
Boethiah is the Daedric Prince of deceit, conspiracy, murder, treachery, and sedition. Boethiah rules over the realm of Attribution's Share in Oblivion. Boethiah's sphere is the unlawful overthrow of authority. A violent Daedric Prince, Boethiah is known for taking enjoyment in the suffering of mortals.
Boethiah is worshipped by the Dunmer people, who count Boethiah among the Three Good Daedra in their pantheon (the other two Daedra are Azura and Mephala). Boethiah's summoning day is the 2nd of Sun's Dusk.
Like all Daedric Princes, Boethiah has no absolute gender, and, as such, chooses to appear as male at some times and female at other times. Boethiah has being choosing to appear as a female in recent years. Boethiah acts the most overtly out of all the Daedric Princes. Boethiah enjoys battle and conflict, and Boethiah's cults often stage huge tournaments to the death to win the Prince's favor.
Even among scholars, who frequently reject the common notion that Daedra are all demons, Boethiah is one of the Daedric Princes consistently viewed as evil in most of Tamriel. Boethiah uses their followers for bloodsport, even turning on their champion seemingly without reason at times. Like Molag Bal or Mehrunes Dagon, Boethiah delights in visiting death and destruction upon mortals, whom they actively strive to torment. Yet despite being feared and vilified by most mortals, a markedly different perception is popularly held by the Dunmer people. While the Dunmer acknowledge Molag Bal and Mehrunes Dagon to be members of the House of Troubles (the four "Bad Daedra" in the Dunmer pantheon, with the other two "Bad Daedra" being Sheogorath and Malacath), the Dunmer worship Boethiah as a good Daedroth: one whom they credit with guiding and advancing Dunmeri civilization.
Boethiah is one of the three Daedric Princes (along with Azura and Mephala) directly responsible for the existence of the Dunmer as a distinct race. During the Merethic Era, some of the Aldmer worshipped the Aedroth known as Trinimac as their chief god. These early mer generally lamented their mortal existence as being caused by the trickery of Lorkhan, who manipulated the gods into giving up their immortality to create Nirn. Boethiah approached a group of Trinimac's followers and began preaching to them an alternative viewpoint: the Aldmer were weak and unworthy of their immortality, and their mortal existence was a trial which all mer had to endure (The Dunmer often refer to their mortal lifetime as "The Testing". Trinimac attempted to stop Boethiah, but Boethiah, being the Prince of Plots, tricked Trinimac into going into their mouth. Boethiah then took on the form of Trinimac himself and spoke with Trinimac's own voice. Thus, Boethiah was able to convince a group of mer, who took the name Chimer (Changed Ones), and these mer followed their leader Veloth to make a new home in Morrowind. As for the fallen Aedroth, the reanimated dung that was Trinimac became the Daedric Prince Malacath. Trinimac's remaining followers were consequently changed and became the Orcs.
Boethiah taught the Chimer many ways to be different from the Aldmer. The source of all manner of cultural advances by the Chimer is credited to Boethiah, ranging from philosophy and magic to their architecture, as well as their current clan-based political system. In most versions of the legend, Azura and Mephala merely aided the Chimer in implementing Boethiah's ideas.
Boethiah continued to play a key role in the religious practices of the Chimer, even after Azura turned the Chimer into the Dunmer by giving them grey skin and red eyes. As part of the Tribunal doctrine, Boethiah, Azura, and Mephala were named the Anticipations of Almalexia, Sotha Sil, and Vivec, respectively.
By the Fourth Era following the eruption of the Red Mountain, a new religious movement for the Dunmer people arose, dubbed the Reclamations. The former Anticipations became known as the Reclamations in the face of the new Dunmer religion.
Like many of the Daedric Princes, Boethiah's name appears in numerous variations across many eras and cultures.
Boethiah and Molag Bal have developed a sort of rivalry between each other. The cause is unknown, although it could be because Molag Bal is the Prince of domination and enslavement, whereas Boethiah encourages treason and deceit against authority.
Other than Goldbrand, Boethiah is associated with the Daedric artifact Ebony Mail. The Ebony Mail's current wearer is a Dunmer man whom Boethiah has named her champion, but he has recently been using the armor for personal gain, rather than in the name of Boethia. Boethiah now wants to select a new champion to slay her previous champion and take the Ebony Mail from him. The Ebony Mail is one of the most powerful armor pieces known on Tamriel. If judged worthy, its power grants the wearer invulnerability to most common magical attacks and a form of drain health.
Quotes:
"Ahhhhgh. Wearing flesh is so... distasteful. You have caught my attention, mortal. That is most unwise."
 "I am called Boethiah. Many names have mortals given me. But I am not interested in names. I am interested only in deeds."
"I abide only those whose will is aligned to my own. Those who oppose my desires perish in the most dreadful of ways."
"We Daedra are far more powerful than any god. And among my brethren, I am the most feared."
"My previous champion displeases me. It is time he is replaced - in the traditional fashion. I am loath to utter his name... one cannot erase a thing if it has a name to be remembered. You will find him holed up at Knifepoint Ridge, where he plays king to bandits and highwaymen. For a time he served his purpose, but that time has ended. He uses my gifts for his own amusement, and the only amusement I tolerate is my own. Kill every single member of his band. Do so as silently and invisibly as you can, for this is not about you. You are to be my instrument in this. Slay him in the coldest of blood. Do not give him the dignity of defending himself. Once his corpse lays cold upon the ground, and all trace of his followers erased, retrieve my Ebony Mail. A gift fit only for my true champion."
author: Bethesda

name: Boethiah Cultist
bio:
Boethiah Cultist is member of a diverse group of Boethiah worshippers residing at the Sacellum of Boethiah, high up in the Velothi Mountains southeast of Windhelm. They are led by the Priestess of Boethiah.
The Priestess of Boethiah is a Dunmer woman who interacts with the visitors to their shrine, informing them of basic information about Boethiah. The Priestess will tell visitors that in order to win the approval of Boethiah and her followers, the visitor must sacrifice a victim to the shrine.
author: Bethesda

name: Bolar
bio:
Bolar is an Orc woman who lives in the Orc stronghold of Narzulbur. Narzulbur is located in Eastmarch, at the foot of the Velothi Mountains, which form the boundary between Skyrim and Morrowind. Narzulbur is just north of Gloombound Mine, which is owned and operated by the Orcs living in Narzulbur. This mine mainly produces ebony ore, but also produces some orichalcum ore and iron ore.
Bolar is the oldest member of the stronghold and thus is believed to be the wisest. Bolar is the aunt of Chief Mauhulakh, and she took care of Mauhulakh’s son Dushnamub and daughter Urog after their mothers died giving birth. Dushnamub and Urog had different mothers, and Bolar was the midwife for both of their births. 
Being the oldest and thought to be the wisest, she is one of the most respected members of the community and Orcs come to her to seek advice and guidance so that they can remain true to the Code of Malacath. She serves as a spiritual leader of sorts, performing ceremonies in which she reads in the animal's entrails.
As the wise woman of the Narzulbur tribe, Bolar is counted upon by the chieftain to communicate with the gods to figure out why all his wives have died. She's not in any rush though, because as far as she's concerned, as long as he has Yatul and herself, he doesn't need anyone else and she thinks he's showing signs of weakness by being sentimental over their deaths.
Bolar secretly deliberately caused both of Mauhulakh’s wives to die in childbirth, due to jealousy over the Mauhulakh’s affection and the desire to maintain influence the Mauhulakh and the tribe, but she will not be willing to admit this to the player.
