Bolar will only be willing to talk about such things with her sister Yatul, who actively encouraged Bolar to kill Mauhulakh's wives. Bolar and Yatul continue to secretly conspire to prevent their nephew Mauhulakh from taking another wife, in order to maintain their monopoly on his affection and attention. 
As the local alchemist, Bolar sells potions and ingredients to anyone willing to buy them. Her workshop has both an Alchemy Lab and a Tanning Rack, outside of Mauhulakh's Longhouse where she lives and sleeps.
Bolar has some ability with magic, and knows the following spells: Firebolt, Fast Healing, and Steadfast Ward.
Quotes:
"I've read the entrails many times, but can't fathom why Mauhulakh's wives keep finding tragedy."
"Mauhulakh was such a darling boy. Until he got older, and started having opinions."
"Urog and Dushnamub were such lovely children. I held them as they watched their mothers die after birth. They know me best, now."
"Yatul and I tend to dote on Mauhulakh. You know how aunts can be with their favorite nephew."
"We have lived in Skyrim since before the Nords came. Our way is simple, all work to make the tribe strong. Only the bravest are allowed to lead, and to marry. A great chief is able to attract many wives and raise bold children. Wise women like myself are mothers of chieftains. We guide the tribe and advice our kin on what is most pleasing to Malacath."
“Malacath is our creator and master. The Daedric Lord of the Sworn Oath and the Bloody Curse. Malacath teaches us to honor all words with action. To demand blood from your enemies and strength from your allies. He watches over all Orcs as his children. A truth those who leave the stronghold are quick to forget."
author: Bethesda

name: Bolfrida Brandy-Mug
bio:
Bolfrida Brandy-Mug, a Nord woman, is a farmer who owns and lives at Brandy-Mug Farm, outside Windhelm. Her farm is a relatively short distance east from the Windhelm stables. She will pay gold to those who assist her in harvesting the wheat from her farm.
She likes to think of creative ways to make crops grow more effectively in cold weather. She is friendly to visitors. She loves her job and keeps a positive attitude.
She employs a practical Dunmer man named Faryl Atheron at her farm.
Quotes:
"Welcome, welcome, welcome! Don't see many strangers out here. Come to get your hands dirty on a real farm?"
"Nothing tastes better than food you've grown yourself. Something magic about dirt and sunshine making food."
"The weather's harsh, but I like to think my sunny personality is what helps the grain grow."
author: Bethesda

name: Bolgeir Bearclaw
bio:
Bolgeir Bearclaw is a Nord man in who lives in Solitude, and is the housecarl of Jarl Elisif the Fair. 
He can usually be found inside the Blue Palace. He has fairly long reddish-brown hair, and a beard. He usually wears a set of steel plate armor, though he rarely wears the helmet piece of the armor set. He carries three weapons, all crafted in Orcish quality, including a dagger and two swords. 
Bolgeir takes his position as housecarl to the Jarl Elisif very seriously, and is quite protective of her. Elisif recently became the Jarl of Haafingaar after her husband (High King Torygg) was killed by Ulfric Stormcloak.
He worries that General Tullius doesn’t have Jarl Elisif’s best interests at heart. Bolgeir has no intention of becoming an Imperial solider, and knows that his place is at Jarl Elisif’s side.
Though he prefers to keep quiet at court, there are times when Bolgeir voices protest against Jarl Elisif's rushed decisions.
Quotes:
"My duty is to keep the Jarl safe. Not play nursemaid to you sycophants."
“We lost another five guardsmen. If General Tullius continues to conscript our men and send them off to battle, we'll have none left to protect the city."
"Keep your weapons out of your hands, and we'll get along just fine."
"Please address all questions to the Steward, Falk Firebeard."
"The Jarl has advised me not to talk about which court attendants I'd like to punch in the face. More's the pity."
author: Bethesda

name: Bolli
bio:
Bolli is a Nord man who lives with his wife Nivenor (a Bosmer) in his house in Riften. He has a long graying goatee, and usually wears high quality merchant clothes, a pair of boots, and a hat.
Bolli owns and runs the Riften Fishery. He has a charitable nature, giving away much of his wealth to the poor of Riften. He is a devout follower of Mara and donates to the temple of Mara in Riften, which is headed by the priest Maramal. Maramal is a Redguard man who is married to a Dunmer woman named Dinya Balu, who is also a priestess at the Temple of Mara. 
Bolli enjoys fishing. Bolli supplies Marise Aravel (a Dunmer woman) with fish for her stall in the marketplace. 
Bolli strongly suspects that his wife has been cheating on him with other men. Bolli has been having a sexual affair with Haelga, a woman who is notorious in Riften for her sexual promiscuity. Haelga operates the Bunkhouse, a lodging facility which houses Riften’s working class. Haelga sometimes tries to convince Bolli to leave his wife in order to be with her in a more official capacity. Bolli carries a Mark of Dibella that was given to him by Haelga in exchange for an intimate favor Bolli performed with her. Bolli will be quite reluctant to admit to the player his affair with Haelga or his possession of Haelga’s Mark of Dibella.
Bolli’s wife Nivenor considers Bolli’s passion for giving to the poor and to the Temple of Mara to be silly and pointless. Nivenor spends most of her time relaxing at home or shopping, and she wastes a lot of money on trinkets. She only works approximately 4 hours a day in the afternoon, doing paperwork in her office at the Riften Fishery.
Bolli may ask the player to deliver a purchase agreement to Kleppr, the innkeeper of the Silver Blood Inn in the city of Markarth.
Bolli sometimes makes trips to Ivarstead, to the west across Lake Honrich.
Quotes:
"Started out with a single fishing pole and now I have an entire building and two boats to my name. Not bad for a middle-aged Nord, eh?"
"New in town, eh? Here for the fishing, I guess."
"There's nothing like fishing on Lake Honrich. You should try it some time."
"If you're hungry, Marise sells fresh fish, caught by yours truly."
"Remember to give at the Temple."
"Divines smile on you, friend."
author: Bethesda

name: Bolund
bio:
Bolund, a Nord man, is a lumberjack who lives in Falkreath. He has shoulder-length blond hair. He is in charge of Falkreath's lumber mill. His brother Solaf is the owner of Gray Pine Goods, a general store in Falkreath. His sister Grelka is a merchant in Riften.
Bolund has a hostile, taciturn nature, and isn't much for talking, especially with folk he doesn't know. Bolund displays an open dislike for outsiders, which contrasts sharply with the attitude of his brother Solaf.
He can usually be found at the Falkreath lumber mill. He also spends some time at his brother’s general goods store, Gray Pine Goods.
Bolund will sell lumber at the price of 10 gold per sawn log.
When Bolund visits the Dead Man’s Drink tavern/inn, he can often be observed being his usual blunt self while talking to the serving girl Narri, saying things like “Hey gossip, bring me a drink.” Bolund doesn't think too highly of Valga Vinicia, the Imperial woman who works as the innkeeper of Dead Man's Drink.
Quotes:
"You'll find my brother Solaf and I are the only true Nords in Falkreath."
"That Valga Vinicia is a gossip and a troublemaker."
"Falkreath is where people go to die. We could be fighting, taking back Nord land!"
If the player is a Nord: "A hearty welcome to Falkreath! All of Skyrim's true sons are welcome here!"
If the player is a non-Nord: "I can't believe we let provincials like you wander Skyrim.”
If the player is an Argonian: "Stay out of my way, boot.
author: Bethesda

name: Bor
bio:
Bor, an Orc woman, is a miner who lives in the Orc Stronghold of Narzulbur. She can usually be found inside Gloombound Mine, an ebony mine within Narzulbur’s territory. If she needs to fight, she will wield a war axe.
Quotes:
"I'm here to mine, outlander. So unless you want to dig, get out."
"I have metal to dig."
"Malacath has given me the task to mine. Good ore brings strength to our people."
"Every Orc learns the heavy labor of mining. All spend years in the caves."
"The mines are hard, but Malacath rewards those who rise to the challenge."
author: Bethesda

name: Borgakh the Steel Heart
bio:
Borgakh the Steel Heart is an Orc woman who lives in the Orc stronghold of Mor Khazgur, west of Solitude. Borgakh is the daughter of Chief Larak and his first wife Bagrak, who is also Larak’s sister (marrying one’s siblings is not unheard of in Orc strongholds). Olur is Borgakh’s half-sister, whose mother is Chief Larak’s second wife Shuftharz. Sharamph is Borgakh’s grandmother.
Borgakh can often be found practicing the use of her sword against a wooden training dummy in front of Larak's Longhouse. She also spends time during the day inside the Longhouse itself. If conversed with, Borgakh will express her envy towards the player, who can freely travel wherever and whenever they wish.
Borgakh will explain that she will soon be of age, and by tradition she will be married to one of the Orc chiefs from another stronghold. To that end, she trains so that she may offer her strength to the other tribe, while her own people will receive good trade in return, thus benefiting both tribes. Asking for Borgakh's opinion on the matter will have her confess that she actually feels caged. She will admit that, while she once looked forward to meeting new people and seeing new places at one of the other Orc strongholds once being of age, she no longer feels the same way about it. She will elaborate that it is her father who will choose which chief she will have to marry, and that she still has no idea who that will be.
If the player requests Borgakh to accompany them on their adventures as a follower, she will at first decline, stating that, despite her feelings, she must follow the traditions of her people, and that she does not want to shame her ancestors. However, after further persuasion (or through paying off her dowry with a sum of gold), she will choose to follow the player after all, stating that Malacath also teaches the Orcs to follow their own fate.
After Borgakh has spent some time following the player on their adventures across Skyrim, she will confess her romantic feelings for the player if the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse). At this point, Borgakh will voice her opinion that the player as strong and clever, and will declare that marrying the player feels right (in contrast with her previously planned marriage to an Orc chieftain in another stronghold). If the player decides to marry Borgakh, then after the wedding ceremony is over, Borgakh will remark that Nord weddings are vastly different from Orc weddings, observing that Nord weddings involve less blood and violence.
Borgakh comes well-equipped with heavy armor. She wields an Orcish sword and an Orcish bow.
Borgakh primarily uses a sword and shield, making her a good front-line combatant. She will usually not use her bow unless she cannot close the distance to her intended target quickly. She is also skilled at stealth, making her a versatile ally.
Quotes:
"I envy you, outlander. You can choose to leave if you wish."
“I want to leave the stronghold, but I must stay here and wait for the day when I'll be married and sent to another stronghold. It is our way, and I am proud to follow my people's traditions, but I can't help but feel chained."
"I am Larak's daughter. Soon, I'll be of age and will be sent to marry an Orc chief in some distant stronghold. Until then, I train. My new home will need strength, and my sisters must know I am not weak when I arrive."
“A chief's daughter marries who her chief wishes. It ensures the stronghold receives a fair trade in goods for my absence. I used to look forward to the day when I was of age, to see new places and people, but now it feels like a cage."
“Soon, I will be of age. The taste is bitter."
"Perhaps I'll join the Legion one day, as my father had done."
author: Bethesda

name: Borgny
bio:
Borgny is a Nord man who lives in Dawnstar. He has long brown hair. He is one of the many miners who work in Quicksilver Mine at the edge of Dawnstar.
Quotes:
"Plenty of ore to dig."
"Mining is an honest trade. No real tricks to it."
author: Bethesda

name: Borkul the Beast
bio:
Borkul the Beast is an Orc man in Cidhna Mine, the prison in Markarth where the inmates are forced to undergo hard labor as miners. Borkul is now a member of the Forsworn, and serves as the bodyguard for Madanach, the leader of the Forsworn within the prison. Madanach is also called “the King in Rags”. Borkul is the only Orc member in the Druadach branch of the Forsworn. He is nicknamed “the Beast” because of his large frame and bulging muscles. Uraccen, a fellow prisoner in Cidhna Mine, has this to say about Borkul: "Madanach's guard. Big, even for an Orc. Heard he ripped a man's arm off and beat him to death with it. He's old-fashioned like that."
Borkul is considered the toughest prisoner in the mine, and he guards the entrance to Madanach’s cell in the rear of the mine. Borkul will grant the player access to Madanach’s cell if the player is persuasive in their claim that Madanach is expecting to see them, or if the player intimidates Borkul into thinking that he would lose in a fight against the player. Borkul will also allow access to Madanach’s cell if the player brings him either a shiv, or a bottle of skooma. Alternatively, Borkul will grant the player access if the player challenges him to a fist fight and wins.
Borkul carries a pickaxe, and wears ragged trousers and a pair of iron gauntlets.
If Borkul escapes the Cidhna Mine prison, he will run east all the way to Druadach Redoubt with his Forsworn comrades, where he will start his life anew as part of the Forsworn along with the other escaped Forsworn prisoners.
Borkul will not leave his post guarding the entrance to Madanach’s cell, but he will be quite talkative. 
Quotes:
When Borkul first meets the player: "The new meat. So soft. Tender. What was it like killing your first one, huh?". 
When asks what he’s in prison for: "Murder. Banditry. Assault. Theft. And lollygagging."
"Guards brought me in about 12 years ago. Was running a good group of bandits up until then. But these Forsworn. They're nothing like the men I cobbled together. They're real killers."
"You serve your time by digging. So dig."
"Prison's not so bad. Less complaints when I kill people."
If the player asks to be granted access to Madanach: "You want to talk to the King in Rags? Fine. But first you got to pay the toll. How about you get me a shiv? Not that I need one, but it's nice to have in case I need to do some 'shaving.' Ha ha."
“That dung heap Grisvar's been known to make a few shivs.”
If Borkul has agreed to grant the player access to Madanach: "All right, head on in. But don't try anything in there. Madanach is smarter than you think."
"The Reach belongs to the Forsworn!"
author: Bethesda

name: Borri
bio:
Borri is an Elder Nord and one of the Greybeards at High Hrothgar.
He teaches the first word, Wuld, of the Whirlwind Sprint shout. He can utilize the shout Whirlwind Sprint to move with improved speed.
Along with the other Greybeards, the only dialogue by talking to him results in him saying "Dovahkiin..." followed by the sound of a distant bell and a violent shaking.
author: Bethesda

name: Borvir
bio:
Borvir was an apprentice mage at the College of Winterhold. His corpse can be found at Journeyman's Nook, adjacent a bandit and a named dagger.
Although able to be found at any point, Phinis Gestor will mention Borvir and his brother among four students who went missing from College of Winterhold, recalling they were working on a way to magically chill mead. Due to the unfinished nature of the quest, there is no further mentioning of him, quest stages, or objectives that point to his location. The location where he can be found suggests the bandit also found there most likely murdered him.
author: Bethesda

name: Bothela
bio:
Bothela, an old Breton Reachwoman, is an alchemist who lives in Markarth. She wears facepaint and has long white hair.
She is the proprietor of The Hag's Cure, where she sells potions and alchemical ingredients. She has a store assistant and friend named Muiri, a young Breton woman. 
Bothela expresses regret at the situation with the Forsworn. She has a nephew named Odvan who is a prisoner in Cidhna Mine for being a member of the Forsworn. If asked about the Forsworn, she will say that a great number of her friends and her kin were lost because they joined the Forsworn.
Bothela thinks that Markarth would be better off without the Silver-Bloods. Yngvar, a Silver-Blood enforcer, periodically comes to forcefully collect gold from her shop s as part of the Silver-Blood protection racket.
Bothela may ask the player to discretely deliver a potion called Stallion's Potion to Raerek, an old man who serves as Jarl's Igmund’s steward in Understone Keep. The potion enhances a man's sexual performance and endurance for about an hour after drinking it.
Bothela sometimes talks to Muiri about Muiri’s former lover Alain Dufont, a leader of a group of bandits. Alain tricked Muiri into thinking that he loved her in order put himself in a position to steal valuable heirlooms from the Shatter-Shield family in Windhelm, to whom Muiri was close. This pain from this betrayal still plagues Muiri’s thoughts. 
Quote:
"A little bit of old Reach magic can cure whatever ills you...."
We'd be better off without the Silver-Bloods. They send their brute, Yngvar, to shake some coins from me every few days. And Betrid Silver-Blood is always asking for more potions to fuel Thonar's 'ambitions.' Gives him a temper fiercer than any bear."
"The only thing I know about the Forsworn is that they break an old woman's heart. So many friends, so many kin, all lost trying to rebuild a past that was over long ago."
"I have potions for disease, love sickness, irritating children..."
"Oh yes... you'll need one of my special brews..."
"Not scared of an old woman now, are you?"
If asked why her shop is called The Hag’s Cure: "Comes with living to a ripe old age, people start thinking there's something magical about you. Then, the insults. Still, a little knowledge of plants and potions can get you by.”
author: Bethesda

name: Boti
bio:
Boti, a Nord woman, is a farmer who lives and works at Fellstar Farm in Ivarstead. She owns the farm with her husband Jofthor, and together they have a teenage daughter named Fastred. Boti, can usually be found tending crops at their farm. She sometimes tells Fastred that she needs to help out more around the farm.
Boti's daughter Fastred is currently considering eloping to Riften with a man named Bassianus Axius. Boti accepts their relationship, only wishing for whatever makes Fastred happy. However, Boti’s husband Jofthor is not particularly accepting of Fastred’s relationship with Bassianus, and wants Fastred to stay in Ivarstead. Jofthor would rather see his daughter paired with Klimmek, a local fisherman with whom Fastred was recently in love. If the player requests Boti’s assistance in helping Fastred to elope to Riften with Bassianus, Boti will agree to help by distracting and calming down her husband. 
Quotes:
If asked about High Hrothgar: "It's frightening living below their monastery. Sometimes I swear I can hear strange noises rolling down from up there. It sounds like thunder, but there's never any rain. What do you make of that?"
If asked about Fastred’s relationship with Bassianus: “Now, don't tell my husband, but I don't have any problem with Bassianus. Even if it means her leaving Ivarstead, I want Fastred to be happy. If they just snuck out of town together, I could manage my husband. Bassianus is still so terrified of Jofthor. If he knew that I'd keep him from hunting the poor boy down, he'd take Fastred to Riften without a second thought. Let him know that I'll look out for them. I just want my daughter to be happy."
"You must be another pilgrim on the way up to High Hrothgar. No other reason to pass through here."
"Pilgrim or not, If I were you, I'd move right through our backwards little town."
"And to think that we've been supplying the Greybeards with our food supplies. What have they ever done for us?"
author: Bethesda

name: Bottar
bio:
Bottar is a Nord child who can be found wandering the wilds of Skyrim.
For a small fee he will mark the location of Deep Folk Crossing on the player’s map. Deep Folk Crossing is a Dwemer ruin located in the Druadach mountains at the far west of The Reach hold. 
Bottar and his friend Sond go around selling various Dwemer artifacts and random potions to travelers.
author: Bethesda

name: Bouncer
bio:
The Bouncer is a Dunmer bandit guarding the entrance to Cragslane Cavern, near the small town of Shor’s Stone in The Rift hold. There are two pit wolves in Master-locked cages next to him. He will attack people if they approach too closely.
Quotes:
"These fights are invite only. And you're not invited. Slag off."
author: Bethesda

name: Bounty Collector
bio:
Bounty Collector is a highly experienced and well-equipped guard who will intercept the player on the roads of Skyrim should they carry a bounty exceeding 1000 gold within a particular hold. Unlike normal guards who can only pursue criminals within the borders of a given Hold, bounty collectors are given free rein to ignore the distinction between the nine Holds of Skyrim. They have jurisdiction throughout Skyrim, regardless of the Hold in which the bounty is incurred.
They come equipped with a quality suit of heavy armor and an enchanted weapon. Under no circumstances should they be underestimated. They will approach the player and demand that they pay the bounty they have incurred for crimes they have committed. If the player cannot or will not pay their bounty for whatever reason, the bounty collector will become offended, and will subsequently become hostile and attack. The total amount which the player must pay is the gold value of the bounty was, as well as an extra 20% fee to cover administrative expenses.
Paying off the bounty to the bounty collector will remove the player's criminal status, and the bounty collector will then allow them to move along.
author: Bethesda

name: Bradyn
bio: Bradyn is a deceased Dunmer miner found in Kolbjorn Barrow during the second stage of the quest "Unearthed."
author: Bethesda

name: Braig
bio:
Braig, a Breton Reachman, is a member of the Forsworn rebellion who has been imprisoned for years in Cidhna Mine, the prison in Markarth where the inmates are forced to undergo hard labor as miners. He is balding and has long gray hair with a thick mustache. He was originally thrown in the prison because he was caught speaking with Madanach (also known as the King in Rags), the leader of the Forsworn Rebellion, before the Nords crushed the rebellion and regained control of Markarth and The Reach hold. Just before Braig was imprisoned, his young daughter Aethra begged Jarl Hrolfdir to take her instead. The Jarl's men then beheaded Aethra in front of Braig, and sent him as a prisoner to Cidhna Mine anyway. Aethra would be 23 years old now if she was still alive.
Braig will only tell the player the story about his daughter’s death if the player tells him that Madanach has requested him to tell his story.
Quotes:
“Everyone in Cidhna Mine has a tale. Let's hear yours first. When was the first time you felt chains around your wrists?"
When telling his story: "I had a daughter, once. She'd be 23 this year. Married to some hot-headed silver worker or maybe on her own learning the herb trade. The Nords didn't care who was and who wasn't involved in the Forsworn Uprising. I had spoken to Madanach once, that was enough. But my little Aethra didn't want to see her papa leave her. She pleaded to the Jarl to take her instead. And after they made me watch as her head rolled off the block, they threw me in here anyway, to dig up their silver."
"I'm not Madanach. I was never a leader of the Forsworn. The only anger I can justify is my own. But every family in the Reach has a story like mine. There are no innocent onlookers in this struggle. Just the guilty, and the dead."
“I'm just a poor Forsworn whose only regret is not killing more Nords before I was locked up."
"Don't reach for a shiv around me, or we'll both regret it."
"What do you want? Have digging to do."
"Glory to the Forsworn!"
author: Bethesda

name: Braith
bio:
Braith is a Redguard child living in the Wind District of Whiterun. She is the energetic and belligerent daughter of Amren and Saffir. Braith’s father used to be a soldier, and her mother Saffir spends much of her time reading adventure and romance books. 
Braith's mother wants her daughter to start reading more and stop getting into fights with just about every child she runs into, but Braith will either ignore her mother or frown at her when she overhears this. Braith has a secret crush on Lars Battle-Born, which is the reason why she is bullying him. If the player convinces Braith to stop harassing Lars, she will elaborate that she would not have had to bully Lars in the first place if Lars would just kiss her.
Braith, Mila Valentia and Lars Battle-Born can sometimes be seen playing tag or hide-and-seek in the city. Braith feels that neither of her parents give her enough attention, especially her mother who always has her nose in a book. Whenever she tries to bring up the subject of her crush on Lars Battle-Born, both of her parents brush her off and tell her that they’re too busy to listen. If Braith sees her father preparing to leave the city for mercenary work, she will ask him if she can accompany him, but he always makes her stay home.
If both of Braith’s parents die, she will agree to be adopted by the player if they offer to do so.
Quotes:
"Stupid Lars Battle-Born. I fight him almost every day, but it's not much of a fight, 'cause he don't fight back."
"Boys, girls, dogs, elders - there's nobody I won't fight!"
"What're you lookin' at? I'm not afraid of you, ya know. Even if you are my elder."
author: Bethesda

name: Bralsa Drel
bio:
Bralsa Drel, a Dunmer woman, is a miner originally encountered at the Earth Stone, outside Raven Rock. When initially encountered, she is constantly working on the structure around the Earth Stone; she talks and acts like she has been indoctrinated, just like the other people around the stone.
Several years ago she was a very successful ebony miner, so much so that she was said to be wealthier than the Councilor Morvayn himself. However, when the ebony mines closed she knew no other trade and turned to drinking to drown her sorrows. She lost all her money and was reduced to a beggar.
After being freed from her indoctrination, she will return to the Abandoned Building in Raven Rock with Rirns Llervu.
She later explains that Geldis Sadri has banned her from drinking at the The Retching Netch and asks if the player can somehow persuade him to let her back in. If she is allowed back she will be very thankful and reward the player with a gift she once carried in happier times.
If the ebony mines have been reopened at the conclusion of the quest, she finds a job working there and things will begin looking up for her as she mentions it.
Quotes:
"I was one of the wealthiest miners in town... I could haul up almost three or four times what the average digger could. I never saw the end coming like it did... the mine running out of ebony. Unlike most of my fellow miners, I was too foolish to save enough coin for that day. The rest I spent on sujamma to drown my sorrows. Councilor Morvayn was kind enough to allow Rirns and I to live in one of the abandoned buildings. At least it keeps the ash out of our eyes."
If the ebony mine re-opens: "Things couldn't be better. The sections that are being opened up have revealed some huge deposits of ebony. Old Crescius has a nose for exactly where to dig. If they'd only listened to him years ago, the town wouldn't have been in such dire straits. At this rate, I'll be able to put a roof over my head in just a few months."
If offered a free sample of Geldis Sadri's new sujamma drink: "The day I refuse sujamma from Geldis is the day I sprout wings and fly off of this rock."
author: Bethesda

name: Brand-Shei
bio:
Brand-Shei, a Dunmer man, is a shopkeeper in Riften. During the day, he sells a variety of goods at his stall in Riften’s Grand Plaza market square. At night, he sleeps in Haelga’s Bunkhouse, a popular lodging facility for the workers of Riften.
He sells various ingots, soul gems, jewelry, potions, weapons, and armor. He also sells specialty goods from Morrowind that other general goods merchants don’t sell.
Orphaned as a child and raised by Argonians from a very early age, Brand-Shei believes that he originally came from the House Telvanni in Morrowind. He has traced his ancestry back to a maid of House Telvanni, who escaped during an Argonian invasion.  Brand-Shei may ask the player to investigate the wreck of a ship named The Pride of Tel Vos, in order to learn more about his own past and ancestry.
Like many in Riften, Brand-Shei has an unfavorable opinion of the Black-Briar family and the Thieves Guild, but is fearful of publicly voicing this opinion.
Brand-Shei is on friendly terms with Svana Far-Shield, a young Nord woman who works for her aunt Haelga at Haelga’s Bunkhouse, where Brand-Shei lives and sleeps. Brand-Shei and Svana sometimes discuss Sibbi Black-Briar’s recent murder of a man named Wulfur. Wulfur was the brother of Svidi. Svidi is a young Nord woman who is the mutual acquaintance of Brand-Shei and Svana. Svidi has recently gone missing.
Brand-Shei is on good terms with Mjoll, a Nord woman who is trying to fight against the rampant corruption and crime that plagues Riften.
Brand-Shei sometimes discusses current events with Bolli (a fisherman) or Shadr (works at the Riften stables), such as the recent destruction of Helgen at the hands of a dragon.
Tythis Ullen, a Dunmer man who works at the Riften Fishery, buys boots from Brand-Shei unusually often. Tythis has bought 20 pairs of boots from Brand-Shei in the last 2 years.
There is a rumor that Brand-Shei is in a secret relationship with Haelga, the Nord woman who owns the bunkhouse where Brand-Shei lives. Haelga is infamous in Riften for her sexual promiscuity and fervent Dibella worship. Even if this rumor about Brand-Shei and Haelga is true, Brand-Shei will deny it if questioned about it.
Quotes:
"If you're ever in the market, I deal in specialty goods from Morrowind at one of the stands."
If at his stall in the Riften market: "Gems, potions, exotic ingredients... I have them all!"
If at his stall in the Riften market: "Can I interest you in some fine goods from Morrowind?"
If at his stall in the Riften market: "Have anything you wish to sell? I pay fair prices for all sorts of goods."
If at his stall in the Riften market: "If there's anything you wish to purchase, just let me know."
"I may be dark elf by birth, but I was raised Argonian. Through reasons I'm still trying to discover, I ended up orphaned then taken in by a kindly Argonian family in Black Marsh. I hope one day to finally find out what happened to me... how I ended up like that."
“When I was found by my Argonian father, I was wrapped in a blanket bearing the symbol of House Telvanni. It was one of the great houses in Morrowind long ago. Whether that means I was one of them or not, I'm uncertain. I learned that a matron who had served for House Telvanni had escaped Morrowind during the Accession War. Records show her buying passage aboard a vessel named "The Pride of Tel Vos," but that's where the trail ran cold. I spent years looking for what became of the ship, but I ended up empty-handed. If you come across anything in your travels that might provide me with the answers I'm looking for, I'd be grateful."
If the player gives him the journal of Lymdremn Telvanni: "Let me see that! Yes... yes. This is it! I don't know how you found this stranger, but you've obviously succeeded where I had failed. Please, let me offer you this key. It unlocks my strongbox under my stand in the marketplace. Help yourself to anything inside. I really appreciate what you've done for me. I'll never forget it."
If inside the Riften Jail: "This city is corrupt! You're all corrupt! This is unfair! I'm innocent! This is all the work of Brynjolf and the Thieves Guild! I’ve been framed! They stole Madesi’s ring and put it in my pocket!”
author: Bethesda

name: Brandish
bio: Brandish, a Breton man, is a mage who specializes in Destruction magic. He is hostile to the player. He can be found inside Fort Neugrad, which is currently occupied by bandits.
author: Bethesda

name: Brelas
bio:
Brelas, a Bosmer woman, works as a servant at the Thalmor Embassy in Skyrim, west of Solitude.
Ambassador Elenwen is the head Thalmor Justiciar at the embassy, and is the First Emissary of the Thalmor in Skyrim. 
Elenwen is hosting another one of her parties at the Embassy. These parties are attended many Jarls, Thanes, and other influential people from across Skyrim. Brelas has been tasked with serving Colovian Brandy to the party guests, free of charge.
Brelas has a strong dislike for Erikur, a Nord man who is a Thane of Solitude. Erikur has been making unwanted sexual advances towards Brelas during the currently ongoing party. If the player engages in a lengthy conversation with Brelas, she may decide to politely ask the player to ask Erikur to leave her alone.
If there is an incident at Elenwen’s party, Brelas may be blamed and sent to the Thalmor Embassy dungeon. If this happens, Brelas will try to escape the dungeon and will flee to the New Gnisis Cornerclub in Windhelm with Malborn. Malborn, a fellow Bosmer, was another one of the Thalmor Embassy’s servants before escaping and fleeing the Thalmor. If Malborn decides to leave Skyrim via the border with Morrowind to the east of Windhelm, Brelas will accompany him out of Skyrim and into Morrowind. 
Quotes:
"I hope you're enjoying yourself."
"What can I get for you?"
“Erikur was talking to me earlier. I could tell what he was after. I hate working these parties. Some of the guests are nice, but there's always a few like Erikur. Please tell him to leave me alone. Politely. I'm sure you'll have better luck getting through to him than I would."
If in the Thalmor Embassy dungeon: "You've got to help me! Please! You don't understand what they do to people here!"
author: Bethesda

name: Brelyna Maryon
bio:
Brelyna Maryon is a fairly new apprentice at the College of Winterhold. Her assigned living quarters are in the Hall of Attainment along with the other pprentices, including Onmund (a young Nord man), J'zargo (a young male Khajiit), and the player.
Brelyna is a Dunmer who has recently reached adulthood. She wears mage robes with apprentice-level magicka-boosting enchantments, and usually has her hood up over her head. She usually carries at least one book in her bag.
Brelyna is a somewhat introverted yet diligent student. Though not yet quite as skilled as J'zargo, she is more than capable and has a good amount of natural talent, despite being a bit clumsy with some of her spells. She is currently mostly skilled with Alteration magic, and is also skilled with ward spells from the Restoration school. Having come from a place where expectations were very high for her as a descendant of a line of powerful Telvanni mages, Brelyna enjoys the lack of expectations or peer pressure at the College, and gladly focuses on studying at a pace that she is comfortable with. House Telvanni is one of the five Great Houses of Morrowind, known for their powerful mages.
She is usually polite when spoken to, though a bit shy. She is not fond of talking about herself, particularly about her heritage. She likes books and can often be found reading, regardless of where she is.
The Arch-Mage of the college is a Dunmer named Savos Aren. However, the Master Wizard (second-in-command) of the college, a Breton woman named Mirabelle Ervine, is the one who mostly runs things.
Brelyna accompanies the rest of the apprentices on Master Tolfdir's field expeditions to the ancient Nord ruin of Saarthal, where Arniel Gane often conducts research regarding several relics found there. Tolfdir assigns Brelyna with the task of detecting magical wards.
Brelyna disapproves of theft and crime. Despite her time in Morrowind, she doesn't know much about the Dwemer or their ruins. However, she does find Dwemer ruins interesting.
Brelyna may ask for assistance with practicing two new spells she is trying to learn. If a fellow mage agrees to be her test target for these spells, Brelyna will be grateful and consider them a friend. If requested, Brelyna is happy to follow her new friend (the player) on adventures across Skyrim.
After accompanying the player on adventures for some time, Brelyna will become willing to marry them.
When in combat, Brelyna is able to deal a decent amount of damage with spells. She usually begins combat by casting Oakflesh for personal protection, then proceeding to use fire spells offensively. She often uses Conjuration magic to summon a Familiar, Flame Atronach, or Frost Atronach to aid her. She will seldom use weapons or armor if they are provided to her, and prefers to use her spells.
Quotes:
"Before you even ask, yes I have an ancestry steeped in magic, and no I don't want to talk about it. Yes, I know Winterhold used to be full of my kind, and no I don't care that they're all gone now. Does that cover everything?"
"I'm Brelyna Maryon, of House Telvanni. First of my family to leave Morrowind in a long time. Now I'm here to study Conjuration. That's what's important."
If asked why there aren't as much Dunmer in Winterhold anymore: Didn't you know? Before the Oblivion Crisis, many elves called Winterhold their home. More visited the College from Morrowind every year. After, growing distrust of magic made life difficult for many. Some left rather than endure the growing hatred from the local Nords. Others returned home after the Red Year, when Vvardenfell erupted and caused much destruction. Winterhold itself died in the years between then and now. What's left out there is a husk. Only the College really remains."
"You know, this is one of a very few places where you can receive a real education in the schools of magic."
"I think my parents reserved a spot for me here at the College on the day I was born."
"There's a lot of pressure for me to excel in my studies. I hope I can live up to expectations."
"I'm liking the College so far, if only because no one is telling me how great I ought to be. I just want to learn, I don't want to think about what's expected of me."
"I came all the way to Skyrim just to get away from my family's expectations."
"We're all trying to become better mages, right? Well, I need someone I can practice a few spells on. Nothing dangerous, really. Would you be willing to assist me?"
After using her experimental spells on the player: "Let's be honest. I have a long way to go before I'm ready for the kind of advanced magic I've been attempting. But at least I know where to start now. Thank you, you've been a great help to me."
author: Bethesda

name: Brenuin
bio:
Brenuin is a Redguard man who lives in Whiterun. He is a homeless beggar and drunkard, and wears a set of ragged robes.
During the day, he can usually be found loitering in the Whiterun marketplace, asking for free food or money from merchants like Carlotta Valentia (an Imperial woman), Anoriath (a Bosmer man), and Ysolda (a young Nord woman). While begging for money, Brenuin will sometimes falsely refer to himself as a "fellow Nord" (despite being a Redguard, though he is particularly light-skinned for a Redguard), in an attempt to draw her sympathy. . Brenuin can also be found loitering around the Gildergreen, the tree at the center of the Winds District in Whiterun. At night, he often visits the Bannered Mare (the most popular inn in Whiterun, where a Nord woman named Hulda is the innkeeper) where Brenuin strolls around until he hits the streets again after midnight.
Brenuin has recently been teaching an orphaned Imperial girl named Lucia how to be a beggar. Lucia says that Brenuin is the only person who cares for her.
Brenuin may ask the player to steal a rare Argonian ale from the Bannered Mare and give it to him. If this ale is brought to him, he will reward the player with a healing potion and will then consider the player his friend. Brenuin will also consider the player his friend if they give him any money.
Quotes:
"That Heimskr's crazy. Him and his talk o' Talos. Wish he'd just shut up."
"What do you want?"
"Sure. Whatever."
"I don't owe you money, do I?"
"What? Why you lookin' at me?"
"I ain't done nothin'."
"Spare a coin for a fellow Nord who's down on his luck?"
“Gods know it's been too long since I tasted real meat."
"That's right, mock the town beggar like everyone else. But I've got a right to browse, don't I? I ain't hurtin' anyone."
author: Bethesda

name: Breya
bio:
Breya was a Nord warrior and explorer who sought the Lexicon at the Dwemer Ruin of Avanchnzel. The expedition included Breya, From-Deepest-Fathoms, Watches-The-Roots, and Drennen. During the expedition she was killed by Dwarven Centurions.
Her ghost can be seen throughout the ruins, and her body is found near the Lexicon's podium. Although at first firm in her job, she got more anxious as the expedition loses Drennen and they begin to fight more and more Dwarven Automatons. She was killed at the bottom of the ruin by a Centurion protecting the Lexicon.
author: Bethesda

name: Briehl
bio:
Briehl is a Nord man who lives in Riften. He is an acolyte who serves under the head priest of the Temple of Mara in Riften, who is a Redguard man named Maramal. Maramal is married to a Dunmer woman named Dinya Balu (who is also a priestess at the Temple of Mara), who is pregnant with her and Maramal’s first child.
As part of his duties, Briehl prepares and attends weddings held at the temple. His only possessions are the clothes he is wearing: a set of monk robes and a pair of boots. He has blond hair. He rarely leaves the temple, and has his own room there where he eats and sleeps. 
Quotes:
"This temple is dedicated to Mara, and the light of love she shines on us all. I'm only a humble acolyte, though. If you wish to avail yourself of Mara's blessing, you should speak with Dinya Balu or Maramal."
author: Bethesda

name: Brill
bio:
Brill is a Nord man who lives in Whiterun. He resides in Jorrvaskr (the headquarters of the Companions), but he is not a member of the Companions himself. He wears a set of farm clothes and boots. He is clean-shaven and bald-headed except for the brown hair at the sides of his head.
Brill is frequently seen in the company of Vignar Gray-Mane, to whom he owes a debt of gratitude after Vignar saved him from a troubled lifestyle. Brill sees Vignar as a father figure, and acts as his aide. Vignar and Brill can often heard be exchanging playful banter with each other, and clearly have a strong bond. 
If the Stormcloaks capture Whiterun, Brill will become the new steward of Dragonsreach.
Quotes:
"Ah, hello, my good friend. Would you do me a kindness? I seem to be down to my last drop of spirits; let me tell ya, sobriety is highly overrated."
"I'd be dead if not for Vignar. Took me in and helped me turn my life around."
"I had a bad time a few years back, and I turned to drink. But Vignar, he wouldn't let me stay weak."
If asked if he’s in the Companions: "Oh, I'm not a Companion, myself. I just help Vignar. He took me in when I was having a tough time, and... well, I owe him."
If asked who the Companions are: "To hear Vignar tell it, they're a bunch of layabouts and useless whiners who used to know how to fight. But he thinks everything used to be better. I, for one, would trust any Companion with my life."
If Brill has become the Steward at Dragonsreach: "When I became Steward, I had to give up the bottle. The people of the hold need me at my best. Vignar and I have our hands full. It's no small task, running an entire hold."
If Brill has become the Steward at Dragonsreach, and is asked how his new job is going: Well, it could be worse. The former steward, Proventus, kept very detailed records. But yes, it's been a lot of work. Vignar doesn't want the change to disrupt the lives of his people. They've got enough to deal with already."
author: Bethesda

name: Brina Merilis
bio:
Brina Merilis is a retired Imperial Legionnaire who resides in Dawnstar. She is an older Nord woman with white hair. She wears fine clothing, befitting a lady of the upper class.
Brina is a stern woman who tolerates no foolishness from those under her command. Brina does have a warm side that sometimes shows, but this is rarely seen due to the Skyrim Civil War, the re-emergence of dragons, the nightmares plaguing the citizens of Dawnstar recently, and other problems. When it comes to the recent return of the dragons, Brina is able to see how serious the problem is, unlike Jarl Skald, who simply believes that the dragons will vanish once the Empire is driven out. If the Imperial Legion takes control of Dawnstar, Brina will be named Jarl of The Pale, and will subsequently move to the White Hall (the Jarl's longhouse) in Dawnstar . If Brina becomes Jarl, she will prove to be a more respected ruler than Jarl Skald is, and will make preparations to address Dawnstar's vulnerabilities to dragon attacks. Brina is mentally flexible and open minded, acknowledging the flaws of the Empire which she supports. Brina sometimes talks to Madena (a middle-aged Breton woman who serves as Dawnstar’s court wizard) about Madena aiding the people of Dawnstar with her healing magic.
Contrary to the belief of some, Brina is originally from Cyrodiil, not Skyrim. Brina came to Skyrim during her service with the Imperial Legion. Once she joined the Legion, she became renowned throughout the Legion for her leadership and her tactical ability. During her time in the Legion, Brina met her man-at-arms and friend: a Nord named Horik Halfhand. Sometimes Brina remarks about how little Horik talks about himself. Horik has been at her side for the past 30 years, but sometimes Brina feels like she barely knows him. One thing Brina does know is that Horik’s parents died when he was young. Brina secretly has romantic feelings for Horik. 
After Brina retired from the Legion, she ended up in Dawnstar with Horik. The Jarl, Skald the Elder, does not trust her because of her history with the Empire, and accuses her of espionage on behalf of the Empire. However, most of the citizens of Dawnstar would rather go to Brina for guidance than go to the Jarl, and thus Brina is one of the most prominent citizens of Dawnstar. Frida, an old woman who is the town alchemist and who owns the Mortar and Pestle shop, has a particularly high level of respect for Brina.
If the Stormcloaks were to recapture Dawnstar after the Legion had first captured it from the Stormcloaks, Brina and Horik would be exiled by Skald and forced flee to Solitude.
Quotes:
"The Jarl and I have our disagreements. Sorry if you had to overhear one of them."
"Not a single man or woman in Dawnstar has gotten a good night's rest in days. We keep having the same nightmare, over and over. If people aren't tired, they're angry, and if they aren't angry, they're afraid. It's made keeping order a mess. I hear Mara has sent one of her priests to the inn to try to calm people down, but I don't know how much words will do now."
"Skald supports Ulfric's rebellion, and he doesn't like having a couple of old Legionnaires living in his town. He's a fool. A dragon has attacked Helgen. Dawnstar needs the Empire now more than ever."
"Stay out of trouble, now."
"You come to Dawnstar at a bad time. Tempers are... fiery."
"Horik and I have lived here ever since I retired. He's a good soldier."
"I wasn't born in Skyrim, but when I served in the Legion this land became my home."
If asked where to get a drink in Dawnstar: "Drowning your troubles in mead? A lot of folks are doing that these days. You'll want the Windpeak Inn.
If asked how to find work in Dawnstar: “You could try to catch Skald in a good mood, but your best bet would be working in the mines. The two mines are on opposite ends of town."
If she has become the Jarl: "You should see the grin on Horik's face now that we're in charge. I know he hides it, but I can tell."
If she has become the Jarl, and is asked whether Dawnstar is prepared for dragon attacks: "No. We're completely exposed. Bows and arrows are in short supply. Every building is made of thatch and wood. I've given standing orders to the guards to prepare water bucket runs to the harbor in case of a fire, but that's all we can do."
If she has become the Jarl, and is asked how the war is going: "The Empire has stretched itself too far. This rebellion in Skyrim is one problem, but solving it won't fix everything. But that's the kind of talk an old warhorse shouldn't be making. Don't worry. I have my problems with the Empire, but I'm still a soldier first. We'll keep peace and order in Dawnstar."
author: Bethesda

name: Britte
bio:
Britte is a Nord child and a resident of Rorikstead. Britte and her identical twin sister Sissel can be found running around the village. Their father Lemkil often complains about how little they help him with his farm. Britte’s mother died while giving birth to Britte and Sissel. Britte can be rather cruel, and often taunts her sister.
If Lemkil died, both Britte and her sister would both be sent to Honorhall Orphanage in Riften.
Quotes:
"Sissel thinks she's so special. No way she's more special than me."
"If you beat up my sister, Sissel, I won't tell."
"I'm the older sister, by nearly five minutes. Sissel's barely worthy to walk in my shadow."
author: Bethesda

name: Brond
bio:
Brond is a Nord warrior who can be encountered in the Windhelm Pit, where local criminals are pitted against each other in a gladiatorial arena. He wears hide armor and hide boots, and carries a steel greatsword, shield, Imperial bow, and 30 iron arrows.
Brond is among the fighters in the Windhelm Pit. According to him, he is a skilled fighter and has been fighting for a long time.
He is Huki's friend, Edorfin's rival, and Liesl's foe.
Quotes:
"I've been a lot of things in my life. Pit fighter's the one I'm best at."
"We should get a dragon for the Pit. I'd love to fight one."
"I've been fighting in the Pit for years. That should tell you something."
"There's two kinds of Pit fighters -- good ones and dead ones."
"Ulfric once tried to get me to fight for him, but marching bores me."
"Steel. Barehanded. Armor. Naked. It's all fighting. I can kill you with a weapon or by myself. No difference."
author: Bethesda

name: Brother Verulus
bio:
Brother Verulus, an Imperial man, is a priest of Arkay in Markarth. He wears a set of hooded monk robes. He tends to the Hall of the Dead within Understone Keep. He has recently been arguing with Thongvor Silver-Blood because Verulus has recently closed the public’s access to the Hall of the Dead. Verulus has done this because he’s recently been finding signs that someone has been sneaking into the Hall of the Dead and eating body parts of the recently deceased bodies within.
When the player first asks Brother Verulus if they can enter the Hall of the Dead, Verulus will simply say that the Hall of the Dead is currently closed. However, if the player continues to pursue this matter, Verulus may ask the player to investigate the mystery of who is eating the corpses within the mausoleum, explaining that flesh of the bodies has been chewed off, and that bones have been snapped to get at the marrow inside. He will then present the player with the key to the Hall of the Dead, and promise a reward from Priesthood of Arkay if the player succeeds at solving this issue.
Being a priest, Verulus knows a decent set of magical spells, including armor spells from the Alteration school and shock spells from the Destruction school. Most of all, he knows a multitude of healing, ward, and anti-undead spells from the Restoration school.
Quotes:
"New to Skyrim? I was confused at first, too. The Nords call their mausoleums the Hall of the Dead."
"Arkay protect you."
"Markarth is a city of wealth, but gold doesn't follow you in death."
"Arkay's blessing to you."
"Don't worry, Arkay's protection is absolute."
If asked about Arkay: "Arkay is one of the Eight Divines. God of the Cycle of Birth and Death. It is his shrine people pray to when they visit the Hall. That his divinity will watch over their ancestors on the way to the next life."
author: Bethesda

name: Brunwulf Free-Winter
bio:
Brunwulf Free-Winter is a Nord man and former soldier who lives on the east side of Windhelm. He wears scaled horn armor. He is bad and has a thick gray beard. He is considered to be a war hero due to his actions in the Great War against the Aldmeri Dominion, 30 years ago.
Brunwulf is in a romantic relationship with Elda Early-Dawn. Elda is the innkeeper at Candlehearth Hall, popular tavern and inn in the center of the city. Brunwulf sometimes talks to Elda about building a log cabin for the two of them to live in, in a clear spot in the middle of a forested area just to the west of Riften.
Brunwulf is known for standing up for the Dunmer and Argonians in the city, and thus openly goes against the opinions of some of his fellow Nords in Windhelm. Susanna (ironically nicknamed “Susanna the Wicked”), who is a barmaid working at Candlehearth Hall, also shares Brunwulf’s compassion for outsiders. Men such as Rolff Stone-Fist and Angrenor Once-Honored do not share Brunwulf’s compassion for outsiders, verbally harassing Dunmer in the city and accusing them of spying on behalf of the Empire. Windhelm and the Stormcloak army are at war with the Empire in an attempt to achieve the independence of Skyrim from the Empire. If the player is a Khajiit, Brunwulf may refer to the them as “cat”, and if the player is an Argonian, Brunwulf may refer to the player as “lizard”, but it is clear that Brunwulf does not consider either of these terms to be an insult.
Brunwulf has a low tolerance for racism and foolishness. If the player expresses the opinion that non-Nords shouldn’t be allowed to live in Skyrim, Brunwulf will respond with "Is that so? You ought to join the Stormcloaks, if you haven't already. Seems to me they're a bunch of narrow-minded bigots, just like you. Meantime, you best steer clear of me."
Brunwulf’s outspoken beliefs have gained him respect by many of the Dunmer in Windhelm, such as the pawnbroker Malthyr Elenil. Some of them, like the merchant Aval Atheron, offer him discounts on their goods because of this, but Brunwulf insists on paying the same price as everyone else. 
Brunwulf prefers not to talk about his experiences as a solider in the Great War against the Aldmeri Dominion, which ended just over 25 years ago.
If Imperial Legion takes control of Windhelm and kills Ulfric Stormcloak, Brunwulf will be appointed the new Jarl of Eastmarch. If this happens, Brunwulf will try to take steps to make the Nords be more accepting of the Dunmer and Argonians in Windhelm, although this may take a long time. Because of this, Brunwulf will decide to keep the Argonians segregated from the main city of Windhelm until those Nords there can learn to accept living amongst them. He will also plan with the Dunmer to renovate the Gray Quarter (where the Dunmer in Windhelm live), but actually funding these planned renovations will prove very difficult due to the current lack of resources.
If the Imperial Legion takes control of Winterhold, then Jarl Korir of Winterhold (along with his wife Thaena, and their son Assur) will take refuge at Brunwulf’s house, where Brunwulf will allow them to stay indefinitely. 
Brunwulf may try to enlist the player’s help with an problem that’s been bothering him, stating "Whenever a group of marauders attack a Nord village, Ulfric is the first to sound the horn and send the men. But a group of Dark Elf refugees gets ambushed? A group of Argonians, or a Khajiit caravan? No troops. No investigation. Nothing. There's a group of cutthroats out there right now that Ulfric doesn't lift a finger to bring to justice, as long as they don't threaten Nord land.” If the player responds with a willingness to help deal with the cutthroats Brunwulf mentioned, Brunwulf will ask the player to kill the bandit leader hiding at one of the following locations (chosen at random): Cragslane Cavern, Gallows Rock, Lost Knife Hideout, Stony Creek Cave or Uttering Hills Cave. If the player later reports back to Brunwulf that they have killed this bandit leader, Brunwulf will reward them with both gold and a valuable lesson in the use of Heavy Armor, saying "Now that's good work. Everyone will be a lot safer with them gone, Dark Elf and Nord alike. Here, some gold as promised, and let me show you a bit about wearing heavy armor. Save you some aches on a long march."
Quotes:
"There's no glory in war. It's just something they tell soldiers so they'll risk their lives."
"The Dark Elves live in a run-down slum called the Gray Quarter. Ulfric's content to keep it that way. I guess they think I can open Ulfric's eyes to their plight, and get him to lift a finger on their behalf. I'm trying, but Ulfric is set in his ways. For him, there's two kinds of people in this world -- Nords, and the folk beneath them."
"May the gods watch over your battles, friend."
"They call me a war hero. I'm no hero, I'm just a soldier who didn't want to die."
If asked why people call him a war hero: "I killed a lot of High Elves in the Great War, and I didn't die. I guess that makes me a war hero. The 'Great War'... there was nothing great about it. Thousands died on both sides and where did we end up? Did we really save the Empire or did we just plant the seeds for Ulfric's uprising and another war?"
If Brunwulf has become the Jarl: "The dark elves and Argonians won't soon forget Ulfric's prejudice, but I'm doing what I can to repair that rift. Being a Jarl isn't something I ever wanted, but if I can help these people, then I will."
If Brunwulf has become the Jarl, and is asked how his new position is going: "Every day is a struggle, but a Nord doesn't back down from a fight when the cause is honorable. I just wish things were simpler. In my days as a soldier, I knew who the enemy was, and how to defeat him. Unfortunately, a sword can't repair damaged buildings, feed hungry people or undo years of prejudice."
author: Bethesda

name: Bryling
bio:
Bryling is a Thane of Solitude.
She is a proud Nord woman who is nearing middle age. She has amber eyes. She usually keeps her slightly graying brown hair tied up. She typically wears an upper-class outfit consisting of a fur-trimmed cloak, fine armguards, pleated shoes, and a copper and moonstone circlet. She carries a steel dagger for self-defense.
The manor where Bryling lives is located just outside the Blue Palace, near the Bards College. Bryling is an important thane and her house reflects this, containing many valuable items and an extensive library.
Bryling can often be found having conversations with members of the Court, including Falk Firebeard, the Steward of Solitude. One of her duties is overseeing the collection of rental payments and taxes from business owners in the city, such as the Altmer twin sisters Endarie and Taarie who own the Radiant Raiment tailor shop near the city's main gate.
Bryling owns the settlement of Stonehills, a small mining camp in Hjaalmarch hold, where the inhabitants work in the nearby Rockwallow Mine. Bryling is the proprietor of this mine. A Nord man named Pactur co-manages the mine with his wife Sorli. Pactur and Sorli have a young adult son named Sirgar, and they have been training Sirgar to be able to manage the mine after they retire. Sorli and Pactur ship the ore from the mine to Bryling in Solitude, although they've recently been having problems with the shipping of the ore. Bryling has not heard from Sorli and Pactur for an unusually long time.
Solitude is the capital of Haafingar hold, as well as the provincial capital over all of Skyrim. Jarl Elisif the Fair has been the ruler of Haafingar ever since her husband King Torygg was killed by Ulfric Stormcloak.
When speaking to Jarl Elisif, Bryling often expresses her concern that the war against the Stormcloaks is draining too many guards and soldiers to the borders of Haafingar, leaving the interior of the hold with insufficient troops to secure against bandits and other internal threats. Despite supporting the Empire, Bryling respects the determination of the Stormcloaks rebels.
Bryling is served by her housecarl Irnskar Ironhand, a loyal man who often guards Bryling's manor when she is at the Solitude court during the day.
Bryling does not get along with Erikur, a fellow thane of the Solitude court. Erikur claims that Bryling is too obsessed with tradition and honor. Bryling considers Erikur to be a pampered fool who has never gone hungry or had to actually work a single day in his life, and who personally benefits from enriching the Empire and the expense of Skyrim's people.
Bryling is in a secret romantic relationship with Falk Firebeard. If asked about her relationship to Falk, Bryling will deny that there is any romantic involvement between the two of them. Bryling feels the need to keep her relationship with Falk a secret, because Falk might be forced to resign from his position as the court steward if people were to find out about his relationship with a Thane. Falk has told Bryling that once the war is over, he will be willing to resign his position as steward in order to openly be with her. Bryling is also worried that Sybille Stentor has discovered the truth about their secret relationship. Sybille is a Breton woman who has been Solitude's court mage for a long time, despite still appearing relatively young.
Quotes:
"Thane Bryling, at your service."
"I can always find time to share a word with a warrior."
"This gods-forsaken war is dividing our people and destroying our land."
"I support the Empire, as we all do here. However, I fear General Tullius is underestimating the Stormcloaks. Too often the general has lost good soldiers because he did not take Ulfric and his men seriously. If this continues, and the worst comes to pass, Solitude will pay the price. The Empire is headquartered here, after all."
"The Stormcloaks only rebel because the Empire uses Skyrim as its personal larder. The more they take, the more support the rebels gain!"
"Our borders are secure, but at the cost of the guards for our towns and roads."
"The Stormcloaks are far from the only threat to the hold. The roads are beset by bandits and beasts... and now there's even talk of bloody dragons."
"Trouble on the roads and cities means less commerce. Less commerce means less money and more starving people. And that means more crime."
"Many condemn the Stormcloaks, but I refuse. There is honor in fighting for what you believe."
When the conversation is drawing to a close: "It's been an honor. I'll get back to court business, then."
author: Bethesda

name: Brynjolf
bio:
Brynjolf, a Nord man, is an important member of the Thieves Guild in Riften. Brynjolf is currently the second-in-command at the Thieves Guild, below only Mercer Frey (the current Guildmaster). Brynjolf wears fine boots, fine clothes, the Amulet of Articulation (which magically increases the wearer’s ability to persuade others), and he carries two daggers. He had red shoulder-length hair.
If Brynjolf meets the player on the streets of Riften, he will direct them to the Ratway, the underground tunnel system underneath Riften, explaining that there is a tavern there called The Ragged Flagon, and states that if the player can make their way to the Flagon, they can join the Thieves Guild.
Once the player reaches the Flagon, Brynjolf will be impressed, and as a further initiation test before joining the Thieves Guild, Brynjolf will ask the player to collect some debts owed to him from several of the shopkeepers and business managers in Riften, namely Keerava (an Argonian woman who runs The Bee and Barb inn), Haelga (a Nord woman who runs The Bunkhouse worker lodging facility and who is known for her Dibella worship and sexual promiscuity), and Bersi Honey-Hand (a Nord man who runs The Pawned Prawn general store). After these debts have been collected, Brynjolf will then introduce the player to Mercer Frey, the Guildmaster, and officially induct the player into the Thieves Guild.
Vex, a prominent thieves guild member, recently failed in her attempt to infiltrate Goldenglow Estate, a honey farm owned by Aringoth which is located on a group of small islands in Lake Honrich, to the west of Riften. Maven Blackbriar, the matriarch of the most influential family in Riften, is a major client of the Thieves Guild, and has hired the guild to infiltrate the estate. Maven contracts Goldenglow with supplying the honey for her Blackbriar Meadery, but Aringoth has recently hired mercenaries to guard the honey farm and has abruptly stopped doing business with Maven. Brynjolf may ask the player to perform the task of infiltrating Goldenglow Estate and find out why Aringoth has been doing this.
Brynjolf will help the player by providing information and advice for future thieving jobs. He seems to care for the other Thieves Guild members, like Vex (an Imperial woman whose hair is white despite Vex not being particularly old), Delvin (a Breton man), Sapphire (a Nord woman) and many others. There is a rumor going around that Tonilia (a Redguard woman who isn’t officially in the Thieves Guild but works closely with them) has been cheating on her boyfriend Vekel (who owns and operates The Ragged Flagon tavern) with Brynjolf, but there isn’t any truth to this rumor, and both Brynjolf and Tonilia will firmly deny any romantic or sexual relationship between them if asked. 
Brynjolf can often found wandering around the Thieves Guild’s cistern and the Flagon.
If Mercer Frey dies or is removed from his position as guildmaster of the Thieves Guild, and if the player has completed important thieving jobs that significantly increase the guild’s influence in the cities of Whiterun, Markarth, Windhelm, and Solitude, Brynjolf will nominate the player to be the next guildmaster, and will also reward them with the Amulet of Articulation.
Brynjolf seems to be fond of children, since children living in Riften sometimes mention Brynjolf giving them treats and promising to teach them "neat things" when they grow older.
Quotes:
“Ready to make some coin?"
If the player asks about an old man hiding in Riften: “Your guy's hiding out in the Ratway Warrens and paying us good coin for nobody to know about it. Well, until now that is.”
“My organization's been having a run of bad luck, but I suppose that's just how it goes. But never mind that, you did the job and you did it well. Best of all, there's more where that came from... if you think you can handle it. The group I represent has its home in the Ratway beneath Riften... a tavern called the Ragged Flagon. Get there in one piece and we'll see if you've really got what it takes."
“Honestly, the debt is secondary here. What's more important is that you get the message across that we aren't to be ignored. A word of warning though... I don't want any of them killed. Bad for business."
If asked about Bersi: "Bersi is as pig-headed a man as you'll ever find. The key is that ugly dwarven urn in his shop. Smash that thing to bits and he'll change his attitude."
If asked about Keerava: "Keerava's stubborn, but she's got a soft spot for family. Talk to Talen-Jei at the Bee and Barb and see if you can get something out of him. They're… well acquainted, if you catch my meaning."
If asked about Haelga: "Haelga is a devout follower of Dibella and dotes over the statue to the Divine that she keeps at the Bunkhouse. Use it as leverage and she'll cave."
After the player has officially joined the Thieves Guild: "Welcome to the family. I'm expecting you to make us a lot of coin, so don't disappoint me."
If talking about the Goldenglow Estate infiltration job: “The Guild depends on an arrangement of influential people to keep things running smoothly. Without them at our backs, we'd be in serious trouble. Maven prefers that Aringoth remains alive, but if he tries to stop you from getting the job done, kill him. The Guild has a lot riding on this. Don't make me look foolish by mucking it up."
author: Bethesda

name: Bujold the Unworthy
bio:
Bujold is the chieftain of Thirsk Mead Hall. She is a Nord woman with amber eyes and blonde hair that she usually keeps tucked into her leather helmet. She wears a full set of leather armor and wields a Nordic war axe.
Bujold's husband Kuvar and her younger sister Hilund are also members of the Thirsk Mead Hall group. Other members of the group include Elmus (he's in charge of brewing the mead), Halbarn Iron-Fur (he's their blacksmith), a man named Sirkjorg, and a woman named Herkja.
Bujold and her group live on Solstheim, an island north of Morrowind in the icy Sea of Ghosts. While the Dark Elves technically rule over the island now, some Nords still live there, as their ancestors have since ancient times.
Bujold and her group of Nords can originally be found at the Bujold's Retreat camp along the eastern shore of Solstheim, south of the Skaal village. Bujold's group were recently forced to retreat from Thirsk Mead Hall by a large raiding group of Rieklings (blue-skinned ice Goblins). Kuvar in particular has had difficulty dealing with the shame of being overwhelmed by these Rieklings, and Bujold often argues with him. If offered assistance by the player, Bujold will rally her fellow Nord warriors to take their mead hall back from the Rieklings.
Bujold will be grateful if the Dragonborn breaks the mysterious mind-controlling spell that compels Bujold and the other Thirsk members to wake up in the middle of the night and mindlessly build a strange shrine-like structure around the Beast Stone, one of the six All-Maker stones on Solstheim.
After the Rieklings and their chief have been slain, Bujold will ask the player to accompany her to Hrothmund's Barrow. Hundreds of years ago, Hrothmund the Red was a Skaal villager who founded Thirsk Mead Hall in order to establish a distinct way of life centered around emulating the ancient Nord warriors. Bujold hopes to cement the legitimacy of her leadership by receiving the blessing of Hrothmund, whose disembodied spirit still lingers in his tomb. However, if Hrothmund's spirit refuses to re-grant her leadership of Thirsk, Bujold plans to defy Hrothmund's wishes and continue leading the group, and to also claim to the other members that Hrothmund actually did grant his blessing, since the others would not follow Bujold if they knew that Hrothmund's spirit rejected her. After visiting Hrothmund's Barrow, Bujold will change her title, going from "Bujold the Unworthy" to "Bujold the Intrepid." If the player agrees to keep Bujold's white lie a secret from the other mead hall members, she will be grateful. However, if the player indicates an intention to betray Bujold's secret to the others, she will be offended and become hostile, and will then try to kill the player in order to maintain her secret and her rightful position of leadership of Thirsk.
Quotes:
When first meeting her at Bujold's Retreat: "Come to mock our shame, like the others? Yes, this camp is small, but it's all we have left. Unless you can help, leave us in peace."
If at Bujold's Retreat and asked why they are camped there: "We've been kicked out of our home. The mead hall, up there on the hill. We were... some Rieklings have taken it over. They overpowered us with tenacity and numbers. Didn't help that we'd grown a little too comfortable up there. Too much mead. Too many stories. Too few battles. We've just got a bit of an infestation, is all. Down here to catch our breath, and then we'll be back in the hall once I get the rest of these up to move."
When addressing her group at Bujold's Retreat after the player offers to help with Rieklings: "Hey, you lazy milk-drinkers, get over here! I know you're all starting to settle in here, and keep up the fat lives you got used to up in the hall. But look here. This outsider has more fire than any of you. All I had to do was mention our little infestation, and they volunteered in a second! I don't want to have my spirit outstripped by some wanderer. So let's get up there and kill us some Rieklings!"
After the Rieklings at Thirsk Mead Hall are killed: "Do you want to come with me to Hrothmund's Barrow? I need to get his blessing again before we take up residence here."
"Good to finally be getting some sleep at night. Things are bad enough without everyone around here looking death-eyed, too."
"Thanks for having my back, friend."
If Hrothmund's spirit doesn't give Bujold his blessing at Hrothmund's Barrow: "Well, he's dead and we're alive. It's time to begin a new tradition for Thirsk. And I'm going to do that. All I need is for you to back me up. You don't even need to lie... just don't tell anyone else what you heard here."
author: Bethesda

name: Bulfrek
bio:
Bulfrek is a Nord man living in Dawnstar who works as a servant to Jarl Skald the Elder at The White Hall. He has dark hair and a thin beard. Bulfrek’s family have been serving the rulers of The Pale for generations. He wears a belted tunic.
Bulfrek is resentful regarding Skald's lack of respect towards him. Skald will often poke fun at Bulfrek, mocking Bulfrek's ambitions to join the Stormcloaks, and giving Bulfrek tedious and frivolous tasks like polishing entire bundles of freshly made weapons. Bulfrek can often be found sweeping the floor while making comments about his dislike for Skald under his breath. 
If the Imperial Legion takes control of Dawnstar during the course of the Skyrim Civil War, Bulfrek will be forced to join Skald in fleeing Dawnstar and taking refuge in the Palace of Kings in Windhelm. 
Quotes:
"There's no honor in being a Jarl's servant. No Sovngarde waits for the dust cleaners."
"My family has served Skald Felgeif's family for generations."
"By the Divines, I'm tired."
"I’m just a servant of Skald the Elder. Not worthy of time or consideration."
"Oh it's just wonderful being Skald's servant. He's not demanding in the least..."
author: Bethesda

name: Cairine
bio:
Cairine, a Breton woman, is a resident of The Warrens in Markarth. She has light-brown hair. She wears ragged robes and ragged boots. The Warrens is where the extreme lower-class citizens of Markarth reside: the miners and smelters, the sick and the lame.
Cairine does not have her own room in The Warrens. She is currently afflicted with a debilitating illness, possibly Rattles or Ataxia. She can often be found sitting on the ground, clutching her ribs in pain. Cairine used to work at the smelter in Markarth, but is now too sick to do so.
If the player is a vampire and turns Cairine into a vampire, Cairine will be very grateful to the player, saying “Great gift of blood you've given me. Blood that boils in my veins. Gives me strength. You can use my coffin whenever you like.”
Quotes:
"You don't want to be here. No one wants to."
“Don't know anyone here who doesn't have Rattles or Ataxia."
author: Bethesda

name: Calcelmo
bio:
Calcelmo is an elderly Altmer man who can be found in Understone Keep in Markarth. His nephew Aicantar helps him in the laboratory. Understone Keep is an ancient Dwemer keep built into the mountainside, used as a palace by the Jarl of Markarth. Calcelmo has a great interest in the ancient Dwemer race and is the author of many scholarly works about them. The Dwemer are sometimes colloquially referred to as the “Dwarves”, despite the evidence that they were on average no shorter than the average modern human.
Calcelmo owns the Dwemer Museum located within Understone Keep. He has been excavating the Dwemer ruin of Nchuand-Zel, the main entrance to which is also inside Understone Keep, on the opposite side of the structure from the Dwemer Museum. As a scholar of Dwemer history and culture, Calcelmo has written several books about the Dwemer, including three volumes of a popular work titled “Dwarves”. Calcelmo is also is an expert on the ancient Falmer (also called the Snow Elves), having deciphered most of their language.
Calcelmo will often be interested in buying Dwemer/Dwarven weapons, Dwemer/Dwarven armor pieces, and other Dwemer/Dwarven items from anyone who brings them to him.
In addition to selling general mage goods (robes, soul gems, spell tomes, etc.), Calcelmo also sells Dwarves, v1, v2, and v3, as he is the author of these books.
Calcelmo insists to his nephew Aicantar that he must join him for the next excavation season, believing Aicantar to be a vital part of his research team. Despite this, Calcelmo will sometimes be busy in thought and get annoyed at Aicantar for speaking while he’s trying to think.
Nimhe is a large Frostbite Spider lurking within Nchuand-Zel that is inhibiting the progress of Calcelmo’s excavation efforts there. Nimhe is the reason that the excavation site is currently closed, and Calcelmo is desperate to hire someone to kill this giant spider so that the excavation efforts can resume. The entrance to Nchuand-Zel is currently locked, and Calcelmo will only give the player a key to entrance of Nchuand-Zel if the player agrees to perform the task of killing Nimhe. If the player successfully kills Nimhe, Calcelmo will give them the keys to the Dwemer museum as a reward. 
Calcelmo is expecting to be delivered a custom-made ring from a Redguard woman named Kerah, who sells the jewelry that she and her husband Endon make in the Markarth marketplace, near the entrance to the city.
Calcelmo is secretly in love with a Redguard woman named Faleen, who serves as a Housecarl to Jarl Igmund in Understone Keep.
Quotes:
"What are you doing here? The excavation site is closed. I don't need any more workers or guards. Why do you people always bother me when I'm trying to finish my research? You idiot. Do you even know who I am? The most recognized scholar on the Dwemer in all of Tamriel, and you people keep bothering me! I... I'm sorry I... I got too excited. I'm in the middle of some very... stressful work, and I shouldn't have yelled. How can I help you?"
"I have things to study, what is it?"
"The artifacts I've discovered in Nchuand-Zel will make history one day."
"I used to travel so much before all this Forsworn nonsense. Such an inconvenience..."
"Look, I'm very busy, so this better be important."
If the player mentions the Dwemer Museum: "I own the Dwemer Museum. It's a private place where I can catalog my research. Occasionally, the Jarl will come in and have questions, but that's thankfully rare. I'll let you in if you agree to something for me. There's a giant spider in Nchuand-Zel. My workers call her "Nimhe," the poisoned one. If you deal with Nimhe, I'll let you into both the excavation site and my Dwemer Museum. What do you say?"
If the player says that they have killed Nimhe: "You have my gratitude. That spider had been interfering with my excavations for months. As promised, here's the key to the Dwemer Museum. Mind the displays. Some of them are quite fragile."
