If asked if he is researching the Dwemer: "Yes. Their history and culture is all around us in Markarth. A race of stonecutters, artisans, and engineers. They invented machines and built elaborate underground cities where they researched powers to rival the gods themselves. And then, at a time we are still not sure when, they disappeared. The whole people, all at once. Leaving behind only their works."
If asked why he needs guards: “To protect my research, for one. There are more cutthroat scholars out there who would steal my findings if they got the chance. And the excavations into Nchuand-Zel are dangerous. Dwemer machines and traps still function even after thousands of years.”
If the player alludes to Calcelmo’s extensive knowledge of the ancient Falmer: “You are well informed. I am at this very moment on the cusp of completing my magnum opus on the ancient Falmer. I'm calling it 'Calcelmo's Guide to the Falmer Tongue'. It will revolutionize the way we understand those ancient beings."
If the player asks to view Calcelmo’s work on the ancient Falmer: "Preposterous! That research represents years of personal toil in some of the most dangerous Dwemer ruins in Skyrim! You must be mad to think I'd allow anyone to see it before it's completed. Perhaps when my research is complete, I'll feel more comfortable discussing my findings with you."
If the player only wants to buy spells from Calcelmo: "Magic. That's what they always want. Never history. Never the secrets of the lost races. No, just little spells and enchantments."
author: Bethesda

name: Calder
bio:
Calder is a Nord man from Windhelm who has been appointed to serve as the player's housecarl. He has red hair. The Jarl has bestowed the title of Thane upon the player, allowing them to purchase the Hjerim residential property in Windhelm. If not following the player on their adventures, Calder will reside at the player's Hjerim residence. He will guards and maintain this house while the player is away.
Calder wears a set of steel armor, a pair of steel Nordic gauntlets, and a pair of steel cuffed boots. He is equipped with a steel war axe and a steel shield. He also uses a hunting bow and iron arrows for long-distance combat. He will be willing to wear higher quality equipment if they are provided to him.
If the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse) and asks Calder to marry them, Calder will accept their marriage proposal.
When Calder speaks, especially during combat, he often incorporates references to Nordic deities like Shor, Nordic legendary figures such as Ysmir, and the realm of Sovngarde.
Quotes:
"Long life to you, Thane."
"I am your sword and shield."
"Honor to you, my Thane."
"As you will, my Thane. I will protect you with my life."
If the player asks him to carry pieces of equipment or other items: “I am sworn to carry your burdens.”
When approaching a Nordic ruin: "Look at these stones. Our ancestors knew how to build, no doubt."
When approaching a cave: "There's a cave. Animals or bandits inside, no doubt."
When approaching a Dwemer ruin: “Get nervous around Dwarven stonework. Legends say that these cities are haunted."
If the player uses a courage Illusion spell on Calder: "By Ysmir, I feel... invincible!"
If Calder is asked to return to Hjerim: "I'm heading back to your house if you need me, my Thane."
author: Bethesda

name: Calixto Corrium
bio:
Calixto Corrium is an Imperial man who lives in Windhelm. He has gray hair, and wears merchant-style attire. As the owner of Calixto's House of Curiosities, he offers tours of the items he and his sister collected during their travels in Tamriel. Calixto also lives and sleeps inside his House of Curiosities. 
Years ago, Calixto and his sister Lucilla inherited a fair amount of money. Using their newfound financial security to travel across Tamriel, they collected several rare items on the journeys, such as The Book of Fate, The Dancer's Flute, and Ysgramor's Soup Spoon. Unfortunately, Calixto’s sister died during this time, and so after settling in Windhelm, he opened a curiosity shop in her name to display their collection.
Calixto is a relatively jovial man, happily proclaiming for all to visit the House of Curiosities for their enjoyment. He appears to enjoy displaying his collection, saying that he believes his sister would be proud to bring smiles to visitors. The Windhelm guards also seem to respect him to a degree, saying that he "has a good eye" for strange trinkets.
While in his House of Curiosities, Calixto offers tours of the trinkets he and his sister collected, for the price of 2 gold. When showing The Book of Fate display, Calixto will claim that it displays the destiny of those who read it. He will then direct the player to the display of Ysgramor's soup spoon, where he will remark that it is indeed a fork, but that this did not stop Ysgramor from using it. He will next show them The Dancer's Flute, which he will say has destroyed empires and won wars, claiming that it will force those around to dance uncontrollably, although he will stop short of activating it. The tour completes after this.
Secretly, the grief of losing his sister was too much for Calixto to bear, and he has secretly begun to lead a life of necromancy in hopes of resurrecting Lucilla, which has involved the murder of several young women in Windhelm. The basis for this ritual appears to be of Aldmeri origin, and was then interpreted by the Ayleids and first transcribed by the Altmer. To help this, he authored a journal in three parts, which describe the exact elements needed for the magic to work, and for this purpose, he acquired the Necromancer's Amulet and Nordic embalming tools to use on his murder victims. 
Calixto’s second victim in the necromantic ritual was Friga Shatter-Shield, the twin sister of Nilsine and the daughter of Torbjorn and Tova. Murdering Friga gave Calixto access to her residential property of Hjerim, which he has since been using for his ritual. Calixto then planned to kill Susanna the Wicked (an ironically named beloved barmaid who works at the Candlehearth Hall near the center of Windhelm), believing her tendons to be of exquisite quality, and came close to being able to murder her before being thwarted by the appearance of guards. The government and people of Windhelm is aware that there is a serial killer in their city, and have nicknamed the killer "the Butcher”. And older Imperial woman named Viola Giordano has posted letters all throughout the city in order to warn the people of Windhelm about The Butcher. Calixto has secretly removed most of these posted letters so that they do not hinder his efforts.
In his secret journals, Calixto criticizes the mages at the College of Winterhold, considering them to be complacent and lacking innovation. Calixto secretly glamorizes the possible innovations of necromancy. He also appears to secretly have little respect for the city of Windhelm in general, calling the guards "idiots" and describing portions of the city and its populace as "rugged bits” in his journals. Calixto is completely devoted to the necromantic ritual, to the point of showing little to no remorse for murdering women. His devotion appears to come from his strong relationship with his sister, whom he loved dearly, and whom he describes as someone who loved the world so much while he did not. Calixto considers his actions to be righteous, believing that the women he has murdered "would surely thank me for the great gift I give them."
Calixto will never admit to secretly being The Butcher who is responsible for the string of murders in Windhelm, nor admit to practicing necromancy in an attempt to resurrect his dead sister Lucilla. If Calixto is questioned by anyone investigating the scene of one of the murdered women, Calixto will lie and claim that he was there to witness the murderer run away, but say little else. If someone brings a strange amulet with a skull on it to Calixto (secretly the Necromancer’s Amulet), Calixto will lie and claim the amulet to be a ceremonial Wheelstone, and that it belongs to Wuunferth the Unliving, the court mage on Windhelm. After lying by claiming that Wuunferth dabbled in necromancy before serving the Jarl, Calixto will request to buy the amulet for 500 gold.
Quotes:
"My sister and I once traveled the world to assemble our collection. Such adventures we had!"
If inside his house: "Welcome to the House of Curiosities! I offer a brief tour for a few coins, or you can simply browse at your leisure."
If he is asked how he assembled his collection: “My sister and I inherited a modest sum of money. We decided to travel and seek out whatever adventures we could find. As we journeyed across Tamriel, we encountered tales of exotic and wondrous artifacts. We decided to collect as many as we could. My sister passed away some years ago, so I settled down here and opened the House of Curiosities. I think she would be happy to know that our collection has brought smiles to faces both young and old.”
If someone asks for a tour of his collection while inside his house: "Indeed! For a few septims, I'll tell you about some of the most interesting curiosities in my collection.”
If he is given 2 gold to pay for the tour of his collection: “Splendid! If you'll just follow me, I'll tell you tales and show you wonders such as you've never seen."
author: Bethesda

name: Camilla Valerius
bio:
Camilla Valerius, a young Imperial woman, lives in Riverwood with her older brother Lucan. Lucan runs the Riverwood Trader general goods store on the first floor of the building, and they eat and sleep on the second floor of the building. Camilla helps her brother run the store.
Camilla has dark brown hair. She usually wears a belted tunic. She often spends her evenings at the Sleeping Giant Inn, a short distance north of her home.
Camilla seeks more excitement from the Riverwood Trader’s business than her brother does. While Lucan seems content to keep selling the same things to the same people, Camilla is always thinking of ways to expand their business to new types of goods and new customers.
Riverwood is located at the southeastern tip of Whiterun Hold, just north of the boundary between Whiterun Hold and Falkreath Hold. The White River flows along the west side of the town. The Throat of the World (the tallest mountain in all of Tamriel) towers over the town from the east. Bleak Falls Barrow, an old Nordic temple ruin in the snow-laden Brittleshin Hills (a small mountain range that divides Whiterun Hold to the north from Falkreath Hold to the south), stands out prominently above Riverwood to its west. The Riverwood Trader is located on the east side of the town's main road, across the street from the house of Alvor. Alvor is the town's blacksmith, and has a wife named Sigrid and a young daughter named Dorthe.
A Nord woman named Gerdur is the de facto leader of Riverwood. She and her husband Hod own and operate Riverwood's lumber mill. They have a young son named Frodnar. Hod and Gerdur’s house is visible from Lucan and Camilla’s backyard.
Recently, a rare artifact called the Golden Claw was stolen from Lucan and Camilla. The suspected culprits are the bandits hiding at Bleak Falls Barrow. Camilla has been arguing with Lucan because she wants to go out trying to retrieve the claw, while Lucan refuses to let her endanger herself. If the player offers to retrieve the claw, Camilla will excitedly show them to the stone bridge at the north edge of Riverwood before she heads back to the store. If the player is successful in returning the Golden Claw, Camilla will be very grateful and will consider the player a good friend.
Camilla is a flirtatious woman, and if the player is a man, there is a strong chance she will flirt with him at some point while conversing with him. If the player is a woman, Camilla may feel threatened, since Camilla enjoys being the focus of attention and attraction for Riverwood's men.
Two men in particular are currently vying for Camilla's affection: Faendal (a Bosmer man who works as a hunter and woodcutter) and Sven (a Nord man who is a trained bard). Both of them live in Riverwood. The player can help Camilla decide which man she should choose to marry. Alternatively, the player may romantically pursue Camilla themself. If Camilla considers the player to be a good friend, and if the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse), Camilla will happily accept a marriage proposal from the player.
If Camilla marries the player, they can either live together at the Riverwood Trader, or move into another home if the player owns one. If they move to another city or town, Camilla will open up her own shop there and give her spouse 100 gold from the shop’s profits, daily.
Quotes:
"I came here from the Imperial province, to work with my brother Lucan."
"It got bad back in Cyrodiil. The war with the Thalmor ruined...everything."
"I just want to find a good husband, and start a family of my own."
“Maybe you can talk some sense into my pig-headed brother."
"I came to Skyrim looking for a better life. So what did I get? Another war."
If she is told that she needs to hurry up and decide which man to marry: "It's bad enough my brother is harping on me to pick one. Don't you start too."
If asked about the bandits at Bleak Falls Barrow: "Those thieves must be mad, hiding out there. Those old crypts are filled with nothing but traps, trolls, and who knows what else! I wonder why they only stole Lucan's golden claw. I mean, we have plenty of things in the shop that are worth just as much coin. Lucan found the claw about a year after he opened the store. He never quite explained where he got it. He's a tricky one."
If the player is a man: “You’re a strapping young man! Don't be a stranger."
If the player is a woman: "The men here like my attention, and I like theirs. Best know your place."
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Aldis
bio:
Captain Aldis, a Nord man, is the captain of the guard in Solitude. Aldis employs a rigorous schedule, supervising the training of Imperial soldiers in the Castle Dour courtyard from dawn till dusk each day, after which he returns to the castle until the next morning. 
Aldis wears Solitude Guard armor, with Imperial bracers and Imperial boots. He carries a Solitude guard's shield, an iron greatsword, an Imperial bow, and steel arrows. He has long dark brown hair and a beard.
Captain Aldis presided over Roggvir's public execution, with the executioner Ahtar delivering the killing blow. Roggvir was executed for opening the Solitude gate in order to allow Ulfric Stormcloak to escape the city. Just prior to fleeing Solitude, Ulfric had entered the Blue Palace, challenged the young King Torygg (the High King of Skyrim) to a duel, and killed him. Ulfric apparently killed Torygg using the ancient Nord power of the Thu’um (also called The Voice). Before Roggvir was executed, Roggvir expressed the belief that Ulfric had done nothing wrong and that he had simply been following Nord customs, which is why he decided to raise the gate to allow Ulfric to escape from the city. Despite believing that Roggvir deserved to be executed for allowing Ulfric to escape, Aldis still considers Roggvir to have been a fine and honorable man.
Captain Aldis may ask the player  to find a copy of a book called “The Mirror”, for use in training his soldiers on how to use a shield. 
Captain Aldis is aware of the recent decent death of Fura Morrard, a private in the Imperial Legion. Fura was the daughter of Angeline Morrard, an old Breton woman who owns the Angeline’s Aromatics alchemy shop in Solitude. Aldis has not yet had chance to tell Angeline about Fura’s death. If the player asks Aldis if he has heard any news about Fura, Aldis will say "Generally, posting information is need to know only." If the player persists in asking about Fura on behalf of Angeline, Aldis will say “I... I've been trying to find the time and place to let her know. Her daughter was sent to Whiterun- the skirmishes there have been violent. The Whiterun legate needed to know the Stormcloak positions. He sent out a party to scout the area. They happened upon a large force... I'm told none of them made it back. Private Morrard... Angeline’s daughter was in that scouting party. She needs to be told".
Before the outbreak of the Civil War, Aldis had a discussion with Gorm about potentially overthrowing Jarl Idgrod Ravencrone of Hjaalmarch. Gorm is a Nord man living in Morthal who serves as Jarl Idgrod’s bodyguard, and who worries that Idgrod is mentally unstable and unfit to rule the Hjaalmarch hold due to her claims that she receives supernatural visions and premonitions. While Aldis is sympathetic to Gorm’s concerns, Aldis doesn’t consider the overthrow and replacement of Jarl Idgrod to be a good idea while the war is still going on, especially since Idgrod supports the Empire over the Stormcloaks.
Aldis is of the firm belief that Ulfric and the Stormcloaks are traitors who deserve to die. If the player expresses support for Ulfric or the Stormcloaks, Aldis will be offended, and will attack the player for being rebel secum.
Quotes:
If asked if he’s with the Legion: "That I am. Train the recruits. Turn boys into men. That sort of thing. Thinking of asking the General for some training books. Give the soldiers something to do while they're on rest. Something besides drinking. Ever seen a book called 'The Mirror'? We used to hand it out to boys looking to learn basic shield work."
If asked the training of his recruits is going: "Their aim could be steadier, but they're battle ready."
If the player has claimed to be the Dragonborn, and Aldis is asked if the Legion is prepared in the event of a dragon attack: “You’re the Dragonborn aren't you? I'm sort of hoping you're going to fight the dragons for us. A normal man is no match for a dragon."
If the player has not claimed to be the Dragonborn, and Aldis is asked if the Legion is prepared in the event of a dragon attack: "Can any man hope to be ready for a dragon? I can but hone their skills and harden their hearts. The rest is up to the gods.”
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Aquilius
bio: Captain Aquilius is a Redguard man currently residing in Markarth. He works as the guard captain of The Wizard Guards, a mercenary group that has been hired by Calcelmo. Aquilius and his group currently guard Calcelmo Tower in Markarth, adjacent to Understone Keep. Calcelmo is an elderly Altmer man who is a renowned archaeologist and scholar, focusing on the ancient Dwemer and ancient Falmer civilizations. Aquilius is stronger than the other guards, and wears steel plate armor. He carries a key to both Calcelmo’s Laboratory and the Dwemer Museum. He has a thick beard.
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Avidius
bio:
Captain Avidius, a Redguard man, is the captain of The Katariah. The Katariah is the personal flagship of Emperor Titus Mede the Second. The Karariah is currently anchored in the Solitude harbor.
Avidius can be found inside the captain's cabin of the ship, and he carries the Katariah Master Key, which unlocks the Emperor's Quarters within the ship. He has dark hair and a beard.
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Hargar
bio:
Captain Hargar, a Nord man, is an officer in the Blackblood Marauders bandit group. He wears leather armor and leather boots. He is bald and clean-shaven. He has vein-like patterned tattos on both sides of his neck and face.
The Blackblood Marauders are led by Jaree-Ra (an Argonian) and his sister Deeja living in the cave at Broken Oar Grotto, north of Solitude. Hargar resides in a ship in the Grotto that became stuck after a cave-in. Hargar’s personal stash can be found in the adjacent sunken ship.
Hargar recently escaped from the Solitude dungeon within Castle Dour, of which Ahtar (a Redguard man) is the jailor.
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Lonely-Gale
bio:
Captain Lonely-Gale is a Nord man, former sailor, and resident of the city of Windhelm. He has dark brown hair and a beard. His outfit consists of fine clothes and a pair of fine boots, and he is wealthy enough to be considered rich. He also carries a steel sword on his hip.
The citizens of Windhelm continue to address him with the honorific "Captain", because was the captain of a ship before he retired. He is somewhat despondent about his wife’s death. Despite this, he is friendly and helpful with advice about things to do in Windhelm. Unlike many Nords in Windhelm, he doesn’t harbor any ill will towards the Dunmer in the city.
He enjoys a rather relaxed life in Windhelm, spending a lot of his time in Candlehearth Hall (the popular inn near the center of the city, in the Stone Quarter), where he sometimes chats with Elda Early-Dawn (the middle-aged Nord woman who works as Candlehearth Hall’s innkeeper) while ordering a drink. In the morning, he can often be found browsing stalls in the market square in the southwest section of the Stone Quarter.
His recent widower status has attracted the romantic interest of Viola Giordano, an older Imperial woman who spends a lot of time in Candlehearth Hall and constantly worries about The Butcher. The Butcher is the name that the people of Windhelm have given to the elusive man who has been murdering young women in Windhelm and carving up their bodies. Captain Lonely-Gale is starting to get quite annoyed with Viola’s repeated expressions of romantic interest in him.
Niranye, an Altmer woman who works as a general goods merchant in Windhelm’s market, sometimes asks Captain Lonely-Gale if he can refer her to any of his old sailor associates for a business proposition. Wary that Niranye is interested in smuggling, he will deny Niranye’s request.
If Brunwulf Free-Winter replaces Ulfric Stormcloak as the Jarl of Eastmarch (as a result of the Imperial Legion capturing Windhelm), Captain Lonely-Gale will agree to serve as the Windhelm court steward.
Quotes:
"Fair winds and calm seas. That's an old sailor's parting."
"The townsfolk call me "Captain" because I used to be a sailor."
If asked who some of the prominent citizens in Windhelm are: “There's an author named Adonato staying at the inn. He's published a few works of historical fiction. The clans Shatter-Shield and Cruel-Sea see most of the gold that passes through the city. And obviously you have Ulfric, the Jarl and future High King. Oh, and that busybody Viola Giordano. She's got her nose in everyone's business, which I guess is one way of being prominent."
If asked about things to do in Windhelm: "If you're looking to pass the time, you can give Calixto a few Septims and gawk at whatever oddity he's come across lately. If you're in need of goods, there's a market. If it's a soft bed and a hot meal you're after, there's Candlehearth Hall."
If asked why people refer to him as a captain: “Folk just call me that because of what I used to do. I was a sailor for many a year. I made my coin as a trader, and in time, I bought my own ship. When I retired here in Windhelm, most folk already knew me as Captain Lonely-Gale, and the name just stuck."
If asked about the recent murders: "Terrible shame, that. Seems we have a killer on the loose here in Windhelm. He's claimed three victims that I know of, though maybe there's more that haven't been found yet. All lovely ladies, too. Let's hope the guards find that demon soon, and introduce him to the headsman's axe."
If asked what the news on the street is: "The dark elves are uneasy. There's a killer on the streets. And Viola Giordano won't leave me alone."
"I made my fortune as a sea captain, but now I'm retired."
"I lost my family years ago. Truth is, I don't really know what keeps me going."
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Metilius
bio: Captain Metilius is a Nord soldier in the Imperial Legion. He is currently sitting at the table with Emperor Titus Mede the Second, within the Emperor's Tower area of Castle Dour, in Solitude.
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Valmir
bio:
Captain Valmir, an Altmer man, is an undercover Thalmor agent who is camping by himself outside of Forelhost. He will disguise himself either a Stormcloak captain or an Imperial soldier, depending on the situation. Forelhost is a large Nordic ruin on a peak southeast of Riften.
Valmir will ask the player to retrieve a dragon priest mask named Rahgot from Forelhost. He will also ask for Skorm Snow-Strider's Journal. Skorm Snow-Strider was commander of a legion of Lord Harald's soldiers in Year 139 of the First Era, thousands of years ago. Around this time, Skorm was leading a campaign in the region near Lake Honrich. During Skorm’s campaign, he inadvertently discovered a hidden stronghold of Dragon Cultists in the secluded monastery of Forelhost.
If the player has successfully retrieved the mask of Rahgot, Valmir try to secure the mask for himself by any means necessary, including trying to kill the player if necessary.
Captain Valmir carries a piece of paper with his orders from his Thalmor superiors. Valmir has been pretending to be an officer of either the Legion or the Stormcloaks, in order to fool soldiers into going into Forelhost to get the Dragon Priest Mask of Rahgot for him. Valmir and his Thalmor bosses want to retrieve Rahgot because it is one of the pieces of the puzzle required to unlock an even more powerful mask, found in the ancient ruin of Labyrinthian in Skyrim. 
Captain Valmir will pretend to be soldier of whatever faction (either the Imperial Legion, or the Stormcloaks) that he believes the player is mostly likely to belong to/support. He considers Nords to be more likely to belong to the Stormcloak faction, and considers non-Nords to be more likely to belong to the Imperial faction. Valmir also carries a torch, a potion of minor healing, and the key to the entrance of Forelhost. Valmir knows some fire spells from the Destruction school of magic, as well as some healing spells from the Restoration school.
Quotes:
"The General has sent me to obtain a powerful weapon for the war effort. This was the last great bastion of the Dragon Cult, and their leader's mask was reported to be quite powerful."
"The research I've done seems to indicate that Skorm Snow-Strider left part of his journal here after laying siege. I believe it should indicate how to enter the blocked off sections of the stronghold. I should warn you that Forelhost is quite haunted, but I'm sure you can handle it. Return to me here once you've obtained the mask."
“It seems that after the strength of the Cult was broken in the Dragon War, a last contingent came here to create a stronghold and regroup. King Harald's forces crushed stragglers here the during the First Era and it has been haunted ever since, but the specifics of the siege are unclear."
If asked about the Dragon Cult: "They were among the first men to arrive from Atmora and they worshipped certain animals as avatars of the Gods; Dragons being foremost. And for their bloody sacrifices, the Dragons gifted their priests with terrible power. But their cruelty was too great for men to bear, and they rose up in what would be called the Dragon War and the Cult swept from the land."
"What are you waiting for? Get in there and find that mask."
When asked why he doesn’t just go retrieve the mask himself: “Me? No, I'm too important to the war effort to risk life and limb in there... Besides, that's what I'm paying you for."
"Don't bother me if you haven't found anything about the mask."
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Veleth
bio:
Captain Modyn Veleth is a Dunmer found in Raven Rock. He is the captain of the Redoran Guard stationed at Raven Rock. He wears Bonemold Armor like his men, but wears the Bonemold Guard Armor instead of the Bonemold Pauldron Armor, and is often seen equipped with an Elven Battleaxe. If the Dragonborn saves him during the quest "March of the Dead," he will thank them by saying, "Thanks... I wasn't sure I'd make it off this farm alive. I wish I could have said the same for my man here."
Located at the Old Attius Farm, the Dragonborn must rescue him from a group of Ash Spawn, which have killed one of his men before the Dragonborn intervenes. He gives the orders to kill General Falx Carius, a former general of the Imperial Legion that was stationed at Fort Frostmoth and was presumed killed when Red Mountain erupted. He will remain outside of the Old Attius Farm until the quest is started, then return to Raven Rock to patrol with his men, joining them whenever Ash Spawn attempt to attack the Bulwark.
After the saving him from the Ash Spawn at the farm, Veleth will ask for help in finding a hidden stash of Emberbrand Wine that his guards have hidden somewhere in Raven Rock.
After the completion of "March of the Dead" and "The Final Descent," he directs the Dragonborn to Adril Arano.
Do you know someone called Miraak? "I might know someone. Or maybe not. I can't remember..."
author: Bethesda

name: Captain Wayfinder
bio:
Captain Wayfinder, a young Nord man, is the captain of the Sea Squall. The Sea Squall is a merchant vessel, and is currently docked in Dawnstar. Wayfinder, can often be found conversing with his crew members, such as Guthrum (an older Nord man) and Ravam Verethi (a Dunmer man). Wayfinder's first name is Leif, but everyone calls him Captain Wayfinder. He has shoulder-length reddish-brown hair, and a small amount of facial hair.
Captain Wayfinder has been the captain of the Sea Squall for one year. Wayfinder inherited the ship from his mother, who passed away a year ago.
Wayfinder often feels frazzled and worried. Despite this, he also seems to be very sure of himself. He is a good-hearted person, and wants his crewmen to enjoy their work.
Wayfinder may ask the player to retrieve a special type of void salts, called Fine-Cut Void Salts. These Fine-Cut Void Salts are a valuable product that they were contracted to deliver. Before they were able to deliver the product, the crew of the Sea Squall got drunk and ended up losing the merchandise in a cave. The location where the Fine-Cut Void Salts were lost will be one of the following caves (chosen at random): Forsaken Crypt, Brood Cavern, Duskglow Crevice, Broken Oar Grotto, or South Cold Rock Pass.
Quotes:
"I don't buy all that talk about ship captains having to be stern and strict. I want my crewmen to enjoy their work."
"I inherited the ship when my mother passed away. She spent her life on the water, and now I do, too."
"I'm good with stars and charts, but I admit I've got some things to learn about leading men."
"Everyone thinks I'm too young to be a ship's captain, but I'm going to prove them wrong."
“My mother ran the Sea Squall as strictly as she ran the house. I've been trying to find new areas of business, trying to win the sailors' respect, but I keep having problems. Take the last trade we did. Some Fine-Cut Void Salts from the College of Winterhold. It’s worth plenty of coin if you know who to sell it to."
If asked how the Fine-Cut Void Salts got lost: "Sailors are what happened to them. They got drunk and ended up losing the merchandise in some cave. If you're not afraid of a little exploring, I'll pay good gold to get those salts."
If the Fine-Cut Void Salts are returned to him: "This is the best news I've had since I set sail a year ago."
author: Bethesda

name: Captive
bio: A deceased Imperial woman. Her body is found at a watering hole near Druadach Redoubt, in The Reach. Her body is lying on a rock, with her clothes lying nearby on the bank of the pool, along with a ring, an amulet, and a journal stating that she has disobeyed her father's wishes, despite the Forsworn activity in the area, and has gone for a swim. There are two Forsworn arrows floating in the watering hole, suggesting she was murdered by Forsworn raiders.
author: Bethesda

name: Carlotta Valentia
bio:
Carlotta Valentia, an Imperial woman, works as a merchant in Whiterun. She sells fruits, vegetables, bread, and cheese at her stall in the market. Carlotta has a young daughter named Mila, who helps Carlotta at her market stall. She has brown shoulder-length hair.
Carlotta gets much of her produce from a farm owned by Severio Pelagia, just south of the city. Severio is an Imperial man who owns a house in the center of the city.
Carlotta gets a lot of attention from men. Carlotta sometimes hyperbolically claims that half the men in Whiterun have proposed to marry her, and that a large fraction of those men have been already married or engaged. Carlotta will say that the only thing that matters to her is her daughter Mila, and that she is determined to let no man ruin her family.
Carlotta may ask the player to convince Mikael to leave her alone. Mikael is a young Nord man who works as a bard, often performing at The Bannered Mare (a popular inn near Whiterun’s market area, owned and managed by Hulda, a Nord woman). When talking about the issue, Carlotta may say “life's hard enough with all these men propositioning me. But that bard is the worst.” If the player successfully convinces Mikael to abandon his romantic pursuit of Carlotta, Carlotta will be very grateful and will consequently consider the player to be her good friend from that point onwards.
Carlotta gets annoyed when the beggar Brenuin (a Redguard man) lounges around her shop without buying anything, something threatening to call the guards on him. Despite this, Carlotta will occasionally show compassion towards him and allow him to eat some of the leftover food that she wasn’t able to sell that day, and that would otherwise spoil before the next day.
Carlotta sometimes refers to her daughter Mila by the nickname “little fairy”. Sometimes she treats herself and her daughter to a nice dinner at The Bannered Mare.
A Redguard farmer named Nazeem sometimes walks by her market stall during the day, claiming that her produce is less fresh than the produce from Chillfurrow Farm. Nazeem and his wife Ahlam own Chillfurrow Farm.
Carlotta sometimes talks to Olfina Gray-Mane (a young Nord woman) about problems such as the rising cost of food and other goods, the war between the Imperial Legion and the Stormcloaks, and bandits. With more and more guards and soldiers being sent to participate in the war, there are less guards to protect against bandits and thieves. 
Carlotta also sometimes talks to a friendly young Nord woman named Ysolda, who is an aspiring merchant. Ysolda often buys apples and other fruit from Carlotta.
If the Stormcloaks take control of Whiterun, Carlotta may sometimes comment about how bad the Stormcloak soldiers smell, and will complain about how several of the Stormcloak soldiers have been making romantic advances toward her.
Quotes:
During the day, at her stall in Whiterun: "Ripe fruit and fresh vegetables for sale! Straight from the fields and orchards of Whiterun, to your table!"
During the day, at her stall in Whiterun: "Fresh-baked loaves! Still warm from the oven!"
During the day, at her stall in Whiterun: "Remember, fresh fruit and vegetables every day! Mostly."
"I've got a hungry daughter to feed, so selling my produce is really the only thing I care about."
“Road patrols were cut in half because the Jarl needed soldiers. Now the bandits are bolder than ever. They've been raiding the farms for food, and supplies are scarcer than ever. Maybe I should sell swords and armor, instead."
When talking about how Mikael is annoying her: “That bard Mikael is begging for a dagger up against his throat, the way he goes on about me. I've heard him boasting at the Bannered Mare, saying he'll 'conquer me as a true Nord conquers any harsh beast.' Hmph."
author: Bethesda

name: Cedran
bio:
Cedran is an older Breton man who operates the stables directly outside Markarth's walls. He wears farmer's clothes, boots, and a hat. He sells his Pinto horses to customers for 1000 gold per horse. He currently only has 1 horse available for purchase. He has 2 horizontal stripes of face paint on each of his cheeks.
Cedran will answer questions asked by the player about the Jarl of Markarth, the Markarth Incident, and the Forsworn.
Cedran has an assistant named Banning (a Breton man), who sells war dogs and also helps Cedran with the horses. If Banning dies, Cedran will lament that he now has twice as much work to do.
Quotes:
"You treat a horse well, it'll take you to Oblivion and back."
"You need a reliable horse in the Reach. That's what we have."
If asked who is in charge of Markarth: "That would be Jarl Igmund. Young for a ruler of a Hold, especially the Reach. Wasn't surprising he stayed loyal to the Empire. His father helped capture Ulfric Stormcloak after the Markarth Incident."
If asked who is in charge of Markarth if the Stormcloaks have taken control of it: “Since the Stormcloaks took over, Jarl Thongvor is in charge. It'll be lean times for the Reach with a Silver-Blood ruling it, that's for certain.”
If asked about the Markarth Incident: "It's the whole reason Ulfric revolted against the Empire. Well the first reason anyway. Forsworn had taken over Markarth, and Ulfric and his men drove them out. Empire promised they'd be free to worship Talos afterwards. Pity no one told the Elves. Whole group of those Thalmor came and they demanded Ulfric's arrest."
If asked who the Forsworn are: "Before the Nords came, we worshiped the old gods, had our own kingdom. Times have been good and bad since then, but some folks couldn't handle not ruling their own land. Those are the Forsworn. The Forsworn follow the old ways, but some of those were best forgotten. Blood sacrifices, communing with Daedra. It's the road to ruin."
If the conversation is drawing to a close: “Safe travels to you. May the crags fail to trip your feet.”
author: Bethesda

name: Celann
bio:
Celann is a member of the Dawnguard, a group of vampire hunters.
The leader of the Dawnguard is a stoic, deadly serious Redguard man named Isran. Years ago, Celann and Isran were members of the Vigilants of Stendarr, an order dedicated to wiping out Daedra-worship, vampires, werewolves, witches, and other abominations. Dissatisfied with the Vigilants', Celann and Isran left the order and worked together, though their partnership did not last long. The increased frequency and severity of vampire attacks in Skyrim made Celann recently decide to rejoin Isran and his new order.
The Dawnguard's base of operations is the ancient Fort Dawnguard in Dayspring Canyon, southeast of Riften and hidden deep in the Velothi Mountains. Built in the Second Era by the Jarl of Riften, this large castle served to contain the Jarl of Riften's son after he became a vampire. To prevent his son from leaving the castle, the Jarl hired a group of mercenaries known as the Dawnguard, who extended their purpose to root out any vampiric presence in Skyrim. The original Dawnguard eventually disbanded hundreds of years ago, but Isran recently rediscovered and repaired their old castle and reformed the Dawnguard order.
The first three members of the new Dawnguard were Isran, Celann, and an orc named Durak. Other members join afterwards.
If the player has become a member of the Dawnguard, Celann will be willing to follow them on missions. Celann will even be willing to be hired as the steward of one of the player's residential properties.
Celann is a Breton. He has blue eyes, light brown hair, and a beard. He is a lawful man and does not tolerate crime. He is clad in a set of Dawnguard light armor. This includes a gray cuirass and matching pairs of gauntlets and boots. He is equipped with a Dawnguard war axe and carries a torch. While Celann primarily fights as a warrior, he can use Sun Fire, an apprentice-level spell which is useful against vampires and other members of the undead.
Quotes:
"Here to join the Dawnguard? Good."
"Isran will decide if you've got what it takes. Go on, he's right inside."
"I'll tell you, the only thing more surprising than hearing from Isran after all these years was hearing that he wanted my help. I immediately realized things must be pretty bad. Looks like I was right."
If asked if he's worked with Isran before: "I have. There was a time, years ago, when we were both members of the Vigilants, and both equally dissatisfied with them. Their hearts are in the right place, of course. But Isran and I were never comfortable. We left together, but that partnership didn't last very long. I didn't agree with some of his methods."
"May you always prevail."
"Isran found something for you to do, eh? I thought he'd like you. Good luck!"
author: Bethesda

name: Challenger
bio:
Challenger is a Breton man who has come to challenge the player to a magical duel. The player is adept in at least one of the five schools of magic.
The Challenger wants his upcoming duel with the player to conform to all of their standards. None of the player's friends should assist the player in their duel. Weapons should also not be used, though the Challenger has a weapon ready for use just in case the player decides to cheat and use a weapon. If the Dragonborn does draw his weapon, the Challenger will draw his own weapon. Bound weapons may not be technically physical weapons, but they still violate the spirit of a magical duel.
If the player refuses the Challenger's request for a duel, the Challenger will become offended and attack the player.
author: Bethesda

name: Champion of Boethiah
bio:
The Champion of Boethiah is a Dunmer man who long ago once served Boethiah, a mighty Daedric Prince. He has been using the Ebony Mail for his own pleasure, rather than Boethiah's, and this has angered Boethiah. A powerful Daedric artifact bestowed about Boethia's Chahmpion, the Ebony Mail is a set of armor which shrouds its user in darkness and slowly poisons nearby enemies. The Champion now leads a group of Bandits out of a fort called Knifepoint Ridge in the Falkreath hold, and resides within Knifepoint Mine. In addition to wearing the Ebony Mail, he also wears ebony boots, ebony gauntlets, uses an ebony shield, and wields a powerful enchanted sword.
Quotes:
“Mind my words or I'll mind them for you: I'm slave to no man, no god, and no Daedra. Boethiah talks about leaving your mark, a sign of your passing.... Well, you can make a mark on the world without treachery and murder. Whenever a man's life is saved by armor made with these hands, these hands have changed that man's destiny and his family's. So you can tell that heartless Daedra bitch I'm done doing her dirty work.”
If asked about being Boethiah’s champion: “I'm done with all that. There's enough blood on these hands. I'm interested in creating things now.”
If asked if he’s afraid: “A man who feels no fear has no heart. I know fear. But it does not control me. If you desire to fight me, then let's get this over with.”
author: Bethesda

name: Chief Burguk
bio:
Chief Burguk, an Orsimer man, is the chief of the Dushnikh Yal orc stronghold. Dushnikh Yal is located in the southern part of The Reach. He wears a set of Orcish heavy armor, which includes a cuirass, boots, gauntlets, and a shield. His weapon of choice is a mace.
Burguk became the leader of his tribe after killing his father in one-on-one combat. Burguk says that one of his sons will someday challenge and defeat him, when the time comes. This custom ensures that the leaders of the stronghold are always strong and worthy.
As chief, Burguk is the only male in the entirety of Dushnikh Yal who is permitted to have wives and father children. He is the most respected member of the stronghold.
Burguk’s three wives are Shel (his favorite wife, and the prettiest), Arob (the Hunts-Wife, in charge of hunting), and Gharol (the Forge-Wife, in charge of smithing). Burguk has two brothers: Oglub and Ghorbash. Ghorbash is referred to as "Ghorbash the Iron Hand".
Burguk has three children: Nagrub (Arob's son), Umurn (Gharol's son), and Lash gra-Dushnikh (Gharol's adult daughter who ran away to the mining settlement Karthwasten in the northern part of The Reach). Burguk has not yet fathered any children with his wife Shel. Shel is Burguk’s favored wife, and he doesn’t make Shel perform laborious tasks such as mining, which the other members of the stronghold are expected to perform. Because of this, Burguk’s other wives are jealous of Shel.
The Forgemaster's Fingers are a pair of enchanted heavy armor gauntlets that were once worn by a legendary Orc blacksmith. If the player is a non-Orc who has found The Forgemaster's Fingers and gives this artifact to any Orc stronghold, its Chief will reward and honor the player by bestowing them with the title of “Blood-kin of the Orcs”, granting them full access to the stronghold. Other Orc strongholds across Skyrim will also be notified of the player’s new Blood-kin status, and will grant the player the same level of respect and access to their strongholds. There are also alternative methods by which the player can achieve Blood-Kin status, such a slaying a dragon within view of an Orc stronghold, or performing a difficult task for a respected Orc. If the player is an Orc, they will already automatically be welcome within all Orc strongholds, and will not need to prove themselves to attain Blood-kin status.
If the player asks Burguk for work, Burguk will challenge them to a brawl, with a bet of 100 gold. No weapons, magic, or potions are permitted during this brawl: only one’s body may be used for the fight. If the player wins the brawl, Burguk will not be angry, but rather will respect the player's strength, and will consequently consider the player as a friend.
Burguk will be grateful If he learns that the player has killed Lurbuk (a weak Orc who left Dushinkh Yal to work as a bard in Morthal). This is because Burguk considers Lurbuk to be an embarrassment to all Orcs. Lurbuk is secretly Burguk’s son, but Burguk may deny this when asked because he is ashamed of Lurbuk’s weakness and choice of profession.
Quotes:
“You speak to Burguk, chief of Dushnikh Yal.”
“This stronghold respects strength, and strength alone.”
"You need steel? Speak to my forge-wife, Gharol."
"Need a poison for your hunting? My mother, Murbul, knows several."
If asked about being the chief: “I earned the right by slaying my father in single combat. One day, I will have a son who will challenge me when I become too old to lead, and the stronghold will have a new chief. Until then, I alone have the right to have wives and children. It ensures our strength.”
If asked how the orcs govern themselves: “The Code of Malacath. It is both tradition and law in the strongholds. Break the code, and you must pay Blood Price. The code is not written anywhere. It is known and carried on by the Orcs, and all who live in the strongholds follow it. For an outlander, following it is simple. Do not steal or attack anyone in the stronghold, or be ready to pay in gold or blood.”
If asked if there are any other Orc strongholds in Skyrim: "There are a few great strongholds worthy to talk about. Dushnikh Yal, Mor Khazgur, Narzulbur, and Largashbur."
If the player is an Orc or has been named Blood-Kin of the Orcs, and asks for lessons in one-handed weaponry: “You'll never compare to me, but I can try and teach you anyway.”
author: Bethesda

name: Chief Larak
bio:
Chief Larak, an Orc man, is the chief of Mor Khazgur, the Orc Stronghold located west of Solitude. He wears fur armor with a pair of Forsworn boots, and is armed with an Orcish war axe and Orcish shield.
Larak has two wives, his first wife Bagrak and second wife Shuftharz. Larak is the father of Borgakh (whose mother is Bagrak) and Olur (whose mother is Shuftharz). Bagrak is also Larak’s sister (marrying one’s siblings is not unheard of in Orc strongholds).
Larak became the leader of the stronghold by slaying his father in single combat, as his father was too old and weak to rule the tribe any longer. Larak hopes that one day his own son will challenge and defeat him when his time comes.
As chief, Larak is the only male in the entirety of Mor Khazgur (and the nearby mine) who is permitted to have wives and father children. He is the most respected member of the stronghold.
The Forgemaster's Fingers are a pair of enchanted heavy armor gauntlets that were once worn by a legendary Orc blacksmith. If the player is a non-Orc who has found The Forgemaster's Fingers and gives this artifact to any Orc stronghold, its Chief will reward and honor the player by bestowing them with the title of “Blood-kin of the Orcs”, granting them full access to the stronghold. Other Orc strongholds across Skyrim will also be notified of the player’s new Blood-kin status, and will grant the player the same level of respect and access to their strongholds. There are also alternative methods by which the player can achieve Blood-Kin status, such a slaying a dragon within view of an Orc stronghold, or performing a difficult task for a respected Orc. If the player is an Orc, they will already automatically be welcome within all Orc strongholds, and will not need to prove themselves to attain Blood-kin status.
If the player asks Larak for work, Larak will challenge them to a brawl, with a bet of 100 gold. No weapons, magic, or potions are permitted during this brawl: only one’s body may be used for the fight. If the player wins the brawl, Larak will not be angry, but rather will respect the player's strength, and will consequently consider the player as a friend.
Larak’s wife Shuftharz sometimes mentions her support for her husband, saying "The forge is strong and so is our chief, Larak. I'm content." Larak's sister/wife Bagrak, however, seems to think he has not quite reached his full potential as chief yet, saying "Larak is strong, but he has much to prove as chief." Larak’s mother seems to be proud of him, saying “Malacath is pleased with your strength, Larak.”
Larak is a master of using a shield in combat, and will sell the player lessons in shield use if requested.
Larak is impressed with the smithing skills of his wife Shuftharz and their son Olur. Sometimes Larak talks to Olur about the smithing techniques Larak learned when he served in the Imperial Legion years ago.
Larak’s daughter Borgakh (sometimes referred to as "Borgakh the Steel Heart") will soon be of age to be married, and by tradition she will be married to one of the Orc chiefs from another stronghold. To that end, Borgakh has been training so that she may offer her strength to the other tribe, while her own people will receive good trade in return, thus benefiting both tribes. Borgakh can often be found practicing the use of her sword against a wooden training dummy in front of Larak's Longhouse. Larak has not yet chosen the Orc stronghold to which he will send Borgakh, to be the wife of the chieftain there.
Quotes:
"You are speaking to Larak, chief of Mor Khazgur."
"You should see my forge-wife, Shuftharz, if you need weapons or armor."
"My mother, Sharamph, knows many remedies you may wish to take with you."
"My place is chief and my challenge is to lead my people."
"I'm a strict follower of the old traditions. Honor, strength, deeds."
If The Forgemaster’s Fingers are given to him: “I don't believe it. You found the Forgemaster's Fingers. You've impressed me, outlander. No one else has returned from this task before. By the Code of Malacath, I name you Blood-Kin to the Orcs. Let it be known among the strongholds that you are family, now.”
If the player has been named Blood-Kin to the Orcs: “Welcome to our stronghold, Blood-Kin.”
If the player beats him in a brawl: "You bested me, an Orc chief. Impressive."
If the player asks him for training in shield use: "You wish to learn from the best, eh? So be it."
author: Bethesda

name: Chief Mauhulakh
bio:
Chief Mauhulakh, an Orc man, is the chief of the Orc stronghold Narzulbur. Narzulbur is located in Eastmarch, at the base of the Velothi Mountains, which form the boundary between Skyrim and Morrowind. Narzulbur is just north of Gloombound Mine, which is owned and operated by the Orcs living in Narzulbur. This mine mainly produces ebony ore, but also produces some orichalcum ore and iron ore.
Mauhulakh became the leader of the stronghold by slaying his father in single combat, as his father was too old and weak to rule the tribe any longer. Mauhulakh states that one day his own son will challenge and defeat him when his time comes. He explains that Orcs in the strongholds have this custom in order to ensure that the leader is a strong one.
As the chief, Mauhulakh is the only male in Narzulbur who is allowed to have wives and to produce offspring with them. He is the most respected member of the stronghold.
Mauhulakh has a son named Dushnamub who works as the stronghold’s blacksmith. He also has a daughter named Urog, who has recently started learning how to hunt from Mauhulakh’s aunt Yatul. Dushnamub and Urog were raised by Mauhulakh’s aunts, Bolar and Yatul. Dushnamub and Urog had different mothers, and Bolar was the midwife for both Dushnamub’s and Urog’s births. Bolar is the oldest member of the stronghold and serves as a spiritual leader of sorts, performing ceremonies in which she reads in the animal's entrails. As the local alchemist, Bolar also sells potions and ingredients to anyone willing to buy them. Yatul is a huntress, and is Bolar’s younger sister.
Mauhulakh spends his days wondering why the gods are angry with him. As an Orc chieftain, he should have multiple wives, but he has none. Every wife he has taken has died soon after marrying them. Several of his wives have died during childbirth, including the mother of his son Dushnamub, and the mother of his daughter Urog. Four of his dead wives are buried in graves located up a hill behind the longhouse of the stronghold. Despite Mauhulakh’s predicament, he is still friendly towards outsiders. While he waits for a wife worthy of the gods, he is taken care of by his two aunts, Bolar and Yatul. This is a strange relationship that hasn't gone unnoticed by his son. Despite his aunts’ affection, they cannot provide him what he wants, which is more children. Another concern is the fact that Mauhulakh has had to hire outsiders from another Orc tribe to work in Gloombound Mine, to make up for the lack of native tribesmen.
The Forgemaster's Fingers are a pair of enchanted heavy armor gauntlets that were once worn by a legendary Orc blacksmith. If the player is a non-Orc who has found The Forgemaster's Fingers and gives this artifact to any Orc stronghold, its Chief will reward and honor the player by bestowing them with the title of “Blood-kin of the Orcs”, granting them full access to the stronghold. Other Orc strongholds across Skyrim will also be notified of the player’s new Blood-kin status, and will grant the player the same level of respect and access to their strongholds. There are also alternative methods by which the player can achieve Blood-Kin status, such a slaying a dragon within view of an Orc stronghold, or performing a difficult task for a respected Orc. If the player is an Orc, they will already automatically be welcome within all Orc strongholds, and will not need to prove themselves to attain Blood-kin status.
If the player asks Mauhulakh for work, Mauhulakh will challenge them to a brawl, with a bet of 100 gold. No weapons, magic, or potions are permitted during this brawl: only one’s body may be used for the fight. If the player wins the brawl, Mauhulakh will not be angry, but rather will respect the player's strength, and will consequently consider the player as a friend.
Quotes:
"The great stronghold of Narzulbur welcomes you, outsider."
“Come to purchase ebony? Our Gloombound Mine runs thick with black veins.”
“The blessings of the mine have been many, but I have no mate to share them with.”
“Been married many times, but the gods keep taking them from me.”
“I'm hoping my next wife can outlast the winter.”
If asked about how he became the chief: “I earned the right by slaying my father in single combat. One day, I will have a son who will challenge me when I become too old to lead, and the stronghold will have a new chief. Until then, I alone have the right to have wives and children. It ensures our strength.”
If asked how the Orcs govern themselves: “The Code of Malacath. It is both tradition and law in the strongholds. Break the code, and you must pay Blood Price. The code is not written anywhere. It is known and carried on by the Orcs, and all who live in the strongholds follow it. For an outlander, following it is simple. Do not steal or attack anyone in the stronghold, or be ready to pay in gold or blood.”
If asked if there are other Orc strongholds in Skyrim: “There are a few great strongholds worthy to talk about. Dushnikh Yal, Mor Khazgur, Narzulbur, and Largashbur.”
If the player asks if there is any work for them to do in the stronghold: “How about a test? Your muscle against mine. The victor gains 100 gold coins from the loser.”
If the player defeats him in a brawl:  "You bested me, an Orc chief. Impressive."
author: Bethesda

name: Chief Yamarz
bio:
Chief Yamarz, an Orc man, is the chief of the Orc stronghold of Largashbur. Largashbur is located in the southern part of the The Rift, at the base of the Jerall Mountains, which form the boundary between Skyrim and Cyrodiil. Largashbur is east of the ancient Dwarven ruin of Avanchnzel.
Yamarz is clad in a complete set of Orcish equipment. This includes the cuirass, a pair of gauntlets, a pair of boots, and a helmet. He is equipped with an Orcish war axe and an Orcish shield.
Like many Orcs who live in Orc strongholds, Chief Yamarz dislikes outsiders. He is generally unpleasant and displays many traits not normally associated with Orcs, such as a conniving nature and an aversion to battle. Yamarz is considerably weak and nervous when it comes to fighting.
Yamarz does not bother maintaining the shrine to Malacath located in Fallowstone Cave, to the east of Riften.
For the past couple months, Largashbur has been continuously attacked by giants, who have so far killed several members of the stronghold. The Orcs of Largashbur are convinced that they are being cursed and punished by Malacath, the Daedric Prince whom they worship. While many in the stronghold (such Atub, a sorceress) have been discussing the possibility of enlisting the help of an outsider to help lift this curse, Yamarz does not like this idea. Yamarz will usually not be very willing to engage in conversation with the player.
The Forgemaster's Fingers are a pair of enchanted heavy armor gauntlets that were once worn by a legendary Orc blacksmith. If the player is a non-Orc who has found The Forgemaster's Fingers and gives this artifact to any Orc stronghold, its Chief will reward and honor the player by bestowing them with the title of “Blood-kin of the Orcs”, granting them full access to the stronghold. Other Orc strongholds across Skyrim will also be notified of the player’s new Blood-kin status, and will grant the player the same level of respect and access to their strongholds. There are also alternative methods by which the player can achieve Blood-Kin status, such a slaying a dragon within view of an Orc stronghold, or performing a difficult task for a respected Orc. If the player is an Orc, they will already automatically be welcome within all Orc strongholds, and will not need to prove themselves to attain Blood-kin status.
There may come a time where Yamarz and the player journey together to Fallowstone Cave, in order to kill the giants there who have overrun the shrine to Malacath which is located within the cave. If this happens, Yamarz may ask the player to fight the giants for him, offering them large sums of gold and requesting that the player not reveal this arrangement to the rest of the members of the Largashbur stronghold, since the Orcs would consider this arrangement to be very dishonorable. 
Quotes:
"Curses aren't enough, now I must suffer you too? What is it?"
"Why are you here, outsider?"
author: Bethesda

name: Christer
bio:
Christer is a Nord man who is currently hiding in a supply closet on the ground level of the north tower of Mistwatch, which is an old fortress currently occupied by bandits. Mistwatch is located on the southern edge of Eastmarch. Christer has a thick brown beard.
Christer is looking for his wife, Fjola, and will ask the player for assistance in finding and rescuing her. Bandits in the area have been kidnapping people and bringing them to Mistwatch. His wife Fjola disappeared about the time that the bandits began kidnapping people, and he believes she is being held hostage somewhere within the fort. He hopes his wife is still alive among the abducted. If the player agrees to help him, Christer will give the player a Mistwatch Key that a bandit guard recently dropped, which should be able to open any locked doors within the fort.
Quotes:
"Please, stranger! I need your help!"
"Stendarr's mercy - you aren't one of the bandits. Please, you've got to help me!"
"It's my wife, Fjola! I think she's being held in this tower."
“Let me explain. Fjola, my wife, left the farm on errands and never came back. It's been months, and I've been searching for her since. I heard a rumor that these bandits were ransoming captives, so I thought she may be here. I managed to sneak past the guards and get this far, but... I don't think I can go on. I'm no warrior! Please, can you look for her?"
If asked if he is sure that his wife is here in Mistwatch: "Honestly? I have no idea. But I've looked all over and the kidnappings here started around when she disappeared. So I have to hope..."
If the player agrees to look for Fjola: “Thank you! I don't have much, but I can give you some coin for the trouble. One of the guards dropped this key while I hid. I wager it will come in handy for you. Please hurry!"
If the player says that Fjola is dead, and that they retrieved her wedding band: "That... I gave it to her on our wedding day. Help me, Divines... it's true isn't it? I'm sorry. Keep the ring. I cannot bear the weight of them in my heart, and I must make the journey alone now. Thank you for... thank you."
If the player says that they couldn’t find Fjola, but that they found her wedding band:” Her marriage band? Then there's hope - she was here! I have to move on if I want to find her. Please, take the coin I promised. Blessings of Stendarr on you”
If the player tells him that they killed Fjola: “What? My Fjola would never... You monster! I'll kill you for this!”
author: Bethesda

name: Cicero
bio:
Cicero, an Imperial man, has the appearance and personality of an eccentric jester. Cicero is the Keeper of the Dark Brotherhood, and one of his responsibilities is to take care of the Night Mother's coffin. He may originally be encountered on the road north of Whiterun, near Loreius Farm, transporting the coffin of the Night Mother (Cicero refers to her simply as "Mother"). Cicero will beseech the player to aid him, stating he needs repairs for his wagon wheel. After this encounter, he may be found within the Dark Brotherhood’s Falkreath Sanctuary or the Dark Brotherhood’s Dawnstar Sanctuary.
The Night Mother is the Unholy Matron, bride of Sithis, and spiritual leader of the Dark Brotherhood. Despite being a powerful spirit, her corpse is needed for communion with her. She receives prayers from people seeking to arrange assassinations via the Black Sacrament, and relays those desires to the Listener, the mortal leader of the Brotherhood. However, since the destruction of the Brotherhood in Cyrodiil, and the death of the Listener in a riot, the Dark Brotherhood has been cut off from contact with the Night Mother. Without a Listener to guide the Dark Brotherhood in the way that the Night Mother wishes, Astrid has foolishly and greedily taken complete control of the Brotherhood for herself. Astrid and the other Brotherhood members have rejected the tenets and traditions of the Dark Brotherhood, which Cicero views as a sacrilege. Although the Night Mother is no longer respected as she once was, Cicero has a plan to help change this and restore the Brotherhood to its former glory.
Cicero was once a member of the Bruma Sanctuary of the Dark Brotherhood before it was destroyed, and later a member of the Cheydinhal Sanctuary. Cicero was renowned for his cloak-and-dagger killing style. Cicero’s journal mention riots in Bravil leading to the death of Alisanne Dupre (the Night Mother's previous Listener) and the desecration of the Night Mother's crypt beneath The Lucky Old Lady statue. After being voted into the role of Keeper of the Night Mother by the remaining Brotherhood members, Cicero fulfilled one last contract before starting his new duties; he was scheduled to kill a jester, with whom he slowly became obsessed. His attire and flamboyant manner mimic this jester. Over time, Cicero has descended into madness, obsessing over this jester and adopting aspects of the jester's persona.
Eventually, through the months after the last Listener's death, the remaining Brotherhood members left the Sanctuary to look for contracts or food and never returned, leaving Cicero trapped alone in the Cheydinal Sanctuary. Eventually, he grew more and more insane from obsessing over his last kill, isolation, and due to trying to talk to the Night Mother and become her Listener. Eight years later, he wrote letters to Astrid in Skyrim to appeal for sanctuary, fleeing from the Cheydinhal sanctuary to Skyrim, taking the Night Mother's coffin with him.
Widely regarded as bothersome, obnoxious, strange, and insane, Cicero sports flamboyant attire and often speaks with a high-pitched voice. Cicero speaks to both himself and the Night Mother's remains often, and as such, he is considered psychotic. As Keeper of the Night Mother, Cicero takes his vocation very seriously, willing to wound or even kill anyone who questions or ignores the Night Mother's authority.
Cicero wants to be the Listener, but despite his best efforts and repeated attempts at conversation with the Night Mother’s corpse, he cannot hear her voice like the Listener must be able to do. If the player tells Cicero that they have started hearing the Night Mother’s voice, Cicero will declare the player to be the new Listener. While Cicero will initially be bitter that he was not made Listener, he will still be excited that that there is a new Listener, and will congratulate the player on their new role. 
Later, in a fit of defiance, Cicero will attack Astrid for challenging the Night Mother's authority, but fail to kill her. After surviving a skirmish with Veezara (an Argonian, and former member of the Shadowscales group of Argonian assassinsa, Cicero will flee to the Dawnstar Sanctuary, with Arnbjorn following close behind. Arriving outside the Dawnstar Sanctuary, Cicero will stab Arnbjorn, causing him to bleed heavily, but not enough to kill him. Before escaping into the sanctuary, Arnbjorn will also wound Cicero, but not enough to kill him. At this point, the player will have to decide whether or not to kill Cicero, and Cicero will try to convince the player to spare his life.
If following the player on their journeys across Skyrim, he makes several off-beat jokes and humorous observations about the current location or quest. While not following the player, he lurks around the sanctuary near the Night Mother's sarcophagus, talking to himself and tending her.
Cicero will often, for no reason, start to dance. This can happen at any time and anywhere.
Quotes:
If the player asks if they can help him with his wagon problem: “Oh. Oh yes! Yes, the kindly stranger can certainly help! Go to the farm - the Loreius Farm. Just over there, off the road. Talk to Loreius. He has tools! He can help me! But he won't! He refuses! Convince Loreius to fix my wheel! Do that, and poor Cicero will reward you. With coin! Gleamy, shiny coin!”
“Is there singing in the Void? Dancing...? Surely the Dread Lord will at least allow poor Cicero to caper…”
“Cicero never understood thieves, really... take someone's things before you kill them? And they call me crazy...”
“Need to get Mother some flowers... pretty, pretty flowers...”
"Let's kill someone."
"Oh, I do wish to get to know you better. But I must tend to mother. Maybe we can talk for just a moment..."
“Humble Cicero lives to serve."
If asked about the duties of the Keeper: "Oh, Cicero takes care of our Lady's body. Oils it, preserves it, keeps it safe. Makes sure nobody disrespects our Matron's coffin."
If the player has been named the Listener: “Cicero is at your service, oh great and powerful Listener!”
If in Solitude: “Hmph. 'Solitude'. Lonely Cicero could tell you a thing or two about solitude...”
If in Markarth: “Forsworn think they're so scary... Cicero will show you who's scary... Stupid Forsworn...”
If in Riften: “Riften. Cicero likes Riften. Cheats and ruffians and cutthroats abound. Finally, some fun.”
author: Bethesda

name: Cindiri Arano
bio:
Cindiri Arano, an older Dunmer woman, lives in Raven Rock on the island of Solstheim. She is the wife of the second councilor, Adril Arano, and lives with him in Morvayn Manor.
Cindiri is originally from Blacklight in northwestern Morrowind, though she hasn't seen the city in fifty years. Blacklight became Morrowind's capital city after the city of Mournhold was sacked by the Argonian invasion 200 years ago. Cindiri has also spent some time in Vvardenfell. She desperately wants to return to Blacklight, but she can't convince Adril to leave Councilor Morvayn's side. She's concerned for her husband's safety, believing his duties put him in harm's way. 
Just like many of the other residents of Raven Rock, Cindiri was recently subjected to the mind-control of Miraak and mentally forced to work on and worship Miraak's foul structure at the Earth Stone, near Raven Rock. Luckily, the player (who is the Dragonborn) freed Cindiri and the others from this mental enslavement, after which Cindiri was very grateful.
Cindiri will willing to accept a free sample of Sadri's Sujamma from Geldis Sadri, the owner of the Retching Netch cornerclub in Raven Rock.
Quotes:
"As the wife to the Second Councilor of Raven Rock, it would be my pleasure to help you any way that I can."
"I can't tell you how relieved I am that Miraak's gone from my mind. I appreciate what you've done."
"I can't believe Miraak made us build those shrines. To take our free will like that... just horrible."
"Ugh, I can't believe I was forced to do manual labor at those shrines. It was horrifying..."
"You've brought Raven Rock back from the brink, traveler. I don't know how to thank you."
"Your efforts in Raven Rock have proven most invigorating for my husband. I haven't seen him this pleased in many years."
"You aren't here with bad news regarding my husband, are you? I couldn't bear it."
"It's been a long time since I walked the ashlands of Vvardenfell. I miss it terribly."
"Perhaps our town isn't as grand as Mournhold, but it's our home and we must make the most of it."
If the player finds her missing folio of the Lusty Argonian Maid from the shipwreck of the Strident Squall: "You found it? You have no idea what this means to me... to my family. Reclamations bless you! Well, you've certainly proven your worth around here to me. Please, accept this gift as a token of my appreciation!"
author: Bethesda

name: Clavicus Vile
bio:
Clavicus Vile, the Daedric Prince of Trickery and Bargains, is one of the seventeen Daedric Princes. He is also known as the child-god of the Morningstar, the Master of Insidious Wishes, and the Consummate Politician of Oblivion. His sphere of influence is the granting of power and wishes through ritual invocations and pacts. He is seen as one of the more sophisticated of the Daedric Princes. He is best known for granting wishes and entering into pacts with mortals, which they inevitably come to regret. His plane of Oblivion is known as The Fields of Regret. Clavicus most often takes the form of a small impish man with a pair of horns, though he has also manifested as a red mist.
The summoning date of Clavicus Vile is the 1st of Morning Star, the same date as the New Life Festival (the holiday commemorating the start of a new year).
Clavicus' dealings with mortals are usually with individuals who wish to have something and, by summoning him, Clavicus gives it to them, albeit in a way that invariably causes the mortal to regret their wish. He loves toying with mortals, generally for his own entertainment rather than for any particular purpose, and is fond of stealing mortals' souls. This has lead some to believe he is, unlike many other Daedric Princes, a deeply social being.
Clavicus has been known to split off portions of himself to create sentient objects or entities. While the permanent binding of spirits into objects is the usual process of creating Daedric Artifacts and Lesser Daedra, Vile's creations have shown more independence than those of most other Daedra's creations. It has been theorized that these creations serve, in part, to meet a desire for companionship that Vile has.
One of these creations is Barbas, is a shapeshifting Daedra who houses a significant proportion of Vile's power. Barbas most often takes the form of a dog, though on occasion he has also taken the form of a scamp named Creeper. Historically, Vile is rarely seen without his loyal companion Barbas, especially in artwork through the ages. Vile has been known to store up to half of his power in Barbas. Despite being useful to Vile, Barbas sometimes bores and annoys Vile, causing Vile to recently abandon Barbas.
Another such creation is Umbra, a sword created by a witch named Naenra Waerr to trap souls, at Vile's request. As part of the creation process, Vile imbued it with part of his essence. Over time, the part of Vile within the sword became a sentient being with its own will.
Another such creation is a Daedric Artifiact called the Bitter Cup, considered highly sacred by worshippers of Vile.
Another such creation is a quill enchanted with the spirit of a Daedra named Feyfolken, who is servant of Vile.
Another such creation is the Masque of Clavicus Vile. Originally made from a deal between Vile and a disfigured noblewoman, the Masque makes its wearer more persuasive.
Another such creation is the Rueful Axe. The Rueful Axe was given to a wizard named Sebastian Lort, who asked Vile for a way to cure his daughter's lycanthropy. Since death cures lycanthropy, giving Sebastian a weapon with which to kill his daughter technically fulfilled Sebastian's request. The axe later found its way into Vile's possession as a gift for his champions.
Despite his reputation as a trickster spirit, Vile is one of the more popular and tolerated Princes among the denizens of Tamriel. He is known for receiving veneration from merchants, traders, bankers, politicians, and bureaucrats, and while he doesn't appear in any of the Tamrielic pantheons, his worship is most prominent in High Rock, Cyrodiil, and Elsweyr. Many mortals believe it is unwise to make deals with Clavicus, and while this is a fair statement to make, Clavicus has been known to keep his word on occasion.
Clavicus finds eternity to be boring, so he finds entertainment in watching mortals, and in occasionally meddling in their affairs. He has been known to be the patron to vampires, gracing them with social stature, reason, and savvy, allowing them to not only live among regular mortals, but to hold powerful positions in society. Not all of Vile's machinations are necessarily insidious; he has been known to reward those who, on his direction, eliminate threats to the general public (while still serving his own interests).
If Vile is spoken to at a shrine of his in a cave in Skyrim called Haemar's Shame, Vile may be convinced to reunite with Barbas if the player retrieves the Rueful Axe for him. Once the Axe is retrieved, Clavicus may request that the player use the Axe to slay Barbas; while Barbas is immortal and can never truly die, striking Barbas with the Axe would disable him for a hundred years or so and allow Vile to absorb back all his power from Barbas without Barbas annoying him with his mellowing influence. If the player uses the Rueful Axe on Barbas, Vile will let them keep the Axe. If the player refuses to use the Axe on Barbas, Vile will instead properly reunite with Barbas as originally agreed, and will then give the player the Masque of Clavicus Vile.
Quotes:
"So, what's your heart's desire? What kind of deal can we strike?"
If asked if he wants to reunite with Barbas: "That insufferable pup? Forget it. I'm glad to be rid of him. Even if it does mean I'm stuck in this pitiful shrine, in the back end of... nowhere. Well... perhaps there is a way he could earn his place back at my side. Maybe. But no promises."
author: Bethesda

name: Clinton Lylvieve
bio:
Clinton Lylvieve is a Breton child who lives in the town of Dragon Bridge, south of Solitude. There is a large bridge to the east of the town that spans a chasm overlooking the Karth River.
Clinton is the son of Michel Lylvieve (a Breton woman) and Azzada Lylvieve (a Redguard man originally from Markarth). Clinton’s parents are farmers. Clinton has an older teenage sister named Julienne, who is training to be an innkeeper under a woman named Faida, at the Four Shields Tavern in Dragon Bridge.
Clinton wants to be a soldier, but his father says that he’s too young to be a soldier, so Clinton patrols the town for now, with his pet goat Lucky. Lucky is his only friend.
If Clinton witnesses the player casting a spell, he will ask them if they can turn him invisible.
Clinton sometimes asks adult strangers to play tag with him. Clinton doesn’t usually get a chance to play with children his age.
Quotes:
"Are you a soldier? One day, I'm going to be a soldier!"
"Soldiers get to stay up late, do whatever they want, and have fun!"
"Have you met my goat Lucky? He helps me patrol the town."
“Pa says I'm too young to fight in the war, but I can still help by patrolling the town.”
If asked about a Moth Priest: “I don't know what a Moth Priest is, but I did see an old man in a robe not long ago. He was riding in a wagon with some Imperial guards. They didn't stop to visit, though. They rode through town heading south, and went across the big bridge. It was only just a little bit ago. I bet you can catch them if you hurry up.”
author: Bethesda

name: Coldhearted Gravedigger
bio:
Coldhearted Gravedigger is a Nord woman who has been digging around in the Hall of the Dead in Windhelm. She wears farm clothes along with a pair of boots and a pair of gloves. She carries an iron dagger.
Quotes:
“I'm dying for a rest. I swear, I could lie down right now, and just sleep forever.”
author: Bethesda

name: Colette Marence
bio:
Colette Marence is a mage and a professor at the College of Winterhold, the primary institution for magical learning in Skyrim. Colette sometimes delivers lectures on Restoration magic in the Hall of the Elements, on the ground floor of the College's central tower. Her living quarters are on the second floor of the Hall of Countenance, the main living and sleeping quarters for most of the higher ranked mages.
Colettea middle-aged Breton woman with graying brown hair. She wears master-level enchanted robes of Restoration, befitting her specialization in Restoration magic.
Colette is convinced that the other mages of the college look down on her for specializing in the Restoration school of magic, and is very defensive about her specialization. She complains about other college members leaving nasty notes about her on her bed, and about her research materials going missing, However, she is polite to the player. She also has no complaints about the Arch-Mage of the College (a Dunmer man named Savos Aren).
