Colette is willing to sell private training lessons in Restoration magic. She sells a variety of tomes from which Restoration spells can be learned. She also sells mage apparel, robes and other clothing items imbued with enchantments that fortify the user's powers of Restoration and Magicka.
Colette knows more than most about the Augur of Dunlain, whose incorporeal form can be found deep within the Midden, the tunnels underneath the college.
Colette spends a lot of time inside the Arcanaeum, the College's expansive library. While there, she sometimes has conversations with other College members, such as Urag gro-Shub (an Orc man who is the College's librarian) and Drevis Neloren (a Dunmer man who is the College's expert on Illusion magic).
Colette knows many Restoration spells, which can heal, protect (ward spells), and repel the undead. Colette also know plenty of spells from other schools of magic, such as Ironflesh, Detect Life, Conjure Flame Atronach, and Sparks.
Quotes:
"Restoration is a perfectly valid school of magic. And don't let anyone tell you otherwise!"
"Restoration is not just healing cuts and bruises, you know. The undead are a very real, very dangerous threat, and Restoration magics can keep them at bay. Not to mention the benefit of wards! How can they continually overlook wards! It's baffling!"
If the player is already an Expert in Restoration magic, and asks Collete how to learn more about it: "Look at you. Such a devoted student of Restoration. It's comforting to see that not everyone has dismissed it as entirely as most members of the College have. Truly comforting. It looks like you're ready to speak with the Augur of Dunlain.
If asked about the Augur of Dunlain: "The Augur was a brilliant mage. Truly inspired. Mastered spells others could barely comprehend. He was especially gifted when it came to Restoration. He's... well, it's a tragic story, really. At least, the way I heard it. But that was a long time ago. It was some experiment gone horribly wrong. Anyway, he's very particular about who shares knowledge. Go on, go talk to him. I'm sure he's been paying attention, and will be expecting you."
author: Bethesda

name: College Guard
bio:
College Guard, a Nord Man, is one of the guards tasked with both guarding the College of Winterhold against external threats, as well as policing any members of the College who break the College’s rules. The College of Winterhold is the primary institution for magical learning in Skyrim. He wears a set of Master Robes of Destruction.
In combat, he will use his wide selection of available spells, including: Ebonyflesh, Frostbite, Frost Cloak, Healing Hands, and Ice Spike.
author: Bethesda

name: Commander Caius
bio:
Commander Caius is a middle-aged Imperial man. He is the captain of the guard in the city of Whiterun, where he resides. His boss is Jarl Balgruuf (a Nord man), the leader of Whiterun. Caius is loyal to the Empire and heavily supports the Imperial Legion over the Stormcloak rebels in the Skyrim Civil War. Caius wears a set of Whiterun Guard armor and a pair of fur boots. He is equipped with a high quality sword. He is balding, clean-shaven, and has brown hair at the sides of his head.
Certain citizens of Whiterun are very vocal about their negative opinions of Commander Caius. A prominent Nord man named Sinmir has no qualms about publicly claiming that Caius is extremely incompetent. Sinmir says that he could do Caius' job better even while being blindfolded.
If the Stormcloaks capture Whiterun, then Jarl Balgruuf, Balgruuf’s housecarl Irileth (a Dunmer woman), Balgruuf’s young brother Hrongar, and Balgruuf’s steward Proventus Avenicci (a middle-aged Imperial man) will be forced to seek refuge at the Blue Palace in the city of Solitude. Jarl Elisif the Fair (a young Nord woman), the leader of Solitude, supports the Empire and the Imperial Legion against the Stormcloaks. If the Stormcloaks capture Whiterun, Caius may be forced into exile at the Blue Palace along with Jarl Balgruuf and his entourage. However, he may also be allowed to stay within Whiterun, despite being stripped of his position by the conquering Stormcloaks. At that point, Sinmir will replace Caius as captain of the guard. If this happens, Caius will spend most of his time at the Bannered Mare, drinking his sorrows away. The Bannered Mare is a popular inn in Whiterun which is owned and operated by Hulda, a middle-aged Nord woman.
If Caius finds himself in Honningbrew Meadery outside of Whiterun, he is likely there to arrest Sabjorn (the Nord man who owns and runs this meadery) and take him to the Dragonsreach Dungeon in Whiterun. Sabjorn’s crime is allowing poor sanitary conditions (like skeever infestation) within the Honningbrew Meadery. 
Quotes:
“I'm the commander of the guard here in Whiterun.”
“My boys will keep you safe. Don't you worry.”
“You're not thinking of causing trouble here in this beautiful city, now are you? 'Cause I'd strongly advise against such foolishness.”
"Yes? What is it?"
If either in the Blue Palace, or the Bannered Mare: “I'll always be a commander, even if those Stormcloak dogs have stripped away my power. The Legion will regain control of the city. Mark my words.”
author: Bethesda

name: Commander Maro
bio:
Commander Maro is an Imperial man and the leader of the Emperor's special security force, the Penitus Oculatus. He is loyal to the Emperor of Tamriel (Emperor Titus Mede the Second), and serves under the Emperor directly. Maro and his subordinates in the Penitus Oculatus are in charge of protecting the Emperor, particularly during his potential upcoming visit to Skyrim. The Emperor's cousin, a young Imperial woman named Vittoria Vici, will soon be getting married to a Nord man named Asgeir Snow-Shod from an influential family in the city of Riften. It seems likely that the Emperor will soon visit Skyrim. After the Emperor’s upcoming visit to Skyrim has concluded, Commander Maro plans to retire. Commander Maro wears a set of Penitus Oculatus armor. He is equipped with a steel greatsword. He has brown hair and a thin goatee.
Commander Maro has a son named Gaius Maro, who also serves the Penitus Oculatus. Commander Maro has recently tasked his son with verifying the security of major cities of Skyrim (Solitude, Markarth, Whiterun, Riften, and Windhelm) in preparation for a potential visit to any of these cities from the Emperor.
The current Skyrim headquarters of the Penitus Oculatus is an outpost located in the town of Dragon Bridge, south of Solitude. There is a large bridge to the east of this town that spans a chasm overlooking the Karth River.
If the player informs Commander Maro that they have killed Astrid (the leader of the Dark Brotherhood in Skyrim), Commander Maro will express profound gratitude, and subsequently provide the player with the pass phrase for the Dark Brotherhood’s Sanctuary in Falkreath Hold. Commander Maro’s agents were recently able to learn this pass phrase, via an undisclosed source. This pass phrase is “silence, my brother”. Commander Maro will present the player with quite a challenge: to infiltrate this Dark Brotherhood sanctuary and kill all the assassins within. This sanctuary is located to the southwest of Falkreath. If the player returns to Commander Maro and informs him that all the Dark Brotherhood assassins within the sanctuary have been killed, Commander Maro will be overjoyed and reward the player with 3000 gold.
Quotes:
If the player says that they’ve killed Astrid: “Astrid? You mean, the leader of the Dark Brotherhood? Dead? And this is no jest? Ha! This is the stroke of good fortune. Long have I watched the Dark Brotherhood's movements... waiting for the time to strike. That time is now! My agents have recently acquired the passphrase to their Sanctuary. It is, "Silence, my brother." Every assassin in that hole must be put down! You, my friend. You've slain their leader. This honor should be yours. Do this, and you will be rewarded most handsomely!"
If the player says that they’ve killed all the assassins in the Dark Brotherhood sanctuary in Falkreath: “By all I hold holy... Can it be true? Have you actually done it? This is a great day, my friend. You have struck a blow against darkness that will not soon be forgotten! Here, as promised - a most generous reward. I'll make sure the Emperor himself hears of all you've accomplished. You've made Skyrim a better place.”
author: Bethesda

name: Companion Ghost
bio:
He is the ghost of an ancient Nord warrior. Many thousands of years ago, he died and was buried within Ysgramor's Tomb, along with Ysgramor and his fellow Companion warriors. Ysgramor's tomb is located on an island in the icy waters of the Sea of Ghosts, near the city of Winterhold on Skyrim's northeastern shore.
Many Companion ghosts are currently patroling the halls of this tomb, having recently been awakened. Their purpose is to test the combat worthiness of some of the modern-day members of the Companions, who have recently entered the tomb complex. Companion ghosts wield a variety of spectral weapons, such as bows, swords, shields, and battleaxes. Despite the ethereal nature of these weapons, they are still capable of inflicting real physical damage. Likewise, these ghosts can be harmed and defeated with normal weapons.
Despite being resolved to attack any living souls that enter the tomb, these ghosts bear no ill will towards the living. The ghosts are simply committed to properly assessing the combat strength and worthiness of these living Companion visitors.
author: Bethesda
note: Shawn - done. No voice model for male or female ghosts. Feel free to change the assigned voice model at your discretion.

note: Shawn - done. No voice model for male or female ghosts. Feel free to change the assigned voice model at your discretion.

name: Constance Michel
bio:
Constance Michel, a young Imperial woman, works at Honorhall Orphanage in Riften, as an assistant to an old woman named Grelod. Constance wears a belted tunic, and has brown shoulder-length hair.
Constance’s boss Grelod has been ironically nicknamed “Grelod the Kind”. In stark contrast to Grelod, who is cruel and uncaring, Constance is a kind person who takes great pride in trying to make the children feel safe and loved. Constance spends much of her time cleaning around the orphanage and cooking for the children, herself, and Grelod.
Grelod is not allowing any of the children in the orphanage to be adopted. The children say that Constance is nice to them, and that they want Constance to be in charge of the orphanage. Even though Constance is appalled at Grelod’s horrible treatment of the children, Constance will still defend Grelod, saying that Grelod is old and knows no other life. If Grelod dies, Constance will express some sorrow, but will not be devastated.
Grelod can often be seen berating and threatening the children of the orphanage, calling the children worthless and claiming that no one will ever love them. If the player witnesses this and asks Constance if Grelod is always so cruel to the children, Constance will admit that she is always cruel to them. Grelod even physically beats the children for frivolous reasons, such as crying because they miss their parents. Under Grelod’s rules, the children are fed only one meal a day, in the late afternoon. A Nord boy named Aventus Aretino recently ran away from the orphanage to escape Grelod’s cruelty, fleeing back to his family’s now vacant residence in Windhelm, which made Grelod furious. Some of the children residing at the orphanage are Francois Beaufort (an Imperial boy who has been at the orphanage for approximately one year), Hroar (a Nord boy), Runa Fair-Child (a Nord girl), and Samuel (an Imperial boy whose mother used to work at the orphanage before dying in childbirth when Samuel was born). 
If Grelod dies or is otherwise removed from her position as orphanage headmistress, Constance will take over as orphanage headmistress. If Constance takes Grelod's position as headmistress, she will greatly improve the conditions for the children living there, and will completely reverse Grelod’s previous policy of not allowing children to be adopted. Constance will subsequently send a multitude of letters and distribute fliers across Riften and the surrounding area, urging people to consider adopting a child.
If someone offers to adopt a child from Honorhall Orphanage, Constance will be delighted, but will ask questions in order to confirm that the child will be going to a good home. Constance will inquire about the prospective new parent's occupation, and whether or not they own a home that is spacious enough to accommodate the child. Constance will not accept prospective parents whose occupations involve criminal activity. If Constance is satisfied with the prospective parent’s answers, she will then ask them to speak to the child they wish to adopt, in order to confirm that the child agrees to be adopted by them. If the child agrees to be adopted, Constance will finalize the adoption and release them into the custody of their new parent. She will not allow the same person to adopt more than 2 children.
Quotes:
"My only concern is for the children. The poor darlings have no one else."
If asked if Headmistress Grelod is always so cruel to the children: "Sadly, yes. Even the townsfolk have taken to calling her 'Grelod the Kind'. Her very existence has become something of a running joke. Grelod runs this orphanage because she's old, and set in her ways, and doesn't know any other life. These children need love, and comfort. I try... But... I'm sorry, you should go. The children aren't up for adoption, and it's cruel to get their hopes up. Besides, Grelod hates... visitors."
“This war has created so many orphans, and so few are willing to open their hearts to them…”
If Constance has become the headmistress of the orphanage, and the player asks if they may adopt a child: “Why yes, yes of course! What a wonderful surprise!”
author: Bethesda

name: Corpulus Vinius
bio:
Corpulus Vinius, an Imperial man, is the owner of the Winking Skeever, an inn and bar in Solitude. Corpulus has light brown hair and a mustache, and wears a set of barkeep clothes. From behind the bar at the inn, Corpulus rents out rooms, and sells food and drink to the inn's patrons. He has 2 children: a young man named Sorex, and his younger daughter Minette. Corpulus has a cousin named Faida who lives in Dragon Bridge, south of Solitude. Faida is the proprietor of the Four Shields Tavern in Dragon Bridge.
During peaks in business, Corpulus will sometimes state that he would like to retire and let Sorex run the Skeever. However, Sorex doesn’t usually seem particularly enthusiastic about running the inn. Minette often states that she wants to take charge of the Skeever instead of Sorex, but Corpulus isn’t keen on letting a young lady run the bar (despite the fact that his female cousin Faida runs a tavern). Admittedly, Minette is quite a smart girl. Minette keeps a good track of their inventory, and is surprisingly knowledgeable regarding the optimal brands and vintages of mead to serve at different times.
Quotes:
"Welcome to the Winking Skeever, friend."
"Need anything, you just say the word."
If asked why the inn is called the Winking Skeever: “Well, as it turns out, I had a pet skeever when I was a boy and he used to wink."
If asked where one can learn about magic: "Magic? You're on the wrong side of Skyrim. You want Winterhold... that College there. They teach it. Otherwise you can try the Jarl's wizard. I wouldn't, though."
author: Bethesda

name: Corrupt Agent
bio:
Corrupt Agent is a Nord man who is currently residing in the Penitus Oculatus outpost in Dragon Bridge.
He will give a sum of gold to the player to assassinate a target, and will then wander through the outpost until the target has been killed.
author: Bethesda

name: Cosnach
bio:
Cosnach, a Breton man, lives in the Warrens of Markarth. He has blond hair, and 2 horizontal stripes of face paint on each of his cheeks. He wears a set of hide armor, and carries an iron mace on his hip.
Cosnach works for the Arnleif and Sons Trading Company as a porter. However, the unfortunate trading situation in The Reach has greatly reduced need for Cosnach’s services, so Cosnach usually just sits in the inn all day, having no work to do. Trade in the region has been crippled by chronic Forsworn raids on supply caravans.
Imedhnain (Cosnach’s cousin) lives in Markarth and works as an assistant at the storefront for the Arnleif and Sons Trading Company, which is a general goods store which is owned by a woman named Lisbet. Lisbet is also Cosnach’s superior, and often complains about Cosnach being lazy.
When Cosnach is not in his room in the Warrens, he can usually be found drinking at the bar at the Silver-Blood Inn. A Nord man named Kleppr is the innkeeper of this inn, assisted by his wife Frabbi and their older teenage children: their daughter Hroki and son Hreinn. Kleppr and Frabbi are constantly bickering at each other, with Frabbi always nagging and insulting her Kleppr. Cosnach sometimes converses with Kleppr across the bar, talking about misfortunes and lamenting the watered-down quality of the drinks.
One of the frequent patrons of the inn is a dirty and annoying beggar named Degaine. He sometimes asks Cosnach for money. 
Cosnach can be challenged to a brawl, with a bet of 100 gold. No weapons, magic, or potions are permitted during this brawl: only one’s body may be used for the fight. If the player wins the brawl, Cosnach will not be angry, but rather will respect the player's strength, and will consequently consider the player a friend. He will also consider the player a friend if they buy him drinks. If Cosnach considers the player a friend, he will be willing to follow the player on adventures across Skyrim. After all, he has nothing better to do.
Additionally, if Cosnach considers the player as a friend, and if the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse), Cosnach will accept a marriage proposal from the player.
Quotes:
If asked where he works: “Arnleif and Sons Trading Company. I'm a porter. Just some muscle hired to move heavy packages."
"I'm drunk, and it's been a while since I had a good fight. A hundred septims says I can take ya, bare-handed."
"There's no shipments coming in, so I do nothing. Just drink."
"No breaks for a good worker out here."
"I think I'm going to get another drink.”
author: Bethesda

name: Courier
bio:
Couriers deliver messages to people. A courier may take days to deliver letters to their intended recipient. Couriers can often be found in inns, as well as on the roads.
A courier is typically a young man clad in a set of farm clothes and boots, and carries a strong dagger for self-defense.
author: Bethesda

name: Cow Hand
bio: Cow Hand is an older Nord man. He wears a belted tunic, a pair of boots and a hat.
author: Bethesda

name: Crescius Caerellius
bio:
Crescius Caerellius is an elderly Imperial man who lives in the Raven Rock settlement on the island of Solstheim. He has a thick mustache and long gray balding hair. He is almost 80 years old.
His wife is Aphia Velothi. Like the majority of Raven Rock's population, Aphia is a Dark Elf. Aphia was once a priestess at the temple in Raven Rock.
Councilor Morvayn is the leader of Solstheim - he represents House Redoran, the Dark Elf Great House that now govern the island.  Without the resources of the ebony mine, Morvayn's actual influence doesn't spread far beyond Raven Rock, which is near the southwest corner of the island.
Over the course of most of his life, Crescius has tried to discover a secret that the East Empire Company is withholding, regarding the Raven Rock ebony mine. He has been trying to reveal the facts surrounding the death of his great-grandfather, Gratian Caerellius. Aphia disapproves of Crescius venturing into the mine, because she thinks he is getting too old for such dangerous things.
Quotes:
"If it wasn't for my wife, Aphia, I'd have joined my ancestors long ago."
"For all I know, I might be the last Imperial left on Solstheim."
"Maybe I won't live as long as the dark elves, but at least I didn't abandon my home."
"There was a time when this town meant something. Now it's all gone."
When asking for help: "Look, my wife nags that I'm too old to go traipsing around these mines chasing my story. Time's my enemy... it's caught up with me before I could find the answers that I'm looking for.  I want to know what happened to Gratian, and what the East Empire Company is keeping from all of us. Gratian kept a journal of notes about his discoveries. If you can find his... remains, I'm hoping it will help. Here's everything I have. The letter, the key. Please, do this for me so I can finally regain the respect that I've lost. Be careful down there, the mine can be treacherous."
If asked if there are any other Imperials in Raven Rock: "Those cowards left decades ago. Every single damned one of them. The moment the ebony mine dried up, they pulled up stakes. Ridiculous! Solstheim is still rich in ebony ore. I know there's more down there... I can smell it. I come from three generations of miners, and I'm telling you that the East Empire Company was wrong. They just didn't want to spend the coin trying to find it."
If asked about his family: "Our home has stood in Raven Rock since the colony was founded. Gratian helped build it with his own two hands. After Gratian died, he left behind a wife and a son... my grandfather, Rellicus. Rellicus lived there for quite a long time, working in the other sections of the mine until he was slain by reavers. I never knew my father... my mother and I always lived alone. I asked her about him many times, but she seemed angry and refused to speak about him, so eventually I let it go. When I was old enough, I began working in the mine hoping to make my fortune and eventually move to the Imperial City. When the mine dried up, I only had enough coin saved to send one of us back to the Imperial City, so I sent my mother alone. I wanted her to see her homeland before she died. I was alone since then, until I met my darling Aphia."
If told that Glover Mallory (a Breton who works as a blacksmith in Raven Rock) wants his ancient Nord pickaxe back from him: "The damn fool doesn't even deserve to have it! The pickaxe was made for mining, not selling. I'll bet he stole it from the Skaal in the first place. Tell him I hope he drops the thing on his foot."
If the mine opens again: "I can't believe you found a way to reopen the mines. I don't know how to thank you. I've been made the foreman of the mine thanks to everything you did down there. It's good to get the old nose working again. I missed sniffing out the ebony deposits and getting my hands dirty. Best of all, Aphia isn't so cross when I go down there any more!"
author: Bethesda

name: Curwe
bio:
Curwe, an Altmer woman, works as a farmer. Curwe and her husband Vantus Loreius (an Imperial man) live together at Loreius Farm, located in a remote hilly region north of Whiterun. There is a large mammoth boneyard to west of their farm.
Curwe has graying blonde hair. She wears a set of green farm clothes and a pair of boots.
The first time that Curwe and Vantus are encountered, Cicero (a strange man named with the appearance of a jester) will be on the road just south of the farm. Cicero requested the assistance of Vantus in repairing the broken wheel on his wagon, but Vantus refused. Vantus had this to say on the matter: “A jester? Here, in Skyrim? Ain't been a merryman in these parts for a hundred years. And he's transporting some giant box. Says it's a coffin, and he's going to bury his mother. 'Mother' my eye. He could have anything in there. War contraband. Weapons. Skooma. Ain't no way I'm getting involved in any of that."
Quotes:
"You need something, talk to my husband, Vantus Loreius.”
author: Bethesda

name: Cynric Endell
bio:
Cynric Endell, a Breton man, is a thief and member of the Thieves Guild in Riften. He wears the standard Thieves Guild armor, including the chestpiece, gauntlets, boots, and hood. He carries a steel dagger and a hunting bow supplemented with steel arrows. He also carries lockpicks.
Before joining the Guild, Cynric was a jailbreaker. He would be hired by a client to get arrested, and would then either break the target prisoner out of jail, or kill the target prisoner (depending on the client’s request). Unfortunately, during one such job, Cynric was caught and unable to escape, and spent three years in a prison in High Rock before he was released. He subsequently promised himself that he would never work as a jailbreaker again, and decided to join the Thieves Guild. Delvin Mallory (a Breton man) is the one who inducted him into the Guild.
He spends a fair amount of his time practicing his archery skills within the Thieves Guild headquarters (the cistern of the Ragged Flagon, within the Ratway sewer system of Riften).
Cynric will at times engage in random conversations with fellow guild members, such as Thrynn (a Nord man who used to be a bandit), Niruin (a Bosmer man), and Rune (an Imperial man). Mercer Frey is the guildmaster of the Thieves Guild.
Quotes:
"I've seen thieves come and go, but I've never seen anyone as good as me."
"I could crack any house blindfolded before you even got your picks out of your pocket."
"Been in the Guild a long time... joined right after Brynjolf. Not interested in leadership though, that's more his kind of thing."
"I don't care if Vex was chosen as a Guild Third over me, she deserved it."
"I kind of like watching things from where I am. Making money is all I care about."
If asked how he became so good at picking locks: "Pull up a chair, my friend... this is quite a tale. When I started out in this business, I wasn't really interested in the Guild or being a thief. I didn't mean to imply I was earning an honest living either. With my lock picking aptitude, I was a natural at jailbreaking... made a great deal of gold doing it too. Jailbreaking is where a client pays you to get arrested, and you get thrown into a prison for the express purpose of breaking out. Usually it's to free someone the client cares about... and sometimes to... well, to kill someone on their behalf. Either way, the trick was in the escape, and that's where my strengths came in handy."
If asked why he stopped jailbreaking: “Well, as a jailbreaker, you work alone. No Guild to back you up. I'd do jobs for the Thieves Guild and the Dark Brotherhood, but if things didn't go as planned, I was on my own. The last jailbreak I attempted failed. I was imprisoned in High Rock for three years before they let me go. After that I promised myself I'd never do it again. I already knew Delvin, I asked if I could join up, and that was that.”
If the conversation is drawing to a close: "I'm sure we'll speak again."
author: Bethesda

name: Dagny
bio:
Dagny, a Nord child, lives in Dragonsreach, the Jarl’s palace in Whiterun. She is the daughter of Jarl Balgruuf the Greater. She has two brothers, Frothar and Nelkir.
Like the other children of Balgruuf the Greater, Dagny has a rather spoiled personality. She may assume the player is a servant.
Quotes:
"Absurd that you can't get good sweet rolls in this skeeverhole of a city."
"One of the new servants? Remember that I like my meat rare."
"Blasted war. I was due a new dress from Solitude, but it will never get here."
"I'm so angry, I can hardly stand it! Father promised me a new dress days ago, now where is it?"
author: Bethesda

name: Dagur
bio:
Dagur, a Nord man, is the owner of The Frozen Hearth inn in Winterhold, where he serves food and drinks and rents out rooms to customers. He has blond hair, and wears typical barkeeper clothing. His wife Haran helps him run the inn. They have a young daughter named Eirid.
Jarl Korir, the ruler of Winterhold, sometimes visits the inn. Korir wife Thaena also serves as Korir’s housecarl. Korir and Thaena have a son named Assur, who often plays with Eirid.
Dagur will often converse with customers and family around the inn. Unlike most of Skyrim's Nord population, Dagur is quite welcoming towards mages and magic in general. An Altmer mage named Nelacar, who is a former member of the College of Winterhold, has a permanent room at the inn.
One of the regulars at the inn is a man named Ranmir. Ranmir developed a serious drinking problem after the disappearance of his lover, a woman named Isabelle Rolaine. While Dagur’s wife Haran feels less compelled to dig into Ranmir's past, Dagur would like to see the Ranmir get back on his feet, and for someone to find out what happened to Isabelle. Ranmir’s sister, Birna, runs a general goods store across the street from the inn.
The College of Winterhold to the north is the town’s main attraction. Winterhold used to be a considerably larger city, but 80 years ago a mysterious event called the Great Collapse caused the ground beneath the northern section of Winterhold to crumble and fall into the Sea of Ghosts. The College of Winterhold was the only structure on the north side of the city which was spared destruction. Winterhold is now a pale shadow of its former glory.
Quotes:
"If you've business with the College, you're welcome to stay here. It's where most of our business comes from, in fact."
"Let me know if you need anything. We're here to provide."
"If there's anything you need, just let me know."
"Unlike some folks here in town, we have nothing against the College or the people that come and go."
"Don't worry about Nelacar. He has a permanent room here at the Inn, but he keeps to himself and doesn't cause any trouble."
If asked about Winterhold: "I'm afraid there's not much to be said. Winterhold is hardly what it used to be. You can talk to Birna if you need to buy anything. She doesn't have much, but could certainly use the coin. And then there's our little inn. Most of the business we get is from folks here to visit the College, though even that's dried up some."
If asked about Ranmir: "Oh, Ranmir was a different person. Happy, outgoing... Like anyone who's in love. See, Ranmir was involved with a pretty young woman named Isabelle Rolaine. The two of them were very happy together, I thought. One day, she just disappeared. Ranmir was convinced she'd run off with someone else, leaving him behind. He turned to drinking, and what's left of him is what you see here every day. I hoped that maybe if she could be found, if he had some sort of explanation, that maybe he could put himself back together. I'm in no position to go searching for her, but perhaps you could?”
If the Imperial Legion takes control of Winterhold: “Turns out who runs Winterhold doesn't change much. Can't say I'm surprised. I won't complain about Korir being gone, but I don't expect things to really be any different."
author: Bethesda

name: Daighre
bio:
Daighre, a Breton woman, works as a miner in Left Hand Mine. She has blonde hair, and wears a set of miner’s clothes and boots. Left Hand Mine is located in The Reach, near Markarth. Daighre is a widow. Daighre, her daughter Erith, and her dog Torom live in Daighre’s house within the settlement near the mine (this settlement is also called Left Hand Mine). The stone buildings in this settlement are of ancient Dwarven construction. Left Hand Mine is on opposite side from Markarth of one of the main tributaries of the Karth River. Several bridges cross the river in this area. This river is the main water source to both the city of Markarth and the Left Hand Mine settlement.
At work, Daighre primarily mines from iron ore veins. She is employed by Skaggi Scar-Face, a Nord man who is married to Sosia Tremellia. Daighre respects Skaggi, and is a hard worker.
Kolskeggr Mine (located a moderate distance to the northeast of Left Hand Mine), was recently attacked by the Forsworn. These Forsworn raiders massacred all the miners except Pavo (an Imperial man) and Gat (an Orc man), who managed to escape the slaughter. Pavo and Gat are temporarily staying in the Left Hand Mine miner’s barracks until it is safe for them to return home. Daighre is worried about a similar Forsworn attack befalling the people of Left Hand Mine.
Quotes:
“I'm the hardest worker in Left Hand. Better than any man.”
“Most women would rather die than dig, but I have a daughter to raise.”
"My Erith has her father's eyes. She's all I have left of him."
"Poor Pavo and Gat. To have lived through a Forsworn attack."
"Another day, another settlement gets attacked. No place in the Reach is safe from the Forsworn."
author: Bethesda

name: Dalan Merchad
bio:
Dalan Merchad, a Breton man, is a sailor. He serves aboard a merchant ship called The North Wind, under the ship's captain Kjar (a Nord man). The North Wind is currently laying over in Windhelm for a while.
Dalan dislikes Windhelm, and is looking forward to when the ship will eventually depart for another port. Dalan has gray hair and a thick mustache, and wears merchant-style clothing.
Voldsea Giryon, a Dunmer woman, also serves aboard The North Wind. Unlike Dalan, she doesn’t mind Windhelm,and often spends time in the city when she’s not working on the docks with Dalan and Kjar.
Quotes:
"I'm a lot happier out here on the deck than I am wandering around in that ruin of a city."
"I heard those forsworn out west live in caves. Can't be any worse than trying to live in Windhelm."
"Can't wait until we raise anchor. Anytime the boat's not moving, I start to get impatient."
"Never much cared for Windhelm. The place is depressing."
author: Bethesda

name: Danica Pure-Spring
bio:
Danica Pure-Spring, a middle-aged Nord woman, serves as a priestess of Kynareth and a healer in the Temple of Kynareth in Whiterun. She usually wears hooded monk robes.
A prominent tree in the center of Whiterun’s Wind District, known as the Gildergreen, is considered to be sacred to Kynareth. The Temple of Kynareth is located very close to the Gildergreen. During a recent storm, a bolt of lightning struck the Gildergreen and gravely wounded it. With the Civil War raging and Danica spending most of time healing the wounded, she has been forced to neglect her other duties as priestess, including tending to the tree. 
Danica may ask the player to retrieve a magical dagger called Nettlebane from Orphan Rock (a Hagraven den located east of Helgen, in Falkreath Hold). This dagger allows one to cut the Eldergleam Tree. The Eldergleam is the oldest living thing in Skyrim, and perhaps the oldest in all of Tamriel. Danica hopes that the player will find Nettlebane, make their way to the Eldergleam Sanctuary in Eastmarch, use Nettlebane to gather some Eldergleam sap, and bring the sap to her. The Eldergleam’s magical sap should be capable of healing the Gildergreen and restoring it to its former state. If the player performs this quest for Danica, she will be willing to sell the player lessons in the Restoration school of magic, of which Danica is a veritable master.
In recent months, Danica has been providing medical consultation regarding the mental condition of a boy from Morthal named Joric, as well as sending potions to alleviate his symptoms. Joric's sister is a young woman named Idgrod the Younger, who has been writing letters to Danica about Joric's condition. Joric’s mother is Jarl Idgrod Ravencrone of Hjaalmarch. Joric’s father is Aslfur, Jarl Idgrod’s husband and steward. Magic runs deep in that family's bloodline. If the player delivers to Danica another one of Idgrod the Younger’s letters, Danica will thank the player and give them a small gold reward for their trouble.
Inside the Temple of Kynareth, Danica and fellow healer Ahlam (a Redguard woman) will often discuss Ahlam's terrible and useless husband, a Redguard man named Nazeem.
Quotes:
“The temple here in the city is my charge. The goddess's divine blessings have no doubt helped make Whiterun a thriving and prosperous city. After all, it is she who brings rain to our crops and fair weather on the harvest days."
If asked if the Skyrim Civil War has affected her priestly duties: “Somewhat, yes. At first it seemed a distant thing, heard only in the idle speech of guards and traders. When the wounded soldiers began to return from battle, I did what I could to help them. As more of the sick and injured came to the temple, my work as a healer became more important than my duties as a priestess. I wish only an end to the fighting, so that I can tend to the temple once more."
“Hello, child of Kynareth.”
“Lately it seems I am more nurse than priestess, tending to those who have suffered, both in mind and body, from this terrible war. These are trying times for us all, I know. Many come to the Temple of Kynareth to pray, and I assist them as best I'm able.”
author: Bethesda

name: Dark Brotherhood Assassin
bio: Dark Brotherhood Assassin is a dead Nord found at Hag's End. He carries the full set of Ancient Shrouded Armor.
author: Bethesda

name: Dark Brotherhood Initiate
bio:
He is a newly recruited Dark Brotherhood assassin. He recently arrived at the Dawnstar Sanctuary in order to join and serve the Dark Brotherhood. He and a woman were inducted into the Dark Brotherhood as initiates at the same time, and they both serve the Brotherhood as its newest members.
The player, who is the Listener of the Dark Brotherhood, was recently successful in completing a historic contract from the Dark Brotherhood: the murder of Titus Mede the Second, the Emperor of Tamriel. The Brotherhood's Dawnstar Sanctuary has recently undergone renovations, which were coordinated by Delvin Mallory of the Thieves Guild, but financed by the Listener. Along with the Listener, there are at least two other members of the Dark Brotherhood who survived the Penitus Oculatus attack on the Brotherhood’s Falkreath Sanctuary. The first is Nazir, a shrewd Redguard Alik’r assassin. The second is Babette, who has the appearance of a young Breton girl, but is actually a 300-year-old vampire and the oldest member of the Dark Brotherhood. Babette also functions as a merchant of potions and ingredients for the Brotherhood, and is a master alchemist. 
It is possible that Cicero (an Imperial man with an eccentric personality and the appearance of a jester) is also still alive. Cicero is/was the Keeper of the Dark Brotherhood, responsible for taking care of the Night Mother’s remains.
This initiate will be willing to follow the Listener on their travels, and will obey the Listener's commands. His weapon of choice is a dagger. He typically wears a full set of red and black Dark Brotherhood shrouded armor. He is a Nord man. He has brown hair and a goatee.
Quotes:
"Yes, Listener?"
"I am yours to command."
"How may I serve you, my Listener?"
“Do you have any orders?”
author: Bethesda

name: Dark Brotherhood Initiate
bio:
She is a newly recruited Dark Brotherhood assassin. She recently arrived at the Dawnstar Sanctuary in order to join and serve the Dark Brotherhood. She and a man were inducted into the Dark Brotherhood as initiates at the same time, and they both serve the Brotherhood as its newest members.
The player, who is the Listener of the Dark Brotherhood, was recently successful in completing a historic contract from the Dark Brotherhood: the murder of Titus Mede the Second, the Emperor of Tamriel. The Brotherhood's Dawnstar Sanctuary has recently undergone renovations, which were coordinated by Delvin Mallory of the Thieves Guild, but financed by the Listener. Along with the Listener, there are at least two other members of the Dark Brotherhood who survived the Penitus Oculatus attack on the Brotherhood’s Falkreath Sanctuary. The first is Nazir, a shrewd Redguard Alik’r assassin. The second is Babette, who has the appearance of a young Breton girl, but is actually a 300-year-old vampire and the oldest member of the Dark Brotherhood. Babette also functions as a merchant of potions and ingredients for the Brotherhood, and is a master alchemist. 
It is possible that Cicero (an Imperial man with an eccentric personality and the appearance of a jester) is also still alive. Cicero is/was the Keeper of the Dark Brotherhood, responsible for taking care of the Night Mother’s remains.
This initiate will be willing to follow the Listener on their travels, and will obey the Listener's commands. Her weapon of choice is a dagger. She typically wears a full set of red and black Dark Brotherhood shrouded armor. She is a Nord woman. She has light brown hair.
Quotes:
"Listener. It is an honor to stand before you."
"Yes, Listener? How may I serve you?"
"Walk always in shadow, my Listener."
"I am yours, Listener."
Quotes:
"Yes, Listener?"
"I am yours to command."
"How may I serve you, my Listener?"
“Do you have any orders?”
author: Bethesda

name: Dawnguard Hunter
bio: Dawnguard Hunter is a Nord and a member of the Dawnguard.
author: Bethesda

name: Dawnguard Novice Hakar
bio:
Dawnguard Novice Hakar, a Nord man, is a novice member of the Dawnguard, an order of vampire hunters based at Castle Dawnguard, in the mountains at the southeastern tip of Skyrim.
Hakar repeatedly fails simple tasks given to him by his superiors. He has been given one last chance to redeem himself by restocking a number of Dawnguard caches throughout Skyrim. 
Just now, Hakar was attacked by two vampires, but thankfully the player intervened and rescued him. If conversed with after being rescued, Hakar will express feeling terrified, and will exclaim that he is quitting the Dawnguard because he can't handle the pressure and the danger. Hakar will then drop all of his equipment, including his Dawnguard heavy armor, an Amulet of Stendarr, a key to Dawnguard caches, and a letter explaining orders from the Dawnguard. He will then flee towards Frostfruit Inn in Rorikstead.
Quotes:
"Gods, Vampires! I... I can't take this anymore! I'm not cut out for this!"
"Look, take whatever you want. I'm getting out of here!"
author: Bethesda

name: Dawnguard Scout
bio:
Dawnguard Scout is a member of the Dawnguard, a group of vampire hunters.
Dawnguard scouts often work in pairs, sneaking around the coast of the secluded island in the Sea of Ghosts that Castle Volkihar is on, waiting to ambush the player, who is a vampire. They can frequently be found camping out at the stone tower near the dock.
They typically wear a mixed set of heavy and light Dawnguard armor, and are armed with a Crossbow and a Dawnguard war axe.
author: Bethesda

name: Dawnguard Vampire Hunter
bio:
Dawnguard Vampire Hunter is a radiant member of the Dawnguard. He is randomly encountered if the Dragonborn has joined Harkon's Court.
This member of the Dawnguard is typically accompanied by two regular Dawnguard members. He will attack the Dragonborn on sight. He carries a Writ of Dawn that implies that the Jarl has granted the Dawnguard permission to kill the Dragonborn for the 'crime' of vampirism.
He typically wears a mixed set of heavy and light Dawnguard Armor, and is armed with a Dawnguard weapon.
author: Bethesda

name: Daynas Valen
bio:
Daynas Valen was a Dunmer treasure hunter and mage, whose corpse rests in Folgunthur; he was searching for The Gauldur Amulet.
From his journals, Valen was very ambitious in his quest, borderline obsessed with obtaining the amulet. To his own misfortune, Valen had met his end at the hands of the Draugr that guarded the halls of the Nordic ruin.
The Ivory Dragon Claw can be found on Valen's dead body. He acquired the Ivory Claw from a collector in Bravil.
author: Bethesda

name: Dealer
bio:
She will initially welcome the Dragonborn to the skooma den hidden under Redwater Den. When asked about the den, she boasts that they are purveyors of the best Skooma outside of Balmora. If asked what is so special about the Skooma, she explains that the secret is the Bloodspring located deep within the den.
She can be persuaded to give a free sample of Redwater Skooma or it can be bought from her.
However, once the Dragonborn opens the gate or drinks the Redwater Skooma, she becomes hostile and attacks with her bows, as will the Attendant, the Doorman, and the Redwater Lookouts should one return via the front door of the den to Skyrim's overworld.
After discovering the Bloodspring, she will be the sole inhabitant of the den not marked as a Vampire's Thrall provided she is still alive, but will not be there on later visits back to the den, such as during radiant quests for the Volkihar Clan.
author: Bethesda

name: Deeja
bio:
Deeja is an Argonian woman living in Solitude. She wears a set of hide armor, and carries a high quality dagger. She can often be found at the Solitude docks, near the East Empire Company Warehouse. Deeja and her brother Jaree-Ra are employed by Vittoria Vici at the East Empire Company.
Deeja is very antisocial, and if the player attempts to converse with her, she will tell the player to back off and stop talking to her. She is extremely rude to the player, and will not answer questions.
At night, Deeja sometimes spends time aboard the Red Wave, a ship docked at the Solitude Docks. The Red Wave is secretly a pirate ship.
Deeja is secretly a member of the Blackblood Marauders, a clan of bandits who are active in the area around Solitude. Her brother Jaree-Ra is secretly the leader of the Blackblood Marauders. Deeja will not admit that she and her brother are associated with the Blackblood Marauders or other illegal activity.
Deeja has another brother named Gulum-Ei, who is secretly a fence for the Thieves Guild in Solitude.
Quotes:
"You, talk to egg-brothers. Deeja has no words for you."
"You have no knowledge of who you speak to. Go away."
"You want knives? You want them in your belly? No? Then you stop talking to Deeja."
"Shoo! Go away! You get nothing from me."
"You bother me again, maybe you will not walk away. Understand?"
author: Bethesda

name: Deekus
bio:
Deekus, an Argonian man, lives by himself at a small campsite near Hela's Folly. Hela’s Folly is the site of a large shipwreck located on the northwest tip of a fairly large island within the Sea of Ghosts, just north of Skyrim’s northern coast. An ancient Nord ruin named Yngvild is also located at the center of this island. Many smaller islands surround this island. The nearest city to Hela’s Folly is Dawnstar, to the southwest. The sea between these islands and Skyrim’s mainland is frozen over and traversable by foot for much of the year, though this doesn’t matter much to Deekus since he is an Argonian and would have no trouble swimming to the mainland if he needed to.
Deekus wears a set of hide armor. He can often be found sitting in his chair at his camp. He is a scavenger and a treasure hunter who has been retrieving items from the nearby shipwreck. There are a number of gemstones and valuables spread around his camp, such as a gold Dibella Statue. Deekus keeps a few bear traps around his camp, helping to guard his camp from the local wildlife.
Deekus is quite possessive of the shipwreck near his camp, and will not be willing share the spoils of the ship with anyone.
Quotes:
"Hrm. You go find your own wreck. This one's mine."
"Go away! This is my wreck! Mine!"
"Go away! I don't know who you are, but this is my spot! Whatever's on that ship is mine!"
author: Bethesda

name: Deep-In-His-Cups
bio:
Deep-In-His-Cups is an Argonian man. He wears a set of hide armor with a matching helmet, pair of boots, and bracers. He carries a high quality mace on his hip, as well as an iron dagger.
When Deep-In-His-Cups first spots the player, he will approach the player in a familiar, friendly manner. Previously, the player and a Breton mage named Sam Guevenne both dared Deep-In-His-Cups to enter a bandit camp and steal a hat, promising that they would pay him 10000 gold if he accomplished this task. The player and Sam were quite drunk at the time. He will be reasonable in negotiating how much gold the player will actually give him, but he will not accept anything less than 750 gold as compensation for having performed the dare.
After being paid by the player, Deep-In-His-Cups will travel to the Bee and Barb inn in Riften.
Quotes:
"Hey! There you are, you drunken bastard. I did it, so pay up."
"Whoa, not so fast there, friend. You owe me money."
"We caroused together with Sam Guevenne, remember? We broke into the Temple of Dibella? How much did you end up drinking? You and Sam dared me to go into that bandit camp. Well I did and brought back his stupid hat like you said, so give me the 10,000 gold you promised."
If the player doesn’t remember what Deep-In-His-Cups is talking about asks him to be reasonable: “Well... all right. Just because we are friends. Give me, say... 750 gold and we can call it even.”
If the player refuses to pay him at all: "If there's one thing I hate more than a mean-spirited drunk, it's one who can't settle their debts."
If the player pays him: “Thanks. You and Sam drink too hard for me. Think I'll take my gold and go buy a nice bit of swamp in Black Marsh. See you, friend. And take it easy on the wine."
author: Bethesda

name: Degaine
bio:
Degaine, a Breton Reachman, is beggar living in Markarth. Before suffering a crippling injury, he worked for an Orc man named Mulush gro-Shugurz at the smelter outside Cidhna Mine in Markarth. Degaine lives a cumbersome existence in The Warrens, where Markarth hides the poor and sick. Degaine can often be found in The Warrens or inside the Silver-Blood Inn. Sometimes, he may be found by the market stalls near the city gate, or simply wandering around the city. He wears nothing but some ragged robes. He is bald and has a thick brown beard.
His attitude towards other citizens is quite hateful and, when the player approaches him, he will be loud and insulting. Degaine likes drinking and will happily accept any alcoholic drinks or gold from the player, but will not express gratitude for these gifts because he feels entitled to them due to his crippled status.
Degaine may ask the player to steal a valuable child-sized gold statue of Dibella from the Temple of Dibella in Markarth. A man from Riften has promised Degaine 300 gold for this statue. Degaine previously attempted to steal this statue himself, but failed. If the player performs this favor for Degaine and brings him this statue, Degaine will compensate the player with 150 gold.
At the Silver-Blood Inn, Degaine often talks with Cosnach. Cosnach, a fellow Reachman, is a porter for Arnleif and Sons Trading Company, but currently has no work to do because Forsworn attacks on trading caravans have crippled trade within The Reach. 
When in the marketplace near the city gate, Degaine often argues with a fat Nord man named Hogni Red-Arm. Hogni is a butcher who sells raw meat from his market stall. 
Quotes:
"Alms. I said 'alms' you backbiter! Give a crippled worker a helping hand."
"Bring more gold next time."
"Come on, you outsiders always have plenty of gold on you. Spare a piece!"
After receiving a charitable donation of gold: "Finally. Now get lost!"
"How about a Septim? Wait, make that two Septims. I feel like living it up."
"Tell everyone you see to bring me some Septims."
“You see that Temple? Way up there? All them women, keeping to themselves. Won't let poor Degaine in, no. But they've got a treasure in there. Gold statue, size of a child. Who knows what they use it for, but I know what I'll use it for."
If the player steals the statue of Dibella and gives it to Degaine: "Give it to me quickly, before they see us together. You've riled up the priestesses, and the guards don't take kindly to that. Here's your share. Nicely done."
author: Bethesda

name: Delacourt
bio:
Delacourt, a young Breton man, works as a bard. His hair is a darker shade of blond, and he has a thin mustache. He wears merchant-style clothing.
Delacourt can usually be found in Dead Man's Drink in Falkreath, often performing for the inn’s patrons. He sings and plays the lute. An Imperial woman named Valga Vinicia is the innkeeper of Dead Man’s Drink. Delacourt will play song requests, such as Ragnar the Red and The Age of Aggression. He was trained at the Bard's College in Solitude. Delacourt may suggest that the player apply to join the Bard’s College. 
Quotes:
"Keep in song in your heart to ward off the gloom."
"Perhaps one day, I'll write a song about you!"
author: Bethesda

name: Delphine
bio:
Delphine, a Breton woman, owns and runs the Sleeping Giant Inn in Riverwood with, along with a Nord man named Orgnar. Behind this facade, Delphine is one of the last remaining members of the Blades, an ancient organization serving as sworn protectors of the Septim Emperors. The Blades were forced to disband 30 years ago, after the signing of the White-Gold Concordat ended the Great War against the Aldmeri Dominion. During this time, Delphine has been searching for a purpose as a Blade, and has recently been trying to unravel the mystery of the return of the dragons.
When it comes to age, Delphine is in her mid 50s. She has blonde hair and blue eyes. As a member of the Blades, she is a high-priority target for the Thalmor, and goes to great lengths to avoid the Thalmor’s notice. During The Great War, Delphine evaded multiple attempts on her life by Thalmor agents. The Thalmor ruthlessly hunted down Blades agents during after the Great War. Delphine may soon need to relinquish her ownership of the inn to Orgnar, in order to resume her activities as a Blade full-time. When away from her inn, Delphine usually wears leather armor with a hood to conceal her identity.
Delphine believes that the Thalmor may be involved with the re-emergence of dragons. Her main goal is to help discover the mystery behind the dragons and their re-emergence. She sometimes visits Farengar (the court wizard of Whiterun) in Dragonsreach, in order to assist him with learning more about the dragons and their re-emergence.
Other than Delphine, an old Nord man named Esbern may be the only other remaining Blades agent in Skyrim, if he’s still alive.
When talking to the player, Delphine will not admit to being a Blades agent unless she has been sufficiently convinced that the player is the Dragonborn. This will probably require her to witness the player slaying a dragon and absorbing its soul. If she is convinced that the player is the Dragonborn, she will be willing to answer all the player's questions regarding the Blades and anything else. 
When in combat, Delphine usually dual-wields a Blades sword (similar to a katana) with an elven dagger, or uses her bow and arrows from afar. Delphine knows a couple Restoration spells, but she rarely uses them in combat.
author: Bethesda

name: Delvin Mallory
bio:
Delvin Mallory, a Breton man, is a high-ranking member of the Thieves Guild in Riften.
Delvin Mallory wrote the book Shadowmarks, which helps members of the guild recognize the optimal buildings and establishments from which to steal, as well as places where presence of the law is high and in which thievery is not recommended.
Delvin has a brother named Glover, who works as a blacksmith in the Raven Rock settlement on Solstheim. Delvin also has a younger sister.
Delvin Mallory enjoys handing out jobs for other guild members to complete.
When Delvin was a new member of the Thieves Guild, he attempted a robbery in an unspecified tavern that resulted in him accidentally committing murder. Gallus (who was the Guildmaster of the Thieves Guild in Skyrim at the time), showed compassion for Delvin and sent him to live with the Dark Brotherhood for several years until the unwanted attention resulting from the murder died down. It was here that Delvin developed a business relationship and friendship with Astrid (the leader of the Dark Brotherhood in Skyrim).
author: Bethesda

name: Dengeir of Stuhn
bio:
Dengeir of Stuhn, an old Nord man, is the former Jarl of Falkreath. After stepping down from his position as Jarl, he was named a Thane of Falkreath.
Dengeir’s brother Thadgeir also lives with him, as does Tekla, his faithful maid. Dengeir is uncle of Siddgeir, the current Jarl of Falkreath who supports the Imperials over the Stormcloaks in the Skyrim Civil War. Dengeir supports the Stormcloaks in the war.
When spoken to, Dengeir displays a higher degree of suspicion towards nearly everyone. He even suspects his maid of passing off information about him to his enemies.
Dengeir’s story of why he was deposed as Jarl differs radically from his nephew's. Dengeir believes he was asked to step down when he took sides with the Stormcloaks and that it was, in fact, an Imperial plot to oust him from his seat of power. Dengeir states that he began noticing that Imperial spies were everywhere amongst the people of Falkreath, keeping tabs on and influencing everyone from the shadows.
When Dengeir found out about this, the spies made a few well-placed bribes, and the next thing he knew, the Nobles were calling for a new Jarl. Siddgeir, who is always willing to please the Empire, was then named in his place. Siddgeir foolishly states that Dengeir had become too frail in his old age to continue as Jarl.
Dengeir may ask for help in retrieving a letter from house of Lod the blacksmith. Dengeir suspects that this letter may contain evidence that Lod is spying for the Imperials. 
Sometime after showing Dengeir Lod’s letter. Dengeir way ask for help with another matter. Dengeir  will explain that a nearby grave has been dug up. The grave was that of his ancestor Vighar, who is a vampire, and has now been freed from his coffin after his grave's wardstone was stolen. Dengeir will request assistance in dispatching Vighar and saving his family's reputation before Vighar's condition is revealed.
If the Stormcloaks take control of Falkreath Hold, Dengeir will be appointed as the Jarl of Falkreath once more. 
Quotes:
If the player informs Dengeir that the vampire Vighar has been killed: "My family thanks you. Take this as a token of our gratitude."
author: Bethesda

name: Deor Woodcutter
bio:
Deor Woodcutter is a member of the Skaal located in the Skaal Village. Until the quest "The Fate of the Skaal" has been completed, he is one of the villagers building a temple around the Wind Stone. He lives with his wife, Yrsa, in his house. During the day, he can be found helping Baldor Iron-Shaper tend the forge.
After listening to a conversation between Deor and Fanari Strong-Voice, a new speech option becomes available to ask him about the missing blacksmith. This will start the quest.
Deor Woodcutter: "There was a great brown bear on the slopes the other day. I could swear by the All-Maker that it was watching the village." Wulf Wild-Blood: "Yes, I know the one you saw. It watches us each night, always moving closer. As the ashfall worsens, the land and water are poisoned. The animals have less to eat and become desperate." Deor Woodcutter: "We had better do something about it then." Wulf Wild-Blood: "It makes my heart heavy, to think of killing a beast when we have no need of its hide or its meat. That is not our way. The bear might find food elsewhere. We will leave it alone."
author: Bethesda

name: Derkeethus
bio:
Derkeethus, an Argonian man, lives in Darkwater Crossing. Darkwater Crossing is a relatively small mining settlement at the remote southern edge of Eastmarch. The tall mountains and cliffs at the northern edge of The Rift are clearly visible to the south of the settlement. Derkeethus works as a miner in Goldenrock Mine, just to the east of the settlement. Goldenrock Mine is rich with Corundum ore and was discovered by a Nord woman named Annekke Crag-Jumper, a fellow miner who lives in Darkwater Crossing with her husband Verner.
Derkeethus will be held captive by the Falmer within Darkwater Pass, until he is rescued by the player. After the player rescues Derkeethus, he will be very grateful and subsequently willing to follow the player on adventures across Skyrim. After following the player for some time, if the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse), Derkeethus will happily accept a marriage proposal from the player.
When back at Darkwater Crossing, Derkeethus sometimes takes a young Nord girl named Hrefna diving down deep in the Darkwater River, south of the settlement. Hrefna’s mother is a young woman named Tormir. Hrefna’s father apparently abandoned Tormir and Hrefna years ago.
Derkeethus is also friends with a friendly Dunmer man named Sondas Drenim, who is a fellow miner at Goldenrock Mine.
Derkeethus is quite skilled at archery and light armor usage, and is also moderately skilled at stealth, shield usage, one-handed melee weaponry.
Derkeethus usually wears a set of miner’s clothes and a pair of boots, equipped with an iron dagger, a hunting bow, and some steel arrows.
Quotes:
If within Darkwater Pass, and the player asks who he is: "Derkeethus, from Darkwater Crossing. Should have known better than to swim all the way to the falls. Please, get me out of here!"
If following the player on their adventures: "May the Hist guide us."
If following the player on their adventures: "Let's tread softly."
If following the player on their adventures: "Lead. I'll follow."
If following the player on their adventures: "To Oblivion and back, as they say."
If following the player on their adventures: "Ours is to follow, friend."
If following the player on their adventures, and asked to do something:  "As you say, it will happen."
If near or inside a Dwemer ruin: "I dislike lurking near dwarven cities. It's like their ghosts are watching us."
If near or inside a Nordic ruin: "Look at those ruins. How long have they stood here, I wonder?"
If in Windhelm:  "The only thing colder than Skyrim is the nords themselves."
If within Windhelm, and the player is an Argonian: "Trust me, Marsh-Friend. You don't want to be living in this city."
If approaching somewhere with an impressive view: "By the Hist, what a sight..."
author: Bethesda

name: Dervenin
bio:
Dervenin, a Bosmer man, is a half-mad servant of the Daedric Prince Sheogorath. He is distraught over being abandoned by his master and wants you to get him to take him back. When first conversed with, it is clear that he is desperate. His master Sheogorath has forbidden him from identifying him by name to others, so Dervenin is forced to cryptically describe his master when talking about him.
Dervenin wanders the streets of Solitude, usually between the Bards College and the Blue Palace. He wears a set of common farm clothes, complete with boots and a hat. Many years ago, he was the High Priest of Mania in the Shivering Isles.
When engaged in conversation, Dervenin will speak of his master leaving him to speak with an old friend in the Forbidden Wing of the Blue Palace. However, his master’s absence has been excessively long. If someone agrees to help him, Dervenin will give them Pelagius' Hip Bone so that they may gain entry to the Forbidden Wing.
Quotes:
"You! You'll help me! You help people, right? That's what you do?"
"My master has abandoned me! Abandoned his people. And nothing I say can change his mind. Now he refuses to even see me. He says I interrupt his vacation! It's been so many years... Won't you please help?"
"Please, take pity on an old madman!"
"Who among you can help me?"
"Wait, hear my plea! My master, he is lost between worlds and I cannot bring him back!"
"Why does everyone ignore me? Why do you turn your heads? Why will no one help me?"
"The flame of my master burns low. Without him, we are all lost and forever gray... Please, help us!"
"Oh, master. It's your time to do with as you please, but what about those who depend on you so much?"
"Tendrils of thought may wind their way through this realm, but those tendrils bind our reality together."
"A method to your madness and your madness is the method and the melody..."
"I found the bone! I've brought it to you but still I am refused..."
If it is suggested that he leave his master: "Oh, you just don't understand. Without him, I am not free! Without him, I am doomed! All of his empire shall fall into chaos..."
If asked where his master is: "Last I saw him, he was visiting a friend in the Blue Palace. But no one as mundane as the Jarl. No, no... such people are below him. No, he went into the forbidden wing of the palace, to speak with an old friend. Said it had been ages since they had last had tea. Oh and you'll need the hip bone... it's very important. No entering Pelagius' Wing without that."
If asked who his master is: "He is a great man, but one rarely praised! He rules twin empires that span the length and breadth of our minds! All know him, but few can name him. But... he has forbidden me from saying his name. He says it distracts him, and woe to those who draw his ire. But you will know him when you see him. He's the one who made me like this!"
If asked why he needs his master back: "Without his guidance, our homeland is falling apart. North wages war against south! The holy flame flickers and dies! We need his return. Oh, but... I'm sure he'll repay you when he comes to his senses! His favor is a powerful, powerful thing. And so very worth any... inconveniences."
If asked how one can get to his master: "He stays in the Pelagius Wing of the Blue Palace. The doors are locked, and only Falk Firebeard can grant entry. But I hear the maids, Una and Erdi, know how to enter it for cleaning. Surely they can help for such an important matter?"
author: Bethesda

name: Desperate Gambler
bio:
The Desperate Gambler is a Nord man. He resides in the Windhelm Barracks in the Palace of the Kings.
He will give a sum of gold to the player to assassinate a target, then wander through the barracks until the target has been killed.
author: Bethesda

name: Dexion Evicus
bio:
Dexion Evicus, an older Imperial man, is a Moth Priest who came to Skyrim following rumors of an Elder Scroll being found in Skyrim, intending to add this Scroll to his order's collection. He has a bald head and a thick gray-white beard.
The player and Serana rescued Dexion from his enthrallment by a vampire named Malkus, who had been imprisoning him within a cave in Hjaalmarch known as Forebears’ Holdout.
As a Moth Priest, Dexion can read Elder Scrolls. If one’s eyes are exposed to the Elder Scrolls for too long, temporary or even permanent blindness can result, and Moth Priests must take great care to avoid this.
If Dexion is in Castle Volkihar, this means that the player accepted Lord Harkon’s “gift” of vampirism after the player escorted Harkon’s daughter Serana to the castle. If this is the case, he will serve as the player’s servant.
If Lord Harkon of the Volkihar clan of vampires has been killed, and if within Castle Dawnguard (which means that the player rejected Harkon’s vampirism and joined the Dawnguard order of vampire-hunters), Dexion will offer to take both the Sun and Blood Elder Scrolls from the player, so that he may take them back to Cyrodiil and archive them in the White-Gold Tower. Alternatively, he can be persuaded to buy both of these Elder Scrolls for 6,000 gold.
During combat, he typically uses fire-based Destruction spells, in conjunction with melee attacks from his Akaviri sword (which is similar to a katana). He will also use Restoration spells to heal himself.
Quotes:
“Dexion Evicus is my name. I'm a Moth Priest of the White Gold Tower.”
If the player and asks him to read an Elder Scroll: "You have an Elder Scroll? Remarkable! I will be happy to assist you with your Elder Scroll.”
author: Bethesda

name: Dinya Balu
bio:
Dinya Balu, a Dunmer woman, serves as a priestess of Mara at the Temple of Mara in Riften.
Dinya Balu is married to Maramal, a Redguard man who is the head priest of Mara in Riften.
When asked if the player can get Mara's blessings, Dinya will reply that only those that would spread love throughout Skyrim can be granted this blessing.
She also may ask the player to distribute 20 copies of a leaflet called "The Warmth of Mara" to the citizens of Riften.
Dinya is currently pregnant with her husband Maramal's child.
Quotes:
“Lady Mara will provide us strength and guidance through these difficult times."
author: Bethesda

name: Dirge
bio:
Dirge, an Imperial man, is a gruff associate of the Thieves Guild in Riften. His brother Maul is Maven Black-Briar's right-hand man.
Dirge works as a bouncer for the Ragged Flagon, the underground tavern in the Ratway that the Guild uses as a base of operations. A man named Vekel is Dirge's employer. In the Ragged Flagon, Dirge can often be found in the front of the bar, or sitting down at one of the tables. He is quite muscular
.
Dirge speaks impolitely. If the player asks why he's called Dirge, Dirge will explain that it's because a dirge is "the last thing you hear before they put you in the ground" and will then aggresively ask if the player has a problem with his name.
Dirge enjoys Black-Briar Mead. He often nibbles on a loaf of broad when not at his bouncer post. He wears a set of leather armor (without the helmet) and carries a steel war axe at his hip.
He often passively threatens people with death, telling them about what he did to the last person who messed with Vekel.
author: Bethesda

name: Dishonored Skald
bio:
Dishonored Skald, a Nord man, is currently lounging within the Bards College in Solitude.
He will give a large sum of gold to the player (a member of the Dark Brotherhood) so that the Dark Brotherhood will assassinate a target whom the dishonored skald designates.
author: Bethesda

name: DomnaMagia
bio: DomnaMagia, an Imperial woman, is currently walking around in front of Hall of the Dead in Solitude. She is wearing a set of Vampire attire. She is skilled with one-handed melee weapons and with Restoration magic.
author: Bethesda

name: Donnel
bio:
Donnel is an elderly man who lives in Markarth. He has long white hair.
Donnel and Nana Ildene work as servants at the Treasury House in Markarth, for the Silver-Blood family. They have both worked there for the last few decades, and spend most of their working hours cleaning the building. His coworker and compatriot Nana is a woman who is slightly younger than Donnel. Donnel and Nana are secretly affiliated with the Forsworn rebel group. Donnel will not admit to being a member of the Forsworn. Donnel will become offended with anyone who asks investigates Weylin's recent attack against Margret in the Markarth marketplace.
During combat, Donnel will use his steel dagger, as well as the spells Flames, Oakflesh, and Raise Zombie.
Quotes:
"I work for the Silver-Bloods. I help clean."
"Just here to work."
author: Bethesda

name: Doorman
bio:
Doorman is a Nord found inside Redwater Den.
He can be found guarding the entrance to the skooma den. He warns all incoming guests to keep all weapons sheathed and not cause any trouble.
He is secretly a thrall of the vampire Venarus Vulpin, as are the dealer, attendant, and the lookouts at Redwater Den.
author: Bethesda

name: Dorian
bio:
Dorian, a Breton man, is a sailor with the Red Wave crew. He has light red hair, and wears leather armor.
The Red Wave, captained by an Imperial woman named Safia, is a pirate ship which is currently docked at the Solitude docks, near the East Empire Company Warehouse. Sabine Nytte (a Breton woman), a strong fighter clad in steel plate armor, is the first mate of the ship. Among the other members of the crew are Eris (a pretty and cheerful young Nord woman) and Xander (an Imperial man who used to be the captain of another ship, but is now just a crewman).
Dorian enjoys quiet and calm seas, as well as reading books. However, his rugged look, his loyalty (to the ship, crew, and its captain), and his determination to kill anyone that steps into the Red Wave's way still makes Dorian a dangerous man. Dorian is a fan of the famous author Adonato Leotelli, and wants to meet him someday.
While Dorian enlisted with the Red Wave crew only recently, he has previous sailing experience.
Quotes:
"Forget wine, women and wealth - give me a calm sea and a good book, and I'm happy."
"I hear Adonato Leotelli's staying up in Windhelm. I've read a few of his works. Be good to meet him someday."
"Don't misunderstand me, friend. I like my quiet, and I like to read. But you trifle with my ship, my crew, or my captain? I will kill you."
"You've not seen the night sky until you've seen it on the open sea."
"I've only been a part of the Red Wave's crew for a few weeks, but I've already learned to stay out of Captain Safia's way."
author: Bethesda

name: Dorthe
bio:
Dorthe is a Nord girl who lives in the town of Riverwood.
Her mother’s name is Sigrid, and her father’s name is Alvor. She has a cousin named Hadvar, who is a soldier in the Imperial Legion. Her father is the town’s blacksmith.
Dorthe is her father's self-appointed apprentice at the forge right outside their house, and looks forward to making her own weapons someday. She wants to follow in her father’s footsteps as a blacksmith, though he unfortunately thinks that she’s not quite old enough to use the forge yet. Dorthe's mother thinks that Dorthe should act more like a girl and spend more time helping her with gardening and cooking, but Dorthe has little interest in such boring things. Dorthe considers herself to be almost a woman, and wants her mother to stop trying to change her.
Dorthe is good friends with Frodnar, despite him sometimes playing mean pranks on her. Frodnar likes playing pranks on everyone. He has a dog named Stump, who often follows him around. They also often play games together, such tag or hide-and-seek. Sometimes, they will even ask strangers like the player to play with them.
Frodnar's parents own and operate Riverwood's sawmill. The mill is located on a small island in the middle of the White River, directly west of the town. This island is connected to the town via multiple wooden bridges. Frodnar's mother's ancestors originally founded Riverwood, and have lived there for many generations. Because of this, and due to the mill's importance, Frodnar's mother is considered to be the leader of the town.
The White River cuts through the Riverwood from south to north. The Throat of the World (the tallest mountain in all of Tamriel) towers over the town from the east. Bleak Falls Barrow, an old Nordic temple ruin in the snow-covered Brittleshin Hills, stands out prominently above Riverwood to its west. The Sleeping Giant Inn is not far from Dorthe’s family’s house. Their house located at the east bank of the river, near the mill.
While Dorthe's family supports the Empire, Frodnar and his family support the Stormcloak rebellion for Skyrim's independence from the Empire. Despite the two families having opposing stances on the civil war, they still generally get along and respect each other as fellow Nords.
Quotes:
"Papa says I'm too friendly with strangers, but you seem all right."
author: Bethesda

name: Drahff
bio:
Drahff, a Nord man, is a small-time bandit who lives in the Ratway sewer tunnels under Riften, He has an accomplice Hewnon Black-Skeever.  Drahff is the brains of the bandit duo, while Hewnon provides the brawn.
Upon spotting the player , Drahff will demand that they give him everything they have
Quotes:
"Hey, you. Stop right there! Empty your pockets or end up as skeever food."
"Brynjolf's been sending idiots like you down here for years looking for their hideout. Funny thing is his stupid Thieves Guild never counted on me and my partner blocking the way. Now, empty your pockets or I'll pick the gold off your corpse."
author: Bethesda

name: Drascua
bio:
Drascua is a Hagraven and leader of a Forsworn clan found at Dead Crone Rock.
Drascua is the descendant of one of the highest-ranking members of the Keepers of the Razor, a militant order that was founded to destroy the remnants of the Mythic Dawn after the Oblivion Crisis.
Her 5th great grandmother was a Breton woman from the The Reach called Sorscha who was named as the keeper of the Pommel Stone of Mehrunes' Razor. She agreed for it to be passed down to the oldest child in order to keep the Mehrunes' Razor forever apart.
The pommel was eventually handed down to Drascua sometime in her youth. In 4E 174, the Markarth Incident erupted, and in the aftermath, Drascua fled to Dead Crone Rock.
Drascua is one of the keepers of Mehrunes' Razor. She can be found at the highest balcony of Dead Crone Rock, near a Word Wall.
author: Bethesda
note: Shawn - started. No available voice model. Feel free to change the currently assigned voice to something else

name: Dravin Llanith
bio:
Dravin Llanith is a Dunmer farmer who lives with his wife Synda at the Merryfair Farm, less than an hour’s walk from the city of Riften.
They make a living growing wheat, cabbage, and gourds. They also have a cow and chickens. Dravin can often be seen milling wheat.
There was a recent break-in at their farm. Among the loot that was pilfered was Dravin's Bow. He believes the Thieves Guild was behind the burglary and that they stashed his bow somewhere in the Ratways beneath Riften.
If the player returns Dravin's bow to him, he will be grateful and consider the player a friend.
Dravin worries about his wife’s safety when she walks to Riften, and urges her to always bring her dagger when she travels so she can defend herself from wolves or bandits.
Quotes:
"It's not safe around here. There's thieves out there looking to steal everything you own."
"Watch yourself out there or they'll take everything away from you."
"Dragons, thieves and war. I should have stayed in Morrowind."
"A few days ago, some thieves from Riften broke in here and stole my bow! Can you imagine? Took the only thing of value we had. If you have the guts to head into the Ratway and get my bow back, I'll pay you what I can."
“We're all alone out here except for a few guards who couldn't give a damn about us. We make easy pickings for thieves looking to steal everything we worked so hard for. Not only did they take my bow, but they took all of our coin as well. Nothing's sacred to these people."
If the player returns his bow to him: "That's it! You found it! I don't know how you got it back, and I don't want to know. Frankly, I don't even care... I'm just so glad to see it again. Here, this is all can afford to give you as compensation. Hope it's enough."
"Azura's wisdom to you, friend."
author: Bethesda

name: Dravynea the Stoneweaver
bio:
Dravynea lives in Kynesgrove, a small town south of the city of Windhelm. The town is located near the base of the Velothi Mountains to the east. Steamscorch Mine, from which malachite ore is mined, is Kynesgrove's main point of interest. Dravynea works at this mine, where she uses her Alteration magic to stabilize the mine's tunnels, while also maintaining a low air temperature so the workers can continue mining. The steam channels concealed behind the rocks of the mine are a constant danger to the miners, making Dravynea's work essential. Due to this, she has the nickname "the Stoneweaver".
Dravynea is a Dunmer woman with dark red eyes and intricate face paint. She usually wears a set of blue mage robes. She came to Skyrim from Morrowind after the Red Mountain eruption many years ago, along with countless other Dunmer refugees.
 Dravynea is old friends with a Dunmer man named Ambarys Rendar, who now runs the popular New Gnisis Cornerclub in Windhelm.
While generally polite and fair-tempered, Dravynea may initially come across as slightly brusque. She is somewhat introverted from the rest of Kynesgrove because of townsfolk's racial prejudice against Dunmer. Roggi Knot-Beard is the only resident of the town who acts somewhat respectably towards her. Roggi is a Nord man who works in the mine, and is a mead connoisseur.
