The mill often requires the maintenance services of Alvor, the town’s blacksmith. Alvor’s house and adjacent smithy are located at the east bank of the river, near the mill. Alvor has a wife named Sigrid and a young daughter named Dorthe, who often plays with Frodnar. Alvor and his family support the Empire, while Hod and Gerdur’s family support the Stormcloak rebellion for Skyrim's independence from the Empire. Despite the two families having opposing stances on the civil war, they still generally get along and respect each other as fellow Nords. Alvor just requested a large order of hardwood planks from Hod, to be used in making shields.
Hod often visits the Sleeping Giant Inn during the evening for drinks. A man named Embry is Riverwood’s town drunk. Embry often asks Hod to buy him a drink when he sees him in the Sleeping Giant Inn.
Hod may remark about the attractiveness of a beautiful young woman named Camilla Valerius. Camilla is being pursued by two young men in Riverwood: a Nord bard named Sven, and a Wood Elf woodcutter and hunter named Faendal. If the player is a woman, Hod may also compliment the player’s attractiveness.
Gerdur’s ancestors originally founded Riverwood, and have lived there for many generations. Because of this, as well as because of the mill’s importance to the town, Gerdur is the de facto leader of Riverwood. Gerdur pays the taxes, and the land of the town is owned by Jarl Balgruuf.
Gerdur and Hod sell their lumber for construction and other uses (such as the war), and can arrange for the lumber to be hauled to a customer’s destination of choice. Each stack of 20 logs costs 200 gold. Hod will let a customer saw their own timber in the lumber mill if he has a high amount of respect for them.
If the player significantly helps his brother-in-law Ralof, Hod will consider the player his friend.
Quotes:
"Got business here in Riverwood, eh? There are worse villages."
"At least the damned war hasn't gotten here. Yet."
"We work hard, try to do right by our families."
"Me, I've got my axe, my wife Gerdur and my boy Frodnar. That's all I need."
"Woodcutting's my trade. Best log splitter from here to Riften."
"You met Camilla yet? Wouldn't mind getting my hands on those trunks. Hehe.”
If the player is a woman: “Now you, lass… you've got some beautiful trunks yourself…”
author: Bethesda

name: Hoddreid
bio: Hoddreid, a Nord woman, was a Hunter of Hircine sent by Lord Hircine to kill a werewolf named Sinding. Hoddreid was a wizard, and her corpse is wearing blue mage robes. Hoddreid was recently killed by Sinding within Bloated Man's Grotto. Hoddreid’s corpse can be found inside Bloated Man's Grotto, along with the dead bodies of two of her fellow hunters, named Batum gra-Bar and Ma'tasarr.
author: Bethesda

name: Hofgrir Horse-Crusher
bio:
Hofgrir Horse-Crusher is a Nord and the owner of the Riften Stables, just outside of Riften.
Hofgrir Horse-Crusher got his nickname by crushing a colt's spine while riding drunk, and as a result, he hasn't ridden a horse since. He also teaches an apprentice, Shadr, and believes that walls of towns are just "a weakling's hiding spot." He likes to boast that he has "the strongest arms in all of Skyrim," which can start a brawl if the player challenges him on this fact.
Hofgrir has a Mark of Dibella given to him by Haelga in exchange for an "intimate favor." Get it from him in as part of completing Svana Far-Shield's favor.
The Dragonborn can accept his challenge and brawl with him on a 100 gold bet. Winning the brawl, and therefore the bet, will make the horses and items inside the stables free to take.
He is a potential target for kidnappers in "Rescue Mission," a radiant quest for the Companions.
author: Bethesda

name: Hogni Red-Arm
bio:
Hogni Red-Arm is a Nord food merchant who is just inside the entrance to Markarth.
Hogni has gruff and impatient mannerisms which annoy many of the citizens of Markarth when he is working. He hates being cheated out of money, which has caused him issue with Degaine's begging and when people turn down his food. Similarly, he dislikes both sides of the Skyrim Civil War, as both the Stormcloaks and Imperials expect compensation. He additionally has a strange fixation on blood and meat, which tends to be a source of discomfort for those around him. Hogni is actually a cannibal, which perhaps explain why he is obsessed with blood. When not at his stall in the market, he tends to keep to himself, taking the largest room in the Silver-Blood Inn so he has more space. 
Like most Nords in the Reach, he detests the Forsworn, believing that they are nothing but trouble.
If asked about the source of his meat, he reveals the location of Dushnikh Yal, an Orc Stronghold where he gets his supplies.
When first arriving in Markarth, Weylin is seen speaking to Hogni before then drawing his dagger to make his move on Margret. Following this, the Dragonborn can ask Hogni about what happened, to which he will mention that Weylin was clearly a Forsworn sympathizer. Like Kerah, he will refuse to sell anything due to the event.
During the Daedric quest "The Taste of Death," it is revealed that he, along with a few other citizens of Markarth, is a cannibal. He implies that he sells human flesh at his shop if talked to at the feast in The Taste of Death, however this may just be a macabre joke as human flesh can never be bought from his stall, even by a cannibal.
author: Bethesda

name: Holgeir
bio:
Holgeir was a warlord in the forests of Skyrim before the dragons returned.
He met Fjori, a huntress, when she was 29 years old. The two battled, falling in love when Fjori broke his axe with her sword, and he dulled her sword with his shield. Shortly after, Holgeir was bitten by a venomous snake.
Fjori obtained an elixir from the Akaviri and saved Holgeir's life. Her love fully-restored, she too was bitten by the same snake after the elixir was used up, falling dead. Holgeir built a tomb for her, killing himself after its completion.
Holgeir appears as a draugr, summoned by Lu'ah Al-Skaven, a Redguard necromancer in Ansilvund. She intended for Holgeir's body to serve as the vessel for her deceased husband, Saeel.
Based on the player's level, he spawns as a leveled draugr, or even possibly a Dragon Priest. After Lu'ah is defeated, Holgeir appears alongside Fjori as a ghost, and awards the Ghostblade to the Dragonborn for freeing them.
author: Bethesda

name: Horgeir
bio:
Horgeir is a Nord lumberjack who resides in Dragon Bridge. He owns the local lumber mill and, according to his wife, is a lazy, good-for-nothing drunk. He says that she is spiteful and unloving.
Horgeir's wife Olda will ask the Dragonborn to retrieve his favorite mead from a secret hiding spot. Once they retrieve it, they can choose to either return it to her or Horgeir. If they decide to return it to Horgeir, he will offer them a Block skill increase.
author: Bethesda

name: Horik Halfhand
bio:
Horik Halfhand is a Nord warrior in Skyrim who lives in Dawnstar. He serves as a housecarl and bodyguard to Brina Merilis, and can be found inside The White Hall once certain quest requirements are fulfilled on the Imperial Quest Line.
Horik has served with Brina nearly his whole life. With no command ambitions of his own, he is content to serve as her bodyguard. Horik has nothing but respect and admiration for his commander, and there are few things that would shake his loyalty of her.
Horik "Are you alright? You seem tired." Horik "No. If we must fight, we will, and you will lead us to victory. As you always have." Horik "Of course. I would have it no other way."
Brina "You never talk about yourself much, do you, Horik? I swear, these past 30 years you've been at my side and I think I barely know you." Horik "What's to say? I was born on a farm, joined the Legion when I came of age, and I've served you ever since." Brina "What about your family? There must have been someone waiting for you back at the farm. Wondering if you were ever coming home?" Horik "No. Can't say that there was. My parents died when I was young. You and the Legion have been my only family since." Horik "You weren't. There's just not much to it."
author: Bethesda

name: Horm
bio:
Horm is a Nord citizen who resides at Katla's Farm outside of Solitude.
Horm is the adult son of Geimund and Fridrika. He and his family all live at Solitude Stables.
He seems to be spending his days indoors, rarely going outdoors. When the Dragonborn tries to have a dialogue with him, he refers to his father assuming it is about the horses.
author: Bethesda

name: Hrefna
bio:
Hrefna is a Nord child living in Darkwater Crossing.
She is the daughter of Tormir. When Tormir is not around, Sondas Drenim takes care of her. She walks around Goldenrock Mine during the day, carrying a pickaxe, but she rarely uses it.
When Derkeethus is missing, she admits she misses him. If and when he returns, she will say that she goes swimming with him in the river every now and then.
It appears that she does not like the Stormcloak rebellion, despite her family's support of it.
She mentions an elf named Meieran (which does not appear in the game) in conversations, suggesting that he is quite friendly with her, and that he teaches her many things.
author: Bethesda

name: Hreinn
bio:
Hreinn's father, Kleppr, will ask him who was attacked in the market, Hreinn will then answer by saying it was Margret, Cosnach will then enter the conversation saying that since Margret was a Nord and a noble that she was targeted by the Forsworn, Hreinn will then reply saying that Cosnach is paranoid and that they control the city, not the Forsworn. Hreinn also has another argument with Cosnach about the Forsworn.
Hreinn thinks that the Jarl has things under control and that this is their city not the Forsworn's. He doesn't think the Forsworn pose a huge threat.
Hreinn "Father, why do you and mother fight so much?"
Hreinn "Today, I've cleaned the linens, washed the floors and checked in on all the guests." Hreinn "But mother says you're a terrible innkeeper!" Kleppr "Never mind your mother, Hreinn. You listen to me and you'll be a great man one day."
author: Bethesda

name: Hroar
bio:
Hroar is a Nord orphan living in the Honorhall Orphanage in Riften, as one of the victims of the cruelty of the disastrously misnamed headmistress, Grelod the Kind.
Hroar claims his name was inspired by the roar of a lion. Although he has never seen a lion, he claims that his late mother told him this was the case. He goes on to say that he wants to be big and strong like a lion, when he grows up. He regrets that neither Grelod nor Constance Michel will allow him to be adopted, claiming, "I'd be the best son ever."
Unlike most of the other adoptable children, he does not mention how he lost his parents. He is one of the children who can be adopted by the Dragonborn.
author: Bethesda

name: Hrodulf
bio:
Hrodulf is a deceased Nord found by a boat near the middle of the southern shores of Solstheim, directly south of his house. A Burnt Spriggan can also be found near his corpse.
His journal reveals he moved to Solstheim and found an abandoned house where he took up residence. Not long after he began to hear noises coming from underneath the house at night. At first he began sleeping in the basement with a knife for protection, however the noises persisted so he began to tunnel deeper under the house to find the source of the noise. He found a large functioning Dwemer machine of some kind, but as time went on the constant rumbling eventually drove him insane.
His lover, Bjornolfr, lived in Solitude but was aware of his plight. Bjornolfr decided to travel to Solstheim to find Hrodulf, but died of unknown causes.
Near his corpse lie a Broken Iron War Axe Head and Broken Iron War Axe Handle. On the seat of the nearby boat lie an Amulet of Mara and a gold diamond ring, suggesting he was going to propose to Bjornolfr. There is also a locked strongbox and a chest next to the boat.
author: Bethesda

name: Hroggar
bio:
Hroggar is a Nord man who works as a lumberjack at the local mill in Morthal.
Hroggar once had a wife, with whom he had a young daughter named Helgi. However, his wife and daughter recently died when their family house burned down one night.
Hroggar's mind is now focused on a lovely woman named Alva, for whom he cares and protects with his life. He moved in with Alva after the fire.
Quotes:
"I... I'm not one for talk. Try to keep to myself."
"I just try and do my job, and not to think about what's happened. Try to find what happiness I can."
"Ignore the talk of spirits and creatures and such. It's just superstition."
"There's enough real troubles in the world without making new ones up."
"Alva's been good to me ever since... well, since the fire."
"I have Alva to take care of now. I don't need Helgi anymore."
"It's true, my house burned down, but I'm in a new house now. A better house."
If asked about a woman named Laelette: "She came by so Alva could kiss her goodbye. Then she left to join the Stormcloaks. Thonnir was cruel to her. He would beat her every night. It's no wonder she fled in the middle of the night."
If freed from Alva's spell: "Thank you for saving me from Alva. I was completely under her evil spell. I'll never forgive myself for what happened to Helgi and my wife."
author: Bethesda

name: Hroki
bio:
Hroki is a Nord residing in Markarth. Hroki can be found during the day at the market stalls inside the gates. She works at the Silver-Blood Inn, which is operated by her parents, Frabbi and Kleppr.
Her schedule consists of spending all day at market and working the inn at nights. She may be found bickering with Hogni Red-Arm, who she believes is the most "disgusting" merchant. She shops at Kerah's jewelry stall, and will tell her she is looking for something exotic that no one else in Markarth has, as well as take an interest in a ring made by Adara.
author: Bethesda

name: Hrolmir
bio:
Hrolmir is an unused Nord in Skyrim. He was supposed to make an appearance in the quest "The Pursuit," but was not added to the final version of the game.
Hrolmir does not appear in-game and can only be located through the use of console commands.
author: Bethesda

name: Hrongar
bio:
Hrongar, a Nord man, lives in Whiterun. He is the younger brother of Jarl Balgruuf, the ruler of Whiterun. Hrongar often gets into disagreements with the Jarl's steward, a meek Imperial man named Proventus Avenicci. Hrongar can usually be found sitting at the table in Dragonsreach, eating, or aimlessly walking the halls.
Hrongar is a devoted warrior and adherent of Nord customs and traditions. Any verbal attack made against him (most notably by Proventus Avenicci) is met with anger. He is not, however, a supporter of the Stormcloaks, often voicing his support of the Empire and how Whiterun should take the fight to the Stormcloaks instead of sitting around and waiting.
author: Bethesda

name: Huki Seven-Swords
bio:
Huki Seven-Swords is an unused character residing in the Windhelm Pit, a location accessible only through the use of console commands.
Huki is the Pit's jailkeeper. She shows little respect towards those in the Pit, as is evident by her dialogue with the Dragonborn. She is a Stormcloak supporter and dislikes the Imperials.
What do I have to do?: "We don't just let people rot in cells until they've served their time. Here, you fight. If you win, you go free. If you lose, well, you'll know the freedom of Sovngarde if you're lucky."
I want to fight Alain Dufont. "Well aren't you in luck. He's the next piece of gutter scum on the docket. Between you and me, I hope you cleave his arrogant head open."
author: Bethesda

name: Hulda
bio:
Hulda, a middle-aged Nord woman, is the innkeeper and the owner of The Bannered Mare in Whiterun.
Hulda has auburn-titian colored hair and hazel eyes. She usually wears an orange set of farm clothes.
Hulda has owned The Bannered Mare for quite some time and she considers herself to be living well. Hulda enjoys her job, but will soon be ready to retire, and is considering selling the inn to Ysolda, a young Nord woman who is an aspiring merchant.
Hulda may tell the player to have a seat by the fire when they enter the Bannered Mare. Once seated down on the bench by the fire, Hulda will tell Saadia or one of the other barmaids to serve the player. If the player is in need of a room at the inn for the day/night, Hulda will rent them one.
Hulda may mention that the Companions at Jorrvaskr are currently willing to accept worthy new members.
Hulda may mention Jarl Balgruuf’s troubled youngest son, Nelkir.
Hulda may mention the damaged condition of the Gildergreen in Whiterun’s Wind District, near the Temple of Kynareth.
If the player claims to have been infected by Sanguinare Vampiris (vampirism), Hulda will talk about Falion, a wizard living in Morthal, who has been experimenting on the undead, including vampires, and is knowledgeable on the topic.
Hulda is willing to buy firewood at the rate of 5 gold per piece of firewood.
Quotes:
If asked about where one can learn more about magic: “Magic is for the weak. Elves, I mean. They keep to that College in Winterhold. They know their place. Of course there is Farengar. He might be the Jarl's wizard, but at least he's a Nord."
If asked about where one can learn more about magic, and the player is an elf (such as a Dunmer, Altmer, or Bosmer): "Pfft, I should've guessed as much. Your kind sticks to that College in Winterhold, as well they should. You'd never think to learn from a Nord like the Jarl's wizard."
If the Stormcloaks take control of Whiterun, and Hulda is asked about how this has affected her: "Well, the Stormcloak guards drink a lot more than the Imperials did, so I've been making more money lately. On the other hand, they're a violent bunch. Every night a fight breaks out and I end up with a smashed chair or a broken table. So, not much has changed, really."
author: Bethesda

name: Hunroor
bio:
Hunroor was a Nord warrior. He is a hero, and his ghost can be found inside the Hall of Valor in Sovngarde. He, Nikulas, and Erlendr were turned into a stone pillar at Brodir Grove by the wizard Grimkell while searching for Sovngarde. Ulfgar the Unending later avenged them by killing Grimkell. Hunroor and his companions eventually did find Sovngarde.
Gain entrance to the Hall of Valor in Sovngarde and prepare for a final assault against Alduin.
author: Bethesda

name: Hunter
bio:
Hunters can be found all throughout the forests, mountains, and swamps of Skyrim. They may be encountered alone or in small groups. Some of them have a dog. Occasionally, they can be found at small camp sites.
Hunters can be male or female, and are primarily Nords. Redguard, Khajiit, and Bosmer hunters make up most of the remaining hunter demographic. They usually wear hide armor or leather armor, but can occasionally be found in studded armor. They often wear boots, gloves and sometimes a hat. Their weapons typically consist of a hunting bow, some iron arrows, and an iron dagger.
Hunters can be found throughout Skyrim stalking animals such as deer, elk, rabbits, and wolves, which they use for meat and hides. Hunters are not hostile to other people, unless attacked. Hunters will usually have hides and meat to sell travelers.
Quotes:
"I've been hunting and fishing in these parts for years."
"It's not like my poaching is hurting anyone. The Jarl can hardly eat every deer now can he?"
"There's enough for all of us if you aren't greedy."
author: Bethesda

name: Iddra
bio:
Iddra, a Nord woman, is the innkeeper of Braidwood Inn in the small town of Kynesgrove. She offers rooms for rent and sells various kinds of food. She has has a husband named Kjeld, and together they have a older teenage son named Kjeld the Younger and younger daughter named Froa.
Iddra may ask the player to convince Roggi Knot-Beard to stop worrying about paying the drinking debts he owes the inn.
Iddra suspects that her husband Kjeld has been cheating on her.
author: Bethesda

name: Idesa Sadri
bio:
Idesa Sadri is a Dunmer and the live-in nanny of Grimvar Cruel-Sea. She may be found at the House of Clan Cruel-Sea or somewhere else in Windhelm. The first time the Dragonborn meets her, she is talking to Grimvar Cruel-Sea about Aventus Aretino commenting about how strange he is and suggesting Grimvar stay away from him.
Afterwards, Idesa can generally be found wandering Windhelm in or near the Cruel-Sea's home or near the marketplace. She can sometimes also be found walking through the Gray Quarter.
Grimvar: "Then it's true, what everyone is saying? That Aventus Aretino is doing the Black Sacrament? Trying to summon the Dark Brotherhood?"Idesa: "Oh, Grimvar... always with the nonsense. No, no, of course not. Those are just tales..."Grimvar: "Fine. Then I'll invite him out to play. He lives right there. I'm going to knock on his door..."Idesa: "No, child! Wait! That boy, that house - they're cursed."Grimvar: "Ha! Then I'm right. I knew it. He's trying to have somebody killed!"Idesa: "All right. I won't deny it, child. What you heard is true. But Aventus Aretino walks a dark path. His actions can lead only to ruin. Now, enough. We will speak no more of this. I am the only friend you need.
author: Bethesda

name: Idgrod Ravencrone
bio:
Idgrod Ravencrone is the Jarl of Hjaalmarch. She rules over Hjaalmarch hold from Highmoon Hall, her longhouse in Morthal. Morthal is the capital of Hjaalmarch.
Idgrod is an elderly Nord woman with long dark hair. She is a seer of psychic visions and dreams.
Idgrod appears relaxed, and chooses to quote phrases of wisdom and patience. She is quite wise and learned, though many of her people seem to think she is mentally unstable due to her enigmatic personality and affiliation with magic. Though she aligns her hold of Hjaalmarch with the Empire, she is not particularly concerned with the ongoing civil war between the Empire and the Stormcloak rebellion (a trait she shares with Jarl Balgruuf of Whiterun) and also dislikes the Thalmor due to their ruthless and treacherous nature.
She associates herself with Falion, a Redguard newcomer to Hjaalmarch and a wizard. Because of their kinship, she is mistrusted by the members of Morthal. Though Falion is disliked by the much of the Morthal's townspeople, he is more altruistic than bothersome.
Idgrod has an older teenage daughter named Idgrod the Younger, and a young son named Joric. She raises her two children with Aslfur, her husband and court steward. A man named Gorm is her personal housecarl.
If the Stormcloak rebellion seizes control of Morthal, Idgrod and her family will be forced into exile at the Blue Palace in Solitude, the provincial capital of Skyrim.
Out of diplomatic necessity, Idgrod sometimes attends parties hosted by Thalmor ambassador Elenwen, at the Thalmor Embassy near Solitude. If Idgrod is encountered at one of these parties, she will be happy to create a distraction if requested.
Idgrod may ask a visiting adventurer to investigate a suspicious house fire in which a woman and young girl were killed. Many suspect that the man of this house intentionally set fire to his house in order to kill his family, with the end goal of entering into a romantic relationship with another woman named Alva.
Quotes:
"So, life has brought you to Morthal, and to me. What purpose this serves, we will no doubt see. Welcome."
"Tamriel is full of wisdom and magic, if one is willing to look for it. Few have their eyes open."
"I speak, and others hear. It is my hope that instead they listen."
"In Morthal, there is little to rule. But there is much to teach. And so, I am Jarl."
"All this talk of rebellion and strife. Too many are focused on what might be instead of what is. It tires me to talk about it."
"There is too much to learn in the world, too much to know, to fight over 'laws' that have no real purpose."
"That which is unknown can cause unease, even fear. It is to be expected. Some fear our new resident wizard. As they grow to know him, they will accept him. Time will prove me right."
"The Divines reveal things to me at times. I do not hide this. It is a gift. Anyone who believes otherwise does not and cannot understand it."
If asked about her stance on the ongoing civil war: "I stand where I have always stood. Here in Morthal. Now is not the time to fight amongst ourselves. I fear dark days approach and all of Skyrim's strength will be needed."
author: Bethesda

name: Idgrod the Younger
bio:
Idgrod the Younger, a young Nord woman, resides in Morthal. She has long, dark hair. She is the only daughter of Jarl Idgrod Ravencrone and Aslfur of Morthal. She cares for her younger sickly brother, Joric. She spends most of her time in or around Highmoon Hall, the Jarl’s longhouse in Morthal.
Idgrod may ask the player to deliver a letter to Danica Pure-Spring at the Temple of Kynareth in Whiterun, regarding the welfare of Joric. Danica had been sending potions to Idgrod to help improve her brother's condition.
Idgrod sometimes converses with Lami at Thaumaturgist's Hut (Lami’s alchemy shop in Morthal).
Quotes:
"I don't... I haven't mother's gift, not quite, but I've seen things."
“Someday I'll be the Jarl. Mother reminds me often. I hope I can help the people of Morthal the way she has."
"For now, looking after Joric is my job."
"It's difficult sometimes... To know whether what I see is real or not."
If asked what is wrong with her brother Joric: "My brother is... sensitive. He has trouble focusing his attention on things. We were taking him to the Temple of Kynareth in Whiterun, just so the healers could make sure he was in good health, and they say he's fine. Are you heading to Whiterun? Could you take this letter to the priestess, Danica Pure-Spring? It's a note about Joric's health."
author: Bethesda

name: Idolaf Battle-Born
bio:
Idolaf Battle-Born is a Nord found in the city of Whiterun. Like the rest of his family, he favors the Imperial Legion in the Civil War. The first time the Dragonborn walks into Whiterun, he can be seen talking with Adrianne Avenicci. He is married to Alfhild with whom he has a son named Lars.
Idolaf: "We'll pay whatever it takes. But we must have more swords for the Imperial soldiers." Adrianne: "I just can't fill an order that size on my own. Why don't you swallow that stubborn pride of yours and ask Eorlund Gray-Mane for help?" Idolaf: "Ha! I'd sooner bend my knee to Ulfric Stormcloak. Besides, Gray-Mane would never make steel for the Legion." Adrianne: "Have it your way. I'll take the job, but don't expect a miracle."
Olfrid: "Foolish old woman! You know nothing! Nothing of our struggles, our suffering!" Fralia: "Nothing? And what of my son, hmm? What of Thorald? Is he nothing? So don't talk to me about suffering!" Idolaf: "Your son chose his side, and he chose poorly. And now he's gone. Such is the way of war. The sooner you accept his loss, the better." Fralia: "I will never accept his death! My son still lives. I feel it in my heart. So tell me, Battle-Borns, where is he? Where are you holding my Thorald?" Olfrid: "[to son] Do you believe this old hag? [to Fralia] "Holding him"? Why, I've got him in my cellar. He's my prisoner. Face it, cow! Your stupid son is dead! He died a Stormcloak traitor. And you...you best keep your mouth shut before you suffer the same." Idolaf: "Come on, father. There's nothing more to be said here."
author: Bethesda

name: Igmund
bio:
Igmund, an older Nord man, is the Jarl of The Reach. He resides in Understone Keep in Markarth. He strongly supports the Empire and peace with the Thalmor. From Igmund, it is learned that the Markarth Incident started the Stormcloak rebellion. He severed his ties with Ulfric Stormcloak after the Third Aldmeri Dominion threatened the Reach with war.
When compared with other Jarls, Igmund is the least worried about the dragons, because Markarth is made entirely out of stone, due to being built into the side of the mountain.
If the Stormcloaks are sided with during the Civil War, Igmund will be replaced by Thongvor Silver-Blood as Jarl of Markarth. Igmund can then be found in the basement of the Blue Palace in Solitude, along with the other replaced Jarls, stewards and housecarls.
If the Empire is sided with after the quest Season Unending, Igmund will regain his throne as Jarl of Markarth. Thongvor Silver-Blood and his steward will be moved to the Palace of the Kings in Windhelm along with the other replaced Jarls, Stewards, and Housecarls.
After retrieving Igmund's father's shield, helping various citizens, and killing groups of Forsworn around the Reach, Igmund will grant the player permission to purchase the Vlindrel Hall residence, and will bestow the player with the Blade of the Reach, as well as the title of Thane.
Quotes:
"There is room in my court for a new Thane. It's an honorary title, mainly, but there are a few perks someone like you could make use of. However, I could only grant the title to someone who is known throughout my Hold, and who owns at least one piece of property in my city. You help my people and purchase a house from my steward, and I'll make you my Thane."
If the players helps enough citizens of the Reach: "Then by my right as Jarl, I name you Thane of the Reach. Congratulations. I grant you a personal Housecarl to watch over your home and this weapon from my armory to serve as your badge of office. I'll also notify my guards of your new title. Wouldn't want them to think you're part of the common rabble, now."
author: Bethesda

name: Ilas-Tei
bio:
Ilas-Tei is a deceased Argonian apprentice mage from the College of Winterhold in Skyrim. He was one of the missing students that Phinis Gestor will tell the Dragonborn of. He died practicing a Calm spell on skeevers, evidently with little success. Two Scrolls of Calm and a Scroll of Fury can be found nearby. The Scroll of Fury is lying right next to him with the Scroll of Calm on a nearby crate.
The apprentice's corpse can be found at the Shrine of Talos: Ilas-Tei's Last Stand, along with his ring. However, since this is a broken quest, acquiring it ends the quest.
author: Bethesda

name: Ildari Sarothril
bio:
Ildari Sarothril, a Dunmer woman, is a necromancer who once served as an apprentice of Neloth, the Telvanni wizard who lives at Tel Mithryn on the island of Solstheim. She is encountered in Highpoint Tower, northwest of Tel Mithryn.
The Telvanni wizard Neloth had been planning for many years to enhance his magical abilities by replacing his own heart with a Heart Stone, similar to how Forsworn Briarhearts replace theirs with Briar Hearts. Ildari, his apprentice, volunteered to be his test subject before he underwent the operation himself, but she was apparently accidentally killed when Neloth performed the operation incorrectly. At least, that was what Neloth believed. In reality, Ildari survived due to the Heart Stone still embedded in her chest, and greatly resents Neloth's bungled operation. Neloth promised her power and glory, but gave her only great pain, and that she plans to get her revenge on Neloth by necromantically raising an army of Ash Spawn to destroy Tel Mithryn.
After escaping her grave, Ildari traveled to Highpoint Tower and was taken in by a group of miners, who believed she was severely injured and nursed her back to health. Through the Heart Stone, Ildari noticed that she had become stronger, could feel the bones in the ash calling to her, and had learned how to bind the spirits to bone and ash and raise a servant to do her bidding. She has a journal in which she details these experiences.
However, Ildari also started to become paranoid from constantly hearing the bones' voices in her head. The voices told her that the miners wanted her Heart Stone for themselves. Raising her Ash Spawn from the ground, she killed the miners' leader and then imprisoned the others as her own test subjects, though it is unknown what experiments she conducted on them. Highpoint Tower thereby became her base of operations where she could plot her revenge upon Neloth undisturbed.
Ildari's journal in Fort Frostmoth details her successful attempts at re-animating General Falx Carius from the dead, to use him as a puppet in her plan to get revenge on Neloth.
In combat, Ildari will use her Staff of Lightning Bolts, ward and Shock spells. If fought in her final chambers, she will be aided by two soul-gem fueled traps that will shoot lightning towards intruders. These traps can be disabled by removing the soul gem manually or with a projectile.
As long Ildari she still possesses her heart stone, she will not die.
author: Bethesda

name: Illdi
bio:
Illdi, a young Nord woman, is a student at the Bards College in Solitude. She has brown hair and blue eyes.
Illdi holds a great deal of respect for Dean Inge Six Fingers, an old woman who is one of Illdi’s teachers at the College. Illdi gets the impression that Dean Pantea Ateia (an Imperial woman who is another one of Illdi’s teachers) doesn’t like her very much. Illdi is very insecure, and feels that she is not very well-liked by most people. She generally spends her evenings wandering around alone in the courtyard outside the College.
Illdi can sometimes be seen at the performing with the flute at the Thalmor Embassy west of Solitude, during parties hosted by Ambassador Elenwen.
A Redguard man named Ataf, who is the youngest student at the Bards College, might have a crush on Illdi.
Quotes:
"You know, I don't get the impression that I'm very well liked at the College..."
"Dean Inge says a bard can never have enough practice. So, would you like a tune?"
If playing at the Thalmor Embassy: "These parties are a great way to earn a little extra money."
author: Bethesda

name: Illia
bio:
Illia is a mage who has grown up living with her mother as a member of a coven of witches and hagravens living in Darklight Tower, at the base of the Jerall Mountains in the Rift. Illia has recently had a change of heart, and wants to escape the coven.
Illia is an Imperial woman with long dark hair. She typically wears a set of blue enchanted mage robes. She is a powerful mage and specializes in Frost-based Destruction magic. She especially favors the Ice Storm spell, which harms and slows everyone within a large area. She also keeps a bow, a dagger, and some healing potions with her.
When first encountered in Darklight Tower, Illia will ask for help in slaying her mother Silvia. Silvia wants to use human sacrifice to transform herself into a powerful hagraven. Witches and hagravens are guarding the path up to the roof of the tower, where Illia's mother is preparing her transformation ritual.
If Illia is assisted with the slaying of her mother, she will become willing to follow and travel with the player on adventures.
Quotes:
When first encountered in Darlight Tower: "By the gods! I know this looks bad. Let me explain... I just can't be a part of this place any more! The things we do here - evil, evil things. No more! We were supposed to find a sacrifice. Human sacrifice. I've done horrible things living here, but never taken an innocent life. I couldn't just find some person for them to kill. They need a sacrifice for the Initiation. My mother is going to become one of those things. A Hagraven. I can't be a part of that. Gods, I can't run away from this. I have to stop her. I'm going up there to stop her. This cycle must end. I don't know what brought you here, but I could use your help, if you're willing. We have to fight our way up the tower. I don't think anyone else here is about to have a change of heart."
When nearing the roof of the tower: "All right. Mother is just outside this door. I have a plan. I'll present you as the sacrifice. Just play along. While mother begins the ritual, I'll strike. Then, together we can... we can kill her. I've thought this through, and it's the only way. She's too far gone, too corrupted by the Hags. At least in death she can be free again. Enough. Let's go."
If Silvia has just been slain: "Don't be sorry for me. I just - if I would have known it would come to this... mother... You should keep mother's staff. Think of it as payment. I want to leave everything from this cursed place behind. Thank you."
If asked to follow the player on adventures after her mother has been killed: "I suppose it would be better than sitting around thinking about all this. I could also do some good for a change. Sure, I'll go with you."
author: Bethesda

name: Imedhnain
bio:
Imedhnain is a Breton food vendor living in Markarth.
He works and sleeps in the Arnleif and Sons Trading Company, in Markarth. He assists Lisbet, the owner of the shop. Imedhnain's cousin, Cosnach, also works for the company.
If the Dragonborn murders Cosnach or steals from him, Imedhnain will send hired thugs after the Dragonborn.
If Lisbet dies, Imedhnain will take over the Arnleif and Sons Trading Company.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Archer
bio:
Imperial Archers are archers used by the Imperial Legion to fight the Stormcloak Rebellion during the Skyrim Civil War.
The Imperial Archer is level 3 by default, but once the Dragonborn passes that level the archers level with them. For example, if the Dragonborn is level 96, then the archers are also level 96.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Captain
bio:
Imperial Captain, an Imperial woman, is a member of the Imperial Legion. She was just recently overseeing the execution of Stormcloak rebel prisoners of war at the town of Helgen, until a black dragon started laying waste to the town with fire breath and meteors from the sky. She then fled into the Helgen's Keep with other Imperial soldiers.
She does not know if General Tullius, the military governor of Skyrim and her commanding officer, is still alive. Two days ago, General Tullius had organized a brilliant ambush of the traitor Ulfric Stormcloak and some of his officers at Darkwater Crossing. After the ambush, the Imperial force marched west past Skyrim's central mountain range with their Stormcloak prisoners, until the reached Helgen, where Tullius decided to execute the rebels without further delay. They also arrested a horse thief named Lokir along the way, who was killed by archers under her order when he tried to flee the executioner's axe. They only managed to execute one Stormcloak rebel before the dragon attacked, who refused his last rites by the Priestess of Arkay. The Imperial force had also arrested the player for trying to cross the closed-off Cyrodiil-Skyrim border. She ordered the player to be executed as well, but before the executioner could strike, the dragon attacked, and the player and many of the Stormcloak rebels (including Ulfric) managed to escape into the tunnels under Helgen.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Courier
bio:
Imperial Couriers are used by the Imperial Legion to deliver war-essential supplies and letters, as part of the ongoing war against the Stormcloak rebellion against the Empire. 
These couriers are usually found on the main roads of Skyrim. They are a specialized variant of Imperial soldier. They are often running and in a hurry to reach their next destination.
They wear a full set of Imperial light armor and wield an Imperial sword during combat. They also carry an Imperial bow and approximately a dozen steel arrows. They also carry a steel dagger.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Deserter
bio:
The Imperial Deserter, an Imperial man, is a skooma addict. He is currently located inside of Redwater Den, a remote secret underground structure whose owners offer a special variety of skooma (a popular illegal narcotic drug) called redwater skooma. This underground structure is hidden within the forests in the northern part of the Rift.
He has short dark hair. He wears a set of light Imperial soldier armor (but with no helmet), and carries an Imperial shield.
He was one of the Imperial soldiers stationed in Helgen when a mighty black dragon swooped in and laid waste to the town. He escaped Helgen’s destruction, but injured his back. To ease the pain, he took to using redwater slooma, and subsequently became addicted to it. He is one of the many redwater skooma addicts found within Redwater Den.
Quotes:
"Wha- who... you're that one from Helgen. Barely made it out of there myself. I hurt my back and I- I just need something for the pain."
"I ain't in the mood to talk. Ohhhh..."
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial General
bio:
Imperial Generals are enemies encountered in Skyrim, if the Stormcloaks are sided with in the Civil War. They may be seen at any number of city battles in command of Imperial forces. 
Imperial Generals will appear as enemies during the battle if the Dragonborn sides with the Stormcloaks.
They wear Imperial Armor, and are usually Imperials. They also wield an Imperial Sword in battle.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Mage
bio: Imperial Mage, an Imperial man, uses magic to serve as a specialized soldier for the Imperial Legion. The few Imperial mages deployed to Skyrim are mostly used to fight against the Stormcloak rebelion.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Officer
bio: Imperial Officers are unused members of the Imperial Legion in Skyrim. They are cut from the main Civil War questline.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Quartermaster
bio:
Imperial Quartermasters are stationed in Imperial camps throughout Skyrim. These various camps are a part of the Imperial Legion's war effort against the Stormcloak rebellion.
Quartermasters are in charge of issuing weapons, armor, and other supplies to the soldiers in their camp, and can service as blacksmiths in a limited capacity. They also help tend to wounded and sick soldiers when necessary.
Quartermasters can be members of any of the 4 human races: Imperial, Nord, Breton, or Redguard. In combat, they wield a variety of high quality one-handed weapons.
If anyone in the area is believed to be (or admits to being) a member of the Stormcloak rebellion, the quartermaster and the other members of the Imperial camp will become offended and attack them.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Soldier
bio:
Imperial Soldiers serve the Imperial Legion, the main armed force of the Empire. Though a fraction of the Imperial forces stationed in Skyrim are not originally from Skyrim, a larger portion of them are local recruits who call Skyrim their home. The Legion forces in Skyrim have received little in the way of reinforcements from the other provinces of the Empire.
Soldiers join the Legion for a variety of reasons. Some join out of tradition, because their parents were Legionnaires before them and they never considered doing anything else. Others join out of a desire to see the world. There are also those who have joined the Legion to help put an end to the Stormcloak rebellion, though this sometimes results in disagreements with family members, who are often times sympathetic to the Stormcloak cause.
Imperial soldiers sometimes later go on to work as mercenaries for the East Empire Company, where they help handle pirates and other threats to the Company's shipping.
Legion forces in Skyrim are largely considered to be militia, and this is exemplified by their armor, which is often light and not meant for sustained heavy combat.
The Legion's forces in Skyrim are ultimately commanded by General Tullius, while the recruitment is overseen by Legate Rikke. Tullius and Rikke can usually be found in Castle Dour in Solitude, the Imperial Legion's headquarters in Skyrim.
The most common races making up the Imperial forces in Skyrim are Imperials and Nords, though Redguards, Bretons, Dunmer, Orcs, and even a small number of Altmer also help comprise its forces. Dunmer farmers within Skyrim can occasionally be seen making their way to Solitude to join up with the Legion, as they see their discriminatory treatment at the hands of the Nords as injust.
Legion soldiers are almost exclusively men. This is in contrast with the demographics of Stormcloak rebel soldiers, whose ranks are filled with a noticeable fraction of women.
If the player is a member of the Imperial Legion, Imperial soldiers will greet them according to their rank.
Most Imperial soldiers wear a full set of Imperial Light Armor, wearing either studded light armor or normal light armor. They sometimes use Imperial shields, and are armed with Imperial swords and bows, using steel arrows as ammunition. The higher ranking Legion officers usually wear heavier armor.

There are also those who have joined the Legion to help put an end to the Stormcloak rebellion, though this sometimes results in disagreements with family members, who are often times sympathetic to the Stormcloak cause.
Imperial soldiers sometimes later go on to work as mercenaries for the East Empire Company, where they help handle pirates and other threats to the Company's shipping.
Legion forces in Skyrim are largely considered to be militia, and this is exemplified by their armor, which is often light and not meant for sustained heavy combat.
The Legion's forces in Skyrim are ultimately commanded by General Tullius, while the recruitment is overseen by Legate Rikke. Tullius and Rikke can usually be found in Castle Dour in Solitude, the Imperial Legion's headquarters in Skyrim.
The most common races making up the Imperial forces in Skyrim are Imperials and Nords, though Redguards, Bretons, Dunmer, Orcs, and even a small number of Altmer also help comprise its forces. Dunmer farmers within Skyrim can occasionally be seen making their way to Solitude to join up with the Legion, as they see their discriminatory treatment at the hands of the Nords as injust.
Legion soldiers are almost exclusively men. This is in contrast with the demographics of Stormcloak rebel soldiers, whose ranks are filled with a noticeable fraction of women.
If the player is a member of the Imperial Legion, Imperial soldiers will greet them according to their rank.
Most Imperial soldiers wear a full set of Imperial Light Armor, wearing either studded light armor or normal light armor. They sometimes use Imperial shields, and are armed with Imperial swords and bows, using steel arrows as ammunition. The higher ranking Legion officers usually wear heavier armor.

The most common races making up the Imperial forces in Skyrim are Imperials and Nords, though Redguards, Bretons, Dunmer, Orcs, and even a small number of Altmer also help comprise its forces. Dunmer farmers within Skyrim can occasionally be seen making their way to Solitude to join up with the Legion, as they see their discriminatory treatment at the hands of the Nords as injust.
Legion soldiers are almost exclusively men. This is in contrast with the demographics of Stormcloak rebel soldiers, whose ranks are filled with a noticeable fraction of women.
If the player is a member of the Imperial Legion, Imperial soldiers will greet them according to their rank.
Most Imperial soldiers wear a full set of Imperial Light Armor, wearing either studded light armor or normal light armor. They sometimes use Imperial shields, and are armed with Imperial swords and bows, using steel arrows as ammunition. The higher ranking Legion officers usually wear heavier armor.

If the player is a member of the Imperial Legion, Imperial soldiers will greet them according to their rank.
Most Imperial soldiers wear a full set of Imperial Light Armor, wearing either studded light armor or normal light armor. They sometimes use Imperial shields, and are armed with Imperial swords and bows, using steel arrows as ammunition. The higher ranking Legion officers usually wear heavier armor.
author: Bethesda

name: Imperial Soldier
bio:
Imperial Soldiers serve the Imperial Legion, the main armed force of the Empire. Though a fraction of the Imperial forces stationed in Skyrim are not originally from Skyrim, a larger portion of them are local recruits who call Skyrim their home. The Legion forces in Skyrim have received little in the way of reinforcements from the other provinces of the Empire.
Soldiers join the Legion for a variety of reasons. Some join out of tradition, because their parents were Legionnaires before them and they never considered doing anything else. Others join out of a desire to see the world. There are also those who have joined the Legion to help put an end to the Stormcloak rebellion, though this sometimes results in disagreements with family members, who are often times sympathetic to the Stormcloak cause.
Imperial soldiers sometimes later go on to work as mercenaries for the East Empire Company, where they help handle pirates and other threats to the Company's shipping.
Legion forces in Skyrim are largely considered to be militia, and this is exemplified by their armor, which is often light and not meant for sustained heavy combat.
The Legion's forces in Skyrim are ultimately commanded by General Tullius, while the recruitment is overseen by Legate Rikke. Tullius and Rikke can usually be found in Castle Dour in Solitude, the Imperial Legion's headquarters in Skyrim.
The most common races making up the Imperial forces in Skyrim are Imperials and Nords, though Redguards, Bretons, Dunmer, Orcs, and even a small number of Altmer also help comprise its forces. Dunmer farmers within Skyrim can occasionally be seen making their way to Solitude to join up with the Legion, as they see their discriminatory treatment at the hands of the Nords as injust.
Legion soldiers are almost exclusively men. This is in contrast with the demographics of Stormcloak rebel soldiers, whose ranks are filled with a noticeable fraction of women.
If the player is a member of the Imperial Legion, Imperial soldiers will greet them according to their rank.
Most Imperial soldiers wear a full set of Imperial Light Armor, wearing either studded light armor or normal light armor. They sometimes use Imperial shields, and are armed with Imperial swords and bows, using steel arrows as ammunition. The higher ranking Legion officers usually wear heavier armor.

author: Bethesda
note: Shawn - generic version, for Mantella to retrieve if there's no ID match. Should be the first Imperial Soldier entry in published csv

name: Imperial Wizard
bio: Imperial wizard, an Nord man, is a member of the Imperial Legion and wears a full set of Imperial light armor. The legion usually deploys his magical expertise during sieges on Stormcloak-occupied forts and cities.
author: Bethesda

name: Indara Caerellia
bio:
Indara Caerellia is an Imperial farmer in Falkreath.
Indara is the wife of Mathies and owns Corpselight Farm in Falkreath with him. They had a nine-year-old daughter named Lavinia, but she was lost recently when Sinding, a transient worker, murdered Lavinia at the lumber mill in town. Indara and her husband are first encountered by the player in the cemetery, attending their daughter's funeral, which is led by Runil.
Quotes:
Indara: "Thank you, Runil. Your support means much to us."
author: Bethesda

name: Indaryn
bio:
Indaryn is a Dunmer, and head of the Black-Briar Meadery in Riften. Indaryn shows no nervousness about losing his job, and unlike most other workers at the meadery, gives his honest opinion of Maven Black-Briar if asked.
Indaryn will send Hired Thugs after the Dragonborn if they steal from the Black-Briar Meadery.
Indaryn had an affair with Haelga, which involves him in the quest "Caught Red Handed." His Mark of Dibella must be obtained from him. If Indaryn dies before the Dragonborn completes the quest for Svana Far-Shield, the quest will fail automatically. The quest will fail if he dies before the quest is started, as well.
In Romlyn Dreth's quest to smuggle a keg of Black-Briar Mead to Ivarstead, instead of delivering it to the Inn there, one can instead rat out Romlyn to Indaryn, who will then give a reward in return, as well as the Dragonborn being able to freely take from the mead barrels in the Brewery.
author: Bethesda

name: Indolent Farmer
bio:
The Indolent Farmer is a Nord contractor for the quest "The Dark Brotherhood Forever." He resides in the Vilemyr Inn in Ivarstead.
He will give a leveled sum of gold to the Dragonborn to assassinate a target, then wander through the inn until the target has been killed.
author: Bethesda

name: Inge Six Fingers
bio:
Inge Six Fingers is an Elder Nord member of the Bards College in Solitude.
Inge is known as the "Dean of Lutes" in the Bards College. She claims to be a master of the lute only because it takes a lifetime to master, which is also why she is known as Six-Fingers. She can be found wandering around the library or upstairs as she teaches the lute and other bardic specialties to students in the classroom upstairs.
Inge asks the Dragonborn to retrieve Finn's Lute, which has been stolen recently, from Stony Creek Cave.
I've found Finn's Lute. "What? You did? Oh sweet Divines! You did! There is no way I can pay you what this lute is worth. But I can teach you a few tricks I've learned over the years."
author: Bethesda

name: Ingjard
bio:
Ingjard, a Nord woman, is a vampire hunter and member of the Dawnguard. She has blue eyes and shoulder-length brown hair.
Fort Dawnguard is a large fort southeast of Riften which serves as the Dawnguard's base of operations. The fort is home to an order of vampire hunters who guard Skyrim from vampires (especially those of the Volkihar clan). The fort is hidden deep within the Velothi Mountains at the southeastern tip of The Rift (and of Skyrim), and can only be reached via Dayspring Canyon.
A Redguard man named Isran is the leader of the Dawnguard. Isran is stoic, uncompromising, and is always deadly serious. Isran probably hates vampires more than anyone else does, and many have deemed his methods to be extreme.
Ingjard and Beleval (a Bosmer woman) are two of the newest members of the Dawnguard. Sorine Jurard and Gunmar joined shortly before Ingjard and Beleval joined. Sorine is a Breton woman who specializes who in the art of crafting crossbows and crossbow bolts, heavily influenced by the methods of the ancient Dwemer. Gunmar is a Nord man who serves as the Dawnguard's main blacksmith, and who also trains and armors trolls for use in fighting vampires. The player joined shortly before Sorine and Gunmar joined, and helped convince them to join.
Ingjard is willing to follow the player on adventures across Skyrim. She will also be open to being hired as the steward of one of the player's homesteaded properties, if asked. Ingjard has a strong moral compass and will not be willing to commit crimes.
Ingjard is skilled with two-handed melee weaponry and ranged weapons, as well as with using heavy armor and a shield. Her default attire is a set of Dawnguard heavy armor. She only puts on her helmet if battle is imminent. When it comes to fighting, her default melee weapon is a Dawnguard warhammer, and her default ranged weapon is a crossbow supplemented with a supply of steel bolts. During combat, she will switch between the warhammer and the crossbow, depending on the situation.
Ingjard spends a fair amount of time practicing with her crossbow on dummy targets within Fort Dawnguard, often alongside Beleval.
Ingjard will still be willing to talk to the player if the player becomes infected with vampirism, but will of course still encourage them to find a cure for it as soon as possible.
Quotes:
"I hear you're doing a lot of the work in tracking down these vampires. If there's anything I can do to help, let me know."
If she is asked how she joined the Dawnguard: "Something bad happens, word spreads. More bad things happen, people worry. The more they worry, the more they talk about it. I've been hearing rumors for a bit now. I was glad to find out not only the bad rumors were true."
"Friends like you are hard to find, and very valuable to me."
author: Bethesda

name: Ingrid
bio: Ingrid, a Nord woman, lived in Helgen before it was destroyed by a mighty black dragon, which breathed fire and rained meteors upon the town until it was reduced to rubble. She is a staunch supporter of the Empire in the civil war against the Stormcloak rebellion. Shortly before the dragon attacked Helgen, General Tullius, the military governor of Skyrim, marched into town with a company of Imperial soldiers, with many Stormcloak prisoners (including their traitorous leader, Ulfric Stormcloak) in tow. They unfortunately only managed to execute one of the Stormcloak prisoners before the dragon attacked, allowing the rest of the Stormcloaks to escape.
author: Bethesda

name: Ingun Black-Briar
bio:
Ingun Black-Briar lives in Riften. She is a young Nord woman with amber eyes and dark hair, resembling her mother in appearance but not in personality. Like the rest of her family, she usually wears expensive fine clothing. Ingun is the daughter of Maven Black-Briar, the matriach of the Black-Briar family. The Black-Briars are undeniably the most affluent and influential family in Riften. Ingun has two older brothers named Hemming and Sibbi.
Ingun is fascinated by alchemy and is quite talented at it. She studies alchemy at an alchemy shop called Elgrim's Elixirs in Riften's lower levels, near the canal that runs through the city. At this shop, she serves as an apprentice to an elderly man named Elgrim. Elgrim's wife Hafjorg helps him run the shop. While Elgrim recognizes and appreciates Ingun's natural talent with alchemy, Ingun sometimes feels like he is too reluctant to entrust her with more advanced formulas.
Ingun been performing morbid but fascinating experiments on animals since she was a child. She spends nearly every day in the shop training in alchemy, and usually returns to straight home to her family's manor in the evening. She usually eats her meals alongside her family in their dining room. Her bedroom is in the manor's basement, which also contains an alchemy lab and ingredients.
Ingun generally dislikes her family. Her mother sometimes threatens to withhold money from her if she doesn't start taking interest in the family's business affairs. Ingun is more eloquent and polite than her brothers. Her brother Sibbi is currently a prisoner in the Riften jail under Mistveil Keep (the jarl's palace in the city). Sibbi is serving an eight month sentence for stabbing and killing Wulfur (the brother of his former fiance Svidi), though Sibbi claims this was done in self-defense.
Unfortunately, Ingun's recent experimental mistakes have wasted some of Elgrim's rare alchemy ingredients (in particular, nirnroot, nightshade, and deathbell), and she may request assistance in replacing these ingredients. Ingun will pay 750 gold for a batch of these three ingredients, and will also provide (as a supplementary reward) a key to her supply chest in the back of the Elgrim's Elixirs shop, in which Ingun sometimes stores some of her crafted potions.
Quotes:
"Hm? Sorry, just thinking about my experiments."
"My mind is on my experiments today. What did you need?"
If asked what fascinates her about alchemy: "It's exhilarating to observe the effects of my potions on the body. Watching the heart stop... the eyes go blind. We're made up of thousands of parts with thousands of different functions all working in tandem to keep us alive. Yet if only a single part of our imperfect machine fails, life fails. It makes one realize how fragile... how flawed we are. You ask why I'm so fascinated? The irony... the irony that the same world that gave us life provides us the means to die."
If asked about her family: "Hmph. My family. All that wealth and they squander it on foolish ventures and political schemes. I was meant for so much more than all of this... I wish to pledge my life and ply my talents in darker circles. If only my mother would let me, I would make her proud."
If asked if she's an alchemist: "I'm aspiring to earn that title, yes. However, the road ahead is paved with loose cobbles and deadly pitfalls. Master Elgrim says I'm a natural; that I have a unique talent. But I fear his approval masks his intolerance for my mistakes. My errant formulas have cost Master Elgrim a fortune in ingredients; some of which are almost irreplaceable."
If asked what ingredients she needs: "To restore Master Elgrim's supply I would need 20 deathbell, 20 nightshade and 20 nirnroot. Am I sensing that you may be interested in gathering these rare ingredients for me?"
If asked where to find the rare ingredients: "Nirnroot is the easiest. It grows only by the water and makes a unique chiming noise. Nightshade is native to the pine forest and marshy tundra regions of Skyrim and has a distinctive starburst-like violet flower. Last we have deathbell which only grows in marshy tundra terrain. Its inverted bluish-purple flower bunches are unmistakable."
If her requested rare ingredients are delivered to her: "Perfect. This is just what I needed. These are excellent samples. Thank you. Here's some coin for all the trouble. Master Elgrim will be pleased that I've restored his stock of these rare ingredients. I feel I owe a bit more than some meaningless coin for all your diligence. Here, this key unlocks my supply chest at Elgrim's Elixirs. Feel free to take what you need from time to time. I'll be refilling it once every few days or so."
author: Bethesda

name: Insane College Wizard
bio: Insane College Wizard is an unused Altmer Mage in Skyrim. The Dragonborn is sent to kill this hostile wizard to save the College of Winterhold's reputation.
author: Bethesda

name: Iona
bio:
Iona is a Nord housecarl in The Rift. She is appointed Housecarl of the Dragonborn when they become Thane of the Rift. She waits for the Dragonborn at Honeyside.
If the Dragonborn wears the Amulet of Mara, they can marry Iona. Like most spouses, she can be moved to another owned house. She is also a possible Blades Recruit.
Iona is eligible to be a steward for one of the Dragonborn's homes if she is approached near the property.
She is skilled in One-Handed, Heavy Armor and Block. It is also wise to give her a bow, as she is almost as skilled in Archery as in One-Handed.
author: Bethesda

name: Irgnir
bio:
Irgnir is a Nord miner in Skyrim who resides in Dawnstar. She works in the Iron-Breaker Mine and can be found at Windpeak Inn in the evening, and she lives in her house.
When the Dragonborn first arrives, she is complaining to Erandur about the nightmares near or inside Windpeak Inn.
author: Bethesda

name: Irileth
bio:
Irileth lives in Dragonsreach, the jarl's palace in the city of Whiterun. She serves as housecarl to Jarl Balgruuf the Greater, and rarely leaves his side.
When Irileth and Balgruuf were battle comrades during the war against the Aldmeri Dominion almost 30 years ago, they agreed that Irileth would serve as Balruuf's housecarl after the war. Irileth is probably more protective of her jarl than any of the other jarls' housecarls in the other 8 holds of Skyrim.
Irileth is very serious about her job and her loyalty to Balgruuf, occasionally to the point of paranoia. She does not care much about Skyrim's traditions or tales.
Irileth was trained by the Morag Tong guild of Morrowind.
If the Stormcloaks capture Whiterun, Irileth, Balgruuf, Hrongar, and Proventus will have to exile themselves to the Blue Palace in Solitude to seek refuge with Jarl Elisif the Fair, an Imperial loyalist.
In combat, Irileth wields either frost-enchanted steel sword or an elven bow, depending on the situation. She can also use simpler Destruction spells such as Sparks and Lightning Cloak, as well as the Oakflesh spell from the Alteration school to boost her defenses.
Quotes:
“Balgruuf and I share a battle bond. We met as youths, and forged our friendship in the fires of war. When he became Jarl, I insisted on serving as his protector. He had no cause to argue."
"I am charged with protecting the Jarl from any and all threats. Powerful men have many enemies. More so, in times of strife. So you can imagine the dangers. Oh, yes, there have been attempts on the Jarl's life. More than one would-be assassin has met his end at the tip of my blade."
“The jarl faces many threats. Dragons, Stormcloak assassins, ambitious and unscrupulous nobles... Sometimes I think his own children want him dead. And those are just the physical threats. Assaults on his sanity are another matter entirely. Every day, he deals with obsequious functionaries and incompetent bureaucrats. Sadly, I'm not allowed to eliminate them. Well, not yet, anyway."
"We can never rest easy, for Balgruuf's enemies will not."
"Please keep your weapons sheathed in the Jarl's presence."
"You are a welcome guest, but you must still respect the rules of the Jarl's household."
If she assists in the slaying of a dragon: "That was the hairiest fight I've ever been in, and I've been in more than a few. I don't know about this Dragonborn business, but I'm sure glad you're with us. You better get back to Whiterun right away. Jarl Balgruuf will want to know what happened here. I'm taking command here for the moment. You head back to Whiterun and let the Jarl know what happened."
If Balgruuf and his court members have been exiled to the Blue Palace in Solitude: "Exile or no, my duty to Balgruuf remains. Keep that in mind when you approach him, for I will be watching."
author: Bethesda

name: Irlof
bio:
Irlof is a Nord pirate in the Blood Horker pirate clan and is working in the crew under captain Stig Salt-Plank. Irlof is blind in his left eye and has a rugged look to his face.
He can be found in the Windpeak Inn in Dawnstar accompanying his captain. After the quest has been completed, he and the other pirates will remain at the Windpeak Inn.
author: Bethesda

name: Irnskar Ironhand
bio:
Irnskar Ironhand, a Nord man, lives in Solitude. He serves as the housecarl of Thane Bryling, an important member of Jarl Elisif’s court at the Blue Palace.
Irnskar has white hair and a thick beard. He wears a set of iron armor.
Irnskar guards and maintains Bryling’s house in Solitude. He can often by seen conversing with Bryling, discussing subjects such as the Civil War between the Imperial Legion and the Stormcloaks, and administrative matters (such as rent and tax collection).
Octieve San, an elderly Breton man, owes Irnskar a substantial of money from gambling debt.
If Bryling dies, Irnskar will temporarily serve as a Thane in her place until a more suitable replacement is found.
Quotes:
"Unless we have specific business, I'm not interested."
"When I was a young rascal, I broke a man's arm with a single punch. Course, I had a horseshoe hidden in my glove..."
"I think Bryling's the one you want to talk to. I'm mostly just here to scare away the riff raff".
author: Bethesda

name: Isabelle Rolaine
bio:
Isabelle Rolaine was a Breton sorceress and thief.
Aspiring to solve her and her lover Ranmir's monetary issues, Isabelle temporarily turned to thievery. According to Vex, however, Rolaine lacked the skills necessary, but regardless sent her to Hob's Fall Cave, where she was slain.
Ranmir believed that Isabelle left him, as he never learned of her fate post-her disappearance. Ranmir became a drunkard, and took refuge in The Frozen Hearth, in Winterhold.
A letter can be found on Rolaine's corpse, addressed to Ranmir before she traveled to Hob's Fall Cave.
author: Bethesda

name: Isran
bio:
Isran, a Redguard man, is the stoic leader and founder of the Dawnguard, an order of vampire hunters. The Dawnguard are headquarted at Fort Dawnguard, nestled in the mountains at the far southeastern edge of Skyrim.
Isran is as a master skill trainer in the usage of heavy armor, and will offer his training services to the player if they join the Dawnguard.
Years ago, Isran was a member of the Vigilants of Stendarr. He joined the Vigilants after witnessing his family's death at the hands of Molag Bal vampire cultists. He joined the Vigil at the same time as Celann. Dissatisfied with the order, and the fact the Vigil found his methods "extreme", Isran and Celann they both left to form their own partnership. It didn't last long, as Celann began to disagree with some of Isran's methods. However, Celann eventually returned to join the Dawnguard.
This year, after a recent spate of vampire attacks, Isran founded the modern iteration of the Dawnguard. In ancient times, the original Dawnguard were an order of master vampire slayers. Isran re-established the Dawnguard's ancient headquarters in Fort Dawnguard, a massive fortress deep within the Velothi Mountains. Isran then rallied new recruits in order to combat the vampire menace.
Isran has a strong sense of righteousness and in addition believes it is his duty to protect Skyrim from vampires. However, he tends to prioritize killing vampires over most other things, and would even put the lives of innocents at stake in order to aid his cause. Even though he is not from Skyrim, he is proud to live there. Despite no longer being a Vigilant, he still worships Stendarr in particular. Isran has quite a cold demeanor initially. His unfriendliness goes to new extremes if the vampire Serana is among the Dawnguard; he talks to her in harsh tones and constantly refers to her as 'it', even to her face. However, towards the end of the main questline, Isran refers to Serana by her name, rather than 'it', and goes as far to thank her for helping kill Harkon, her father.
According to Isran, his hatred of vampires is what keeps him strong; that, and constant vigilance. Compared to Gunmar, who also lost his family to vampires, Isran's goal of purging the land of vampires is less out of a desire to help people from the vampire menace, and more out of a pure hatred for vampires. Despite this, Isran can still be compassionate and forgiving.
Isran is so tense and alert that he belittles the player for sleeping, claiming it to be a weakness. He is perfectly content expecting the worst to happen. However, while others mocked him, he read the signs and was able to take the right measures.
Isran apparently has a consistent habit of falling-out with people and holding grudges. The Vigil let him go after he proved too "extreme." Celann explains that he was never happy with Isran's rough and violent methods, and broke off their partnership. Florentius, the priest of Arkay, never got on with him either. However, Isran is not so petty as to stay mad at people in times of need. To the surprise of his old colleagues, he recruits them to help the Dawnguard. In his own gruff manner, he continued to care for these people too. Upon hearing of Keeper Carcette and the other Vigilants' deaths, he shows sorrow and compassion for their losses. If anything, it gives him more fuel for his obsession: to exterminate all vampires.
He makes this more clear if the player returns to Fort Dawnguard after either contracting vampirism or becoming a Vampire Lord, angered that the player has become one of them and directs them to Morthal to seek a cure from Falion, stating that until the player does that, he will not allow them to remain in Fort Dawnguard, saying "How dare you come back here after being infected by one of them." and "Get out of here, monster."
Isran is a formidable warrior, more than capable of spearheading an assault on vampires. In battle, he expertly wields a Dawnguard warhammer, which is especially deadly to vampires. He also uses a special spell called Stendarr's Aura.
After hearing about an order of vampire hunters who are recruiting, the Dragonborn goes to join them at Fort Dawnguard. Isran and Celann meet both the Dragonborn and Agmaer and induct them into the group.
After a plea from Tolan, Isran sends the Dragonborn to investigate what the vampires who attacked the Hall of the Vigilant were looking for within Dimhollow Crypt, which was just up the mountain from the Hall of the Vigilant.
Furious at the Dragonborn's compassion to Serana and delivering an Elder Scroll to the Vampires, Isran orders the Dragonborn to make amends and recruit two of his old colleagues to their cause: Sorine Jurard and Gunmar. When they return to Fort Dawnguard, Isran checks to make sure they haven't contracted Sanguinare Vampiris, then lets them into the fort to begin their work with strengthening the Dawnguard for future battles with the Vampires.
Isran brings the player to reunite with Serana, who has fled from her father, Harkon. While disgusted at her presence, Isran is interested to hear about a Moth Priest in Skyrim and could help them understand the Tyranny of the Sun that Serana mentions. He sends the Dragonborn to retrieve Dexion Evicus to help read Serana's Scroll and see if it provides any details that could aid the Dawnguard against Harkon.
After the Dragonborn retrieves Auriel's Bow, leaving him amazed that they have the object that Lord Harkon seeks to complete the Tyranny of the Sun prophecy, Isran rallies the Dawnguard to prepare for the final assault against Harkon and his court at Castle Volkihar, taking Sorine Jurard, Durak, Florentius Baenius, Gunmar, Celann, and an Armored Troll with him to the castle. Once joined by the Dragonborn and Serana, they attack the castle and eliminate all of Harkon's court members, including his two Death Hounds, Garmr and CuSith, leaving Serana and the Dragonborn to face Harkon alone. After Harkon is slain, Isran thanks Serana for her help, showing newfound respect for Harkon's daughter. He offers the Dragonborn a chance to return to Fort Dawnguard to continue working with the Dawnguard to weed out other vampires around Skyrim, knowing that Auriel's Bow is in good hands.
He and the others members in Fort Dawnguard are targets for this vampire side quest with eliminating them to ensure the Dawnguard won't be a threat to Harkon's court any longer.
Isran requires help dealing with a vampire masquerading as a Visiting Advisor to a Jarl.
Quotes:
If the player has killed the vampire in the Jarl's court: "Good. Maybe now they'll afford the vampire threat a tad bit more respect, eh?"
author: Bethesda

name: Istar Cairn-Breaker
bio:
Istar Cairn-Breaker is a Nord warrior and a Commander of the Stormcloaks.
He can be found inside a tent in the Haafingar Stormcloak Camp right next to Dragon Bridge, and can later be found in Castle Dour if siding with the Stormcloaks and completing the Civil War questline. As an essential character, Istar cannot be killed without the use of console commands.
author: Bethesda

name: Itinerant Lumberjack
bio: Itinerant Lumberjack is one of the ten recurring targets for the radiant Dark Brotherhood quests. He will only appear in Morthal, and can be mostly found around the woodmill.
author: Bethesda

name: J'darr
bio:
J'darr is a Khajiit in the Alftand glacial ruins. He has long since been driven mad by Skooma withdrawals, and is standing next to the body of his brother, J'zhar.
However, in spite of his Skooma withdrawal, the 'hallucinations' are implied to (in part) be the Falmer who inhabit the ruins, and it is in fact the Falmer who took Valie. J'darr and his brother are apparently the only two of the group to avoid the Falmer's grasp, but it is unclear whether J'darr killed J'zhar or if the latter died from unrecorded wounds.
Like most Khajiit, he speaks in the third person, referring to himself as "this one". For example, if he wanted to express that he is tired, he would say "This one is tired".
author: Bethesda

name: J'datharr
bio:
J'datharr is a Khajiit assassin waiting outside of Windhelm, behind the stables. He is sent by the Thalmor to kill Malborn after the completion of the quest "Diplomatic Immunity," before he can flee Skyrim. He carries a note addressed to him.
Since he is not part of a Khajiit caravan, killing J'datharr will incur no bounty, even if witnessed by the other Khajiit. Hold Guards will not react to any assault towards him either, and may actually help in killing him.
Like most Khajiit, he speaks in the third person, referring to himself as "this one". For example, if he wanted to express that he is tired, he would say "This one is tired".
author: Bethesda

name: J'Kier
bio:
J’Kier, a Khajiit man, is one of the Hunters of Hircine. Hircine is the Daedric Lord of the Hunt. J’Kier and several other Hunters of Hircine have been sent to Bloated Man's Grotto, which is located in the mountains at the northern edge of Falkreath Hold. J’Kier wears a set of leather armor with a matching pair of boots. He carries an iron sword and dagger. 
The Hunters of Hircine are composed of men and women of many different races and backgrounds, about half of them being Khajiit. J’Kier and several other Hunters of Hircine have been sent by Lord Hircine to kill the werewolf Sinding, in order to send Sinding's soul to the Hunting Grounds. The Hunting Grounds is the afterlife destination associated with Hircine, and is where all werewolves and followers of Hircine are sent after their death.
J’Kier has been just been mortally wounded by Sinding. J'Kier's injuries are so severe that no amount of medical treatment nor magic can save him from death now. J’Kier can feel his life rapidly ebbing away, and he expects to die within the next few minutes. His dialogue is punctuated by ragged breaths as he struggles to breathe.
Like most Khajiit, he speaks in the third person, referring to himself as "this one". For example, if he wanted to express that he is tired, he would say "This one is tired".
Quotes:
"Has the Bloodmoon called you, fellow Hunter?"
"The prey is strong. Stronger than the hunters. But more will come. Bring him down, for the glories of Lord Hircine."
“May Hircine guide your blades.”
author: Bethesda

name: J'zargo
bio:
J'zargo is an apprentice at the College of Winterhold, the primary institution for magical learning in Skyrim. J'zargo is a Khajiit from Elsweyr. His living quarters are in the college's Hall of Attainment, along with the other apprentice mages. J'zargo can often be found practicing his spells in the Hall of the Elements, located in the college's central tower.
A skilled mage, J'zargo is confident to the point of arrogance, offering few words of praise for the work of others. J'zargo is highly competitive and strives to be the best of the College's students, using any means available, including theft and reckless experimentation. Despite his great ambition, J'zargo has no qualms accepting that he still has a long way to go before becoming a powerful wizard.
J'zargo typically wears mage robes and a hood, which are imbued with novice-level magicka-boosting enchantments.
As a strong Khajiit male, J'zargo's is physically durable and resilient. Despite being a mage, he has an unusually high skill with heavy armor as well as with one-handed weaponry.
An old Nord man named Tolfdir is the senior mage in charge of overseeing the apprenctices' training. Along with J'zargo's fellow apprentices Onmund (an adolescent Nord man) and Brelyna Maryon (a young Dunmer woman), J'zargo has complained to Tolfdir that he has not yet taught them much in the way of practical magic. Tolfdir has been prioritizing safety and more abstract knowledge before teaching many actual spells.
J'zargo knows spells from all five schools of magic, but is most proficient with spells from the Destruction school. He favors casting less advanced but magicka-efficient spells in both hands, though he will switch to more advanced (and magicka-costly) spells if facing a strong enemy, such as a dragon. Shock spells, such as Sparks, are his favorite. He also commonly casts Firebolt and Ice Spike spells when fighting long distance over large open areas. If his magicka reserves run low after prolonged combat, J'zargo will fight with his fists and claws until his magicka reserves recover.
J'zargo may request help in testing a batch of magical scrolls, which he crafted himself. These scrolls cast a Flame Cloak spell upon its user. If someone assists J'zargo in testing these scrolls, J'zargo will be grateful and subsequently be willing to follow them on adventures.
