Like the rest of the Companions, he lives in Jorrvaskr in the Wind District of Whiterun. He is a Master-level trainer in two-handed weaponry and serves as the Dragonborn's shield-brother in several of the Companions' quests. He is also one of the Companions who can assign radiant quests to the Dragonborn.
Upon completion of the Companions' main plotline, Vilkas can be recruited as a follower and becomes a potential marriage candidate. He can be recruited into the Blades if the Dragonborn talks to Delphine while having him as a follower, or as a steward.
Vilkas and his twin brother, Farkas, were both raised in Jorrvaskr by Jergen, who rescued them from a cult of necromancers. It is unknown if he was their biological father. According to Vilkas, Jergen left to fight in the Great War but never returned.
Eventually, Vilkas and Farkas both officially joined the Companions and rose to the ranks of the Circle. They were said to be the youngest members to ever join, though this may be a play on words by Vignar Gray-Mane, referring to the twins' young age during their residence at Jorrvaskr rather than the age at which their membership became official.
As Master at Arms, Vilkas is in charge of training the younger members in weapon combat. He has a reputation of being hard on his students but is an excellent teacher.
At first, Vilkas seems to think the Dragonborn is not worthy of being a Companion. He does eventually warm up to the idea after the completion of "Glory of the Dead."
Vilkas is well-spoken, and considered to be an intelligent man by the other Companions, the counterpart to his brother's physical prowess. He, along with his brother and Kodlak, resists the call of the beast-blood, choosing instead to refrain from transformations. However, he struggles with the side-effects more harshly than the others.
He resents Jergen leaving them, and looks down on his brother's rosy description of their childhood. He at first claims that it is the promise of coin that feeds his blade, but later admits his respect for what the Companions represent and upholding the legacy of Ysgramor. He has great respect for Kodlak and trusts his judgement, even when it disagrees with his own.
Vilkas is also thought of as a hot-tempered man. For example, during "Purity of Revenge," he does not hesitate to avenge Kodlak's death. However, he does later show remorse for his rash actions, as seen in "Glory of the Dead," during which he refuses to enter the rest of Ysgramor's Tomb, feeling himself unworthy.
After the Companions' main questline is completed, Vilkas will eventually give the quest "Purity." In this quest, he will ask the Dragonborn to cure him of beast blood.
He wears a set of Wolf Armor minus the helmet, and carries a unique Skyforge steel sword and banded iron shield. After the quest "Take Up Arms," he carries a Skyforge steel greatsword.
Before Take Up Arms and after "Glory of the Dead," Vilkas can be randomly encountered in the wilds of Skyrim traveling with fellow Companion Ria.
When the Dragonborn first approaches Kodlak Whitemane to join the Companions, he and Vilkas are having a private conversation. Kodlak assigns Vilkas the task of testing the Dragonborn's skill. Vilkas escorts the Dragonborn to the training yard and endures a few swings, then tells the Dragonborn to deliver his sword to the Skyforge for sharpening.
In this radiant quest, Vilkas requires the Dragonborn to track down and kill an escaped prisoner in a specific hold.
This radiant quest requires the Dragonborn to retrieve a random weapon or item from a radiant dungeon and deliver it back to Vilkas for payment.
In this radiant quest, Vilkas requires the Dragonborn to rescue a kidnapped citizen and escort the citizen home safely.
After Vilkas informs the Dragonborn of Kodlak's death, he demands they accompany him to Driftshade Refuge to retrieve the Fragments of Wuuthrad and wipe out the Silver Hand once and for all. Once the mission is complete and the two have returned to Whiterun, he informs the Dragonborn that all the Companions are meeting at the Skyforge for Kodlak's funeral.
After Kodlak's funeral, Vilkas accompanies the remaining members of the Circle to The Underforge. When the Dragonborn enters, he and Aela are arguing about granting Kodlak's final wish. The decision is made for the Circle to travel to Ysgramor's Tomb and cure Kodlak's spirit of lycanthropy so he may ascend to Sovngarde.
Once the Circle arrives and the tomb is opened, Vilkas chooses not to proceed, due to his grief clouding his judgement and making him unworthy. He cautions the others on what to expect and waits next to the statue of Ysgramor outside the burial chamber. Once the quest is complete, Vilkas decides to stay at the tomb with the other Circle members for a while.
Vilkas wishes to rid himself of his beast blood. To cure him, the Dragonborn must take him to Ysgramor's Tomb, throw a Glenmoril Witch Head into the fire, and then kill Vilkas's beast spirit.
author: Bethesda

name: Vilod
bio:
Vilod, a Nord man, is known for making a special type of mead with juniper berries mixed in. He usually wears hide armor and boots. He lives in the town of Helgen. He is a supporter of the Imperial Legion in its war against the Stormcloak rebellion. Years ago, Vilod was on good terms with a young man from Riverwood named Ralof, but Ralof unfortunately decided to become a traitorous Stormcloak soldier.
General Tullius, the Imperial Legion military governor of Skyrim, recently marched into Helgen with a large number of Imperial soldiers and some Stormcloak prisoners, including Ulfric Stormcloak himself. Vilod cheered as the first Stormcloak rebel traitor was beheaded. However, before the rest of the Stormcloak prisoners could be executed, a mighty black dragon attacked the town, breathing fire and raining meteors down from the sky. Vilod was just gravely wounded by this dragon attack, and is bleeding profusely.
author: Bethesda

name: Vingalmo
bio:
Vingalmo, an Altmer man, is a vampire and member of the Volkihar Clan. He is one of Lord Harkon's primary advisors. He and fellow senior vampire Orthjolf are embroiled in a feud over the throne, and can be often heard making cutting remarks towards one another.
Vingalmo was first met when the player enters Castle Volkihar with Serana. He confronted the player for "trespassing," but upon seeing Serana he excitedly announced to the rest of the court that she has returned. The second time he is encountered, he and Orthjolf will be arguing in the dining room. Once their dialogue is complete, he will warn the player not to trust Orthjolf, and Orthjolf says much the same about Vingalmo.
He is also mentioned in the Night Of Tears, which says he wrote a book about ancient Saarthal called "Treatise on the Altmer Antecedent".
Upon starting the quest, Vingalmo is surprised to hear Harkon is sending the Dragonborn to fill the chalice and reacts with suspicion.
Once the player fills the chalice from the bloodspring, Stalf and Salonia Caelia spring an ambush. It is revealed that Vingalmo sent Salonia Caelia in pursuit to kill the player and retrieve the chalice. Vingalmo hoped that this would give him more power and would bring him one step closer to claiming Harkon's throne.
Vingalmo has found a new candidate, ripe for Harkon's Gift. He sends the player to welcome the person into the family.
Vingalmo mentions that he knows the player has a spouse, and asks that they be turned into a vampire.
author: Bethesda

name: Viola Giordano
bio:
Viola Giordano, an older Imperial woman, lives in Windhelm. She often spends her evenings at Candlehearth Hall, which is run by a woman named Elda Early-Dawn.
Viola worries excessively about the Butcher and his recent murders of young women in Windhelm. Viola is the author of the "Beware the Butcher!" flyer posted all around the city. In addition to her constant fretting, Viola also has an obsession with Captain Lonely-Gale, the retired ship captain living in the city. Viola bothers the Captain quite often, with trivial questions regarding lovers and the recent murders. Lonely-Gale's wife died a little while ago. Viola sometime tries to ask the Captain out on a date.
If the player is tasked by the Jarl's court with discovering the Butcher's identity, Viola will be happy to assist in the investigation.
Quotes:
If asked about the Butcher: "I've been following him for months now. Well, not actually following. Trying to find him. The guards won't help. The people won't help. I'm the only one who thinks he can be caught."
author: Bethesda

name: Vipir the Fleet
bio:
Vipir the Fleet is a Nord thief and a member of the Thieves Guild in Riften.
When inquired about his nickname, he will reveal that while on a job in Windhelm with Vex, their client alerted the authorities to their presence in the city. They were pursued by the guards and got separated. Vex was able to lose her pursuers rather quickly by blending into the shadows; however, Vipir was not able to lose the guards and ran out the main gate and ran all the way back to Riften. Upon arriving and seeing Vex and the rest of the Guild laughing at him, he only then remembered that he and Vex had left their horses just outside Windhelm. Vex had ridden hers to Riften, arriving hours earlier. Once he is done telling his story, he asks the player not to tell anyone.
Vipir the Fleet is the Master level trainer in Pickpocket. He will only offer this service to the player if they are a member of the Thieves Guild.
author: Bethesda

name: Virkmund
bio:
Virkmund is a Nord child who lives in Morthal with his family.
Virkmund's father is Thonnir and his mother is Laelette. He can be found in Thonnir's House.
Like his father, he believes that his mother has abandoned them to join the Stormcloaks, but the events of the quest "Laid to Rest" contradict this belief.
author: Bethesda

name: Visiting Advisor
bio:
Visiting Advisors are vampires sent to infiltrate a hold and influence the Jarl.
Isran asks the Dragonborn to find and destroy the vampire masquerading as a Visiting Advisor to the Jarl of a radiant city. However, to avoid slandering the Dawnguard's name, permission must be gained from the Jarl to kill the creature or the guards will see it as murder. During battle, the Advisors will cast Vampiric Drain and Ice Storm. With low Magicka remaining, they will cast Ice Spike repeatedly along with Vampiric Drain. When their Magicka pool runs dry, they will switch to their enchanted dagger and use Vampiric Drain on occasion until their Magicka regenerates, and the process continues until they are defeated.
Gunmar asks the Dragonborn to find and destroy a vampire masquerading as a Visiting Advisor in a radiant city. However, unlike Isran or Gunmar's other disguised targets, there is no option to get permission, or have the target follow the Dragonborn to a secluded location. The kill must be made at risk of a bounty.
They always wear Vampire Robes, Vampire Gloves, Vampire Boots, and a Vampire Hood.
author: Bethesda

name: Visiting Noble
bio: Visiting Noble is currently visiting Dragonsreach, the Jarl's palace in the city of Whiterun.
author: Bethesda

name: Vittoria Vici
bio:
Vittoria Vici is an noblewoman living in Solitude, the provincial capital of Skyrim. She is an Imperial from Cyrodiil. She has long brown hair. She typically wears expensive sets of fine clothing.
During the day, she works near the East Empire Company Warehouse, down by the docks outside the walls of the city. Her job is to manage the shipments of goods for the Company, standing watch in the customs office near the entrance to the warehouse in the large cavernous inlet under the city.
Vittoria is the cousin of Titus Mede the Second, the Emperor of Tamriel. Vittoria's mother Alexia is Titus' sister.
Vittoria sometimes excitedly gushes about planning her upcoming wedding to Asgeir Snow-Shod, a successful businessman from a prominent Nord family in Windhelm. This upcoming marriage is politically useful, as the Snow-Shods are ardent supporters of the Stormcloaks, the opposing faction in the ongoing Skyrim civil war. However, Vittoria also genuinely loves Asgeir, and it is eagerly looking forward to marrying him. The reception after their wedding ceremony will be held in the Castle Dour courtyard, and will be be open to the public of Solitude.
Evette San, a woman who works a spice wine stall in the Solitude Market, has asked Vittoria to release the most recent incoming spice shipment without having to pay the heavy tariff on these goods. If someone else also asks Vittoria to release this shipment, Vittoria is open to being persuaded to release it without requiring the tariff to be paid.
Vittoria sometimes attends Thalmor Ambassador Elenwen’s parties at the Thalmor Embassy west of Solitude. Vittoria considers these parties boring, and only attends because the East Empire Company and the Thalmor have business relations. If asked persuasively, Vittoria will be willing to create a scene during one of these parties.
Quotes:
"Hmm? Sorry, I was lost in thought. I'm planning my wedding, you see. So many details to work out."
"Some say I got my position because my cousin is the Emperor. Nonsense. The man's given me nothing. He can't even be bothered to attend my wedding."
"Good business for the East Empire Company means all the more gold for the Empire."
"I don't have time for anyone too lazy or cowardly to make their own way in this world."
"One thing everyone can agree on. This war is bad for business."
If asked if the East Empire Company does business with the Thalmor: "A delicate question, to be sure. I'm the Emperor's cousin, and the Empire has little love for the Thalmor. On the other hand, the Thalmor have considerable funds and are looking to expand their shipping. I haven't signed any deals yet, but I'm sure my cousin will want a cut if I do. What better way to soothe his wounded pride?"
If at the Thalmor Embassy: "Just between us, I've got more important things to do than attend these meaningless parties."
If asked to cause a scene at one of Elenwen's parties at the Thalmor Embassy: "Well. Anything to relieve the boredom. As long as it doesn't get back to me."
If asked about the spice shipment: "Ah yes. If Evette wants to pay the two thousand gold tariff, we'll be all set."
If told that Evette can't afford the tariff: "I suppose I could make an exception. I do like her spiced wine. Fine, tell Evette San her shipment will be brought up to Solitude shortly."
author: Bethesda

name: Vivienne Onis
bio:
Vivienne Onis is a Breton living in Solitude with her aunt, Angeline Morrard. She can be found at the Winking Skeever, or helping her aunt manage Angeline's Aromatics.
She is the childhood crush of Sorex Vinius. If the Dragonborn marries Sorex, Vivienne will be a guest at the wedding.
Addvar: "Svari, you need to go home. Go home and stay there until your mother comes." Vivienne: "You should tell her that her uncle is scum that betrayed his High King. Best she know now, Addvar." Aldis: "Roggvir. You helped Ulfric Stormcloak escape this city after he murdered High King Torygg. By opening that gate for Ulfric you betrayed the people of Solitude." Roggvir: "There was no murder! Ulfric challenged Torygg. He beat the High King in fair combat." Roggvir: "Such as our way! Such as the ancient custom of Skyrim, and all Nords!" Vivienne: "Cut 'em down!"
Vivienne: "Which one is that again?" Vivienne: "In that case, I'm pretty sure it tried to buy me a drink last night."
author: Bethesda

name: Voada
bio:
Voada is a Breton who works in Understone Keep in Markarth for Chef Anton Virane.
Voada and Rondach are Ainethach's children.
Anton: "Voada, you spilled laundry water in the soup pot again! Do I need to cut off your fingers to teach you a lesson?" Rondach: "You touch her and I swear it'll be your fingers that go missing, you stupid Breton!" Voada: "Now, now, brother, Rondach was just being his usual gloomy self, he didn't mean it, did you Rondach? You're just being silly again."
Anton: "Filthy natives. Get to work. We have meals to prepare and no time to prepare them!" Voada: "Right away, sir!"
author: Bethesda

name: Voldsea Giryon
bio:
Voldsea Giryon is a Dunmer sailor and a crew member of Captain Kjar's ship, the Northwind.
She lives her life on the river and greatly appreciates feeling solid land under her feet once in a while, and is the only sailor of the Northwind to do so while docked in Windhelm. She holds a great respect for her captain as being fair to his crew and seems generally happy living the sailor's life.
Voldsea states she does a lot of walking to prevent weak legs, and that is indeed all she will do. She will loop the Gray Quarter and lower residences for the entire night. She will never go to the west side of town or even the docks. The only building she will enter is Candlehearth Hall, where she will remain from 4:00 A.M. to 4:00 P.M.
author: Bethesda

name: Volk
bio:
Volk is a Nord charmed Vigilant of Stendarr in The Elder Scrolls V: Dawnguard who can be found inside Ruunvald and the author of Volk's Journal. Like the rest of the vigilants at Ruunvald, he is under the influence of the warlock Minorne and the Staff of Ruunvald, which forces him to attack the Dragonborn on sight.
Volk was a member of the Vigilants of Stendarr stationed at the Hall of the Vigilant prior to its destruction by the Volkihar Clan. For months while he was at the Hall of the Vigilant, Moric Sidrey, a fellow Vigilant, had been trying to convince the rest of the order to help him excavate the ancient Nordic ruin Ruunvald.
Volk initially dismissed Moric's claims about the ruin, as he had never heard of it and doubted there could be anything of value to be had there. Most of the Vigilants shares Volk's views on the matter, but Moric was able to secure a small team to begin his excavation.
Soon, Moric was sending word back to the Hall of the Vigilant of ancient treasures he was uncovering there, drawing more attention from the order and bring more workers and even a handful of huskies to Ruunvald. Eventually, after Moric had broken into the main chamber, Volk finally relented and joined the expedition. Due to his late-coming, however, he was placed of guard duty outside of the excavation site, along with the priest of Arkay, Florentius Baenius.
After two weeks of completely uneventful lookout duty, Volk began keeping a journal in which he described the events leading up to his guard duty. The only notable thing to happen was when the workers came back up to the surface for supplies. This would become increasingly infrequent, raising Volk's suspicions about the Ruunvald excavation. Two days later, a Vigilant named Apa came up with an emotionless expression to tell Volk and Florentius that they should come down to the site, and Apa was the last Vigilant Volk saw.
After three more days, Volk recorded the final entry in his journal, and he and Florentius went down into the excavation site, where they discovered that the excavation was really being led by the warlock Minorne, who had been using the Staff of Ruunvald to subjugate the wills of the Vigilants there. She then charmed Volk and imprisoned Florentius, who was likely resistant to the staff's effects.
When the Dragonborn arrives at Ruunvald looking for Florentius, Volk is charmed like the rest of the Vigilants and will attack the Dragonborn on sight. While it is possible to sneak or run past him without killing him, Volk will ultimately die when Minorne dies, as will Moric, Apa, and the other twelve charmed vigilants in Ruunvald. Since Minorne must be killed to free Florentius, as the key will not appear until she is dead, it is impossible to spare Volk without modding the game.
author: Bethesda

name: Vorstag
bio:
Vorstag is a Nord warrior who lives in Markarth. Found sitting by the fire in the Silver-Blood Inn.
When traveling with the player, Vorstag is eager to investigate caves: "Looks like a cave. Think we should check it out?" However, he does not like mines, and, when taken inside one, comments on how they are dangerous and sometimes filled with poisonous gas.
He possesses knowledge about Dwemer artifacts, making comments on their trap-making skills whenever he enters Dwemer Ruins.
The player can hire Vorstag for 500 gold. After he has been hired once, Vorstag becomes a candidate for marriage.
Vorstag's highest skills are Heavy Armor, One-Handed, Archery and Block.
Vorstag wears a set of scaled armor by default, excluding the helm.
Vorstag may use his default Scaled Boots over other footwear. Even when the player gives him better light armor boots, he refuses to wear them. However, he wears any heavy armor boots deposited in his inventory. After the player has given Vorstag a better bow, sometimes he still chooses to use his default Hunting Bow.
author: Bethesda

name: Vuljotnaak
bio:
Vuljotnaak (Dragon Language: Dark-Maw-Eat) is a dragon flying circles between Fort Sungard and Broken Fang Cave. He is relatively easy to defeat compared to most other dragons.
He is located at the Great Henge Dragon Burial Mound, northeast of Sunderstone Gorge, not far from Bloated Man's Grotto.
He is also one of the dragons that can be seen being resurrected by Alduin.
author: Bethesda

name: Vulthuryol
bio:
Vulthuryol (Dragon Language: Dark-Overlord-Fire) is a hidden Ancient Dragon, summoned in the underground Dwemer capital city of Blackreach. He is a metallic bronze color with a black and beige pattern on his wings and tail.
To find Vulthuryol, access the center building area in Blackreach where there is a large yellow orb above the Blackreach Debate Hall and the Hall of Rumination. The closest exit from Blackreach to this orb is the Great Lift at Mzinchaleft.
The orb is visible upon entry. A number of Falmer and Falmer Servants will be hostile and one must thus fight their way through them. After doing so, use Unrelenting Force on the orb. Doing so will make the orb ring and echo throughout the caverns. This will summon Vulthuryol.
If the Dragonborn summons Vulthuryol and does not engage in combat with him, he will eventually take up a stationary position on the ground outside of the south entrance to the orb complex. If the Dragonborn is positioned on the ramps leading from the top exit of the Hall of Rumination or another high vantage point, Vulthuryol can be range attacked and he does not rise from the ground. Vulthuryol can only be summoned once.
author: Bethesda

name: Vulwulf Snow-Shod
bio:
Vulwulf Snow-Shod is a Nord Stormcloak veteran in Skyrim who resides in Riften. He is the patriarch of the Snow-Shod family. Spending most of his time at the Bee and Barb, Vulwulf often promotes Ulfric Stormcloak and the goal of a liberated Skyrim. If initiated in dialogue, he will often be asked to be left alone, as he is mourning the loss of his daughter, Lilija.
As worshipers of Talos, Vulwulf and his wife became furious with the Empire when the White-Gold Concordat was signed. Thus, when Ulfric Stormcloak started the Civil War for Skyrim's independence, Vulwulf and his wife began supporting the Stormcloaks. Together with Nura, he had two sons, Asgeir Snow-Shod and Unmid Snow-Shod, and a daughter named Lilija. Much to his content, the oldest son, Unmid, became a housecarl to the Jarl of Riften, and his daughter, Lilija, joined the Stormcloaks as a healer. However, she had died a few months later, despite being a non-combatant. Vulwulf mourns her death deeply, and it has caused him to become bitter, acting highly aggressive towards anyone he suspects of being an Imperial sympathizer.
When offered The Warmth of Mara, Vulwulf would respond with doubt in Mara, stating that she is not doing anything about the war, in which hundreds of Stormcloak soldiers die in for no good reason.
Vulwulf appears at the wedding ceremony of his son Asgeir and his fiance Vittoria Vici. He strongly disapproves of their wedding, claiming that there are "lots of eager Nord women" and considers the marriage to be the loss of a son. Vulwulf will claim that Vittoria's death was an Imperial conspiracy to blame the Stormcloaks.
author: Bethesda

name: Wary Outlaw
bio:
Wary Outlaw is a Nord contractor in Skyrim who resides in the Bee and Barb in Riften.
He will give a leveled sum of gold to the Dragonborn to assassinate a target, then wander through the inn until the target has been killed.
author: Bethesda

name: Watches-The-Roots
bio:
Watches-The-Roots was an Argonian explorer who sought the Lexicon at the Dwemer Ruin of Avanchnzel.
The expedition included Roots, From-Deepest-Fathoms, Breya and Drennen. During the expedition, he was killed after he ignored Breya's warning that "something doesn't feel right" and walked right into a booby trap.
His corpse can be found just outside Avanchnzel Boilery, shortly after a swinging blade booby trap, which may have been what killed him. His ghost can be seen throughout the ruins, musing over the Dwemer technologies. He seemed to covet the Lexicon for himself.
Breya: "Its a simple job, Drennen. We get in, we steal the Lexicon, we leave. Don't get jumpy." Roots: "Enough. Their services will be more than adequate. Let us continue."
author: Bethesda

name: Watchman
bio:
Watchman is an Elder gatekeeper of Castle Volkihar.
He stands watch over the entrance to the castle. When he sees Serana, he enthusiastically opens the gate.
author: Bethesda

name: Weylin
bio:
Weylin is a Breton Forsworn agent in the city of Markarth. Working as a miner of silver ore at Cidhna Mine, Weylin lives in The Warrens.
As the Dragonborn comes through the doors of Markarth, Weylin draws a blade and stabs a Nord woman, Margret. Alternatively, the Dragonborn can stop Weylin from killing her by killing him first. Choosing the second option, Margret rewards them with a Silver Emerald Necklace she planned to give to her sister later.
Eltrys confronts the Dragonborn, after killing Weylin either way and hands them Eltrys' Note, saying that they dropped it. Choosing to rendezvous with Eltrys at the Shrine of Talos, the Dragonborn learns of The Forsworn Conspiracy and agrees to help Eltrys investigate Weylin's involvement.
Receiving a key to Weylin's room, in The Warrens from Garvey, the Dragonborn discovers that Weylin was ordered to kill Margret, an undercover operative of the Imperial Legion, by Thonar Silver-Blood. If Margret was saved and is found in the Silver-Blood Inn, she will tell the Dragonborn that she is an Imperial Spy.
author: Bethesda

name: Whiterun Guard
bio:
Whiterun Guards act as the military and police force of Whiterun Hold. These guards serve under Jarl Balgruuf, and defend Whiterun against any threats.
Their relatively light armor is a scaled vest with a chainmail shirt underneath, and is covered by distinctive yellow cloth. Their conical helm completely covers their face, except the eyes. They wear fur boots. Their circular iron-trimmed wooden shield is also Whiterun's distinctive yellow color, and is painted with Whiterun's emblem (an elegant image of a horse's head). They are armed with an Imperial sword, bow, a quiver of steel arrows, and a steel dagger. They often carry a torch, for patroling at night.
They often can be found patroling the streets of Whiterun at any time of day or night. They usually sleep in the guard barracks near the city's front gate, unless currently posted within Dragonsreach (the Jarl's palace) or its underground dungeon. Additionally, a few guards are stationed at the Western Watchtower west of the city, as well as at Whitewatch Tower north of the city, where bandits are more common. Some Whiterun guards may also be posted in remote towns within the boundaries of Whiterun Hold, such as Rorikstead and Riverwood.
Whiterun is a city on an elevated hilly region, surrounded by open plains. The Throat of the World (the tallest mountain in Tamriel) is visible to the southeast of the city. A narrow tributary of the White River runs just south of the city's walls.
Jarl Balgruuf (the ruler of Whiterun) is widely considered to be the embodiment of a true Nord, and Whiterun's guards are quite loyal to him. Balgruuf has two young sons and a young daughter, though Balgruuf's wife is now deceased. Balgruuf's personal housecarl is a Dunmer named Irileth, whom Balgruuf fought alongside in the Great War against the Aldmeri Dominion, 30 years ago. Irileth is also respected amongst the guards, and she has authority over them. Other members of Balgruuf's court include Balgruuf's younger brother Hrongar, the court steward (an Imperial man named Proventus Avenicci), and the court wizard (a Nord man named Farengar Secret-Fire).
Whiterun guards are proficient in the use of melee weapons, archery, a shield, and both heavy and light armor.
Quotes:
"I used to be an adventurer like you. Then I took an arrow in the knee..."
"Disrespect the law, and you disrespect me."
"Fear not. Come dragon or giant, we'll be ready."
"I'd be a lot warmer and a lot happier with a bellyful of mead..."
"I mostly deal with petty thievery and drunken brawls. Been too long since we've had a good bandit raid."
"They say Ulfric Stormcloak murdered the High King... with his voice! Shouted him apart!"
"Stormcloaks, Imperials, dragons. Ain't no matter to me what I kill. Let them come."
"As if Skyrim didn't have enough outsiders. Now we've got mercenaries from Hammerfell struttin' about..."
During night hours: "Bit late to be wandering around, isn't it?"
Between the hours of 11 pm and 4 am: "Just a few more hours and I can crawl under some furs..."
If speaking to a thane of Whiterun: "I hope you're finding the city in proper order, thane."
If speaking to the Dragonborn: "If we killed a dragon once, we can do it again. With your help of course."
If making an arrest: "You have committed crimes against Skyrim and her people - what say you in your defense?"
author: Bethesda
note: Shawn - doneish. Should not activate until other Whiterun guard entries and their IDs are ready to go

name: Wilhelm
bio:
Wilhelm is a Nord innkeeper and owner of the Vilemyr Inn, in Ivarstead.
Wilhelm wants someone to investigate Shroud Hearth Barrow because he believes it to be haunted. An adventurer by the name of Wyndelius Gatharian has gone missing in the barrow, and spirits have been spotted outside. Bringing Wilhelm Wyndelius's Journal will reward the Dragonborn with the Sapphire Dragon Claw that is required to travel further into Shroud Hearth Barrow.
Romlyn Dreth, from Riften, asks the Dragonborn to deliver a stolen Black-Briar Mead Keg to Wilhelm.
Lifting the Shroud must be completed in order for Wilhelm to become available for marriage.
Where can I learn more about magic? "I've got no interest in magic users. No use for their kind at all. They're way up north in Winterhold, and that's fine with me. I don't even like our Jarl havin' a  court wizard."
author: Bethesda

name: Willem
bio: Willem is a Breton miner who works the Left Hand Mine outside of Markarth. After a day of work he retires into the Miner's Barracks outside the mine.
author: Bethesda

name: Wilmuth
bio: Wilmuth is a Nord farmer working at Chillfurrow Farm, east of Whiterun. He can be found there chopping wood or tending to the land 8 AM to 8 PM and sleeps from 12 AM to 4 AM. While Nazeem owns the farm, Wilmuth maintains the farm by himself. He wears a set of farm clothes and a pair of boots, and is armed with an iron dagger and carries the key to the farm.
author: Bethesda

name: Worshipper
bio:
Worshippers are Nords in Skyrim that potentially reside near the Guardian Stones. Thalmor Soldiers were instructed to slay these worshippers, who pledge allegiance to Talos, the Ninth Divine considered unholy by the Altmeri political presence of Skyrim due to his assumed apotheosis.
Directly southwest of the Guardian Stones, four Talos worshippers lay dead. Next to them lie four dead Thalmor soldiers with random loot, with the exception of a letter called "Thalmor Orders," stating that the Nords were worshipping the god Talos in secret from the Empire and Aldmeri Dominion.
Rumors spread, and soon a Thalmor agent named Sanyon sends seven reports that Talos worship has been happening in the Lake Ilinalta region. In the letter, Elenwen states that there is no proof and that she needs better evidence, not wanting to waste good agents. Sanyon would travel only to kill four worshippers, then be killed himself. Judging by that, Sanyon was killed also indicates that some worshipper(s) killed him and fled from the scene not to return.
author: Bethesda

name: Wounded Soldier
bio: The Wounded Soldier is found in the Temple of Kynareth. He is usually laying on a platform with his hand on his chest. He will occasionally groan in pain, and will not attack. They can also be found in any Stormcloak or Imperial camps. However, the Wounded Soldier at the Temple is unique in that he wears the Whiterun Guard's Armor.
author: Bethesda

name: Wujeeta
bio:
Wujeeta is an Argonian skooma addict, who can be found walking around the Riften docks or inside the Riften Fishery during the day. In the evenings, she will be at Haelga's Bunkhouse, while occasionally she can be seen standing on the porch of Honeyside.
Wujeeta starts the quest "Skooma Trade." She is in danger of losing her job at the Riften Fishery due to her skooma addiction, and requests a health potion to help her get off of the drug. This quest must be completed to become a thane of Riften.
After she receives the potion, she can be talked to again in order get more information on who is supplying the skooma and where to get it.
She will also have a Purchase Agreement in her inventory, showing further proof of the Skooma Trade.
Once she has been helped, she will give a random item as a reward, and call the Dragonborn "hatchling of the heart."
author: Bethesda

name: Wulf Wild-Blood
bio:
Wulf Wild-Blood is a Skaal hunter who lives in the Skaal Village. Until the shout Bend Will has been used on it, he is one of the villagers working on the temple around the Wind Stone.
Before Wulf came under the control of Miraak, he had a brother who eventually disappeared and has not heard from him since.
 He suspects that his brother has become a werebear.
author: Bethesda

name: Wulfgar
bio:
Wulfgar is an Elder Nord, and one of the Greybeards. As for the other Greybeards, save for Arngeir, his voice is too powerful to be heard by common people, so he does not speak.
Along with the other Greybeards, the only word he says, when interacted with, is "Dovahkiin..." which is accompanied by the sound of a distant bell and what seems to be a small earth quake. He, along with the other Greybeards also speak the Dragon Language when the Dragonborn retrieves Jurgen Windcallers horn.
author: Bethesda

name: Wuunferth the Unliving
bio:
Wuunferth the Unliving is an elderly mage serving as the court-wizard for Jarl Ulfric Stormcloak. He also teaches Adept-level Destruction magic.
Wuunferth resides in the Palace of the Kings in Windhelm. He has a room at the end of the hall on the second floor - the first door on the left when entering the Palace of the Kings - which has an arcane enchanter and alchemy lab. If accused of crimes during "Blood on the Ice," he will be moved to the jail of the Windhelm Barracks, known as the Bloodworks. After being exonerated, he will return to his normal duties.
In addition to being a member of the College of Winterhold, Wuunferth the Unliving is aware of the nature of the Necromancer's Amulet, apparently knowing it "well." He has never kept a journal, even for study, a fact which supports his innocence. Wuunferth has been investigating "the Butcher's" murders for some time before the Dragonborn, to which he has noted a pattern to the killings, although without the Dragonborn's help, he is unable to know exactly what this means. Calixto Corrium claims that he dabbles in Necromancy, and Viola Giordano will note that rumors have circled around him for years. Wuunferth will later rebuke this, saying that he in "good standing" at the College, and that they have banned Necromancy for centuries.
As a court mage, Wuunferth expresses heavy interest in magic, unlike the rest of the Stormcloaks in Windhelm, and, unlike someone more physically-inclined, Wuunferth believes that magic is the "true power" of the world and that brains are better than brawn. Viola Giordano regards him as a "dangerous man," supporting his title as "the unliving." He appears somewhat arrogant in this regard, claiming that everything said about him is "probably true" and that most of his research would confuse the Dragonborn. He also acts spiteful when he is turned against, proclaiming that the city has "lost their brains" and that it "isn't over" to Jorleif when arrested. Despite this hostility, though, Wuunferth is loyal to Windhelm and Ulfric Stormcloak. He is willing to do favors to Ulfric without hesitation, and is actively investigating the murder spree of the Butcher while the city guard are preoccupied with the war. He puts aside his previous grievances with the Dragonborn to do this, showing that his spite does not blind him to his duties, and that he is willing to move on in order to save the people of Windhelm.
It is possible that Wuunferth is the target of a radiant quest for the Companions. Farkas asks the Dragonborn to intimidate a citizen of Skyrim. It is the Dragonborn's duty to track down the person of interest and "rough them up" by initiating a bare-knuckle fight with them until they yield; killing the target while on the job will result in failure, although since Wuunferth is essential, this is impossible without console commands. Returning to Farkas completes the quest.
An initial investigation leads the Dragonborn to believe that Wuunferth the Unliving is the Butcher responsible for the killings on advice from both Viola Giordano and Calixto Corrium. He can be reported to Jorleif as such, to which he will then be imprisoned; the quest will end, with the Butcher seemingly caught. After this, though, murders continue, proving that he was innocent after all, and that he was in fact framed by Calixto. Alternatively, the Dragonborn can accuse him of Necromancy directly, to which the truth will come out that he was in fact investigating the murders himself. Regardless, he will tell that the Strange Amulet was in fact the Necromancer's Amulet, and that there appears to be a ritual at play. He will then instruct the Dragonborn to survey the Stone Quarter, where he predicts a new murder will take place.
I've heard you dabble in necromancy. "I beg your pardon? Necromancy? I am a member of the College of Winterhold, in good standing! They haven't allowed necromancy for hundreds of years!"
The killer has struck again. "Oh, isn't that a shame. And here I am in the Bloodworks. Looks like you aren't such a sharp investigator after all."
author: Bethesda

name: Wylandriah
bio:
Wylandriah is a Bosmer mage in Skyrim who serves as the court wizard to the Jarl Laila Law-Giver of Riften.
She is chronically forgetful and talks to herself, often losing her train of thought. Wylandriah's main focus in life is the pursuit of her research, and she cares for little else. While talking with her, she will ask the Dragonborn to assist her in retrieving three items she has misplaced.
As the court wizard, Wylandriah also sells items relating to the arcane arts, and is known to have, at least on one occasion, caused much consternation to the College of Winterhold.
After giving her all the items, she will thank the Dragonborn for the "uncanny foresight" as, by then, she has completely forgotten about them. She will still offer a reward, however.
author: Bethesda

name: Wyndelius Gatharian
bio:
Wyndelius Gatharian, a Dunmer, is a tomb robber who now resides in Shroud Hearth Barrow, just outside the town of Ivarstead. He is a skilled mage, particularly with Destruction magic.
Some time ago, Wyndelius journeyed into the barrow in search of the Sapphire Dragon Claw. As he wanted to stay within the barrow, he fooled the villagers into believing the barrow was haunted by rattling some pots to scare them away. The barrow's "haunted" reputation gave Wyndelius an idea to create a potion that would make him appear like a ghost, and further used this to continue to frighten the villagers. However, he soon grew mad, possibly as a side effect of the potion, and eventually began believing that he was the guardian of the barrow.
Wyndelius warns anyone intruding into the barrow to leave at once.
Quotes:
"Leave this place... Leave this place..."
"Leave... Leave... Leave..."
author: Bethesda
note: Shawn - started. Note: his actual voice type is MaleUniqueGhost, for which there is currently no voice model. Feel free to change the assigned voice model at your discretion.

name: Xander
bio:
Xander is an Imperial sailor and Red Wave crew member, which can be found next to the East Empire Company Warehouse, outside Solitude.
Xander has what most would call a refined taste in finery. He wears fine garments and talks elegantly. His attitude is proud and self-absorbing.
Hailing from Cyrodiil, he was forced to leave after an incident with the law and took on a life at sea. He was once a ship captain of the ship Argent Raptor who sank after hitting an iceberg just north of Windhelm. He joined the Red Wave crew after that and began his career leap from ship captain to crewman, but admitting that he might have earned his position because of his habit of wasting gold on women and gambling. His fellow crewmen scoff at his love of finery, but he hears only jealousy from their part.
He can be a target for a Fishing Job where the Dragonborn is required to steal Xander's Ruby.
author: Bethesda

name: Yag gra-Gortwog
bio:
Yag gra-Gortwog is a deceased Orc mercenary found outside the Alftand Animonculory.
Yag was hired to keep the workers in line during an expedition inside Alftand, an ancient Dwemer ruin. In her sleep, she and some of the other members of the expedition were caught by some Falmer and locked inside a cell. When they escaped, Yag was killed by Falmer while buying time for one of her companions, Endrast, to flee.
author: Bethesda

name: Yar gro-Gatuk
bio:
Yar gro-Gatuk, an Orc man, is one of the Hunters of Hircine. Hircine is the Daedric Lord of the Hunt. Yar and the other Hunters of Hircine have been sent to Bloated Man's Grotto, which is located in the mountains at the northern edge of Falkreath Hold. Yar carries a bow and arrows, and an iron dagger.
Yar and the other Hunters have been tasked by Lord Hircine with killing the werewolf Sinding, in order to send him to the Hunting Grounds. The Hunting Grounds is the afterlife destination associated with Hircine, and is where the souls of all werewolves and followers of Hircine are sent after their death. If the player expresses the intention to attack and kill Sinding, Yar will help the player, and be friendly with the player after Sinding is killed. If the player indicates that they intend to help Sinding, Yar will become offended and hostile to the player.
author: Bethesda

name: Yatul
bio:
Yatul, an older Orc woman,lives in the Orc stronghold of Narzulbur.
She is one of Chief Mauhulakh's aunts and she has a great-nephew, Dushnamub, the local blacksmith, and a great-niece, Urog. She is the local huntress and currently she is teaching Urog how to hunt.
Yatul sometimes complaining about the fact that the chief spends his time looking for wives, when all he needs is her and his sister Bolar, the spiritual guide of the community.
In the daytime, Yatul patrols the stronghold's walls, as well as scouting the surroundings from a small watchtower.
Yatul: "I hear Mauhulakh is wandering again. He's after a new woman."
author: Bethesda

name: Yisra
bio:
Yisra was an apprentice mage at the College of Winterhold.
Her burned body is located on a patch of scorched earth on the shore east of Dawnstar and south of Yngvild, near the Sea of Ghosts. She most likely met her fate while attempting to perform Flame Cloak spells.
author: Bethesda

name: Yngvar the Singer
bio:
Yngvar the Singer is a mercenary residing in Markarth. He is a gruff Nord man. He works for the Silver-Blood family as a lookout.
Yngvar is a former Bard who studied at the Bards College in Solitude. He is now a mercenary, stating that more gold is earned by swinging an axe than by singing songs. As a former bard, he is a well-known ladies man.
He often can be found in the Markarth Treasury House at night, or in the Silver-Blood Inn during the day.
If the Stormcloaks take over Markarth, Yngvar will become the housecarl for the new Jarl, Thongvor Silver-Blood.
If asked about Faleen (the Redguard woman who serves as Jarl Igmund's housecarl), Yngvar will reveal that a close friend of Faleen, he knows that she enjoys poetry, and will offer to write a poem on the behalf of Faleen's secret admirer for 200 gold.
Quotes:
"Markarth. Is it bloody enough for you, outsider?"
"Outsiders. Pfft."
"Blood and silver, friend. Blood and silver."
"Just turn around and leave the city. That's the smart move."
"If the Forsworn don't get you, the guards will throw you in Cidhna Mine to work your fingers off. Think that's water in the river? Blood and silver are what flows through Markarth, friend."
If asked what he means by "blood and silver": "It's right there in the name of the most powerful family in Markarth. The Silver-Bloods. They have a whole mine filled with prisoners to dig up silver ore, gets smelted by workers they pay, and they own half the city. I work for them. The inn is named after them. When the guards make an arrest, they check with them first."
If asked where one can find work in Markarth: "Jarl is who you want to talk to. Always coin to be made killing off some Forsworn in the hills. As long as you don't mind going axe-to-axe with a bunch of Daedra-worshipping savages who practice the dark arts."
If asked if he lives in Markarth: "No. I live in a nice house in Solitude where the air isn't filled with smoke from the silver smelters and golden-haired girls shine my shield. Been here ever since I left the Bards College. Turns out a few muscles earn more gold than a damn lute. The Silver-Bloods pay me, let me crack a few skulls, and keep the guards off my back. That's all I need."
author: Bethesda

name: Yngvild Ghost
bio:
Yngvild Ghost is the spectral ghost of a dead young Imperial woman. She lived and worked as a milkmaid in Dawnstar when she was alive, but she now exists as a ghost within the ancient Nordic ruin of Yngvild. She is a result of the High Elf necromancer Arondil's perverse experiments.
Having successfully raised and bound Yngvild's uniquely female Draugr population to his will, this necromancer Arondil turned his experiments toward young hapless milkmaids from Dawnstar, whom he sends his Draugr minions to kidnap. Arondil kills these young women and reanimates them into spectral ghosts. Arondil derives intense pleasure from touching these ghosts.
This ghost is trapped as member of Arondil's perverse ghostly harem. Devoid of free will, she and the other ghosts are forced to serve Arondil's every desire.
Like the other ghost women, she is unfortunately compelled to obey Arondil's orders to attack any adventures or other intruders who enter Yngvild. She wields a spectral dagger when attacking intruders. Her ghostly form can be harmed both by normal weapons and by magic.
author: Bethesda

name: Yngvild Ghost
bio:
Yngvild Ghost is the spectral ghost of a dead young Redguard woman. She lived and worked as a milkmaid in Dawnstar when she was alive, but she now exists as a ghost within the ancient Nordic ruin of Yngvild. She is a result of the High Elf necromancer Arondil's perverse experiments.
Having successfully raised and bound Yngvild's uniquely female Draugr population to his will, this necromancer Arondil turned his experiments toward young hapless milkmaids from Dawnstar, whom he sends his Draugr minions to kidnap. Arondil kills these young women and reanimates them into spectral ghosts. Arondil derives intense pleasure from touching these ghosts.
This ghost is trapped as member of Arondil's perverse ghostly harem. Devoid of free will, she and the other ghosts are forced to serve Arondil's every desire.
Like the other ghost women, she is unfortunately compelled to obey Arondil's orders to attack any adventures or other intruders who enter Yngvild. She wields a spectral dagger when attacking intruders. Her ghostly form can be harmed both by normal weapons and by magic.
author: Bethesda

name: Yngvild Ghost
bio:
Yngvild Ghost is the spectral ghost of a dead young Nord woman. She lived and worked as a milkmaid in Dawnstar when she was alive, but she now exists as a ghost within the ancient Nordic ruin of Yngvild. She is a result of the High Elf necromancer Arondil's perverse experiments.
Having successfully raised and bound Yngvild's uniquely female Draugr population to his will, this necromancer Arondil turned his experiments toward young hapless milkmaids from Dawnstar, whom he sends his Draugr minions to kidnap. Arondil kills these young women and reanimates them into spectral ghosts. Arondil derives intense pleasure from touching these ghosts.
This ghost is trapped as member of Arondil's perverse ghostly harem. Devoid of free will, she and the other ghosts are forced to serve Arondil's every desire.
Like the other ghost women, she is unfortunately compelled to obey Arondil's orders to attack any adventures or other intruders who enter Yngvild. She wields a spectral dagger when attacking intruders. Her ghostly form can be harmed both by normal weapons and by magic.
author: Bethesda

name: Yrsa
bio:
Yrsa, a young Nord woman, lives in the Skaal village at the northeast corner of Solstheim. She is the wife of Deor Woodcutter. She wears a thick Skaal coat with matching boots and hat. Fanari Strong-Voice is the leader of the village. Fanari was chosen to become leader after her predecessor (Skaf the Giant) died.
Yrsa was recently trapped under the mental enslavement of Miraak, being forced into a trance-like stance in which she and Oslaf (who is the husband of Finna and father of a young girl named Aeta) were forced to build a strange structure around the Tree Stone, on top of Miraak’s Temple in the center of Solstheim. Fortunately, Miraak's spell on Yrsa and Oslaf was broken as a result of the player's actions within Miraak’s Temple, after which Yrsa and Oslaf returned to the Skaal Village. While this was happening, most of the other members of the village (including Yrsa’s husband Deor) were also being mentally dominated by Miraak’s spell, but were instead sent to build a mysterious structure around the Wind Stone to the west of the Skaal village. Fortunately, the player broke Miraak’s spell over the villages at the Wind Stone as well. 
Yrsa occasionally makes snowberry pies, which the villagers (especially Oslaf) think are delicious.
Quotes:
"I fear what would have happened if you hadn't freed us."
"The Dark Elves of Raven Rock keep to their city, and we Skaal keep to our village."
"Fanari speaks her mind, perhaps more than she should."
"The Skaal and the land are one, joined by the All-Maker."
author: Bethesda

name: Yrsarald Thrice-Pierced
bio:
Yrsarald Thrice-Pierced Yrsarald Thrice-Pierced is a Nord warrior and a member of the Stormcloaks residing in the Palace of the Kings in Windhelm.
He is a high-ranking officer in the Stormcloak faction. He wears Stormcloak Officer Armor and is present in the Stormcloak command rooms beside Galmar Stone-Fist and Ulfric Stormcloak.
author: Bethesda

name: Ysgramor
bio:
Ysgramor is a legendary Atmoran hero warrior. Since his death, he has been dwelling in Sovngarde, the Nordic afterlife. He wears ancient Nord armor. He also bears his signature axe, Wuuthrad, on his back.
Ysgramor is currently in the Hall of Valor in Sovngarde. After speaking to the other Nordic heroes, Ysgramor will talk about Kodlak Whitemane, and tell the Dragonborn not to fail him.
Quotes:
"Welcome, Dragonborn! Our hall has stood empty since Alduin first set his soul-snare here. By Shor's command we sheathed our blades and ventured not the vale's dark mist. But three await your word to loose their fury upon the perilous foe. Gormlaith the Fearless, glad-hearted in battle; Hakon the Valiant, heavy-handed warrior; Felldir the Old, far-seeing and grim."
author: Bethesda

name: Ysolda
bio:
Ysolda is a Nord woman living in Whiterun, spending much of her time near the marketplace. If she considers the player to be her friend, and if the player is wearing an Amulet of Mara (signaling one’s intention of finding a spouse),Ysolda will accept a marriage proposal from he player. 
Ysolda comes across as a bargain hunter and keen tradeswoman. Her personality is quite friendly, if a bit nosy. Most of her interactions with other characters are friendly, while at other times she will exchange a few hostile words.
Ysolda would like to someday buy the Bannered Mare from its current owner and innkeeper (a middle-aged Nord woman named Hulda).
Ysolda may ask the player to find her a Mammoth Tusk, which she she says that needs to give to a Khajiit caravaneer as part of a trade.
If the player travels to Sleeping Tree Camp and enters Sleeping Tree Cave, Ulag will have a note from Ysolda about Sleeping Tree Sap. Ysolda will offer 150 gold for every bottle of Sleeping Tree Sap brought to her, since her previous supplier of the sap is now dead.
Ysolda has a romantic interest in Mikael, the bard who often plays at the Bannerer Mare.
author: Bethesda

name: Zaria
bio:
Zaria is a Redguard alchemist and the owner of Grave Concoctions in Falkreath.
She came to Skyrim when her family didn't approve her choice of becoming an alchemist and her interest in poisons and death. Once she arrived in Falkreath, she felt right at home, citing its huge cemetery as the likely reason for the feeling.
She explains the name of her store was a result of Falkreath being defined by its large cemetery.
author: Bethesda

name: Zaynabi
bio:
Zaynabi is a Khajiit trader traveling alongside Ahkari on the route between Dawnstar and Riften. They occasionally set up camp outside of the two cities to trade.
Like most Khajiit, she speaks in the third person, referring to herself as "this one". For example, if she wanted to express that she is tired, she would say "This one is tired".
author: Bethesda

name: Brutius
bio:
Brutius is an old man currently residing in Morthal. He is an expert fisherman. He has publicly issued an open challenge to anyone who thinks they can best him at fishing. He is willing to bet up to one thousand gold as a wager for this fishing contest.
He is secretly a skilled mage.
author: Bethesda (CC)

name: Lynea
bio:
Lynea lives in Markarth. She is a Breton woman with blue eyes and light brown hair, and wears an amulet of Dibella. On many evenings, she can be found in the Silver-Blood Inn, which is run by Kleppr, his wife Frabbi, and their two adolescent children.
Lynea wants to learn how to fish properly, and has reached out to the famous Riften Fishery (at the other end of Skyrim) in request of a private fishing instructor.
author: Bethesda (CC)

name: Swims-In-Deep-Water
bio:
Swims-In-Deep-Water is an Argonian who lives in Riften. He works as the master angler of the Riften Fishery on the docks of Lake Honrich. He is willing to take an apprentice fisherman under his tutelage.
He owns a special Argonian fishing rod, which is particularly useful in catching larger fish. He is also the current holder of the ancient Fang of Haynekhtnamet artifact, a dagger with a powerful shock damage enchantment that was carved long ago from the fang of a Wamasu beast.
Swims-In-Deep-Water is the author of the five-part "Fishing Mastery" book series.
He will be very happy if someone finds and returns his lucky fishing hat, and will reward them with 400 gold.
Quotes:
"So you have decided to learn how to fish! Good for you! It's a noble endeavor, and with plenty of practice, it can be profitable one. Keep in mind that every journey begins with a single step, one that is usually clumsy and will end with you falling on your face. That is why, for your first lesson, it's recommended that you stick to calmer skies and fairer climates, where the fish will happily bite on even the most unattractive of hooks."
If someone finds and returns his lucky fishing hat: "You are like my brood to me. Here. A token."
author: Bethesda (CC)

name: Viriya
bio:
Viriya is a Redguard woman who lives in Riften. She is a retired adventurer, though not yet actually old. She works at the Riften Rishery on the docks of Lake Honrich, where she handles special fishing requests.
Viriya intends to set up a mudcrab breeding program. Her dream is to set up a market stall in the Riften Grand Plaza marketplace in the center of the city, where she hopes to sell the meat from her mudcrab breeding project.
She owns a special Alik'ri fishing rod, which is particularly useful in catching smaller fish.
author: Bethesda (CC)

name: Al'Hassan
bio: Al’Hassan, a Redguard man, lives in Morthal. He is a blacksmith who claims to specialize in scimitars. He is the owner of the Curved Sword, a specialty store devoted to selling weapons from Hammerfell. While Al’Hassan does not sell any swords at the moment, he assures the player that all his swords are quality items. Secretly, the swords are actually replicas made by a Nord with a talent for forgery. Al'Hassan tries to hide the fact that his swords are forgeries, and will only admit it if specifically called out about it.
author: Deathbane

name: Amicus
bio: Addicted to dreaming, Amicus has difficulties staying connected to the real world. Amicus is initially encountered sleeping in one of the beds in Haelga’s Bunkhouse in Riften. Upon being awoken, he will initially assume the player is Haelga pestering him and will display annoyance. Once he realizes that a stranger has disturbed him, he will compose himself and explain that he spends most of his life sleeping, as he’s addicted to his particularly vivid dreams, which are situation in which he really feels alive. This lifestyle is not without its drawbacks however, as he now rarely washes, barely eats, and steals to fund his lifestyle. A prolific but light sleeper, he considers the amount of noise at the Bunkhouse and how any disturbance or measure of awareness breaks his dream, which is unrepeatable.
author: Deathbane

name: Amras
bio: Amras is a fence that appears in Robber’s Refuge or the Mzinchaleft Depths.
author: Deathbane

name: Anum-La the Swamp Knight
bio:
Anum-La, an Argonian woman, is a capable warrior who has taken the title "The Swamp Knight". She was the youngest member of The Honorable Eight, a group of warriors for hire. She was considered a clean slate when she joined the group, and each member of the faction had a different influence on her personality. The Honorable Eight has now disbanded. As the name suggests, there were eight members: Dalum-Ei, their leader, Anum-La, Bodan, Moon-Tail, Elia, Arnwulf, Ula-Wei, and Indrel. Arnwulf was a former member of the fighters guild of Cyrodiil, and was a big Nord man with an even bigger laugh. Ula-Wei hardly ever said a word. Ula-Wei was a retired Argonian shadowscale, who could often by found sharpening his daggers. Moon-Tail was a conjurer, and a prolific liar. Elia, a Breton woman was a promiscuous healer. Indrel was a lazy Bosmer, though highly observant. Bodan, a Redguard man, was gifted with musical ability, and possessed a silver tongue that could convince anyone. Dalum-Ei, an Argonian man, was their leader, a legendary swordsman who fought in the Great War.
Anum-La is an honorable warrior with a good heart and a good sense of humor.
author: Deathbane

name: Arelthor
bio: Arelthor, an Altmer man, is currently standing outside ancient ruin in Hjaalmarch. He is a Thalmor Justiciar. He is snarky and pessimistic, but decidedly cordial - providing a much-needed foil to the guilded preteniousness that oft parades through Skyrim.
author: Deathbane

name: Arghus
bio: Arghus was the scryer for the Jarl of Markarth in the years before and after Madanach took the Reach. When his daughter left to join the Forsworn, it fractured his marriage and turned him into a drunkard.
author: Deathbane

name: Asteria
bio: Asteria is a bard residing in the small settlement of Old Hroldan, in the Reach. She plays there in hopes that word of her talents will reach the Jarl of Markarth, as the Silver-Blood Inn is already occupied by a skald named Ogmund. Asteria plays an original song: Dusk on Anvil Harbor. However, the song is known to be infamous given its association to a certain thief. As such, Asteria carries a birth certificate on her at all times to prove her identity. Secretly, she is the Raven of Anvil, a fact she conceals from everyone, including the fact that the birth certificate is a forgery.
author: Deathbane

name: Azzarian
bio: Azzarian, a Dunmer man, is a bandit who is in search of a hidden cache, the nature of which he wont readily discuss with anyone, stating that it's "on a need to know basis, and you don’t need to know". He is not particularly secretive about his bandit craft, boasting “there’s only one reason people know about me, I’m not afraid to tell them”. He is not well liked in Windhelm because of his "profession" as a bandit, and was recently ejected and banned from the New Gnisis Cornerclub in the Gray Quarter of Windhelm by its proprietor Ambarys Rendar for similar reasons. He is looking for someone to hire to find two books for him. There is however, a catch - he doesn’t know the names of the books he’s looking for, or what they are about. He only knows who has them. The first book is owned by a well known fence who likely keeps it hidden in a safe. The second book is owned by a Dunmer man named Sadrin Reloro in Riften.
author: Deathbane

name: Batheru
bio: Batheru is a belligerent racist living in a watchtower in the hilly forested northern section of the Rift. After spending years in the Gray Quarter, his only goal in life is to direct unsuspecting visitors toward the roof of the tower, where a vicious Dremora is waiting to kill them. Batheru has a number of racist taunts and jokes, and his dialogue will account for the race of the player, which he will explicit ask them about during their first meeting.
author: Deathbane

name: Beatrice
bio: Beatrice is a former Forsworn and one of two skooma addicts living at a small encampment near Druadach Redoubt. Her gift of speech is the result of finding a speechcraft amulet at the bottom of the river. Together with an Orc named Urzub, she regales travelers with poetry and song.Urzub.
author: Deathbane

name: Berg
bio: Berg is a Nord, who believes himself to be a giant. He speaks in stunted sentences, like a low intelligence barbarian. An example of his speaking style is "Real Giant club intruders on sight, but not Berg. Berg talk to you, even if not azgrok, clan. Real Giant know how to make cheese. Berg know only how to drink mead sauce. It make him yell at noisy bard."
author: Deathbane

name: Bilbus
bio: Bilbus is an explorer who can be found in Robber’s Refuge on Turdas.
author: Deathbane

name: Brakh
bio: Brakh is an Orc man who lives in a broken tower north of Knifepoint Ridge. His dialogue is simple, terse, blunt, and to the point, which mirrors his personality. Hhe is hunting an Orc man Lagdu, a former friend who is responsible for the death of their mutual friend, Sevaris.
author: Deathbane

name: Carmella
bio: Carmella, a Redguard woman, is an artist who uses necromancy as her brush. She tries to shock her audience to elicit more natural emotions, and from their reactions find varying interpretations of the piece. In addition to her visual art, Carmella is also a fan of asks hypothetical questions o learn more about people. If one describes her work as "necromancy" instead of "necromantic art", she will reply in a negative and condescending way, as she holds the distinction between the two very important. She trained at the College of Winterhold, where necromancy is legal and accepted, but unfortunately only for research and study. The college does not support the use of necromancy for art, and this fallout is what caused Carmella to leave the college. The only thing Carmella misses from the college were the bright minds around her during her time there. Otherwise, she is thrilled to no longer be stifled by their rules. She can often be found in the hilly area just south of the road that runs south of Lake Ilinalta, where she artistically and magically manipulates a group of skeletons.
author: Deathbane

name: Cassius
bio: Cassius is a charitable, optimistic but ultimately naive Imperial noble who wants to reform bandits rather than remove them. However, his efforts have done nothing but earn him a trip to the dungeon.
author: Deathbane

name: Cassock
bio: Cassock, an Orc man, is a vampire who is bored with his immortality. As such, he often spends his time devising violent games to play with adventurers, in an effort to end his boredom and sate his bloodlust. If the player beats Cassock in one of his violent scheming games, Cassock will be willing to follow them on adventures.
author: Deathbane

name: Caylene
bio: Caylene is a beggar posing as a busker and street performance artist. She will perform a variety of one-man shows and even a few songs if given a gold piece.
author: Deathbane

name: Clario Moorsley
bio: Clario is an experimental chef who cooks with alchemy and magic. He can be found at the Understone Keep and the Silver-Blood Inn, where he interacts with the Dibellan priestess, Jolene. As a traditional Breton, his accent, manner of speech, and character are heavily influenced by French cuisine and culture, particularly the Gourmet’s signature dish “Potage Le Magnifique.” He harbours a bit of jealousy and anger toward the Gourmet, whose more pedestrian dishes have garnered far more acclaim.The book Mortar, Pestle, and Pot, written by Clario’s assistant, can be found in the Understone Keep kitchen, atop a crate. Clario’s accent implies he was raised in the same region where the Gourmet trained. Ironically, while the Gourmet is the outsider, it is Clario’s cooking that is more experimental, although this could be a product of his failure to surpass the Gourmet’s potage.
author: Deathbane

name: Daenlyn Oakhollow
bio: Daenlyn, a Bosmer man, was recently taken a prisoner by three Thalmor Justiciars, for singing the song "Age of Oppression" a bit too loudly while performing in a tavern. Luckily, the player saved Daenlyn by killing the justiciars while they were escorting him on the road as their prisoner. Daenlyn is a bard who possesses a quick mind and a strong sardonic wit. He has a background in art and art history due to his extensive bard training.
author: Deathbane

name: Dar'Rakki
bio:
Dar’Rakki is a Khajiit immigrant who came to Skyrim at the urging of his friend Adanja to join the Khajiit Caravans. However, after crossing the border, the two were attacked by bandits, resulting in Adanja’s death. As Adanja had promised Dar’Rakki she would remain by her side, and Dar'Rakki views her death as a betrayal. Consequently, he has difficulty trusting others.
He is currently staying at the Vilemyr Inn in the town of Ivarstead, which is located at the base of the Throat of the World, the tallest mountain in all of Tamriel. He is extremely interested in whether the famous 7000 steps to High Hrothgar (the Greybeard monastery near the top of the mountain) really contain 7000 steps. If he was to learn that the true number of steps is exactly or close to 7000, he would feel relieved. However, if he was to learn that the true number of steps is nowhere near 7000, he will be absolutely distraught over the prevalance of such blatant lies, and will kill himself as a result.
Like most Khajiit, he speaks in the third person, referring to himself as "this one". For example, if he wanted to express that he is tired, he would say "This one is tired".
author: Deathbane

name: Darcy
bio: Darcy is a traveling bard who recites poetry in lieu of music.
author: Deathbane

name: Dravos
bio: Dravos is a Dremora who defected from the ranks of Mehrunes Dagon to serve the Lord of Debauchery, Sanguine. He holds court in Rift Watchtower with a handful of other revelers, all of whom are locked in a perpetual state of bliss. The only exception is a Dark Elf named Batheru, who serves as the doorman for his eternal bacchanalia.
author: Deathbane

name: Duraz
bio: Duraz is an Orc sellsword based in Old Hroldan. She works for boon as opposed to gold, and if asked why will sardonically comment on the existing mercenary structure in Skyrim; this is because she sees the typical 500 gold payment as an ostensibly paltry sum for what could be an infinite amount of service.
author: Deathbane

name: Edwayne
bio: Edwayne, a Breton man, studyies at the Bards College in Solitude. His only motivation for wanting to become a bard is to best a Nord man named Skjarn. Edwayne and Skjarn have been dueling (both verbally and physically) for quite some time, for reasons that are unclear and offenses that are both real and imagined. Edwayne is secretly a vampire, though he will not admit this to anyone.
author: Deathbane

name: Efram
bio: Efram is a well spoken Imperial man who acts as the mouthpiece for a bard he always accompanies who is called the Songstress. He and Songstress constantly travel back and forth back and forth between the Cornerclub and Old Hroldan. At each location, the Songstress will perform beautiful songs. If he is asked about the Songstress he will make clear than she is a mute, often saying "For ten gold she will sing, but not speak". He is also quick to point out that she is referred to as ‘The Caged Bird’ throughout the provinces of Tamriel, quipping that only through the patronage of others may she truly metaphorically spread her wings.
author: Deathbane

name: Eldar
bio: Eldar is a former farmer who lost his job at Chillfurrow Farm for sleeping on the job. Desperate for money, he attempted to sell a family heirloom only to find Belethor was more interested in buying his junk. He then developed a business to charge adventurers to alleviate them of their junk and sell it to Belethor for an additional profit. Filled with vitriol for his former employer, the Redguard Nazeem, Eldar hopes of one day reaching the Cloud District. high elf and destruction mage who specializes in fire. She has spent many a day in Whiterun where she has made acquaintance with a number of people including Larkspur, Hulda, and Sinmir. A devout lover of wine with a playful sarcastic nature, she is ostensibly an ordinary drunk. However, she is also a member of the Radiant Dark. This is a secret she will not reveal unless pressed. She has an on-off relationship with Sinmir, who she seems to be growing bored of.
author: Deathbane

name: Fa'nar
bio:
Fa’nar, a Khajiit man, patronizes Robber’s Refuge on Fredas and Loredas. He is an ex-Imperial soldier, who left after they kept giving him only menial tasks to perform as a punishment. The reason Fa’nar was punished by the Imperial army is because he holds a favourable opinion of Ysmir, the Nordic aspect of Talos. He has always been a fan of Nordic culture, and can even recite the story of the 500 Companions from memory. He does not know if Talos is indeed a god, but reckons if any mortal would be worthy of such a title, it would be Talos.
Like most Khajiit, he speaks in the third person, referring to himself as "this one". For example, if he wanted to express that he is tired, he would say "This one is tired".
Quotes:
"I have always been the black cat of the family, or should I say the white one".
author: Deathbane

name: Fareloth
bio: Fareloth is an Altmer man who is searching for his doppelganger, who led an ostensibly identical life to Fareloth's until the start of the Great War 30 years ago. Fareloth believes meeting this person will allow him to get a glimpse of the life he could have had. Berdier Wreans, who wrote the book "The Mirror", is Fareloth's favorite author. He has six brothers.
author: Deathbane

name: Feldi
bio: Feldi is a nord and the the mother of Fuki and the spouse of an female Argonian named Vukeera. Their child’s unusual name is a conflation of her parents’.
author: Deathbane

name: Fig
bio: Fig is the squire of Whig, a patron at Robber’s Refuge who appears if the tavern is serving Spiced Wine. She dutifully follows Fig, who instructs her regarding his various theories on the universe.
author: Deathbane

name: Fjord
bio: Fjord, a Nord man, is an eccentric bone collector who resides in a camp overlooking the town of Riverwood.
author: Deathbane

name: Fontaine
bio: Fontaine is a spellsword conjurer who comes to Robbers Refuge after the player sends out letters advertising the tavern. He has no time for teaching, and instead prefers to focus on the thrill of fighting. He trained as a swordsman, but his real talent is conjuration. He loves summoning atronachs, but also falls back summong wolves when low on magicka. He is not afraid of getting hit in a fight.
author: Deathbane

name: Frik
bio: Frik is a deckhand with "more callouses than sense", as he puts it. He is a straight-talking nord sailor who the spends the majority of his time working on the deck of the Sea Squall. He often retires to the Windpeak Inn for a drink. His acquintances include Jaspar Gaerston and Captain Leif Wayfinder. It is also implied that he is the inspiration for the book, the Duke of Beards, written by the publisher Flin Horstad. Frik is glad that the old captain finally died, as she was a hard disciplinarian - he often refers to her as an old hag.
author: Deathbane

name: Fuki
bio: Fuki is a young child. She is the daughter of an Argonian named Vukeera and a Nord named Feldi, and her unusual name is a conflation of theirs. Her parents have left her in the inn so they can climb the Throat of the World, ascending the 7000 steps, without putting her at risk
author: Deathbane

name: Geel-Jah
bio: Geel-Jah, an Argonian man, is a treasure hunter and friend of a Nord man named Torveld. Geel-Jah often convinces Torveld to accompany him on adventures in search for lost treasure. These trips usually have typically undesirable results.
author: Deathbane

name: Gerrod
bio: Gerrod is an Alteration mage posing as a hunter. He is secretly a member of the Radiant Dark, which he attempts to conceal from everyone. Unlike illusion mages who seek to conceal their identity by pretending to be hunters, Gerrod takes the extra step of actually learning the craft and being competent at it.
author: Deathbane
note: The listed IDs are for his Cliffside Retreat iteration, not his Radiant Dark iteration

name: Glathriel
bio: Glathriel is a Bosmer woman in search of her mother, whom she suspects may have transformed into a monster of the Wild Hunt. Born in Solitude, Glathriel was raised a city girl, but is now forced to confront the realities of her heritage. She now lives in the wilds of Skyrim. Glathriel doesn’t get lonely out here in the wilds, and if asked, she will remark that nature is good enough company. Her mother used to often tell her stories about Valenwood, because her mother used to love Valenwood so much. Glathriel takes comfort in wondering if her mother somehow found her way back to Valenwood.
author: Deathbane

name: Gnives
bio:
Gnives is a Khajiit thief found in the Ragged Flagon. As a khajiit, he uses his heightened sense of hearing to gain an advantage both as an assassin and a thief. Gnives' mother died during his birth. Due to the grief of losing his wife and Gnives' color of mane being red while both his parents mane's were gray, implying that Gnives may have been a product of adultery, his father beat him frequently. Gnives ran away from home as he could not stand the abuse any more. He pickpocketed skooma addicts' purse afterward to earn his keep until he was caught red handed by his future-mentor, a former member of Dark Brotherhood, Ra'jirr. Ra'jirr taught him his various skills; stealth-related skills and even cooking. Due to being aware that Ra'jirr was only using him from the start, Gnives killed him one day. He wandered north to Cyrodill, stealing from houses and pockets alike. As he grew weary, he found a book titled "Shadowmarks" written by Delvin Mallory and then brought himself to Skyrim. He soon infiltrated Erikur's House in Solitude. While he tinkered with Erikur's safebox, Melaran, Erikur's housecarl, caught him red handed and guards were called. Gnives requested that Erikur see the content of the safe again. Erikur soon obliged with Gnives' request and ordered guards to release Gnives. Confused by Erikur's order, Melaran commented that the safe should be mostly empty as they had to pay for party at the previous day. It was then revealed that Gnives didn't try to take from safe, he was trying to fill in the safebox as gifts. Thanks to Erikur's connection, Gnives was able to join Thieves Guild.
Like most Khajiit, he speaks in the third person, referring to himself as "this one". For example, if he wanted to express that he is tired, he would say "This one is tired".
author: Deathbane

name: Godrod
bio: Godrod is a mentally disturbed character who worships Ulfric Stormcloak and believes himself to be a key part of his rebellion. He will also insinuate that Ulfric is the reincarnation of Talos, in addition to making other wild claims regarding the origins of this rebirth. Godrod will have on his possession two letters, one for Ulfric and another for “Jarl Tullius,” whom Godrod believes is the current Jarl of Solitude. Despite his mad ramblings, the name Jarl Tullius accurately reflects what many in Skyrim believe, that General Tullius holds far more sway in Solitude than Torygg’s widow Elisif.
author: Deathbane

name: Griffith
bio:
Griffith is a former assassin who abandoned the Dark Brotherhood when he was contracted to kill an orphaned child, deciding to kill the person who performed the Black Sacrament on the child instead. Now serving as the guardian of this child (a young girl named Morrigan), the two have made a home out of an unused building at Mixwater Mill. The two are on the run from the Dark Brotherhood due to Griffith's disobedience. Griffith is very fond of Morrigan, but fears that as an a former assassin, he is a poor father figure for a child.
Griffith also holds a vendetta against a powerful nobleman named Gabania, who was responsible for the murder of his family and destruction of his village.
author: Deathbane

name: Gromash
bio: Gromash is an Orc and a member of the Narzulbur Orc stronghold in Eastmarch. He mans the stronghold's guard post during the day, and retreats to the stronghold's longhouse at night.
author: Deathbane

name: Gwyvane
bio: Gwyvane is a Breton woman who can be found in the Hall of the Dead in Solitude. She has gone insane, and can only speak in riddles. An example of such cryptic speech is "For when darkness fells the day swallows the stars, all that is left to light the fire is the fire than burns in mortal hearts".
author: Deathbane

name: Haakon Iron-Fist
bio: Haakon Iron-Fist is former Stormcloak soldier who committed atrocities at Karthwasten during Ulfric’s campaign to retake Markarth from the Forsworn. Haakon’s lack of contrition and defiance of his superiors resulted in him being imprisoned, mostly due to the politics of the time. As Ulfric had yet to kill Torygg and announce his rebellion, Haakon implies an acquittal would have raised suspicions of a possible insurrection by the Stormcloaks. However, his personal pride would not allow him to apologize for his behavior or serve under a man who asked him to. He is a violent man who speaks gruffly, and is entirely unrepentant of his crimes.
